South Beach Special ~ Turkey, provolone, artichoke hearts, sun dried tomatoes. A well balanced and "healthier" meaty sandwich still full of the familiar Italian flavors.

Give it up for Molinari's ~  fresh bread, imported salumi, great cheese and simple toppings make for great sandwiches and Molinari's has all of those ingredients. The friendly staff swiftly prepare all sandwiches, made to order or pre set as on menu, to perfection. Grab a bottle of wine and you gave yourself a perfect picnic lunch or dinner. BURP!!! 5 stars! 

*TIP - ask for extra garlic spread on your sanwiches gifts it that umph and kick for an even better sandwich experience.
author: Maria M.

description:
I was reminded of Molinari a little too late when I was leaving North Beach last week after picking up my items for my Italian themed dinner that night.  Knowing that I was returning this week, I made it a point to stop by to pick up some deli meats to make my own sandwich with the sheet of plain focaccia from last week that I froze.  They do sell focaccia at Molinari if you did not have a chance to get it from Liguria.  

Since we came a little earlier before dinner, we did not get a chance to try their sandwiches this time around.  There is a system for sandwiches here where you grab a number, then your French roll which you would then hand to them when your number is called.  We still had to grab a number for the deli and they will freshly slice for you based on what you want.  I got 1/4 lb salami, 1/4 lb mild/sweet coppa, and 1/4 lb mortadella with pistachios.  Other offerings include soppresata, prosciutto (both domestic and di parma), etc..  Since they had a promotion for fresh Italian Sausage, I bought a lb of the links as well which I froze and may be making an appearance soon in a Baked Ziti.  They also sell their Molinari Salami for $8.95 for a small which would be great to go with a hard cheese which they have a huge variety of as well.  

Dried and pre-packaged items from Italy is also available so I picked up a box of Ziti and a bottle of passata (fresh tomato puree).  Looks like that ziti dish will be hitting my blog soon!!

Update:  Here is that ziti I made and coincidentally my 300th blog post - http://www.cookwithzee.blogspot.com/2015/11/baked-ziti.html
author: Joyce Z.

description:
A Tourist Trap- PRODUCTS FROM COSTA RICA, US, & SUCH.....

NOTHING LIKE A TRIP TO ITALY 

or a good East Coast place....OR EVEN DOWN IN THE SLO AREA

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Not really worth a special trip.  Besides the mass produced Salami, which is nothing special, they really do not make much of their own stuff, nor really import anything that you cannot find elsewhere.

I far prefer the local artisan Salami that they make down here in SLO...with fresh Truffles too!

I asked for canned Tuna Belly & they showed me a bottle of Tonnini brand, which is not even Italian, 

IT IS FROM COSTA RICA!   & sold at WF.  What kind of stupid crap is that?
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I can get the Italian version from my local Pizza place down in Pismo Beach.


They have a poor pathetic selection of cured meats....like American Prosciutto...which is blasphemy. 

They have a poor selection of any fresh roasted or smoked meat (only "cured").
Even WF in SLO has fresh Garlic Roast Beef & the Butcher down here in AG smokes & makes all kinds of Pork chops, pastrami, & sausages.

If you look at the pics, they have the low class to precut/ slices lots of their meats to make a fast sandwich.  They do that crap in many crappy supermarkets, but you would never see this in a good upscale Deli....even Whole Paycheck Market cuts fresh stuff for you.

Any ingredients that are precut are going to lose flavor & freshness immediately....how dare they.

I did pick up some Gnocchi on sale & some very pricey Parmesan cheese, 

which they claimed was "the best"  ( IT IS NOT )

.....a Rocca Brand....

which while it is an Italian Reggiano, it may be no better than Costco's or WF's.  

According to my Goggle search, it is rather a generic Parmigiano Reggiano.

I could find several much more interesting PR cheeses under the Ambrosi or Merro labels online.

I really hate when a place totally brags about something that they are FOS about. The Rocco brand, at about $19/lb is not likely to be that "special".

Judging by the zillions of pics of their sandwiches, they do look quite pathetic.

Molinari, like Mara's, down the street have seen better days, and now appeal to tourists & younger Yelpers who have not traveled nor experienced much in their brief lives. 

I am not even sure if these Deli owners have any real current culinary connections with modern day Italy....I surely did not see anything special.

My local Italian Deli (De Palo's in Shell Beach) hand makes an amazing homemade Mozzarella Cheese fresh every morning.....& it is a whole block away from my Condo.....they also have great Biscotti....

Yes, I am spoiled....I also grew up in an Italian neighborhood in Brooklyn NY.....
author: Paul M.

description:
oh so good... really, this was pretty amazing.
I got the one named after the store, since it has to be good right?!
I got everything on it then drove it all the way to Monterey and it wasn't soggy and still delicious.
Even picked up a pasta salad since they also looked amazing and it did not disappoint.
Parking was a bear near here!
author: Kelley S.

description: I had their Luciano special which was great but I felt like it lacked some flavor. Maybe I should've gotten with some balsamic which would've probably done the job. However I felt that the prosciutto and the copa themselves were lacking just a bit in the sense of the saltiness and deeper flavor I would usually get out of good prosciutto . Still made a great sandwich and an awesome lunch!
author: Tomoki T.

description:
That guy was really eager to sell his fresh balls to me.

MOZZARELLA.

For gosh sakes, people!!! It's a deli.

Which happens to be the BESTEST deli this side of town.

Why do I need mozz balls? well, my co-worker had a brilliant idea of having a sandwich potluck party. Everyone brings a sandwich ingredient (cheese, spreads, bread, etc) and we get creative with what we have. (would you believe that we got so creative that no one listed mayo on the sign up sheet!)

I wanted to bring something different other than the usual deli meat, so I headed to the sandwich masters' office. A wide variety of bread, MMMeats, cheeses and trimmings are available for your choosing. I got a jar of imported Olive spread from Italia to up the chic factor even more.

The mozz balls were divinely fresh and super creamy and if you want to splurge even more, they offer burrata here as well. Do stop by for a well stuffed sandwich made by true Italians, you are in the heart of North Beach after all. 

And the mozz balls? mama mia!
author: Janice C.

description: My Prosciutto di Parma was inspirational. The meat, which is imported from Italy, is perfectly cured. I chose to pass on mayonnaise and go with mustard, lettuce, tomato, and provolone cheese (their recommended pairing). I think fresh mozzarella would also be a nice caprese style combination. I also really liked how you pick out the piece of bread you want it made on and give it to them. Overall I thoroughly enjoyed the sandwich. It's not cheap but well worth the price of admission.
author: Michael S.

description:
The quintessential old school, family, Italian delicatessen.  A North Beach institution & tradition.  

Here is the Molinari's experience...

Walk in.  You're immediately struck by the incredible aromas.  It's heavenly.

You'll pass the stellar assortment of cheeses as you walk up to the deli case.

You'll be struck by the assortment of salami.  You'll want to sample a couple.  They welcome this.  Go ahead.

You take a number.

You go & pick the bread you want your sandwich to be made on.  People love Dutch crunch, but I'm a soft roll kinda girl.

When your number is called, you hand them your bread selection as you tell them what sandwich you'd like.  Now you wait for your perfect sandwich to be made.

The staff.  Always a smile.  Always gracious.  Always personable.  Great family.

You peruse their fresh ravioli packaged for you to take home & cook.  And their sauce.  Any fridge or freezer that has Molinari's ravioli or tortellini & sauce in it is a happy one.  The easiest fabulous dish you'll ever make.  Love.

Honorable mention to their chicken cutlets.  Delicious.  There's an enticing array of other prepared dishes as well.  Sausage & peppers, sautéed mushrooms, etc.  All fantastic.

You choose some salami & they slice it for you.  Then you grab some cheese.  Then a bottle of wine.

Your sandwich is ready.

Now you're ready for anything.

These guys are the best.  5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Well, the Yelpers have done it again. I was searching for a great sandwich last week in SF and this came up with really good solid tips and reviews. So, off i went.

You walk in and are taken by how real it is. No fake chain crap here, just old Italian goodness. I was overwhelmed with what to get. So, I look at the board and it all comes clear....I went Italian special. First (and very important!!) pick out your bread. There are people waiting around with role in their hands and I thought...Wow, that's weird. Until I asked and was told and shown where the bread is. Loved it!!!

Sandwich had all the fiixins you need plus some. Don't give directions, just order and eat. Perfect. We also had the turkey with sun dried tomatoes and basil dressing. Also really good. Good spot to get cheese and meat/bread to take back to the hotel for a little snack later. The beer and wine section is awesome as well.

I could live here. And yes....maybe someday I will.
author: Peter I.

description: Had the renzo and chicken parmesan.  It was wonderful, living in Seattle there aren't any joints with chicken parm wedges.  I was so happy!  The line was a little long but worth it.... It's a sin to put mayo or mustard on a Italian combo!!
author: Alan L.

description:
Classic Italian deli that sets a gold standard for being authentic. 
We were here to get sandwiches which were excellent. Fresh bread and generous portions.
They of course have their signature salami but it is all excellent.
Always a stop on my trips to SF.
author: Barry T.

description:
Loved it! This was the first stop on a North Beach food tour and it did not disappoint. Small, cozy inside with a few tables outside. The interior was incredibly unique, it's almost worth it to come in just to get a picture. I had a vegetarian panini (can't remember the name because it was ordered by the tour guide) but it was incredible - mozzarella, sun dried tomatoes, artichoke, pesto, red peppers and more. 

It's the real deal - you feel like you've been transported to another place when you step inside.
author: Hailey H.

description:
I heard about this place from my brother and I must say this deserves a bookmark. This place is busy but it was worth it. As everyone has stated:
1. Grab a ticket from the dispenser when you enter located on the right side.
2. Pick out what bread you want it on. Work your way towards the back on the left side. 
3. Since its your first time order the Luciano Special. Comes with its own bread.
4. Wait for them to call out your number and watch as they make you an awesome sandwich.
5. Enjoy.

Wife and I had the Luciano Special and sausage sandwich. Both were good however the Luciano Special stood out more. Good quality very nice staff.
author: Stephen G.

description:
Oh man, I'm just on a 5 star review roll today. I guess I did plan out an entire day of delicious places I found on Yelp so it's not a huge surprise lol.

Le fiance and I came here for sandwiches to go for our picnic lunch in Washington park. We also wanted to get some Old Amsterdam Cheese for our homemade mac and cheese. 

One of the best European and Italian delis around. You can get homemade pasta here, authentic Italian subs, olive oil straight from Europe, etc. Such a great place to come and peruse for great cooking ingredients. 

It's cured meat and cheese heaven, and nothing better exemplifies that than getting one of their famous subs. Just do it already. With the mozzarella and foccacia. I promise you won't regret it.
author: Courtney C.

description:
I've probably stated in many of my reviews how picky I am when it comes to food. This is probably THE best sandwich I have had in a very long time. I love deli sandwiches and most are yummy and leave me satisfied but when I like something, I reaaaally like it. To the point where I had it again the next day. And thought about it all day today. 
Point? If you want a bomb ass sandwich, this is your place. The meats are all moist and super fresh (hey, I've been to places where lunch meat tastes old, woof), lettuce and tomatoes super crisp, and their basil garlic spread---I think this is what sets it all off. 
So happy I found this spot! Will definitely be back again real soon.
author: T A.

description:
This place has really great Italian sandwiches. Would be willing to go out of the way to get lunch here. The cold cuts are fantastic, and they slice them when you order the sandwich. All the classic Italian lunch meats you want are here: soppressata, mortadella, prosciutto. They put a generous serving into each one as well. Never had a better classic Italian sandwich in San Francisco. Also this place is only a five minute walk to Washington Square Park, so it's an ideal spot for lunch in the park.

They have a nice little selection of Italian market goods, cheeses, and dried pastas (including rustichella d'abruzzo!) The only weird thing is the way the sandwich line works. You grab a ticket, and they have a basket of bread that you need to bring up to the counter for your sandwich when they call your number. Not sure why they do it this way, but it is kind of weird standing around with a load of bread in your hands while waiting...
author: Michael S.

description:
O my gosh.  Brooklyn Italian deli flashback. 
Hanging sausage - fresh sandwiches on light crusty bread. Half bottles of wine. 
Huge assortment of cheeses  olives oils etc... Tomato and pastas packaged 
Grab a table outside and melt into a soft sandwich with roasted red peppers prosciutto and mozzarella cheese. 
Grab a little table - wine which they will open for you and sit outside to people watch. then head across to Stella's for dessert
author: Laura G.

description: Excellent Italian deli, with great sandwiches. I thought their prosciutto was a little too salty, but their meatball sandwich was awesome
author: Bobby K.

description:
I made sure to go early around 11:30am on a weekday and there was only one person ahead so there was no need to grab a number. For my bread, I picked up Italian ciabatta and it was oh so soft. I ordered the Renzo Special ($8.75) and added marinated artichoke hearts ($0.50 extra). 

The ingredients were super fresh! While I was eating my sandwich, I found myself picking out pieces of meat, mozz and veggies and eating them like potato chips since each was so good but nonetheless, the bread was definitely fresh. The Renzo Special doesn't come with mayo or mustard so I find that it's the oils from the meat and sun dried tomatoes (and also the marinated artichoke hearts I added) that soak into the bread, moisten it and flavor the sandwich. 

Service was fast and friendly, and the items around the deli are worth a browse so you may end up picking up some additions. I'm excited to try another sandwich soon!
author: Maya S.

description: I came here with a group of friends while staying in the city and the food was absolutely amazing! The Ambiance is like a true Italian meat market with salami hanging from strings fresh meat cut up into sandwiches and definitely worth the money for how big your meal is. It was fresh, delicious and we will definitely be going back again
author: Marisela S.

description: I have worked a few doors down and have never really paid attention to this hidden gem! I always thought they were out of business wen in fact business was booming! Such an amazing place for authentic Italian sandwiches! Coming back for the amazing service and authentic sandwiches!
author: Paulo F.

description:
This is the first five star review I've posted yet. This place is quaint, quick, and simple but produces one of the best sandwiches I've had. I ordered a turkey and fresh mozzarella sandwich. Loaded it with mustard, pepperoncinis, lettuce, and tomato. The lettuce is crisp and fresh. Tomatoes are ripe and juicy. Peppers add some salt and tang. Ate it on a wheat roll. Added some jalapeño chips. So freakin' good. I know this is a sandwich that anywhere could have, but just come here and watch them make it for you, and then eat it and love it. 
Prices are good--cheapest meal I ate in SF. $26 for 2 people for lunch isn't bad at all. 

I wish more restaurants kept things this low key while still maintaining quality products. 
Check this out if you're in/near Little Italy or make a drive or take a bus. It's worth it.
author: Rachel W.

description:
On a sunny day, stroll to North Beach and visit this classic deli. 

Grab a number and pick your bread. When it's your turn, order from their extensive sandwich menu; the options seem endless. I chose the veggie sandwich and added soppressata. I recommend chasing your bites with sparkling water -- it's beyond refreshing. Eat your sandwich in Washington Square Park to soak up maximum sunshine. As you bite into your bread and listen to the bells at Saints Peter and Paul Church toll in the background, you might even trick yourself into thinking you've taken a vacation to Italy. 

Cin-Cin!
author: Cecelia Y.

description: Anytime I hear of people talking g about a trip to The City I recommend this place. Great cured meats, great sandwiches, and the nicest people ever who will literally give you the short of their back!!! Last year when I was in town I let them know I was a butcher and asked if they had any shirts for sale. The guys sadly said no but went and gave me one of his work shirts. Now that's service. Keep it up guys!!
author: Nathan T.

description: Marveled at the lovely selection of wine and authentic Italian deli goods. Funny and friendly staff -- family owned and run.  Freshly sliced meats and cheeses. Pick up a nice sandwich and carry it out for a picnic. Worth the trek from anywhere.
author: Barbara D.

description:
Came in about half an hour before closing time. This deli is so cool! There's so much stuff everywhere to browse. First thing that must be done is grab a ticket right when you walk into the door. You have to choose your own roll from a bin in the back and hold it until they call your number for the sandwich. It can get quite crowded in there and a lot of people don't know what's going on so congestion happens. 
We got a sammich and you can always add extra slices of stuff or kind of a make your own thing. I'm not sure if they charged extra for adding the extra meat. I didn't want a sammich so we asked if I could just get the deli meat. I ended up getting slices of proscuitto, salami, headcheese, and 3 meat meat. The total of my lunch was like $6....super awesome. 
All of the meats were delicious! I also tried some of the bf's sammich and it was also pretty amazing. They pack a lot of stuff in it so I think it's worth it.
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
It's the holy grail of Italian subs. It's one of the only lasting original Italian Delis in the city. In fact, it's one of the oldest Italian delis period. It's on the corner of Vallejo and Columbus in between part of the busiest tourist area in North Beach. They have amazing sandwiches and the price is right for what you get. The line on the weekdays will kill you though if your hungry and waiting for a sandwich. Awesome that you can call in a sandwich on Sunday and pick it up and not have to wait in line. 

Aside from really great sandwiches they also have a huge selection of deli goods from salads to pastas. They make their own salami and they have a great selection of chips and drinks. That makes this the perfect place to pick up lunch for a picnic in the park. 

It's old school and it's one of the best in town. It's also worth the wait if it's busy, not many things are.
author: Ben M.

description: It must of been their off day cause they all had a really bad attitude, no smiling no conversation no nothing, bread was pretty hard and barely any selection, we asked if that was the only bread they just said...ughhhh yeah! To bad, we had heard good stuff.
author: Lionel C.

description: Their deli meat and cheeses are great, and not as expensive as other places I've found near by. I was disappointed by their eggplant Parmesan sandwich though..it wasn't very flavorful and was super messy, not really in a good way. The people who work here are always very friendly!
author: Elena K.

description: I've been going to Molinari's since I was a kid... Today I was saddened to be treated so poorly! I ordered two sandwiches and the cashier added up my tab and it was $30 flat. Which is a little higher than usual, When I asked to see the itemized receipt (the one he already typed up) he needed to make a new one instead. Don't jack
author: Sharon N.

description: This has to be on of the best bargains in San Francisco.  For about ten bucks you get a huge sandwich.  Only a few tables on the street but there is a park just a couple of blocks away.  Heaps of your favorite deli meats and all the trimmings on a sour dough roll.  YUM!
author: Bob S.

description:
An amazing and authentic Italian deli nestled in the heart of North Beach. You cannot go wrong with any of their cured meats on a sando--my go to is the pastrami ($10.50).

The service is what you'd expect from a tiny and busy deli: there can be a bit of a wait if you come right at lunchtime but the dudes that work there are really cool. I usually try going right at 11am to beat the crowds. 

All in all, excellent quality meats, fresh produce, and sandwiches that rival almost any other spot in the city. Keep doing you, Molinari.
author: Leah G.

description: I had the Italian combo. Really good. 30 min wait on a Thursday at 1230 which was expected. You pick your bread out of the bin but I waited til they came within two numbers of calling my number to grab my bread (why hold it for 30 mins lol) the meat and ingredients are really fresh. $10 flat was the cost of my sandwich. Credit cards are accepted (no Amex). Right in the heart of the north beach area. I would come back for sure.
author: Ben L.

description:
i can't believe i haven't been to Molinari until this weekend. My parents were in town for Father's Day and my dad wanted a chill day so we decided to do a picnic at Washington Square park and get food nearby. My mom saw this place on Anthony Bourdain's show & since it was close we decided we'd go. What a great call! it's a cute little Italian deli in the heart of North Beach.  

i got the Molinari special w/ provolone on dutch crunch + basil spread & oil/vinegar. 2 words: GET THIS. the sandwich was huge so I only ate half (i'll have the rest for dinner tonight :) ) the meats were full of flavor & a nice variety. Get it with everything & you have to ask to add the oil/vinegar & basil spread ... but you won't regret it ... my belly was happy. 3 of us got this special & loved it. 

my dad and brother got the pastrami on whole wheat & i got to try it ... great flavor in the pastrami & they give a nice serving of it. was great with provolone & mustard. if i don't get the Molinari special next time I will definitely order this. 

we got a few sides : they have a small size so we tried 4 ... in order of how we liked them :
1.pesto pasta - this was our favorite. had olives, great sauce & sundried tomatoes ... highly recommend it! 
2. potato salad - my sister really wanted this one. nice crunchy bits of celery, not too mayo-y 
3. pasta salad w/ asiago cheese. this was good ... def very cheesey. 
4. mixed assortment of olives, great for a picnic... although they were a tad too salty. 

they make their own salami and i got a 1 LB thing of it, but i haven't tried it yet ... def excited for it though. 

the guys that work there are so friendly & if you ask to try something they give you a nice sample size.
author: danielle a.

description:
A true San Francisco gem!!

Came here for lunch after getting snubbed by an employee at the Dogpatch Cafe, who literally GRUNTED and turned away when my boyfriend and I walked in and said hello. 

It's so wonder how Molinari has existed for so long in SF. They are friendly, efficient and delicious. I can't recommend it enough!! What a pleasant experience, especially compared to all the new attitude-heavy places popping up in SF. Guess it's only the old-school restaurants and cafes that care about customer service. It makes a huge difference.

Thanks for such a wonderful lunch, Molinari.
author: June L.

description: The sandwiches take a long time to make and the lines are long...I don't understand why there isn't a simple check out for people just trying to buy a frozen product or bottle of wine. I asked the cashier if I could just buy my frozen ravioli without waiting the hour plus for all the people getting sandwiches. He said it wouldn't be fair. So I will buy my food elsewhere from now on...Most grocery stores don't make you wait an hour to purchase something from their freezer. This rating doesn't reflect the quality of their food, just this poor customer experience if you aren't waiting for a sandwich. Sad.
author: Mary C.

description:
Old School Italian Deli with a whole lot of goodness. That's how I would describe Molinari's.  Back in Jersey, you find a lot of places like this. But to find one in the middle of San Fran, was quite a surprise. 

As soon as you walk in, there are shelves filled with Italian products, including pasta, olive oil, wines, cheeses, hanging cured meats, spreads, etc.  This, my friends, is the real deal. First things first, take a number.  Once you've selected a number, pick out your fresh bread from the bin and hold on to it until your number has been selected.  I opted for the Renzo special (thinly sliced prosciutto, coppa, fresh mozzarella, and sun dried tomatoes), the perfect combo of grade quality meats and cheese. The sandwich was delicious, filling, and full of flavor. It definitely brought back memories as a kid when I used to go to these old school delis. The sandwich was also pretty big, as I wasn't able to finish everything all at once.

The staff was super friendly and took the time to beautifully craft the sandwiches the right way.

Once done, pay for the sandwich at the counter (credit cards accepted) and take it to go, or eat it at the tables outside. Either way, you won't be disappointed.
author: Amanda D.

description: Excellent food!! We had read reviews before visiting the city. Our tour bus stopped right down the road, so we figured we'd try it. Get a number when you walk in then decide what you want. They're very fast and very busy. The food was hot and fresh!  I got the chicken parmigiana sandwich and my wife got the meatball. Delicious!!
author: Joshua P.

description:
Their sandwiches are quite expensive, but the sandwich was huge and really tasty. So Glad I pre ordered their sandwiches thru yelp because I've got a small discount! (-^  ^-) 
Will definitely come for sandwiches other times.
author: Lily C.

description: We have been coming to Molinari's for years. Perfect, delicious sandwiches. Can't go wrong with anything here! The fresh pasta is a must to take home if you're visiting!
author: Lisa G.

description:
Definitely has the feel of a real Italian deli.  The wife and I ordered two sandwiches to take to Sonoma.  The sandwiches were stuffed nicely and very tasty.  While the prices are a bit on the high side, considering the decent amount of cured meats and good quality ingredients, it is still a good value.

Parking is super tough, as it is in a very busy section of the city.  I thought the bread bin setup was not very well thought out.  We had to pick out the bread ourselves and hand them over to the server behind the counter.  It would be more sanitary if the customer can tell the sandwich maker which bread from behind the counter to use.
author: Mark D.

description:
#1/100 in 2016

Yum! I had the Joe's special, which is mozzarella, pesto basil sauce, sun dried tomatoes, and sweet red pepper. I added smoked ham. It was absolutely delicious! It's definitely salty, though, so make sure you have water nearby. 

Three sandwiches, one small side pasta salad, and one San Pellegrino came to $44. Yikes! Definitely on the pricey side. The sandwich was huge though, definitely enough for two lunches.

No restrooms.
author: Kendra N.

description:
Take a number, it's worth it. The prosciutto here is AMAZEtotheMAX! Also get some of their mortadella. 

This place is great. There's lots of unique items. The cured meats are amazing. We also tried a few of their hot and regular Italian sausages. Also mega delicious. Lots of cheeses to choose from, although we didn't pick any up this time. 

A fellow shopper recommended a bottle of red to us that he swears by. It was only $14 so we grabbed a bottle too. I haven't cracked it open yet, but if it's anything like everything else here, it's probably great. 

Places like this make me miss glutens BIG TIME, because the sandwiches that everyone ordered looked great. Crusty bread with a soft center...and piles upon piles of meat and veggies. And I didn't ever crave sandwiches when I was eating bread....so yeah. If only...
author: Carol M.

description:
And on the seventh day, God said, "Let Bonnie's workplace be a block away from Molinari's, because I know that broad loves a good sandwich." 

Molinari represents everything holy and good: from the fresh pastas you can buy by weight, to the awesome wine selection, to the decadent imported cheeses, to the AMAZING sandwiches made to order. 

This little deli gets pretty busy during lunch hours, and they have some outdoor seating if you want to sit on Columbus and enjoy your sandwich. My go-to favorite is the Renzo's Special on Dutch Crunch with added homemade pesto. The guys working behind the counter (a little rough around the edges but friendly) slice handfuls of the prosciutto, or whatever meat you have on your sammie, right in front of you and I try my hardest not to drool each time. 

The South Beach and Chicken Parm are also good options and even my vegetarian coworkers love the Eggplant Parm sandwiches.

Rules:
- Grab a number
- Use the damn tongs to pick up your bread of choice from the bread bin
- Peruse the wine and olive oil selections
- Gawk at the glass case full of fresh pastas, salads, meats and cheeses
- Order your sandwich
- Don't forget to get a stamp card for your sandwich purchase because you WILL want to come back.
- Cash tips only! Throw a dollar down into that glass vase they have on the counter dammit.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
This place is awesome! I was strolling around the neighborhood when I noticed a line out the door for this place (usually a good sign). There are a million meats, cheeses, wines, olives, etc. Aka it's heaven.  I had the  Renzo Special with fresh mozzarella, sundried tomatoes, 
proscuitto, and coppa hot or mild. I should of gone hot coppa, my one mistake!
author: Jessica C.

description: Really disappointed with my sandwich today. After reading the reviews I was dying to try the Renzo sandwich... Much to my disappointment, the sandwich was severely skimpy on the meat, and d hardly any toppings. the dutch crunch bread i picked was really dry and tasted old. It definitely could have used some kind of sauce, but overall was serious let down. Didn't look anything like the pictures. My girlfriend had the luciano special and that was much better. As an added bonus, the russian guy who made our sandwiches tried to flirt with my her right in front of me. Part of me thinks he made my sandwich crappy on purpose!
author: Jimmy J.

description:
As far as sandwiches go, I have to say this place is pretty bomb.

I guess I have different expectations for Deli's so if you're looking for that kind of Ike's messy crazy flavors type of sandwich, maybe this is not the spot for you.

But if you're looking for a classic italian, great cured meats, etc. with pretty authentic cheeses look no further than Molinari's. Their sandwich selection is decent and it's made on the spot. You can also make a custom one on your own but it seemed like too much work at the time.

You grab your own roll out of their roll bucket and you just hand it to the guy who whips up the pictures of dense sandwiches you see as part of the Yelp listing. Not too pricey, and hits the spot.
author: Lorrie M.

description: 100% by far the best sandwich this side of San Francisco.  Get the Molanaris special w fresh mozz or the Renzo. The only downfall about this place is that around noon the wait can be a bit lengthy. I've started going in around 11:45am or post 12:30pm and generally don't have to wait for long. Guys that work there are super nice and friendly. Maybe I'm delusional, but since I frequent this place I feel like they recognize me now! They also have "dirty chips" which are sooooo good and a huge selection of drinks.
author: Taylor P.

description:
I have been looking into great deli shops over the past, couple of months because sandwiches are so convenient during lunch breaks!  It's simple enough where you can pack it to go and devour it by the end of the lunch hour.

The ambiance definitely speaks mama papa deli shop right in North Beach - Little Italian town!  

Do order their Renzo Special - prosciutto, pesto, mozzarella and sun dried tomatoes marinated in olive oil.  It sounds, looks and tastes grand!  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/FmGF1B-Rpsjq1f5b56qMwg?select=uXrmrF5CDfFK6PMBXiGOoQ#HbhwojG1nmDeUmL-heX_Cg

Before you order, you get to pick your choice of bread personally from a plastic case and hand it over to the server upon ordering.

They also offer fresh meat on display and Italian delicacies - cheese and wine.

Seats are only available outside!
author: Tiffany D.

description: If everybody had a neighborhood Deli this good... world peace would probably be possible.
author: Eric T.

description:
The funny thing is we usually ordered heros for take out here when I worked in the financial district. This time we came here for goodies to bring to my friend's Thanksgiving party. We picked up prosciutto, house made salami, soppresata, parmesan, piave, triple cream brie, and point reyes blue cheese. All the above was lovely. 

The charismatic guy working who was not our server convinced us to buy a barolo for $8. This was a steal of a purchase. This store was packed, yet professional and kind service. I love this shop and lucca in the Marina.
author: Greg O.

description:
Love these deli Italian markets.  Get ur ticket number and wait for it to be called.. Then go crazy with your cheeses, meats and prepared food items. 
For sandwiches, pick your bread (literally) from the bread containers.  Then place your order when your number is called. 
Got the molinari special, which is a combo of Italian cold cut meats.  Simple, delicious, and rustic!
author: Linda T.

description: From out of town and wanted an authentic Italian sandwich.  Yelp had this place listed as no.2.  I didn't try no.1 because they were closed so I can't compare but the "molinari" was delish! Will go back again for sure!  The whole experience on picking your own bread and bringing it up to the counter when it's your turn to order was interesting.  I had to observe the process because I was simply clueless
author: Bernie H.

description: This spot is the REAL DEAL!!! Authentic deli at it's finest. Whenever I'm in San Fran I stop here for a sandwich and I normally don't even eat bread, but I'll make an exception here :)
author: Derek T.

description: Food is delicious l got a sandwich and a ravioli and marinara sauce for take out. The bread is cool but you have to pick it up with my own bare hands so l had to make garlic bread out of it so it would kill some bacteria. Everything looks good tho.
author: James D.

description:
Still great!
Best meats and sandwiches.

Used to work for many years in North beach. Only regret is I didn't come here more often.

No real place to sit down to eat. So best sandwiches to go.  Best for buying great deli meats to take home or on the road to napa... :)
author: Tgolf T.

description:
OLD SCHOOL DELI WITH GLORIOUS SANDWICHES FOR CHEAP! 

If you like good sandwiches, get your @$$ in here asap!!! If you don't like good sandwiches, something is seriously wrong with you.

You can find decent sandwiches at Ike's but there is no "experience". At Molinari's, walking into a room filled with cured meats and ripping a deli number at the counter just make you feel OG straight outta Goodfellas. I need to refrain from busting out my Joe Pesci accent when I order.

Sandwiches are Mantastic, no man (or woman) can hate on the glory to be had here for under $10. I always get a simple Italian combo because I am a big fan of the classics, but the other stuff is probably great too. Meat portions are legit, they got the Dutch Crunch bread, and it is so cheap! My first visit I thought it was going to be another North Beach tourist trap, I was dead wrong.

Added bonus for any Staten Islanders out here, this joint (and a random coffee shop in Napa), share a name with our childhood borough president.
author: Roger L.

description:
The Molinari Special was probably one of the best Italian meat sandwiches that I've ever had in my life!  The two Lyft rides that I used to get here from SOMA was well worth the trip.  Inside, the place is an old school deli with a large long counter with a huge glass display of all the meats on offer.  They  have the number dispenser thing near the front so make sure to grab one before ordering.  The sandwich list is listed above the case and make sure to grab your bread from the sealed bread case, I got dutch crunch for me.

$8.50 for the sandwich with cheese?  Hell yeah!  The guys behind the counter also move really quick too so I got back to work in plenty of time to slowly enjoy the sandwich.  There's no question I'm coming back here!
author: Ben H L.

description:
Has changed a bit since I was here years ago. I had the margarita sandwich. Good. Sandwich and service. I'm still not convinced this is the same  place as when I lived here in the 90's but worth a stop. 
Going to venture out again today. I remember it being bigger with side salads but now gelato-nothing wrong with that. 
Run by Italians! A plus. Nice place. Give it a try if you want a good reasonably priced sandwich. Good drink choices too. 
Yep this is the same place. I went to the other deli-down the street last night. 
Molinari's hasn't changed a bit!! Went there for lunch today.  Great!
Be sure to grab a number on your way in!!
author: Laura C.

description:
If you're looking for Italian food for snacking, light meals, cooking, or whatever, this is the one-stop get-everything place to go to. While I went there mainly for cheese (and oh what a cheese selection they have), there's also many types of sausage and meats, fresh and dried pasta, wine and canned tomatoes. I can't even recall what else they had in the deli, there's just *SO MUCH* and the place is always packed whenever we go by (since it's pretty much in the centre of North Beach and tourist-ville). 

While it's out of the way for me most of the time, I'm keeping Molinari's in mind for any of my Italian food and cheese needs. Despite the volume of customers, the service from the people behind the counter was quick and very friendly and welcoming. They use a number system regardless of whether you're buying something from the shelf or from the deli counters. Highly recommended.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Holy f that was a good sandwich!!!
They cured meats beautifully! And the focaccia is to die for!
Can't wait to go back and try the other meats and the pastas!!
author: Grace M.

description: BADA-BING! what's not to love about a REAL Italian deli?  Deli meats hanging from the ceiling, a big bin of Italian breads, sliced cheeses and deli meats for fresh sandwiches. . . . .the guys behind the counter are too happy to help.  Super busy, though, so be prepared to wait.
author: Debbie R.

description:
It's not fast or cheap but a real pleasure to eat here.  Top drawer sandwich selections and some very nice Italian grocery items for sale.  

On vacation?  Get something to go and eat in Washington Square park nearby or up at Coit tower.  

Yumm!
author: Joe B.

description:
Eating a Molinari sandwich in Washington Square Park still feels like the ultimate San Francisco experience. It's right up there alongside getting drunk at dive bars in the Mission and eating bacon-wrapped hot dogs - I mean, except this is much, much classier. 

How it works:
1. Grab a number as soon as you walk in, it's right at the door.
2. Select a piece of bread from the bin, you'll need to hand it to the person who calls your number when you tell them what sandwich you'd like.
3. Grab a drink from the refrigerator while they make your sandwich.
^that's it.

I am so in love with the environment inside Molinari. They offer beautifully packaged olive oil, sauces and cheeses. Sinatra was playing. The staff are all very refined looking and friendly gentlemen. The meats are out of this world. They slice the meat per order - so your sandwich feels very special. 

Everything about Molinari feels very special.
author: K M.

description:
Hands down my favorite deli in the city. This is a true Italian deli, they really have it all!  I had the most delicious deli sandwich - I recommend the Molinari special, it's heaven and only $8. As we were waiting for our number to be called, I had a chance to look around and see all the other goodies they offer - everything from imported Italian wines from every region in Italy, to fresh pasta, to pre-made dinners, to Italian desserts. 

The only weird thing (I thought at least) was that you have to pick up your own roll of bread to use for the sandwich. So when you give your order, you hand over the roll that you want used. My hands weren't the cleanest walking in there, so it was a little gross to me that I had to hold onto my bread the entire time. Maybe they could offer wax paper to grab them with or some other kind of barrier for sanitary purposes. 

The staff is really really friendly. And there are some tables outside you can sit on to enjoy your amazing sandwich. I will definitely be back, especially since my sister just moved in next door ;)!
author: Corrina S.

description:
Molinari's is a North Beach institution, it was established in 1896 (wow) and is said to be the oldest deli west of the Rockies. And if you are looking for an authentic San Francisco Italian deli experience here's all you need to know: Joe DiMaggio specified in his will to have them cater his funeral...

They could have survived since 1896 on business from the Renzo Special sandwich alone: prosciutto, coppa (I get the sweet), their fresh mozzarella, and sun-dried tomatoes. And although they are packed for sandwiches, don't sleep on getting some groceries, olive oil, wine, and their famous sausages there as well. A real treat is their homemade ravioli and tortellini, so good all you really need is a little melted butter with some of their Parmigiano-Reggiano freshly grated to finish it...

A great selection of classic cold cuts and antipasto as well with none of the big city deli 'attitude' - you may end up waiting for a few minutes but you'll smile with the guys making the sandwiches while in line. A legendary local business, for good reason...
author: Arthur S.

description: Stop reading reviews on this place and just get there as fast as you can. You will not be disappointed. I had the Luciano and it was hands down the best sandwich I've ever had. I'm not a focaccia bread fan until today. The service was friendly and helpful. I felt like I was transported to Italy.
author: Tina M.

description: If you are looking for a great Italian sandwich, this is the spot. You pic your bread, take a number and wait in line. Within twenty minutes you will have your lunch. I had heard of this place for years watching the travel channel and it exceeded my expectations. On the way out we grabbed a wrapped piece of salami and it was VERY good. I strongly suggest coming here if you can bear the wait for an excellent lunch. Enjoy!
author: David L.

description: Good afternoon it getting sunly an warm will love this sandwich it across from the church and is located in North Beach the sandwich place been here for a while and I always come here support your local shop and is also found me on so its good I hope you guys enjoy your Sunday morning from a great afternoon nice and warm stay cool drink plenty water have a good evening
author: Miko A.

description: This place is great I wish they were open later. They should charge just to smell the aroma in here I could never forget. The sandwiches are the best made anyway you like it or try the specials they are the best. The cheese the meats everything is delicious. If I lived around the corner I wouldn't stay away a day.
author: Stef M.

description:
Hands down one of the best sandwiches I've ever had. When you first walk in, there's a bunch of meats hanging and all different types of meats and cheeses in their fridge. You pick a number, go to the back and pick a bread. They're pre sliced for the sandwich and the breads are fresh. You wait until they call your number and pick the type of sandwich you want. 

We chose the Luciano special, and they will freshly slice the meats needed to go into your sandwich. I would highly recommend the Luciano special and would get it again next time I'm in the area. But this place isn't just a sandwich shop, they also sell ingredients, pastas, meats, etc. I haven't personally tried anything but the sandwich but saw Italian families and Italian grandmas picking up fresh ingredients here. 

I would highly recommend this place and hope to come back next time I am in San Fran.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
After a few days of going Jabba the Hutt on all of the best dim sum, Vietnamese, and Korean food I could find, I had to call a timeout on Asian cuisine and find something different. I am usually the last to get burned out on Asian food, but it happened. 

Molinari's is a haven of cured meats, sausages, cheese, olives, wine, and made-to-order sandwiches that are divine. I didn't know I needed to pick out my own bread from the bin in the back and actually hand it to the woman making my sandwich, but I didn't mind feeling uninitiated in this place. It was like a rite of passage, and I came out with one of the best sandwiches I have ever eaten, the Renzo special. 

The only downside is there are just a few tables and seats out front, but if you're up for it, eating your sandwich on the go or taking it to a second location is definitely worth it.
author: Michael C.

description:
Best prosciutto and mozzarella sandwich I have ever had even better than in Italy and I lived there. They are so so delicious. Choose your own bread. And take a number. Don't go during rush hour. 

Closes at 6pm so hard to get to after work. Definitely a Saturday spot. 3/4 tables outside but usually taken on a nice day. 

Order their italian meets. They make them themselves. They also have artichoke hearts. And sun dried tomatoes. Very authentic.
author: Dakin G.

description: Amazing Italian deli with delicious sandwiches. I ordered the Luciano special with oil and vinegar. The mozzarella and sundried tomatoes are incredibly fresh and tasty! Coupled with the prosciutto and coppa makes this sandwich to die for.
author: Leticia C.

description:
So today I thought about the Italian Captain of the cruise ship Costa Concordia that jumped ship before any of the passengers were evacuated.  

Also today I thought of the Ford Model T.  The first affordable automobile and most influential car in history that shaped how cars would be made and have improved and evolved into the cars we have today.

I thought of both of these today when trying to explain my feeling about Molinari.  It has the look.  Great tasting salami hanging throughout the store.  Focaccia bread at the counter.  Items like yellowfin tuna in a can and many Italian items you won't see anywhere else.

The other day I ordered a couple sandwiches because I have heard nothing but good things regarding the deli at Molinari.  I ordered the Luciano and the South Beach.  One had I believe prosciutto, mozzarella di bufala, and sun dried tomato,etc.  The other had turkey, artichoke, etc.  Both were disappointing.

I'm not sure if the original owners have jumped off the Molinari ship and nobody has caught on.  Or if Molinari is the original like the Ford Model T which set and shaped how sandwiches are made today.  With other deli's taking that format and improving and evolving into better sandwiches of today.  Just like the cars today out perform the Model T. 

I recognize Molinari as being a San Francisco Institution.  And I hope it stays forever.  I love the salami and the products they have.  But the deli just doesn't make the cut in my opinion.
 
I may have a lot of people disagree with me.  But just because something is original or old, doesn't equate to good.  I'm gonna take the Ford Mustang over the Ford Model T.  And whether the Captain of the Molinari ship ditched or not, I'm not sticking around to find out and to end up like Leonardo.
author: Michael L.

description: My first time there was today. I ordered a Turkey and basil, smoked turkey, and an Italian herb roast beef. Everyone on the first bite said how good they tasted. The customer service was great. They were so friendly and helpful despite how busy they were. Definitely worth many more trips back just to eat there.
author: Isabel H.

description:
Thank you for the artichokes. They were delicious.


To the cute Italian from NAU

From Savannah from AZ
author: Savannah R.

description:
This review is long overdue as I've been getting sandwiches here forever. The best lunchtime sandwich for my money in San Francisco any day. This is an old school joint, beloved by many and a San Francisco institution. When I don't have to take clients to a fancier establishment for lunch I always stop by here. Sometimes you just need a good sandwich for lunch instead and this place never disappoints. Anything on the menu is great, but I always get the Luciano special. Hot panini with sundries tomatoes, prosciutto, cheese, lettuce. Perfection on focaccia.

They also sell other Italian fare to take home, like cheeses, salamies, cured meats, salads of various kinds, frozen pasta, very good wine, candy, etc. At lunch and on weekends the place is packed, so expect a wait, but very worth it. Certainly a lot better than a lot of establishments in North Beach that cater to tourists with overpriced and crappy food. This places closes early, around 5 I think, so plan accordingly.
author: Sam W.

description:
Upon coming in, I liked the feel of the place. You come in, grab a number, select your bread and wait for your number to be called. 

The service was great but maybe my choice (Italian combo) wasn't great. The meats tasted good but the onions and mayo and mustard overpowered it. And $10 for a sandwich is pretty pricey. Since my boyfriend and I shared this, I also bought the pesto pasta salad. That was really good!

I feel like I made a bad decision in my sandwich choice so I'll be back when I can to write an updated review.
author: Kelly T.

description: pretty good sandwich! got the molinari special which is just a great combination of cold cuts. the bread is pretty tough to chew though, i think that's my only complaint on the otherwise yummy sandwich. we also got a bottle of wine - they have great italian wine selections - all really reasonably priced. it's a great little deli/shop - and very popular.
author: Christina L.

description:
Got a sandwich here the other day with few coworkers and was not disappointed. 

I'm a sandwich loving guy. The only problem I found with the sandwich I got (Italian Combo) was that the bread that comes with it was very hard that it made the sandwich difficult to eat. It was not just toasted, it was "knock on wood" sounding hard. The meat, however, was absolutely delicious! It was so flavorful. I believe I would just need to change it to a softer, less difficult to bite, kind of bread next time. 

Definitely will try again!
author: Robbie P.

description:
The most important part of this review is: JUST GO, IT'S DELICIOUS. 

So, I work in the FiDi of SF and there are plenty of sandwich shops to grab lunch, but my coworker insisted that we take a walk over to North Beach to grab sandwiches from Molinari. (We even put it on our calendars) 

After walking almost a mile, we came upon Molinaris.  There were tons of cheeses, cured meats, wines, and other yummy goodies.  I had already looked up their menu via Yelp so I knew the "Renzo Special" was the sammie for me--with the addition of basil spread.  

When you walk in for sandwiches, you grab a number from the counter, then select your bread from the box in the back (I got the rosemary roll).  Then you wait patiently for you number to be called.  

After a short wait, my number was called.  A beautiful, blue eyed, middle aged man took my bread and made me the most delicious sandwich, adorned with prosciutto, hot coppa, fresh mozzerella, sun dried tomatoes, and basil spread.  Then I went back to my office, stuffed my face, and dealt with my food coma for the rest of the afternoon.

Would I go again? DUH, already planning on it. 
Would I recommend this place to friends/family? Already have.
author: Sarah P.

description: Delis like this are what dreams are made of. Meats, cheeses and wines cover the walls and ceilings, and the inside is filled with the smell of warm bread. You can pick your bread out of a big bin, and they'll fill it with whatever meats and cheeses you lay your eyes on. Everything is very fresh and rich in flavour. I recommend the Molinar sandwich, because it is stuffed with fresh cold cuts!
author: Carolina S.

description:
BEST SANDWICHES.
About $10 a pop, but so so SO worth it!
Grab a number pick your bread, and chat it up with the people beside you! Go early- the locals know that 11 or even a bit earlier is prime time to beat the lunch crowd  just a tip I picked up from the lady next to me in line (who has been coming to the deli for over five decades!!).
I got the Molinari special I've heard ALL of the sandwiches are GREAT. 

Story time: When I came home, I told my dad I'd gotten the best sandwich of my life at north beach today (this is not an exaggeration and since I love food and cooking, plus it takes a lot for me to go out and buy a $10 sandwich- and then to say it's worth every penny?! Yeah, so this is the real deal here!). He said there was a deli he used to got to when he lived and worked in the city and GO FIGURE IT WAS THIS VERY DELI!

Now I leave you with this: Go. You won't regret it.
author: Melissa R.

description:
God I love this place. It's the kind of place I'd almost rather not tell people about because it's already crowded. But people deserve a great sandwich and deli. It's an American right. 

Everyone is super cool here. The food is great and reasonably priced. Grab and sandwich, bottle of wine and some sliced meat to go. Makes for a lovely afternoon.
author: Jason B.

description: Hooo boy, this is the deli that I've been looking for in city. Cured meats, fresh cheeses, delicious Italian style sandwiches. Everything on the menu looked incredible, but after milling over my thoughts for a bit, I decided on the Luciano Special. It was nothing short of amazing. Soft savory prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, sweet sundried tomatoes and onions on a crispy flaky focaccia panini topped with some rosemary. After trying out Deli Board and a few other San Francisco staples, I can confidently say Molinari's  has my favorite sandwiches in city. I'll be back for many lunches and dinners to come.
author: Patrick S.

description: Take a number. Haha Everything is so good. I Oreos ally recommend the fresh mozzarella, sopressada, and mini pepperonis.
author: Melissa S.

description:
This is my favorite sandwich place in the Bay Area. The Italian meats are so fresh and tasty. Service was quick as well. 

I used to always get the Molinari special on Dutch crunch. It was awesome. But nothing compared to the Luciano special on focaccia bread. Oh. My. God!!  Honestly, if you don't try that one, you are crazy. It's amazing!  

This place is a much try. Hands down.
author: Steve J.

description: The best sandwich I have ever had! The Luciano was so yummy. Worth the price. Can't wait to try the raviolis!  Will definitely come back! Very nice people!
author: Lisa F.

description:
The.
BEST.
Coldcuts.
I've. 
EVER. 
Had. 



EVER. 


And I'm an Italian Jew from the BRONX for f***s sake!
author: Steven C.

description:
After eating their Italian salami for years the time has come to visit the location that started it all: Molinari Deli in San Francisco's  North Beach.

The exterior looks exactly as you would expect for an old school deli that has been in business for ages. Actually it looks even older considering they moved to this location back in the 60s, though they have been established at the end of 19th century. It has this cool semi-dirty look that is so specific to these places in North Beach that have been around forever.

When you walk in, the shelves stacked with Italian delicacies look at you from all sides. The long counter with staff behind splits the room running vertically across. Behind are all sorts of deli meats, cheeses, pickled veggies...Heck, they even make their own mozzarella. If you want a sandwich you grab a number and wait. This place is always busy so the wait will most likely not be short but worth the while. If you're getting a sandwich make sure to grab your roll from the pile and take it to the counter when your number gets called. The store has all sorts of Italian groceries to kill time while waiting so you might even pick some unexpected items to take home.

My favorites here are definitely the cured meats with their super delish hot coppa sliced thin being a standout. You can't go wrong with anything sliced here...it looks so good that I wouldn't even mind trying that (otherwise nasty) head cheese.

The service is very old-fashioned friendly and each customer is treated like a regular. Some guys behind the counter even speak Italian. Like some reviewers noted parking in this area is not the best and my advice is to park in the North Beach garage on Vallejo St. 

If you are in the area, looking for authenticity, and/or on the budget there are no better options than Molinari: this is essential San Francisco experience. I cannot recommend it more highly...5 stars well deserved.
author: Vedran V.

description:
Is it possible that a freshly made Italian deli sandwich can taste really good? Apparently, this place can make it happen. This place is a very "old-school" looking traditional Italian deli right in San Francisco. I walked inside, and grabbed a tiny piece of paper from a small red machine dispenser. The piece of paper had a number on it, and you have to wait for them to call the number. 

I ordered a Molinari special with everything, and asked for mozzarella cheese and a focaccia roll. You may have to pay extra, but this $10 sandwich is really large. It should be enough for two lunches for a man. Everything refers to lettuce, tomato, onion, mayonnaise and mustard. I took a bite out of this sandwich, and I had a nice wonderful feeling after each and every bite. The bread was fairly fresh and had a nice chewiness. The meats inside the sandwich had a nice fresh taste, and the portions are excellent. The mozzarella cheese, the mayonnaise, and the fresh vegetables enhanced the flavor very significantly, and I thought I was eating an almost perfect cold sandwich. I felt like a very happy carpenter who just had a very tasty lunch after a hard working but rewarding morning.

I saved another half of that big sandwich for about 24 hours, and it was enough for a good lunch during my flight out of San Francisco to the somewhat decent city of Boston. As long as you put the sandwich in a refrigerator and give it a tiny "reheat" back to room temperature or a tiny warmness, the sandwich should still be good. This is not a good place if you are in a rush, because there seems to be a queue. The location is not too bad, it's very close to Chinatown, and it's within walking distance to Coit Tower. 

Overall, I thought I had the biggest, tastiest and the most wonderful cold cut sandwich in San Francisco so far. If I wanted to bring my lunch, I would love to come back to buy some cold cuts to make my own tasty sandwich. This place is possibly one example of San Francisco's cold sandwiches at its finest, and these guys have been doing it for a very long time, since 1896.
author: Ambrose C.

description: Molinari's delicatessen is boasted as the oldest delicatessen in the United States and now they should also be known as having the best sandwiches too. It so happens to be in San Francisco. ( i thought it might be in NY but nope) Located in Little Italy this place is bustling with locals and tourists alike. Upon entering, make sure you pull a number ticket or you won't get any service. Being my first time I was a bit confused as to why all the people were standing around with a roll of bread in their hands. I felt like Sherlock trying to decipher what the hell was going on. Ok, fine. So I figured they picked their own bread out and soon found the bin they had picked them from. The meat and cheese selections were as expected from a deli that's been around so long. They even had some gourmet items to choose from. I ordered the, "South Beach sandwich" with a side of Calamata olives and a bag of chips. Excellent! The bread was fresh and the meat was hand sliced. It was excellent. BTW, I was only able to finish half a sandwich. A must if your in the Bay Area and want a casual bite to eat.
author: George S.

description:
Simply put, bomb.com

This is a must for the locals and the tourists! Pick your bread and watch the masterpiece come together!
author: Cole L.

description:
It was nearly empty when we walked in at 10 am on a Thursday morning, which is the way I like it. We got enough for a picnic - typical antipasto - mushrooms, artichokes, sun dried tomatoes, mozzarella balls, seafood salad, olives, cheeses. Their olives were delicious and the cheeses were excellent - great variety. The seafood salad, not so much. I had high hopes for it, but the marinade was sour and offputting. We ended up throwing it out, which was a shame.

Cute Italian deli in a good location - would go back and maybe try a sandwich this time.
author: Courtney R.

description: I never had a sandwich at Molinari's. I usually shop there for staples, prosciutto , Parmesan, a jar of anchovies, etc. I recently bought a couple of cans of SM tomatoes. They were on sale, but the same price as elsewhere. I chuckled to myself, as in who are they kidding. Well, I was the fool! It turns out they were way past their due date. Just to make sure, I went into the store to check, and fair enough, all of the canned SM tomatoes had expired, most of them in 2011. Those cans are still on display at the store. I have received very disrespectful service here more than I can count. The staff, formed mostly by uneducated, rude men, makes fun of the customers at their face., and the exchange can at times get hostile. They are obviously never bothered by complaints, fully knowing suckers will be lining up for their sandwiches and expired cans of tomatoes.
author: Firat Y.

description: Best deli sandwich I've ever had. Period.  Definitely get one with the marinated bell peppers and sun dried tomatoes.
author: David H.

description: Every time we visit San Fransisco we stop here... they have an amazing Italian sandwich and we always buy two sausages which we fly home with. We literally were stopped by the TSA agent screening our bag... he is looking at it for a long while.. and he says... "Is that sausage in there?"... lol.... Yup.... told him where to go to buy one...
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
This place kind of reminds me of Woodside Deli - really large selection of Italian sliced meats, except the bread here is really fresh and delicious. Seriously, that Ciabatta was delicious. 

I've decided I'm not a big fan of Italian sandwiches because they tend to be too salty for my taste. But if you like salami meats and the like, this place would be heaven for you.
author: Jess C.

description:
Cute little Italian deli shop, filled wall to wall (and ceiling) with wines, cheeses, and meats. 
Many different combinations, it was hard for me to choose: get the sandwich with mozzarella, but then lose out on the basil garlic? There was probably a build your own option, but I didn't notice.
Sandwiches range from 8-10 dollars.
The sandwich was a hearty size and they pack it a lot of meat.
The prosciutto and sun dried tomatoes were delicious! 
(I got the renzo)
I had a bite of my friend's north beach.
They, on the menu, were near identical, but they tasted unique from each other (and delicious)
author: Trang B.

description:
Very Good sandwich. Not worth $10 though. Potato salad is not San Francisco style.
They are playing up to the tourist trade.
Your choice.
author: Mag N.

description:
My boyfriend and I were walking down the street for a nice stroll over to fisherman's wharf on our weekend getaway. We saw this deli on the corner and we walked in. This place was right up my alley. We were both full but checked the yelp reviews and couldn't resist ordering the South Beach. Before we ordered we asked to sample the salami and they were more than happy to let us try a couple different kinds. 

I really resisted from ordering more but ordered the South Beach. It came with turkey (sliced on the spot), provolone, artichoke hearts, sun dried tomatoes and a basil garlic spread. I also grabbed a bag of sriracha kettle chips and 1/8 lb. of hot dry salami to nibble on. We walked down to the park to a bench and dived into the bad boy. It was just great. You can tell how fresh the food is with every bite. No heavy, gross bloated feeling after eating it like other places. Nice and clean meats and cheeses. Real quality. Tasty flavors. Would love to go back and try one of their many sandwiches. Would definitely make sure to recommend to anyone who can appreciate a good sandwich.
author: Ida A.

description:
Best delicatessen ever. Just go. Joe's special has always been my personal  favorite. Get a number, grab your bread, have the guy make your sandwich, and enjoy!

Every time I go here I feel like I just walked into the movie, "Moonstruck".

Basically a to-go place, although there are now a couple of tables outside. Totally worth getting a couple of sandwiches and hiking up to Coit Tower or going over to the park to eat.
author: tracy c.

description: Seriously? I drove all the way from San Jose, fought parking, waited 30 numbers, got a sandwich that looked nothing like the pictures. Pinner sandwich, I had the renzo, and for 11.50? I think not. Here's the advice you want a sandwich that's mostly bread and hardly worth the wait. You can count on molinaris... This place is weak...
author: Chris M.

description:
Molinari's is the real deal. A lot of stores and restaurants in the Bay Area use their meats, so it's a foodie thrill to come to the source of these high-quality products. First step: grab your choice of bread roll from the case opposite the meat counter. They have a number ticket dispenser, but it wasn't that crowded when we went on a Thursday around noon. When it's your turn to order, hand your bread over to the server and he will put together your yummy sammich. My friend and I both got their special for $7.75, which is a combination of classic Italian meats, including my favorite, salami. I got mine with all the regular additions of lettuce, tomato, onion, pepperoncini, and mustard, so minus mayo and cheese. 

Molinari's is one of those places where technique is not really so important, because the authentic, freshly cut meats and breads make even the simplest sandwiches shine. In addition, the service is personal and fun--our server man smiled as he teased me in a friendly manner about my condiment preferences, and later when he saw me peering into the store from our table outside he gestured in a "sandwich good?!" kind of way and of course I responded in the affirmative.  

I'm not even sure if Molinari's overhang is labeled with its name, but thankfully I recognized the store from photos on Yelp so didn't miss it while power-walking down Columbus. And now that I've experienced the gourmet ingredients and amiable service for myself, I will never forget it!
author: Amy G.

description:
Agreed, best deli in San Francisco! 

I love their meats, their breads, their vegetables, and their cheeses. You go in, choose which bread you want (they have an assortment of dutch crunch, french, wheat, the usual...) and you hand it over. Then you tell them which sandwich combo you want, and they make it for you. 

All their ingredients are very fresh. I forget exactly what I ordered (maybe the North Beach special or something like that), and it was huge! I definitely spent a good chunk of my afternoon working on the first half of the sandwich, and then I saved hte other half for the next day (which still tasted amazing). 

Great spot to hit if you're really looking for some delicious gourmet deli sandwiches! I only wish they pressed their sandwiches and made paninis, which would make this place even more amazing.
author: Jeanette S.

description: Impossible not to give this place 5 stars. I went for lunch on a Sunday afternoon and got the South Beach special with turkey, artichoke hearts, and pesto. My wife got the Renzo which had fresh mozzarella and sun dried tomatoes. Both sandwiches were incredible! They also have a good selection of sodas and chips to go with your lunch. Grab a number when you walk in. The service is prompt and friendly. I'm definitely coming back soon!
author: Russell W.

description: Luciano's special is one of my favorites, alongside the chicken mozzarella warm sandwich, which is smothered in home made marinara sauce. Service is great friendly people all around and if you are not too sure of what to get they will always recommend something delicious.
author: Miguel A.

description: You cant get a better italian sandwhich in SF , and definitly the best I have ever had and I have been to Europe... So good.
author: Leon H.

description:
I purposely saved this review as one of my last, especially after the awful dinner I had.

Spent my final day on my mini-vacation in San Fran. This place was recommended by my foodie friend--he said all the sandwiches were "meatacular."

Before we even walked in, there was a group of old Italian men sitting outside, eating and arguing loudly. "Well, that's pretty legit," I thought. It was old school and all kinds of awesome.

We split a sub--they have you go to a bin of sub rolls and pick out what you want. We chose a delicious-looking roll dusted with flour. We ordered the Renzo Special--brushed olive oil on the bread, sundried tomatoes, fresh mozzarella, capicola and prosciutto. 

OMFG. Forget the fact that service was amazing and our sub guy was super, super friendly--this sandwich was absolutely incredible. Top quality meat, delicious bread, and an outrageous combination of flavors. I'm pretty sure my cholesterol went up about 50 points eating here, but fuck--this place is delicious.

This reminds me so, so much of Little Italy, but the meat was just completely awesome. SF, I'm jealous.
author: Dylan K.

description:
I used to love this place. The sandwiches I just got were almost inedible. The bread was so stale and hard it literally cut my mouth. The lettuce was limp. I got a small potato salad and it was only about a third full. The pasta salad tasted like an old sock. 
I'm so disappointed. I've always sung the praises of this authentic Italian deli but no more. I'm pretty sure that was the worst sandwich I've ever had.
author: Missy F.

description:
On Saturday, 2/7/15, my girlfriend and I were in the mood for a sandwich so we decided to hit up Molinari Delicatessen. I've been wanting to try Molinari for a while now. I had high hopes for this place based off the reviews I've read on YELP and what people have told me first hand. 

Atmosphere/Decor:

Molinari Delicatessen reminds me of a typical Italian deli. The deli itself was very cluttered inside. It was like they hired a hoarder as their interior designer. They have a lot of Italian food items spread throughout the deli. I'm assuming most if not all of these products are from Italy. They have a few tables located outside. 

Food: 

I ordered the Smoked Ham on a French Roll with mayo, lettuce, onions, tomatoes, provolone and American cheese. I'll start off with the bread. When my girlfriend and I arrived at Molinari we were told to choose a roll. There's a designated area where you can hand pick your own bread roll. I know a lot of delis have this option but in a way it's really unsanitary and gross when you think about it. You don't know who touched the bread rolls. We all know that a lot of nasty people don't wash their hands after using the restroom and in general. If you really think about it those bread rolls probably have all kinds of human fluids on them. At least some other places have tongs to get the rolls out. There weren't any labels informing the customer of what type of rolls there were. I wanted a French Roll and when I asked the guy that worked there (possibly the owner) he didn't even know if there was a French Roll in there. He even made me pick up the roll to show him. He said that's not a French Roll. He told me he had some French Rolls behind the counter. I proceeded to put the roll, that he asked me to show him, back in the container with the expectation of him telling me to give it to him because I touched it and I was surprised that he said nothing. So someone that day got a roll with my FUNK on it....Sorry!

When I took my sandwich out of the bag it felt beyond hard! Every French Roll that I've eaten at a deli has been really soft. Usually Sourdough Rolls are very hard. I went back in and asked the employees if their French Rolls are supposed to be hard. They told me yes. I shook my head as I walked back outside to our table. The first bite of my Smoked Ham Sandwich was a challenge. The French Roll was so damn hard! I could of definitely broke a window with this sandwich. The roll was hard as a rock. Even though the roll itself tasted really good I don't see how somebody can enjoy the actual sandwich. It was very time consuming while eating this particular sandwich. It took me over 30 minutes to eat this sandwich. I could usually eat a sandwich in about 5 to 7 minutes. My jaw muscles were very sore from all the chewing after I ate this sandwich. The Smoked Ham was really good and had a lot of flavor. It was definitely some of the best deli ham I've ever eaten. The condiments and cheeses were fresh. I think it would have been a really solid sandwich if the French Roll was softer. 

My girlfriend ordered the Turkey Pesto Special on a Sourdough Roll with fresh mozzarella, sun dried tomatoes and marinated peppers. She said her sandwich was terrible! The Turkey had no flavor. The mozzarella tasted like nothing. The pesto was over oily and the basil in the pesto was not even chopped finely. The sun dried tomatoes didn't taste good. They were really soggy and had a sour flavor. The peppers just didn't taste good as well. My girlfriend also said the bread was just whatever. She gave her sandwich a 1. If she could of given her sandwich a 0 she would have. She only ate half of her sandwich because it tasted like crap. 

We ordered a side of Macaroni Salad and Asiago Cheese Pasta Salad. They were okay. The Macaroni Salad had a weird flavor. Overall it was underwhelming. 
 
Service:

The guy that made our Sandwich who I'm assuming was the owner was kind of rude and not personable. Don't be in customer service if you don't like people. 

Overall:

Molinari Delicatessen is definitely not worth the trip. Their sandwiches are way overpriced for what you get. We spent almost $30 for two weak sandwiches and two shitty pasta salads. IKE'S blows this place out of the water! I won't be coming back.
author: David R.

description:
I'm having a bad run on sandwiches lately. Though each has been good for what it is, they haven't been exceptional. I've had Molinari bookmarked for a while due to the 7x7 things to eat list which recommended the Renzo Special. From Yelp reviews I surmised I should get it on the foccacia bread and get it toasted. At 3 PM in the afternoon there's only a handful of people. I took a number though it was unnecessary. They took out a huge leg of prosciutto for the sandwich and just took a few minutes to assemble and another few minutes to toast. During that time I browsed around the store. Yes, it's a pretty cool deli but my heart belongs to Lucca Ravioli - a similar old school Italian deli in my hood where I've been shopping for 8 years (hopefully the guys at Molinari approve of this). 

The sandwich was okay in the end. I'm not a big fan of their foccacia bread. The dough was like normal fluffy white bread but studded with green onions. I prefer the foccacia that's more holey and stiffer if that makes sense. The prosciutto was good though - nice and meaty. Went well with the mozzarella and sun dried tomatoes. But I felt like the sandwich was missing something - maybe it needed a sauce to bring the flavors together? It was also a bit dry - don't eat this without some water nearby.
author: Jean K.

description: My family and I drove all the way from San Jose just for Molinari's. They have the best sandwiches and we always take home salami! Definitely a must!
author: Tamlyn M.

description:
Best place to grab a sandwich and some good vibes. These gentlemen are extremely friendly with their customers and are always having a good time with each other. It's such a warm atmosphere. 

Thank you chewy!
author: Amber G.

description: The dry cured salami is My favorite. Even better than my hometown's Salumi in Seattle. Sure it's "touristy" but i absolutely loved the deli . Very compact shop with a variety of wines, snacks, fresh made ravioli, etc..  the molinari special , which is a basic Italian Sammie, is to die for. Soft chewy bread with a mouthful of flavorful Italian cuts.
author: Lili P.

description: Came during a Thursday lunch hour and had a bit of a wait but nothing crazy. Long story short: Great sandwiches--got the special on focaccia and the basil turkey. The ingredients were all incredibly fresh and well worth the short wait.
author: Will D.

description:
Sandwiches are a necessary awesome in the lunch rotation. Molinari's is here to help solve the problem of where to get that next awesome sandwich.
