Came on a Monday around 1:30pm, so a little after any lunch rush, and had about a 10 minute wait to order. The old-school deli vibe is fantastic, and the deli staff putting sandwiches together is friendly and generous. Made for a great service experience overall! 

General advice going in:

1 - Grab a number.
2 - Grab a roll of bread from the bin by the giant electronic number sign showing whose number is up (try not to nibble on bread - easier said than done..).
3 - Peruse the hanging menu trying to decide on which sandwich would be most delectable.
4 - Stop perusing the menu. Get the Renzo Special (trust me).
5 - Resist taking your sandwich out of the bag before you leave the store and enjoy at any lunch location destination of your fancy.

I know number 5 is hard, but I believe in you!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Came here on my birthday while strolling the city looking for a grab to bite. THANK GOD FOR YELP! Because I was treated to this treat which was Featured on Food Network and I just seem to have that birthday luck so it was nice to keep the tradition ;) 

The owner of the shop asked us where we were from as he saw we didn't know the customs and was VERY welcoming and honest when helping me choose my sandwich since I had already done the research. 

The ambiance of the store, originality, and variety honestly made me wish I was a part of this culture/ knew some more about the food/ HAD ONE IN TX because it was mind blowing. Such a dive into the culture and I love stuff like that!!

I got the Luciano Special as the owner said many sandwiches set them apart but its THAT one that takes the cake/ is Truly different. I asked for Pesto and to have it toasted and he took very good care of me. 

For a girl who hadn't had 1/4 of the stuff on the sandwich before... I LOVED it.! They are kind of pricey but this meal lasted me 2 days. After a while the sun dried tomatoes and one of the meats started becoming too much for me, but that's just because I haven't acquired the taste yet as again, this was my first time for these things/ to have them be so pure and fresh. 

Either way, I would happily do it all over again :)

They do have a lot of tourist groups and only like 3 tables outside so be prepared to grab and go when it's busy!
author: Monae M.

description: I love this store and sell...they have everything you need. It reminds me of being a kid in north beach. Best deli in North beach for your Italian needs
author: Tina W.

description: Really good sandwiches ! I had the North Beach. The amount of meat inside makes it definitely worth the price. I had enough for 2 meals :)
author: Ilona N.

description: Best sandwich spot we have found in SF. Everything is so fresh. You can pick your own bread and even customize your sandwich. Ask them to throw it on the grille and make your sandwich into a panini.
author: H K.

description:
15 years ago when I lived in the area this was an enjoyable salumeria.  A place I could go comparable to quality salumeria in my hometown brooklyn. you could get a good salami, a sandwich, or some cheese and groceries.  Now its just so overcrowded I frankly can't see myself shopping here. 

Popped in after Xmas and the place was a madhouse.  30 minute wait to get some attention. Rude staff and even more rude customers.

Ah well,.I.guess I could just buy the salami in the supermarket now and avoid the crowds.
author: Patrick L.

description: I'd neer been to an official Delicatessen up until I went here.  I didn't know what to expect, as we don't have places like this where I'm from, but it was awesome and the service was excellent.  The man behind the counter recommended a sandwich for me.  The woman described it as a 'Dinosaur Sandwich'  it was amazing, huge, just packed with meat, maybe some cheese and mayo, but damn, comparing it to scrubway (Subway) is not even a fair comparison.  I paid ten dollars for this monstrosity.  Ate it for two days.
author: Dave M.

description:
I found my way to Molinari's with a couple of locals on the way out of a nearby watering hole, eager to find something to eat.  From the moment I walked in I realized that this place was legit!  

Hanging cured meats, shelves graced with Italian specialties, both imported and housemade, and a display case full of things that made me salivate in anticipation.  The guys behind the counter had a great banter of English and Italian going on, making me feel welcome while being simultaneously entertained by the genuine old-school interaction with customers.  You won't get this kind of connection with the folks behind the counter at your local Chipotle.

I was instructed by my local acquaintances to pick my bread (all of which was fresh and smelling great) and bring it to the counter, where after some deliberation I chose the Renzo special.  The ratio of meat:cheese:toppings was spot on, and I voraciously went to work until all that was left was a very tasty memory and some butcher paper.

If you're near North Beach and even think you might have room for a sandwich, do yourself a favor and stop in.  It's worth it.
author: Thomas G.

description: Ohhhhhh the sandwiches, they are soooo good.  They are so big, I can usually only eat half of one.  This is also an amazing deli with fresh and frozen pasta and imported ingredients.
author: Greta R.

description:
I will take the hour bart ride from Hayward/Union City to come here for a delicious sandwich. So worth it. 

Other than sandwiches they also carry some groceries. Mainly cheese, crackers, wine, salami, pasta, etc.. All great varieties. 

After writing this review it makes me want to go back now!
author: Jennea N.

description: We've walked past this place on every visit, and finally made it a stop on the way to our Alcatraz tour with the boys.  Growing up in the NJ/NY area, I've missed this kind of deli, and Molinari's is one of the best ever.  Get a sandwich made, and sit out front and watch the world go by in North Beach!
author: Mike W.

description:
This is the real deal- an original Italian deli with an incredible selection of Italian salami, cured ham, prosciutto, cheeses in the deli case that make for incredible sandwiches.  They also have a fine selection of Italian wines, San Marzano canned tomatoes, fresh pastas (gnocchi, tortellini, fettuccini), burrata, mozzarella, etc.
The store reminds me of the Italian market in Chelsea Market in NYC, but Molinari has the complete deli experience.  This is an old San Fran landmark full of character, and a total foodie experience.
author: Michael M.

description:
First of all, this is not a one-dollar-sign place. The sandwiches are pretty pricey. 

The quality of the meats do match up though. You can see all the chunks of different types of meat in front of you as you pick. As for the other stuff inside the sandwich, I personally don't like the mustard and I think it takes away from the taste of everything else. The veggies added a nice crunch.

I would recommend the prosciutto sandwich.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Luciano Special was awesome. Parma prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, sweet coppa, and sun dried tomatoes... Wow this sandwich was not lacking in flavor. 

The bread is fresh: I would go with Foccacia or Dutch Crunch-- and ask for their pesto sauce over the Mayo if possible: it is delicious. 

Prices are pretty high, but then again it is a prime location and quality ingredients, so I'm willing to pay since the meat is fresh and tasty. 

They don't skimp with the fillings here, so if you aren't a meat fan it might not be the place for you. There are a few tables outside where you can sit and watch passersby. They do accept credit cards.
author: Neal C.

description: Best prosciutto sandwich ever! Make sure to get in early as lines can fill up the room very very fast.
author: Zachary F.

description: Bought to eat in the airport and it was very good. Though I would have loved to see more imported meats. A must stop in San Fran
author: Howard W.

description: One of the best delis in SF. Portions Are generous, quality is superior and customer service is genuine. It was Valentin's day weekend and it was busy, but it was organized busy. Even my 6 years old son commented on how good his pastrami sandwich was.
author: StoryTeller D.

description: A great San Francisco icon of an Italian delicatessen. Fresh wholesome variety of lunch meats, bread, cheeses,etc.  You will witness true "customer service" by all the people behind the counter. Whether its a sandwich, creating an Italian meal, or recommending any type of Italian products, their there for you. Enjoy the experience of a traditional Italian delicatessen that has been around North Beach for decades, you will not be disappointed.
author: Kurt C.

description:
The place is like a butcher shop selling cured meats, cheeses, snacks, and wines.

Nice people work here. Someone working there (possibly owner) was nice enough to enlighten me about the history of this quaint store on the edge of Little Italy. It turns out the store is ~100 years old. Back then, the meats were made right in the same building. Afterwards, the meats were made in a factory. Nice that the taste still reminds people of Italy.
author: Judge F.

description: The luciano sandwich is like falling in love... So amazing.. And the employees were so sweet and kind.. I did an online order and i couldnt get there til after they closed and they waited for me.. Such an amazing place all around!!
author: Brandi D.

description: I was here on Friday evening and just popped in to drool over the fabulous Italian goodies in this place, since we don't have any really great Italian shops like this in Atlanta. I bought some incredible pasta and wanted to thank "Kenny Chesney" for giving my son and I a slice of the best salami I've had in 10+ years!
author: Sonya V.

description: Awesome dry goods. Salami, cured meat. We come here every times we go to sf. the soft bread sandwich with salimi slices are great.
author: Nick N.

description:
This review is for the raviolis. If I had read Yelp first maybe I could have avoided the mistake of ordering them as I see nothing but sandwiches reviewed in the 8 pages I just read.

My husband and I love veal and spinach or beef and spinach raviolis. They have become impossible to find and if you do either the dough or the filling is not good. By good dough, I mean al dente. So we knew Molinari had a great reputation and gave them a call inquiring if they made raviolis. The guy who answered the phone said yes.  His wife makes them daily and they always sell out. So we decided to have them for our New Year's Eve celebration.  What a disappointment and mistake.

We ordered 4 pounds.  We cooked the first two and planned to freeze the other two.  My husband drove from Sunnyvale to get them and I guess we were optimistic.  Wrong. We followed the directions and boiled them 3 minutes. The dough turned to slime on the top side, broke open and we couldn't even fully drain them as the filling liquified and was pouring out with the water.  Still we sat down and tried to eat them with the beautiful homemade tomato sauce from the tomatoes I grew this summer.  The texture was like eating a bowl of slimy cream of wheat. We threw them away and decided to cook the other two pounds.

For the next batch, we put them into the boiling water and took them out the second the water came to a boil.  This time when we drained them most of the filling stayed in. We sat down and gave them a try but still they were inedible. Just a big plate of slimy texture - filling and pasta. For some reason, they use rice flour.  Not sure if it is in the pasta or the filling.  I suspect maybe both which might account for the texture.  Also no spinach or swiss chard in the filling either which we were assured they made them with.

I am sorry to write such a bad review but I really hope to spare other fellow ravioli lovers out there a bad experience.  Wish I would have known.  We wasted time, money for gas and the raviolis.  And it ruined our New Year's Eve Party.

I now wonder if the ravioli making wife selling out the raviolis every day is just hype to get the ravioli deprived to come in and buy once.
author: Judy A.

description: Great authentic italian deli experience. Went for lunch with a buddy and ordered Molinari special. So much meat on the sandwich it won't even stay together. For $10, i don't know where you beat this deal. Place has been around supposedly around 1900, they do something right.
author: Robert W.

description: The best sandwich I've ever had. It changed my life, I have dreams about being there. Came here on a vacation, and had to go back the next day. I ordered the South Beach special and the Molinari special, both amazing! Come to Los Angeles please!
author: Jasmine D.

description:
My last day in SF went for early lunch. My bf and i both had the italian combo, he added sun dried tomato. We shared a small asiago potato salad. Every thing was delish. I would just request easy mustard next time.

So many great looking things behind the glass... Definitely want to return!
author: Shawn G.

description: Just incredible. Went there New Year's Eve and got sandwiches for the family. Great family store with a good vibe. Sandwiches were excellent.
author: Art T.

description: One thing San Francisco LOVES is a business with a ridiculous wait. This is one of those places. Today I went in twice, both times there were 20 people ahead of me. At 3-4 minutes per customer, that would be a one hour wait. With two employees, that would be a half hour wait. Still way too long. There seemed to be no way to know how anything works-I learned more from the review by Lindsay B. than I did waiting in there today.
author: Richard V.

description: As a visitor to your city this is exactly what I'm looking for. The guys behind the counter have sufficient sass mouth going, they know what they're doing, and they keep things moving quick for the crowd of customers coming in. I got the Molinar Special with fresh mozzarella and foccacia bread. A couple ahead of me got the meat ravioli and told me they drove from the other side of the bay to get it.
author: Steven C.

description:
I came here to try a sandwich just because of the pictures... definitly worth every dollar i spent!
I tried the Molinari special, is big but is so good that you eat without even noticing the size. Best spot i found around.
author: Carol R.

description: We're back after 7 years. 2nd stop while in San Fran and looking forward to another great Italian sandwich.
author: Louis G.

description: Italian wonderfulness! I adore this old world deli. Meat is hanging from the ceiling over the deli counter, a plethora of cheeses awaits your selection and there is fresh braked bread just waiting to be picked up and stuffed with the aforementioned in anticipation of becoming the world's best Italian sammie! Go for it!
author: Nichole N.

description: Average sandwiches at best. SF has awesome sandwiches and this place is way overrated (by tourists?). Absolutely nothing special here especially the bread. And if you have to request sandwiches to be toasted, you know you're in the wrong place.
author: KWANG L.

description:
This is a divey, (somewhat) dusty little deli that just happens to have awesome produce and sandwiches... it's a must if you're in the North Beach area! 

Think simple, quality ingredients, traditional Italian deli items and wine... perfect! Staff are really friendly (they love to flirt) and you're pretty much guaranteed the same high quality food every time you visit. 

I'm a fan of the olives, cheese and imported Italian beverages... and I know people who travel across town just to buy some of the meaty items. 

Buy take-away and sit in the park up the road or take a break on the outdoor seating on Columbus...
author: Guida B.

description: Tucked away in an obscure corner of San Francisco, Molinari Delicatessen is one of the last great meat shops.  Walking into the store, the smell of sausage and fresh bread greets your nose.  It will be crowded but it's worth the time to wait.  If you want a sandwich, feel free to select one from a bin filled with fresh bread then let the clerk know what you want in your sandwich.  While your soon-to-be-eaten sandwich is being built, feel free to look at the items on the shelves and the sausage hanging from the ceiling.  These guys make the best pepperoni sausage I've ever had and everytime I'm in the area, I try to bring some back to munch and share.  When your sandwich is done, in addition to the collage of delicious smells wafting from the wrapper, you'll notice the bread is significantly heavier before you had anything added.  Savor the first bite because it's the start of a vacation for your tastebuds!  If you have a hearty appetite, you'll be able to finish but don't expect to be able to eat anything immediately afterwards.  If you have a modest appetite, this will probably be lunch and dinner for you.  It's a great place to visit and dine.  Stop by if you get a chance!
author: Randall S.

description:
Felt like I walked into Italy. Great deli and market. Can have a Long line at lunch time so give yourself some time. They make your sandwich fresh from all kinds of Italian meats and cheeses. Salads and other  yummy deli choices to add to your sandwich or have on the side. They have a big selection of wines and sweets as well. 

We ordered several deli meats cheeses some bread and marinated artichokes and took it for a sack lunch in the park just one block up the street. Our kind of meal. Yum yum.
author: Karen D.

description:
Came in on Saturday April 26th, 2014 around 3 PM in the afternoon for a Prosciutto Sandwich which never disappoints.

As many have pointed out when first coming in stop at the counter and grab a number and then go grab your bread for the sandwich before being called. Once, your numbers called order what you like - I chose the Prosciutto Sandwich with everything on it besides mayo and add fresh mozzarella for $1 and then wait for your masterpiece.

The sandwhich was piled high with meat and cheese and was amazing like always. I got a 1lb of their famous Salami to 2 day mail to a out of town guest and it was about $17 overall. I'd recommend to everyone as this place is part of my sandwhich rotation with Tommy's Joynt, Lefty O'Douls, and Marina Subs.
author: Brian D.

description:
Came here last Monday, and really enjoyed it.  Needed a place to grab a late lunch after going up Coit Tower, and a sandwich sounded like just about the best thing ever.
Got there about 2pm and expected to find the place empty, but still waited about 15 minutes to be served, so I'd hate to see what it's like at lunchtime.  My friend and I split the Luciano special, which is a grilled sandwich on focaccia bread with prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, sundried tomatoes, sweet peppers, and some other things I don't remember.  We also got a small container of some pasta salad.  The salad was very rich (but good), and the sandwich was the star.  It was different from what I usually order (I'm typically a ham and cheese girl), but it was perfect.  They product their own cured meats so I wanted to try those, and I wasn't disappointed.  All the flavors melded together in a symphony of deliciousness.  
The sando was $11, so not cheap, but it was also big enough to share so that helps.  The fresh pastas and sausages looked great, and I would like to go back to try those sometime.  They also had lots of intriguing Italian cookies, crackers, and other foods that were begging to come home with us.  A great authentic Italian establishment!
author: Calee S.

description:
If you love a great sandwich...this is the place for you.

After reading many yelp reviews, i decided to visit Molinaris and see for myself.  I picked out my bread and then spent a few minutes deciding which sandwich i wanted to try. Whew...what a task! So many delicious choices to chose from! The South Beach had turkey, provolone, sun-dried tomatoes, artichoke, garlic and basil spread. 

 Not much room to eat so I took my sandwich home to enjoy. Take note, the sandwiches are large and could easily feed two people, depending on how much you can put away. I of course ate the whole thing because I couldn't stop myself.

Molinari's also offers many fresh meats, cheeses, homemade pastas, as well as a variety of freshly made deli salads and sides. try it you will not regret it.
author: andrew c.

description:
Yep. this is a damn fine sandwich place. I've know about this place forever, but I guess I've always got some other "destination" place in mind when I am in North Beach. Recently I saw some article about the top 10 sandwiches in SF, and the Renzo from here was on the list. (also the turkey sandwich from Arguello Supermarket - which I thought was horrible, so wasn't sure if the list was legit) but hey, even bad Italian sandwiches are usually pretty good.

Today we were taking a hike out in Ross, and if this gal is gonna hike 4-5 miles, you BETTER bring some good vittles, or she may opt to sit in the car and read a book.  But if a good sandwich is hiking 4 feet ahead of me, you bet I'll be hot on its heels.

We brought the Renzo to split (and some macaroni salad, though looking back I wish I had gotten the gigantic bean salad...next time). It wasn't cheap, 1 sandwich and a small mac salad was about $15.

But really this was a perfect sandwich for hiking, big enough to satisfy, not so big as to slow you down. I would like to go back and try the eggplant sandwich.  Next time I hope the hike is to a bar.
author: Amy W.

description:
One of San Francisco's oldest delicatessens, Molinari's is a beloved SF institution.  Established in 1896, is the oldest deli west of the Rockies!  The most important thing to know before visiting this deli for a sandwich, is that you must select your bread from the case before ordering your meal!  The staff here are knowledgable, friendly and masterful sandwich artisans who effortlessly build classic deli sandwiches with only the freshest Italian meats and cheeses.

FUN FACT:
Molinari Deli is so special that when Joe DiMaggio died, he specified in his will that the reception after his funeral be catered by Molinari's.
author: Matt S.

description:
There are some things in San Francisco that are unique.  Molinari Deli is one of those places. The signature Charcuterie is one of the best in the country and rivals that from Italy. The little Italian deli cranks out fantastic sandwiches, like the Renzo Special. Fresh ingredients, and quick service make this a classic. Get a soda and take your Food up to Columbus square to.eat or take it for later like we did.
Just do it!
author: John B.

description:
I understand there is somewhat of a cult following here at Molinari, more recently thanks to Anthony Bourdain.  However, I was less than impressed.. or at least my stomach and digestive system were.

When my coworker and I walked in here after seeing Prez O's motorcade pass through Chinatown, we were super excited because we'd heard so many great things.  We grabbed a number and were helped almost immediately because we beat out much of the lunch crowd (we arrived around 1:30 and there was a crowd around 1:45).

What you're supposed to do is choose a type of bread from this bread bin in the corner.  My first reaction was, "GERM BIN."  Sure, there were a pair of tongs in there, but who knows how people have been reaching in?  And to top it all off, a girl tried to walk in there with her dog (luckily the store employees told her to leave him outside).  Which means that.. you get the picture.

I ordered the Molinari Special ($6.75) which is basically a hefty salame sandwich with peppers, onions, cheese, mustard, and mayo.  Not knowing what was included, I just took everything but would've rather opted out of the mayo and gone light on the mustard.

It's one of those sandwiches that, with the hard bread (untoasted), was impossible to eat whole because the innards kept squishing out and pissing me off.  Nonetheless, I finished it, and a few hours later, threw up my guts.

I'm not sure if it was the germy bread bin that caused food poisoning (that sandwich was pretty much one of the only things I ate yesterday) or something in their meats, but it sure as hell didn't bode well for my Thursday night.  

In the future, I'll only be back for their fresh pastas, because at least I'll have to prepare and cook them myself.
author: Tori S.

description:
"Go get your bread."  

On a sunny San Francisco day, I decided to walk here and even ended up sweating.  Who knew the weather could be so nice in March?  There are a lot of older folk here, and a lot of Italians, so I'm glad we're no longer blatantly racist and that even I can partake in the joyous sandwiches they offer.  

I asked for the Renzo's Special ($8.75) and the first thing the man told me was "go get your bread."  Okay, I will take notes for my next visit.  I quickly turned around to the plastic case, opened it up, and grabbed the first appealing thing to me: Dutch Crunch!  

Renzo's Special consists of prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, pesto, and sun dried tomato.  It was such a simple sandwich but the quality of each item made all the difference.  Fresh fresh fresh.  Mozzarella wasn't rubbery, pesto was chunky and light, sun dried tomato wasn't acidic -- these are important!!  

If you don't need a sandwich, just come do your grocery shopping for your "Pasta Night" here.  I swear it will end up being 10x better than you had originally planned.
author: Shannon L.

description: Delicious sandwich and friendly service! We got the Turkey Pesto. I ordered online though, and when you walk in they want you to grab a number. Once your number is called they make your sandwich and the take it to the register to ring you up, so it's kind of hard/awkward to butt in during a busy time and be like "HEY, I ordered online, I shouldn't be grabbing a number!" cause they'll think you're just standing around waiting for your number to be called.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
When I was little, I would go to Sorrento, which was located in the Excelsior (it's closed now...sniff sniff), with my grandma. The guy who worked there was someone my grandparents had known for a long time and he would always give me a small sandwich made with mortadella and provolone. 

Now I might not be as cute as I was when I was 5 years old, so I'm not getting free sandwiches, but I still love deli sandwiches just the same. I've had a few sandwiches from Molinari's but today was the first time I had actually gone in and ordered one myself. It reminded me so much of Sorrento with salami hanging from the ceilings and the smell of fresh bread and cured meats.

The whole grab-your-ticket-and-loaf-of-bread situation reminded me a lot of The Soup Nazi from Seinfeld. If you don't grab a ticket, you won't be served and if you don't pick out your bread before they make your sandwich, you get yelled at...at least I'd imagine you would ;P 

I ordered a prosciutto and provolone sandwich with a little bit of mustard and mayo on a soft roll. The bread was soft, the prosciutto had so much flavor and the provolone was fresh. You really can't go wrong with anything that you order from Molinari's. They also offer tons of imported goods and they make homemade pasta like ravioli. They also carry panettone and pandoro during Christmas.

Whether you are coming in for a sandwich or grabbing some homemade pasta, you really can't go wrong with Molinari's!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Delicious and fresh sandwiches made on the spot!
I heard many good things about this sandwich spot and I knew I had to try it!

So how it works is you walk in and you MUST take a number. Then you choose what you want on the menu then choose the kind of bread you want in the box on front of the counter. 
The first time I went, I had a Molinari Sandwich with everything but mustard on it, YUM!
The second time I went, I had to wait about 30 minutes since we went during lunch time.. but I knew I needed to try the Turkey Sandwich with mozorella cheese and it was soooooo good!
Twice with no disappointments. I will definitely be coming here for lunches for often!
author: Linda K.

description: I can't believe this hasn't made my radar until now! Words can not describe the heavenly combinations, endless bottles of wine, homemade fresh bread, homemade Italian goodies, meats cheeses, pastas, homemade salami's displayed for you to drool over. This is the beginning of a beautiful relationship!
author: Brandy R.

description: Updated. We returned a few weeks ago and for newbies, which took us looks five trips to understand: Walk in. Take a number. Weave through the throngs to a bin of breads, and pick a favorite. Pick a sandwich from the menu. Shop while you wait. When your number is called, hand over the bread and order. Prepare yourself for the amazing food. Help tourists find the bread bin. Pay for food. Enjoy!
author: Amy R.

description: I have been several times and each time this place is great. Great food, Great people, and the prices are reasonable. Go early and make sure you make the best choice on your sandwich the choices are many and the combinations are vast. The good thing is that you cant go wrong with any of them. Some of the fun is watching the newbies navigate the Number grabbing and bread selecting process. Hands down the best deli in North Beach.
author: Manny G.

description:
I don't know much about Italian delicatessens, but I know this place makes a "mean" meat sandwich for $9-$12 and makes you feel like you just transported out of SF and into a deli in Italia!! 

Only been once so far and tried the RENZO (seems as this is a popular first-timer choice).  I only managed to eat half because it was so - meatilicious, but rather heavy. Happily ate the second half for a late afternoon snack.

Go in, take a number, get your preferred bread, then figure out what you want - many speciality sambos.

Also, lots of wine, olive oil, meats, snacks, etc to shop from while you wait.
author: Melody T.

description: Sandwiches are made to order. You grab a ticket number and pick your sandwich bread. When they call your number, hand them the bread and let them know which sandwich you are ordering. They have a few guys making the sandwiches so the line moves smoothly. I did think the line took a bit longer than expected though. Sandwich was good but a bit oily.. I think the pesto was starting to drip out while eating. Will be back to try other sandwiches. Definitely a fun spot in north beach! They have about 4 tables outside the deli market for you to sit & eat.
author: Lily M.

description: We stopped in here to check out everything; from the olives to the sandwiches, meats, homemade ravioli etc., we vow to return & try everything.  Keep up the good work guys.
author: Brian S.

description: We go here every time we go into North Beach. Get your bread before getting into line to order a sandwich. Wonderful sandwiches. It is a neighborhood favorite. They have delicious sausages and cheeses to purchase. Love this place.
author: Dee J.

description: My sister and her boyfriend took me to molanari's today for my first time. I ordered the luciano special. It might have been the best sandwich I've ever had. There was plenty of meat in it and the flavor was awesome. I can't wait to try some of their other sandwiches.
author: Bryan C.

description:
Plus one for being real, being part of the history, a beautifully rustic space, and having their own rituals like the customers have to pick out a roll out of a bin and bring it to the counter for them to make a sandwich.

Food wise it's only medium. Their own meats are great, they're for sale all over town including Safeway, Whole Foods, and Trader Joe's, and it's great to come to the source. If you order a sandwich here you get a healthy heap of their meat, and some other nice stuff like sundried tomatoes, fresh mozzarella, basil pesto spread, etc.

The only two minuses, and these are big ones if you're going out of your way for a deli. First, the sandwiches themselves are nothing special in terms of conception, flavor, construction. They don't have any patent on great sandwiches, they just pile on some good ingredients. Second, beyond the sandwiches there's almost nothing to buy here, not too many salads, sides, accompaniments, or surprises. You just come in and you order a sandwich. To be fair there are a lot of Italian pantry items like chestnut flour and olives, just nothing you would want for a picnic.
author: Gil S.

description:
My friends and I came to Molinari's for some good old fashioned sandwiches.  They have a variety of meats and cheeses to choose from, while also offering some side dishes.  The interesting thing about this place is that you literally choose your own bread.  You go to the box with all the bread rolls, pick the one you want, and hand it to the guy to make your sandwich.  The South Beach and Molinari's sandwiches were good and hearty, but we all agreed that the bread itself was stiff and a little stale.

Service was quick and efficient.  Don't be intimidated by the line, the wait goes by quick.
author: Gina J.

description:
I wish they didnt keep the selection of bread out for anyone in the store to touch.  Its kinda gross.  That being said I always ask to have it finished on the panini press so I'll have the peace of mind of a "clean" sandwich. 

Plenty of selections to choose from but I went with the following

Basic roll
mortadella, pastrami, swiss. pepperoncini, lettuce, mayo, mustard.

The sandwich was pricey and I have to assume it was because I asked for mortadella but they barely put any in there.  I think it was probably 2 slices of that lovely mortadella and the rest was pastrami (see pic).  The pastrami was ok.  I love pastrami and I thought it could use a bit more umph!

Swiss cheese was solid. 

I'll try out their signature selections next time but this visit was not worth it at all.
author: Sun T.

description:
What an authentic little deli! From the moment you walk in (you should grab a ticket with a number!) you feel transported to a little Italian deli. The older gentleman behind the counter seems like he could have worked at the deli all his life. And this is a place that doesn't take kindly to tourists who don't know what the heck they're doing. So if you're unsure, ask someone around you and be sure to read all the signs! Here are a few tips:

1) Take a ticket.
2) While holding your ticket, pick out your bread from the box directly in front of the deli counter. Oh, and be courteous, use the tongs!
3) Select what you want. If it's not a special sandwich, then decide what cheese, and if you want 'everything' on it.
4) When your number is called, tell them what you want and hand them your bread choice. 
5) Then you wait for your unbelievably delicious sandwich to be made.
6) ENJOY

I got the pastrami with Swiss and everything, warm. It was phenomenal.

PS: from watching the interactions of the other customers while waiting, if you want great service treat them with respect and know that a good sandwich during the lunch rush will take time. If you do this, you won't be disappointed!
author: Emily S.

description:
Absolutely fantastic sandwiches. Yes they are crazy busy, but you know what the secret is? Go on the weekend when they first open then it's just a couple of us crazy early risers. DAMN! I just gave away my secret. Well, what can I say, I'm too nice.

Their sandwiches are great and of course you have to go for the classic Italian Combo with their fantastic Italian meats. One is definitely big enough to share, but you just might not want to.

As others have mentioned the rules of the store:
1) Grab a number
2) Grab your bread - from the bins in the back on the left
3) Know your sandwich and be ready to order it
4) Grab it and enjoy! You will not be disappointed

So, go, try it out, maybe I'll see you there one weekend morning!
author: Ben B.

description: Quality ingredients all around, shared a pressed Luciana gourmet sandwich, and wanted to buy literally everything in the cute compact market. Perfect place to stop in and pick up your picnic goodies and hit Washington Sq park.
author: Angela L.

description:
Decent enough, but others make better sandwiches now. The pepperoni is a disappointment. Still, the quality is there. 

In fact, almost the entire North Beach seems to be declining severely. I love the area, and it hurts to see this happening.
author: George T.

description:
Five stars from me! If you've got a little bit of extra time to wait in line on a Saturday (they close at 6 pm on weekdays), Molinari is a little slice of heaven.

Each time I go in, I seem to discover more delicious Italian treats! Of course, they're famous for their gourmet sandwiches (mmmm....), but they have a ton of freshly made ingredients and pastas as well.

On my most recent trip, the boyfriend and I picked up a sandwich (South Beach Special with turkey, artichoke hearts, and garlic basil spread) to share, plus a handful of ingredients to make pizza at home (dough, Calabrese hot Italian sausage, roasted red peppers) plus salami for snacking. 

My eyes also wandered to the: homemade ravioli, pasta sauce, and great selection of imported cheeses. Like I said, it's super crowded on Saturdays, so prepare to wait, but definitely take the risk and squeeze your way in between some tourists to get a closer look at all the deli case goodness.
author: Laura H.

description:
Steps to the perfect Molinari Deli experience 

1 - grab a number 

2 - grab your bread from the case ( Rosemary Roll ) 

3 - order your sandwich & hand over your bread ( Joe's Special ) 

4 - run to the nearest spot to unwrap your sandwich & dig in! 

This was an 8 napkin sandwich.....I knew I was in trouble when I saw the guy pouring almost an entire gallon of olive oil into the sundried tomatoes container BEFORE putting them on my sandwich 

Not to mention the marinated red peppers (pimentos, if you will), marinated fresh mozzarella, AND pesto (also all drenched in oil) that make up Joe's Special 

You'll be thankful for the huge, honkin roll you selected to soak up that Italian goodness.....but be sure to eat this over your plate, sandwich wrapper or whatever - b/c it's like wringing out a mop (lots of oily dribbles) at each bite 

Keeping it simple w/ fresh ingredients & hearty Italian goodness, this is a spot you gotta try.....and get your weekly allotment of oil, all in 1 shot
author: Adrienne G.

description: . THE WORST MEATBALLS EVER.  I had better meatballs in my army field rations . I gave them to a homeless guy. He thought they were horrible.
author: Stash P.

description:
I love this place. I stumble upon it after a sunny afternoon, strolling down the bustling street of Chinatown and across sits the Italian Deli on the busy side of little Italy. I always want to visit Italy but unfortunately only seen the beauty through T.V this place seems as authentic as can be. I spoke to the owner a few times and he barely knows English and yet we had a nice conversation. 

I came here a few times to get the the Molinari Special which he recommended. I had the soft bread and it was loaded with a lot of meat. 7 or 8 different slices of cold cuts, mayo etc. The sandwich was pretty big and you can actually finish it in one sitting. I did. Also bought creamy cheese and their bottled orange soda. They have things and can goods imported from Italy. I assume they have imported a lot of yummies from their homeland.

I wish they weren't located on the corner which has a slight hill and gets pretty windy outside. Makes it difficult to enjoy a meal when constantly trying to chase down your napkin and moving hair out of the face. Esp when the table is tilting back and forth. It'll also be more feasible if there's space to sit and eat indoors, that way there's no feeling of rushing a delicious meal just to leave.
author: Joanne L.

description: Great location for a lunch stop.  Service was friendly and the high number if locals was a great sign.  We ordered the combo and sausage sandwiches.  Loved it and will go back before leaving San Francisco!  No indoor seating so be prepared to sit outside or take it to go.
author: Charles O.

description: It's a good Italian deli but seems more like a place to go because it's a landmark.  The premium Italian cold cuts are really good,  no doubt about it. The bread leaves a bit to be desired unless you happen to literally get a fresh batch. The wait is nuts at lunch... Even on a Saturday afternoon, I waited 30 minutes from door to sandwich.  There are numerous places equal or considerably better in New York City.  But this is San Francisco. I would come back if seeking a good deli sandwich but would not go out of my way. I am being somewhat generous with four stars.  But the staff is friendly and they also have great sides.  For sandwiches,  the North Beach Special and Sausage Sandwich are great.
author: Rick C.

description:
Molinari, the ultimate San Francisco Deli has been around for since 1896. This place is also one of my touchstones when I return to the neighbourhood, as the surroundings have changed significantly over the years.

Walking into this North Beach landmark is half the fun, as it's stuffed to the rafters with imported meats, cheeses, wines, canned goods, and Italian attitude. You can also get "high" (and disoriented) on the energy of this place and the smells. The sandwiches are excellent (Go get your bread!) and if there's space, limited outdoor seating is available. The ravioli (with sauces) are also a good thing to bring home for dinner. The only thing missing is a container of Pedroni's potato salad.
author: Eric B.

description: Upon entering, make sure to grab a number, and then choose your bread for your sandwich in the bread box.  I'm Asian so I always like to dig for the biggest piece with the tongs.  I've been here a few times, and it has always been a decent sandwich places.  I was always satisfied with their sandwiches, but have never been impressed.  The guy who was making my sandwich was super generous and gave me 2 inches of sliced prosciutto!  Thank you :)
author: Lynn L.

description: Outstanding salami! Definitely must stop by and buy some authentic Italian meat!
author: Joseph M.

description: What do I think of this place? I love it! That's what I think of this place. Total San Francisco place! Great deli In the middle or the hustle and bustle of San Fran! Go into the deli and grab a sandwich. Grab a seat out side and enjoy! But before you leave you MUST pick up a salami or two! I do every time I am in San Fran. I am enjoying a few thin slices as I write this. GREAT!
author: Steve W.

description:
Arrived with my family on a weekday, before noon. After some browsing, I asked the older gentleman working there if they carried semolina Italian bread. I explained that we recently moved from the Northeast, and that we were having a hard time finding it. 
"You mean semolina flour." His reply wasn't a clarifying question, it was a correction.
 "No sir, I mean semolina bread. Do you know where I can find some, maybe?"     
"No, try up the block." 
They weren't busy. Yet, the man behaved as if I was wasting his time. After our brief exchange, he turned around to organize a display. 
I've been in the restaurant/food business my entire life, and coming across this attitude still baffles me. Be a helper, be passionate about food (especially in a specialty store). I'm not upset that we were unable to find what we were searching for. I'm simply disappointed with how we were treated.
Thanks for nothing, pal.
author: Frank B.

description:
I love, love, love this little deli!!!!

Super authentic, reasonably priced and delicious!!!!!!

GO, just Go and get the prosciutto cotto sandwich!!!!!!!
author: Jackie S.

description: Apparently this is an Anthony Bourdain spot. Walking in is like walking into Italian-ville. Everything from pasta to candy to coffee to cheese. If you want a sandwich they ask that you pick your own bread from the bread bin on the side. Hand it over and the guys work their magic to make you the best sandwich possible. Definitely different from the Italian sub from Geppeto Deli down the street. But it was good. Huge selection of salads, pastas and deli items. Best part about sandwiches is that you'll never get the same sandwich. Each place has its own variation. A definite to-try if you are ever wanting a really good sandwich.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
If you're in North Beach, want good food, and don't feel like spending extra bucks or joining the tourist constellation to get it, then come here. I was pleasantly surprised by the authenticity and quality of my meal here.

Pick a number, decide what you want, & (assuming you choose a sandwich) select which roll you want it built on (fish for one in the plastic bin!). Yes, you will wait--roll in hand! I ordered: Joe's Special: mozzarella, dried tomatoes, basil garlic, and sweet bell peppers (I requested these on the side). My additions: mild coppa & a drink. All for $10! 

In addition to a reasonably priced lunch, there is a great selection of cured meat, cheese, olive oil, & wine. Very limited seating. There is a park nearby, but best beware of hungry, zealous pigeons.
author: Briana F.

description: This place is amazing! Amazing sandwiches, meats, cheese, odds and ends, life! My family is from the boot and this makes me feel like I have a small connection with them.  I also maybe secretly feel like there's some Soprano naughtiness going on through there. The staff is friendly but the food is what keeps this legend alive!
author: K H.

description:
I just ate an entire South Beach Special from Molinari's in approximately 10 minutes. I don't know whether to blame how delicious it was or whether to blame myself for waiting until 2:30 to have lunch. Maybe both.

I may feel a little sick from eating too much, but damn their sandwiches never fail to impress. All sandwiches are made using your choice of roll. They mean this very literally - you actually go pick out the roll and give it to them. The South Beach Special ($9.25) is then slathered with a garlic spread and packed with turkey, provolone, artichoke hearts, sun dried tomatoes. Just the right balance of sweet from the tomatoes and sour from the artichokes. Yum. 

They also sell an array of pastas, cheeses, wines, snacks, salamis, and more. This place is a one stop shop of deliciousness.
author: Talia G.

description:
1.  Get a huge jones on for a great Italian sub
2.  Mosey on over to Columbus Ave. near Kearny; find Molinari on the corner
3.  Take a number as soon as you walk in
4.  Pick your bread from the bin and order the Molinari Special
5. Grab a small Pellegrino from the fridge in the back
6. Take your sandwich outside and grab one of the random tables and chairs
7. Sit, eat and enjoy.  The best Italian sub with the freshest meats, cheese and bread
8.  Heavenly.  Jones satisfied.
author: David P.

description:
If you want a TRUE Italian deli then this is it. Italian wine, cheeses, Salami, great rolls and of course delicious sandwiches. Be prepared to wait in line like all great delis.
We had the Molinari combo and the North beach special. I would never ask for 
sun dried tomatoes in my sandwich but it was awesome! The prosciutto was fabulous. Any of the specials are really good. Get a little of everything and go have a picnic.
author: Joshua B.

description:
So some friends and family brought me here because they said I would love it - and it is a pretty cool deli, but here are the issues:

1. Location - unless you live downtown, it's a pain in the butt, parking sucks
2. Always busy - this place is jammed and you're going to wait awhile, and theres not a lot of standing room - lots of people. 
3. The bread for the sandwiches was too hard, it actually hurt to eat the sandwich.
4. There are only a couple of tables outside - good luck finding a place to sit down and eat your food. Either plan on taking it home, or go sit in the park if you want to walk down.

Besides the bread, the rest was good - but not good enough to deal with these things. There wasn't anything to me so special that I would drive into town for this place. 

If you live close, it's a great place to get a sammich and take home!
author: Tom C.

description: This was the most authentic Italian deli I have ever been to. Huge selection of meats, cheeses, olives, etc and their sandwiches are the best! We tried the South Beach turkey special with a basil spread, sun dried tomatoes, and artichokes and a simple turkey and provolone with veggies on wheat - something different and something more simple to enjoy the quality of meat, cheese, and bread. Service was quick (grab a number, grab your bread, and figure out what you want - be ready!). They also sell beer, wine, and all sorts of non alcoholic drinks for you to enjoy with your sandwich outside on one of their patio tables. Worth the wait when there's a long line!
author: Heather A.

description:
This is by far my favorite delicatessen and one that I am sure to visit during any trip to SF. Why do I like it so much? It's simple really. It is a deli that lives in the heart of North Beach and when I step foot inside the doors, I am immediately transported to Italy. The walls are lined with olive oils, spaghetti sauce and pastas. The other wall is lined with imported Italian wine and limoncello. Dried meat hangs from the rafters and fresh meat entices customers from inside the refrigerated glass cases. If that isn't enough, homemade pasta and raviolis tempts you from the back freezer. It's an Italian's dream deli and one that provides the most delicious quality of food. 

During my visits to SF, I take a stroll that starts in Union Square, travels through Chinatown and before I browse through North Beach, I stop by Molinari's for a fresh prosciutto, mozzarella and red pepper sandwich on a fresh sourdough roll. Before I leave, I purchase some fresh foccacia and pasta to take home with me. If I lived in SF, I would pay Molinari a visit on a weekly basis.
author: Lindsey D.

description:
Molinari's is the most wonderful little "Mom and Pop" Italian delicatessen. They have a nice selection of salumi, cheeses, pastas, and nonperishables like anchovies and tomato sauce, but what truly makes this place stand out is the quality of the ingredients used in their sandwiches. The fresh bread, hand sliced meats and cheeses, and specialty items like tangy artichoke hearts, feathery balls of mozzarella, and rich sundried tomatoes make the sandwiches extraordinary. That being said, the sandwiches are a bit pricey, but still priced comparably to other sandwich joints in the city.

My go-to order is the Luciano Special, which has parma prosciutto, sweet coppa, fresh mozzarella, sun dried tomatoes, onions, and lettuce, and is served on grilled focaccia bread. Treat yourself to one of these great sandwiches and enjoy it a few blocks down the street at Washington Square Park. Just make sure you don't try to do this on Sunday, as they are closed!
author: Brita B.

description:
the best italian deli i've ever been to!

i've never even heard of molinari...thank you, Anthony Bourdain, as he visited this little spot on his show, the layover.  i'm such a sucker for freshly sliced prosciutto, coppa, salame, and mozzarella balls.  

molinari can be found in the north beach district...arguably the cutest district in the city.  there are a few metal tables and chairs outside...try not to fall as the chairs do rest on a small hill.  as soon you as walk in...bam!  sticks of salame, cured meats, cheeses, misc italian items, a variety of salads, antipasto, and freshly made pasta. 

the first sandwich we tried was the molinari special...aka the italian combo.  every single sandwich is special.  grab a number!  pick your choice of bread from one of the bins...if you want focaccia, it's a little extra.  they call out your number...tell the guy what you want.  you'll see him start handling your sandwich with care.  he'll slice every single meat right in front of you...and they are NOT skimpy whatsoever.  the special came with 3 types of meat and all the fixings...i asked for fresh mozzarella for my cheese...just a little extra in cost.  grab a half pint of pasta salad...a san pellegrino (blood orange)...and you're ready to go.  the molinari special was wonderful...definitely too big to finish on my own so wifey and i shared.  awesome quality...you just can't get it better anywhere else!

the second sandwich we tried was the renzo...this one was the winner winner.  it came with a huge pile of freshly sliced prosciutto...sun dried tomatoes (with the oil spread out onto the bread)...and mozzarella.  my goodness...i could probably eat this everyday!  we also ordered a half pint of calamari salad.  very fresh...seasoned well...perfecto.  

the prices range around $8 per sandwich...well worth it for the quality and the amount of meat you're getting...

service is also super friendly...

i think molinari is going to be my treat for my upcoming days off...i'm getting antsy just thinking about it.  5 stars!!!
author: Jen W.

description:
Whilst in San Francisco, I made it a point that we had to try some of the places Anthony Bourdain had recommended. Luckily for us, we were staying at the edge of Chinatown and North Beach... and half of Bourdain's episode of The Layover was in Chinatown! One afternoon, we swung by Molinari Delicatessen to grab some sandwiches.

This shop is cool. A lot of cured meats and canned foods, but fresh cheeses as well. Everyone seemed to be regulars and knew to first pick up a number, then grab their own bread to get their sandwich assembled.

I got the Molinari special (~$10). It was so good and definitely some of the best Italian meats I've had. And it had everything you would want in a sandwich like this too -- mozzarella, lettuce, tomatoes, onion, mayo, mustard, and of course, a generous amount of meats.

Most importantly, the meats had a fresh taste to them (despite being cured...) and the sandwich was just really well put together.

Julian opted for the Joe special (~$10) which had mozzarella, dried tomatoes, bell peppers, and basil garlic. Good diversifying. This was really good too, since there was so much cheese, and the pesto-y flavours were good. However, I still liked my Molinari special more. Definitely one of the best cold cut sandwiches I've ever had!
author: Janice L.

description:
Don't know how I haven't written a review for this place yet... 

Absolutely the best deli in the city. Everything is fresh, they slice the meat when you order it and the vegetables are very high quality. Any sandwich with artichoke hearts or mozzarella cheese will taste like heaven in your mouth. 

Lunchtime is extremely crowded but if you call in a little early (just before noon) you can order sandwiches for pick up and take them to Washington Square park a few blocks away. If you call for pick up right in the middle of the lunch rush though they probably won't take your order cause it can get pretty crazy. However even when the line is really long I haven't had to wait more than 20 minutes. Make sure to pick up your sandwich roll from the plastic case before you order though!
author: Grace P.

description: Visiting the city, walking through town, actually... was looking for another restaurant when this little gem caught my nose! I grabbed a table, left husband to stand on line to order whatever! Because everything smelled AMAZING! While waiting at the table many, many people were caught by the nose! Lunch was served up: grilled sausage, peppers, onion, melted mozzarella and basil spread and a turkey, mozzarella, roasted tomato and peppers with basil spread, holy heavenly divine food for the gods!! The deli is as authentic as it gets, served up by men as lovely as the cheese, meats, olives, wine and bread! In all the years I've been to the city to explore I have to say l, this place is by far one that will go down for the books. My only regret is that I shared my sandwich! Go visit the boys at Molinari's, go and go hungry! Let the aromatic breeze lead the way and taste the divine for yourself. You'll be hard pressed to find another place to satisfy those pangs!
author: Teresa C.

description: Good lunch meat, but DO NOT order condiments on your sandwich. I asked for mustard, and my sandwich was soaked and dripping with it. I could barely taste the sopressata, which was a real shame.
author: Colleen M.

description: Excellent fresh sandwiches and friendly service. You will not leave hungry!
author: Steve C.

description: Authentic. Amazing. Delicious. Classic. Perfect. All the guys behind the counter were very friendly and helpful and I love how you literally pick your own bread. Felt almost like being back in Italy.
author: Wes A.

description:
This is a great place for the ultimate Italian sandwich. There was a great crew with personality behind the counter. A must go to place in San Francisco!Your review helps others learn about great local businesses.

Please don't review this business if you received a freebie for writing this review, or if you're connected in any way to the owner or employees.
author: Gary G.

description: Amazing & Delicious lunch!!  Fun experience.  This place is PACKED.  Plan about 30 minutes to have a chance to order at the counter.  We grabbed a number.  Waited through people to get our bread and then to order.  Was able to find a little table out front to sit at.  The proscuitto and mozzarella sandwich was the best sandwich I ever had in my life!
author: Jasmine C.

description: Came here on a food tour. It was one of our stops and I am sure glad it was. I went back to purchase a pound of perfectly sliced and flavored salami! Get a number as soon as you walk in, grab some bread and pick your sandwich! Great food, great service.
author: Jackie D.

description: Absolutely delicious sandwiches. The guys here have the best ingredients and are pumping them out all day. Interesting how they have you choose your own bread but it really makes for a great experience when you walk in and it's a little busy. Grab your ticket and peruse the shops a little. Check out the cheese and grab yourself a drink. Everything is good so just go for it.
author: Max G.

description: This place is so perfect Italiano.  As a sandwich person, this is as great it will get.  Mortadella!  When I saw the short line, I made a dash for it.  Customer service is a diversified staff.  Who would have thought someday you can be a Gringo and work there.  It's all good in NB.
author: BanBan B.

description: It pains me to give this place 3 stars because I've heard only unbelievable things and had been waiting so long to try it. So this review is based solely on what I ordered, the Renzo Special. For $12 this sandwich came with hardly any meat and way too much bread. It looked nothing like every other Yelp review of it, so I'm pretty confused as to what happened. My friend and i both ordered it and were pretty let down. Anyways it came with sundried tomatoes, prosciutto and mozzarella (but hardly any). I would maybe come back here and give a different sandwich another shot if I was in the area, but then again there are so many great delis in north beach so that's not too likely to happen.
author: Allison D.

description: Awesome sandwiches -- fresh bread and deli meats. There was a bit of a crowd when we went, but it took no more than 15 mins to get our sandwiches.  Great place to get a quick bite in North Beach.
author: Annie M.

description:
A solid Italian deli in the heart of North Beach, Molinari's has been around since the 1800's and it's even more famous than Lucca's. It certainly looks the part with their walls stacked ceiling high with Italian goodies. The sandwich ingredients are top notch. Just try their sun-dried tomatoes! I think it's the buttery olive oil they use that give it such amazing flavor.

Remember to get a ticket number and pick out a roll. I recommend the South Beach special or anything with those tomatoes.
author: Mimi X.

description:
AAA approved!

AMAZING DELICIOUS SANDWICHES!!
AWESOME SELECTION OF CHEESES AND MEATS!!
ATTENTIVE, FRIENDLY, EFFICIENT SERVICE!!

This deli rocks!! I love it! The sandwiches are HUGE and so delicious! My favorite is the Basil Turkey Special (turkey, mozzarella, AND sun dried tomatoes?! HELL YEAH). The walls are jammed with special Italian goodies and there are salamis and cheeses galore!

I love walking into this place and imagining that my kitchen will one day look like it, complete with the workers slicing the meats and preparing sandwiches to my heart's content.

It definitely gets busy in here, especially on the weekends, so always grab your number (when you enter, it's on the right) and if you're getting a sandwich, grab a roll of bread. The guys who work here are great! They treat every customer like an old friend! There's limited seating outside, but Washington Square Park is a short walk down, so if you want, relax in the park and indulge!

I have yet to buy their home-made pasta, but I will...very VERY soon!
author: Kei H.

description:
To get a sandwich:

1) Walk in, grab a number and grab choice of bread from the clear plastic containers.

2) Wait for your number to get called on, order your desired sandwich (and hand em your bread).

3) Pay.


I did not find anything spectacular about the sandwich. The spread was good, and there is plenty of meat as they weigh the meat (at least for sliced turkey) before making the sandwich. The bread was really dry but that's expected since it's just sitting there, chilling, in them plastic containers. I enjoy a juicy sandwich and the bread really ruined it.

And it's pricey. Sandwiches range from 9-12$.
author: R H.

description: They are  a great Italian Deli everything was fresh real good enjoyed my lunch today. The people were great great choice to get a sandwich
author: Nicey S.

description: The master of sandwiches! You pick your own bread and then they go to town with whatever you want on it. Hellllll yeah! They even have homemade pastas, a mini cheese and mean counter...mmmmmm. IT sucks that they are not open on Sundays, but they are so dang good I don't care. A must in the city!
author: M H.

description:
A local institution in the North Beach area of San Francisco. Molinari's is an outstanding delicatessen. The freshly made to order sandwiches are the best I have ever had. And when I say freshly made to order I mean it. 

You hand pick your freshly made bread and hand it to a specialist behind the counter to build your sandwich. In my case the Renzo Sandwich. They then take each ingredient from the deli case and slice everything from the meats, sun dried tomatoes and mozzarella there and then. Nothing on my sandwich was pre-sliced. On a nice day (like when I visited), we took our meal a few blocks north to Washington Square for an impromptu picnic. Which is a great way to enjoy any meal. I will alway have Molinari's on my must go to places when visiting San Francisco.
author: Mike M.

description: Most amazing sandwich I've ever had! Freshly cut rare roast beef, first place I stop everytime I come to SanFran!
author: Ashley T.

description: OG deli with an amazing selection of meats, cheeses, olives and fresh bread.  They also slice up your choice for a quick sammy and offer several refreshments stocked in a cold fridge.
author: Brooke M.

description:
i definitely liked my sandwich.  I just didn't think it was that amazing.  and boy was it expensive.

i got the renzo special which is prosciutto and coppa with fresh mozz and sun dried tomatoes on the roll of you choice.  the bread wasn't particularly fresh (being from New York, this makes a huge difference for me) and the amount of filling was not the right proportion to how thick the bread was. and at almost $10, this sandwich was not a great value.

I would come back to try just an italian deli style sandwich (just like turkey and veggies with the pesto I've heard so much about), but I wasn't so pleased with my first experience here.
author: Lisa C.

description:
If u get a chance GO HERE

Had the best turkey pesto sandwich ive ever had here, funny thing is i had the sandwich 6 months ago and im posting something now because im hungry for another....but im on the other side of the country :(
author: Srv A.

description: Grabbed some sandwiches here to take along on our tour of Alcatraz.  There was a line, but it moved fast.  You choose your bread and the sandwich you want, and they make it happen.  They were very helpful and kind about me being a novice with their sandwiches and their system.  The sandwiches were so good that we contemplated making a 2 hour trek later in the week to get some more!  Yes, it was that good.
author: Tim A.

description: New favorite deli! Glad we paid a visit while we were in the area today. I love how everyone is so chippy inside and so welcoming. I had the Renzo sandwich while my boyfriend has the Luciano. Both great sandwiches but I would definitely go back to grab a Luciano for myself the next time :P oh god, the prosciutto and coppa are the BEST!
author: Jingi A.

description: Hands down the best sandwich's I have had in a long time. The Renzo and the Italian combo was amazing. All of f the cured meats looked amazing.
author: John S.

description:
Oh my lord, this place is fantastic!! Be prepared for a wait because the deli  does get busy. I didn't mind standing around for a while because my attention was completely monopolized by the wide selection of meats and cheeses. I wanted to try a slice of everything. 

We shared two sandwiches, the Italian combo and the North Beach special. The Italian combo was a cornucopia of various sliced meats -- I think the guy put in coppa, mortadella, headcheese (at my request) and a few other nameless slices. The North Beach special (or was it the South Beach? I forgot) had sweet peppers, sun dried tomatoes, fresh mozzarella and prosciutto. Both sandwiches were fabulous, although we both agreed that we preferred the second one. 

They could easily charge 50% more for the sandwiches here and everything just screamed quality and freshness. On a nice day, heck, even if the weather was crummy like yesterday, order a few sandwiches at Molinari, get a bottle of wine at one of the many wine shops in the neighborhood and go to Washington Park for an impromptu picnic. I'm so happy that in a tourist death trap like North Beach, neighborhood delis like this still exist.
author: Alice W.

description:
Molinari is to San Francisco what Alicia's Market is to Oahu. It is the prize-jewel lunch & party food source for its local citizens. Like Alicia's, Molinari manages crowd control with the ticket-pull method. Molinari also has rows of savory delicacies sequestered behind shiny glass and a squad of men servicing the always bulky crowd. Waiting customers are mostly local working folk with a few well advised travelers. Service is quick and pleasant. 

Hubby understands there are two MUST GO SF locations for a happy wife: Yank Sing and Molinari's. He also knows he must risk a pat down at the airport because the dozen-plus dry salami sausages in his carry-on look like a mini atom bomb.

Ahhhhh, I love their salami. Yes it is available at R Fields. Yes there are other brands. But there is amazing pull to know our sausage is the freshest and best tasting available. Although awesome by itself, my favorite use of this savory Italian staple is in my pasta salad. (Fusilli, mozzarella, Parmesan, diced dry Molinari salami, diced carrots, celery, tart pickles - all topped with creamy Italian dressing). YUM.

Staff is efficient and pleasant. They look for opportunities to exchange a joke and laughter with their customers. Molinari has other goodies - various cured meats, cheeses, pickles, Italian groceries and pre-made salads. Conveniently located at the top of Russian Hill, you can swing by at the end of your traipse through China Town or North Beach.

Service - 5 stars
Amenities -5 stars
Food - 5 stars
Overall rating - 5 stars
author: Bonnie O.

description: Truly delicious sandwiches, and a very decent deli selection with quality items.  It feels on pace with an East Coast deli with aesthetics to match.  A trip to North Beach isn't complete without stopping by for a snack or a meal.
author: Jimbowicz J.

description:
Grab some bread, meat, cheese and wine and head over to Washington square park and enjoy the afternoon.

This is one of, if not the best, deli's in the city.  Great meats, killer sandwiches, real bread.  Good Italian wines.  All at decent prices.  The prices have gone up over the past few years, but so has everything else.

So follow the directions and be ready for a wonderful meal.

Now I can hear you asking why only 4 stars.  Well, parking in the area is a drag.  On weekends, get there early or be prepared to wait behind rude and clueless tourists.

Even with those drawbacks, still well worth going there often.
author: Jeff H.

description:
The absolute best in serving some of the best sandwiches made from great cheese and bread.  I adore the mortadella here......rich and moist, the meat is dotted with that conspicuous fat deposits.  Prosciutto is the best for a quick snack of baguette and swiss cheese.

For that reminders in the freezer, we left with several boxes of their raviolis. Frozen, we ate them for dinner the following two nights.
author: Miika M.

description: Wow, they have really good stuff.  The sandwiches are AMAZING and ENORMOUS.  They are definitely for sharing.  There isn't much seating, there are a few chairs outside.  On a nice day you can take your amazing sandwich and sit at the park.  The line is usually really long and you will have to wait, but it's because they take time with each customer......you'll appreciate it when it's your turn :o)
author: Sarah S.

description:
It may be a little odd to some folks to pick your own bread from the bread basket, but I have to admit - I loved it. The moment they told me to pick a bread from the box to make my sandwich I was a bit surprised and then I was like "Ah, yeah. I'm gonna pick me a winner!"

Truth be told, that's just empty words, really. As there's not any way to walk out of this place without being a winner. The food is so good and the selection of Italian deliciousiness is so ripe that you'll have no other option. 

The way to go is with the Molinari special with everything. Put your trust in their hands and believe me, they will make your taste buds soar like the tubed cured meat that is hanging in this shop

While it was the dude's first day on the job, he made my Molinari special like a champ. That sucker was seriously one of the best sandwiches I have eaten.

The joint also has a lot of goodies. Such as pates, imported wines and vast selection of goods you probably could only find in the mother land of Italy. From the meat hanging on the walls to the other side filled wines, it's just a massive taste of Italy that you can't forget. 

The servers there have a bit of a sass, but it's nothing worse than talking to someone from Jersey, youse know? 

I was looking for an Italian wine and wasn't finding it. Asked the workers and bam, they not only found it, they also suggested a couple of bottles like it. Now that's what I call service. 

But back to the sandwich for a moment. The thing was delicious. You really can't go wrong with it as they pile the meat and other fixings up to make it incredibly delicious. It doesn't move around all that much either, which is something of a pet peeve for when I have sandwiches. 

Structural integrity and proper foundation laying in your food is always essential. You'll not spend all that much money here and walk away stuffed with a little filling of culture. Get what I'm saying. 

No way you can go wrong and if you're visiting the S.F. area or live here and haven't had this in a couple of months, you need to get down and enjoy it as it's a staple of the North Beach area.
author: Javier J.

description: Worst sandwich ever!! I ordered a Molinar (cold cut Italian combo) sandwich and ended up throwing half of it out. The bread was this horrendous roll, it was drowning in mustard, and just tasted terrible. Total bummer! I've been craving a yummy Italian sandwich since moving from Philly. If you're from the east coast please don't bother coming here, you'll be appalled by what they're passing off as Italian deli sandwiches.
author: Ritu K.

description: I love these sorts of ethnic delis of which there are none where I am from.  I agree with the others the sandwiches are delicious.  My wife was having a craving for the ravioli while in SF and they told us theirs was served at Trattoria Contadina over on Mason a few blocks aways.  We went there for dinner and the ravioli was indeed superb.  Gonna have to get some shipped.
author: Roger Y.

description: While in Little Italy San Fransisco who doesn't want to walk the streets and venture to every corner? I stumbled upon this little old fashion Deli and Cheese place and it totally reminded me of the word "Tradition" This place was small but had a good variety of meats and cheeses to select from.  You would grab a number and when your number came up your can place your order.  You can even get a fresh sandwich made on the spot.  You pick the bread and they will make your sandwich.  I had to take away some stars because although pretty neat to see something traditional is lasting there was roaches crawling around that made me nervous.  I decided to opt out of the meat and cheeses and just purchased a bottle of oil and vinegar.
author: Connie G.

description: Good ole fashion Italian deli. Pick a number when you enter and wait for your turn. Pick your own bread loaf before you order. Great sandwiches prepared fresh and made to order. Try the frozen lasagna and sauces!
author: Paul S.

description: I must have tried this on a really, really off day. Fourth of July weekend, mid-afternoon and the place was empty. Store looked a little TIRED. Had the Molinari special sandwich and the North Beach. Felt like an idiot because I did not know that I was supposed to pick up my own bread roll from the other side of the store. DUH !!! Sandwiches were FINE but no big deal. GOOD, DECENT but not great. Not sure what all the fuss is about. There are so many places to try in SF that I don't think I'll go back. BOO.
author: Lauren C.

description: SO wonderful, we placed our order online right when they opened- I dropped in 15minutes later- and it was ready- We took our Italian sandwiches to Alcatraz- and raised them to toast Al Capone. Oh and all the sandwiches were delcious!
author: Sherelle S.

description: Get it early because this place is crazy,great sandwich,take so long to get u number but that deserve because is really great,small place classic
author: Juan M.

description: The south beach sandwich was excellent. Turkey, sun dried tomatoes and artichokes with pesto is such a great combo! Top off the sandwich with the potato salad and a peroni beer! A few outside tables (4-5) and chairs and great people watching.
author: Kimmie B.

description: Good sandwiches, need to hire more staff or be informative to tourists, feel so bad when they ass up new customers they do not know to take a number & to pull their own bread. Put the bread behind the counter guys, so many damn germs. It wouldn't kill you to move a little faster either, I'm a local lets get better servic
author: Stan L.

description: Grand slam!  Hat trick!  Call it what you want.  This place is 'da bomb'.   I'd give it 6 stars if I could.  Came up from San Jose with my hiking group to trek the Barbary Coast Trail (also highly recommended) over Labor Day weekend.    The day before, had everyone individually order sandwiches (37 total) from Molinari Deli via their Yelp Group Order app.   (Also, talked with 'Vinnie' (aka Vincent) to make certain all was in order and understood).   Anyway, when we showed up the next day, all 37 sandwiches & accessories were neatly packaged, labeled (with your name) and ready-to-go.  Absolutely delicious.  Everyone thoroughly enjoyed.  And not a single error.  Abondanza!
author: Ed K.

description:
I have to thank fellow Yelpers who guided us to this amazing place! I also have to thank fellow Yelpers for teaching us the tricks & keys of how to order & what to do when you get here so we wouldn't seem so "lost". I will pass on this advise to others to make your experience easier as well.

Came here on a Saturday. I've read so many reviews that this place can get busy. Came here a little bit before lunch (noon) I was expecting to see a crowd, but luckily as we approached I didn't see a line out the door, good sign. Walked inside and it wasn't so bad. There were about 5 groups/couple of people ahead of us.

You walk in and it's just a mish mosh of everything everywhere! Stuff on the wall, stuff hanging, pictures, & just a lot of stuff on shelves & everywhere that makes it feel like a little neighborhood deli that more than likely carries everything & anything you're looking for. The deli cases & counter are the main focal point of course. If you glance up stairs you can see what may have been a seating area at one point way back when, but now you can see the wooden beams upstairs have been turned into wine racks with dozens of wine bottles.

You walk in & the first thing you need to do is grab a number. Second thing you do is make your way towards the back where you'll find the bread bin & grab a piece of bread. Now you just look over the menu & figure out what delicious sandwich you want them to create for you. There are plenty of signs & descriptions to help you in your decision process. Especially on what you want IN your sandwich... Be sure to read the board that tells you everything they offer & what "everything" can mean.

I had the Renzo's Special: Prosciutto, FRESH mozzarella, pesto & sun dried tomatoes. The first thing I noticed is the Prosciutto that the man behind the counter pulled from the deli case. I've seen prosciutto in many different places and they're mostly round. The prosciutto he pulled out looked like the whole leg. Not just the "rounds" that you usually see in the stores. He cut my Prosciutto from the more square part of the leg, big, fat & juicy. First PLUS! Then he pulled two fresh mozzarella balls out of their deli and sliced them right in front of me on the counter. Talk about fresh! They have chips & drinks in a freezer case if you want to complete your meal. All in all the sandwich was a great portion and DELICIOUS!

We got there at just the right time, because after we placed our order and got one of the 3 tables/chairs that were outside, more people started to come in. There came a point where they got pretty busy that people outside walking up turned around because they didn't want to deal with the crowd. Too bad for them. I could even hear a few people say that they've wanted to come here, but didn't want to deal with the crowd. Believe me people, it's worth the wait! Patients rewards here!

If you find yourself around the Ferry Building area, Molinari's is just blocks away. It's a great scenic walk. You pass the TransAmerica Pyramid plus see a little bit of Little Italy & a glimpse of Chinatown down a couple streets.

'Til the next food find...

Eat it... Love it?... YELP IT!!!
author: Joel R.

description:
Molinari is a North Beach institution. It's an authentic Italian deli that takes you back to the old days or at least what I imagine them to be like.
