Come for lunch. You first take a number and then pick up your own loaf of bread from a bin. Once your number is called, you give the bread over and tell them what sandwich you want. I got the salami sandwich which was packed with meat and had a decent portion of veggies -- all for $6.75. It's a really good deal. You can add amazingly fresh mozzarella for only $1 more too.

The wait during the weekday lunch hour seems to only be about 5-10 minutes and is totally worth it.
author: Victor W.

description: You guys. You have to get the Luciano Special. This..sandwich...for lack of a holier word...would make vegetarians weep with pure green envy. My co-workers and I just happened to stumble upon this exquisite, authentically Italian deli during our lunch hour and now our lives and mouths are forever changed. GO!
author: Alli H.

description:
This is *THE* go to place in North Beach for all things Italian - a HUGE selection of pastas, olive oils, wine and specialty items, as well as a deli case full of meats, cheeses and salads. You can have a sandwich made or just get meats and cheeses to go. Prices are reasonable and the selection is tremendous. For such a relatively small shop, there's a lot to look at inside! 

Two cool things worth noting (sorry -- I'm a dorky tourist!): 1) they carry the cool large olive oil cans in many different brands. I collect these to decorate my kitchen, so we always go in and pick up one or two, and 2) they've got some OLD balsamic vinegar - I'm talking 100 years old!
author: Lisa D.

description:
The sandwiches in this place are fine, but nowhere near the cream of the crop in San Francisco, and certainly not worth dealing with the inattentive and perfunctory at best service from the sandwich making staff. 

I'll plan ahead and go to Ike's from now on.
author: Michael M.

description:
Sandwich heaven. We happened to be strolling up Grant just past Chinatown and began looking for a place to lunch. Seeing a crowded corner deli, we ventured in. The Molinari Special is one of the best things in a loaf. A bit weird, but you have to first grab a piece of bread to your liking and then order the type of sandwich/pannini you want. These folks are purists and don't rush anything. My wife and I were floored and were gald that we had stopped here. 
Get the sandwich and try to snag a chair on the scant side-walk space. You won't regret it. This is as good as it gets.
author: Arvind J.

description: The sandwiches were the best in the city make sure you make a good choice when choosing your bread, you have to choose your bread before you make the sandwich and bring it to the deli. I got stuck with one hard piece of bread other than that the sandwiches were damn good!
author: Peter T.

description:
Came back here on a Saturday at 3PM and it was packed! At least 15 people ahead of us, but that was ok. We perused the market for a bunch of items.

Like in my previous review, cheese selection is very slim. The only good one I found that we both thoroughly enjoy that we always get at other stores is the Paive Vecchio!! YUM. Everything else was a local cheddar or Parmesan Reggiano. Not something to pair with salame and wine :)

We ended up with two layers of the Prosciutto di Parma (one would have been enough), 3/4 lb of hot coppa with garlic and black pepper (yum! too much meat) and 1/4 lb of this salame infused with wine (which was just ok).

They also have head cheese here! eek! Never had it, but maybe one day if I'm adventerous enough to try it I know where to go.

Definitely walked out with a box each of their Chicken and Cheese only ravioli's. SO yummy! I forgot how good they taste and how soft and moist these little suckers are. I was definitely teased a little bit about how I had to get two boxes when everyone else made out with one, but I'm not in the city often to always grab some! :)  

Can't wait to come back and grab some more goodies next time!

Note: Don't forget to grab a number to be serviced!
author: Ling H.

description: The service was not that great. If you want an amazing Italian Combo go to Lucca's in the Marina. Hands down the best!
author: Blaine H.

description:
I should have brought a bigger backpack..... 

In coming here I was immediately jealous because we have nothing like this in Santa Cruz that can ever compare.  Lots of meats, wines, fresh pasta and sauce, sweets and panatone (drools).  Out of all this good stuff.. I ended up buying a vitamin water to share with my little brother while the other folks in our group got some pasta/sauce. LOL.  

I need to come back up here and get some real goods. RAVIOLI your days are numbered!!
author: Vicky T.

description:
Holy MEAT! Really that's all I can say about my sandwich. It was stuffed with turkey. 

Next time I go I think I'll order something else because there is only so much turkey I can handle. Salami and pepperoni-- now those I can handle. 


TIP- grab a BIG roll of bread= bigger sando
author: Cesie A.

description:
So I walked into Molinari's, took a number (#17) and stood beside a woman.
She said you know who's been here? 
I said who
She said Jay-Z
I said nuh uh
She said yuh huh
I said nuh uh
She said yuh huh
I said wow thats cool and threw up "the roc" (formed my hands into a triangle)
She just smiled and looked confused
I lowered my hands and kindly smiled back......................never mind
Then she said you know who else has been here 
I said who
She said Jesus, our Savior
I laughed and said wait you mean Anthony Bourdain?
She said who?
I said oh.

a
w
k
w
a
r
d


Then a voice from behind the counter yelled 17!  And I mumbled thankthelord 
Then she said see, he's here again.




o_O
help. .. 





Nervously, I ordered the chicken parmesan sandwich.  
I turned around and saw the woman leaving.
So I joked w/the guy at the counter, and said I'm having second thoughts.  What did Jesus order? har, har
He said, a meatball sub.  And winked.
A meatball sub it is, then.
And it was good. Really good. 
Dang.

Trust Jesus.





*pardon my blasphemous mouth
**you can trust whoever you want
***i don't know shit
****i'm just here for savasana
author: Rho T.

description:
These sandwiches are no joke delicious.  They're also large, so if you aren't super hungry it's not a bad idea to split one.  Most range from $10-12.

It's definitely a little intimidating walking in for the first time, not knowing how the system works.  You walk in, grab a number immediately, make your way through the crowd of people hanging in front of the deli counter to the "bread bin" (in the middle of the shop against the left wall) and grab your choice of bread.  Then you figure out what you want to order from the deli board and wait for them to call your number.  You then hand your bread to the gentleman that called your number, let him know what sandwich you want, and pay attention because he's going to ask you some follow up questions (with everything?  what kind of cheese?  who do you know here?  just kidding.) 

The Molinari Special is definitely the most popular, and it's delicious, but next time I'm excited to try one of the Gourmet Sandwiches.   Enjoy!
author: Riley D.

description:
YUMMM!!!!

I came here on my lunch break today and I thought that their would be a huge wait like some reviews had stated, but I probably waited about 10 minutes to give my order. But I did go past 1pm so the lunch rush might have past.

Like other reviewers stated, you must get your number first and wait to be called. Also you pick you bread out of a big wooden/plastic bin, or you can have focaccia which is on top of the deli case for an extra dollar.

I had the Renzo sandwich with pepperoncini. It had Proscuitto, Coppa, Fresh Mozzerella, and sun dried tomatoes on the most perfect roll. I love the butt of every bread (end piece) and I loved that I could choose it myself over the middle pieces hehe. The meats were perfectly chewy and salty, the cheese was creamy and soft, and the sun dried tomatoes were marinated to perfection.

I seriously want to eat here every meal of every day.
author: Angie S.

description:
Thank the lord I found my new sandwich spot! Good hearty Italian deli. You just can't go wrong. 

I like the north beach, but i swear everything is good here. Everything is fresh and salty and probably terrible for your health. Service wasn't too quick, but very sweet!
author: Mimi D.

description:
i hate to break it to you all, but this is NOT an italian deli...sure it has italian foods, and feel, but these "subs" are have NOTHING on a sub in ny/nj/philly.  It's in the bread folks and this bread is straight up crap.  the outside should have a crunch the inside should be soft, it shouldnt taste like your biting into foam as it does at this place

it's like saying sf has good pizza, if you actually think that, then you'll like this place.
author: christopher h.

description: Truly fabulous sandwiches.
author: Giacomo C.

description: Old School Italian Deli.  Everything is fantastic. Space just brings you back in time. Sandwiches and deli cuts are perfection.
author: Rudi R.

description: I stumbled upon this place when I first explored to North beach and now I myself am hooked along with all my friends! We love to buy a tub of the homemade sauce and a couple rolls and head over to the park and munch away!
author: Erica D.

description:
Being from the East Coast and having lived the last five years in an Italian Deli desert  known as Portland, I was overwhelmed by the authenticity at this place it really made me feel like I was back home.  Every choice Italian meat and cheese you could ask for (whether you could pronounce it or not) and not too bad of a line, we went right around noon and waited about 15 minutes which was the perfect amount of time to ogle all of the amazing items in the store.

Would recommend to any and everyone who want a little slice of Italy packed neatly between two pieces of Focaccia.
author: Noah T.

description: A true classic.  With an excellent assortment of delicious foods.  Love the Sandwiches.   And the atmosphere.
author: James H.

description:
Like many, I came her for the famous "Renzo Special."

The atmosphere is very no-nonsense, and you kind of have to rely on your fellow customer to figure exactly what is going on.

First things first...be sure to grab a number as soon as you walk in!

Secondly, if you're there for a sandwich, it is your responsibility to grab your own bread out of the bin.

Thirdly....I wish someone had told me this. While the Renzo was exceptional, I didn't hear this insider tip from Serious Eats until afterwards:  request the round, plate-sized foccacia. Then ask them to lightly toast it in a sandwich press "with a rub of flavor from the sun-dried tomatoes, it's crusty, oily, and well worth the extra dollar."

It was very good, but I feel like those minor details are what probably hits it out of the ballpark. Next time!
author: Katie S.

description:
We walked in on the recommendation of my niece.  Too bad we had already eaten but we had to try something!  This place is old-school like it's right out of a Francis Ford Coppola movie.  I kept looking around for that secret back room and was ready to hit the deck at the slightest suspicious activity.  Happily, it was a peaceful today.

They are known for their housemade salami and coppa and after a generous sampling of both, we walked out with some salami - it's really good.  My son loves mortadella - theirs is imported from Italy so took some of that too.
author: Eric Y.

description:
FANTASTIC sandwiches. Come early to get the really fresh bread. My favorite sandwiches are the Luciano and Renzo special sandwiches. Make sure to add their signature garlic/basil spread. Delish!

A few other tips:

1) Take a ticket.
2) While holding your ticket, pick out your bread from the box directly in front of the deli counter. Oh, and be courteous, use the tongs!
3) Select what you want. If it's not a special sandwich, then decide what cheese, and if you want 'everything' on it.
4) When your number is called, tell them what you want and hand them your bread choice. 
5) Then you wait for your unbelievably delicious sandwich to be made.
6) ENJOY
author: Beth L.

description:
Molinari's you have excellent sandwiches and Italian deli foods, I'll give you that.  But, sadly, you continue to embody that whole North Beach, Italian elitist vibe and lifestyle that I will never be accepted into and frankly shouldn't have to be accepted into just to get some frickin' decent service.

Typical imaginary conversation between me and them follows:

Me: Yes, I'd like to order an Italian combo sandwich, I think.
Them: Scegliere il pane che si desidera.  

Another customer in front of me: If you want to order a sandwich you have to pick your bread from the bin.

Me: Huh?  Oh, yeah, OK.  (Picking some sweet Italian bread roll and getting back in line).

Them: Cosa vuoi?
Me: Hmm?

Them: Che non parlano italiano?

Me: Huh?  Sorry, I don't understand.  I don't speak Italian.  I dated an Italian once, does that count?  Well, actually he was half-Italian.  But, he speaks fluently.  Maybe I should call him?

Them: Andare via.  
Me: Huh?

Them: Uscire.

Me: I'm sorry.  Can I just order an Italian combo sandwich with provolone cheese, light on the mustard?

Them (Looking past me, to the next customer in line): Next, who is next?...  (With a big smile) Can I help you , Sir?

Me (Putting the bread back into the bin): Addio.
author: Danielle O.

description: My twin sister saw this on the food channel in Tucson Arizona and wanted to go there to get a sandwich while visiting me.. We did and it was a good as good can get, excellent service, very nice people to help us and the best sandwich we've eaten by far.. They were very busy and in there you have to get a number but well worth the wait & money paid for them.... Although their a little far from me I will not hesitate to go back and plan on it... For this I give them a 5star review..
author: Yvonne L.

description: Delicious, fairly priced Italian sandwiches along with reasonable wines and cheeses.  What more could you ask for?
author: Josh Q.

description: Avoid around lunch time if you just want to buy something from their deli.
author: Bradley C.

description:
Molinari's has FANTASTIC sandwiches. For $10 (yes, a bit steep) you can get quality sandwiches. 

I got a Luciano special which was Pastrami with sun dried tomatoes (awesome) and the sandwich was HUGE. 

If I am looking for a great sandwich I'd definitely brave the 15 minute line for a sandwich.
author: Carlos A.

description:
One of my top 5 sandwiches of all time.

Great bread, very fresh ingredients, friendly staff.
author: Jack C.

description:
These people have no respect nor knowledge of sanitary rules. They grab the salami or whatever with NO glove NO tongs, they slam the slice  in your sandwich and then with the SAME hand they grab the money and on they go to the next one...
I am surprise that  the Health Dept. doesn't do anything about it. 
This is unacceptable.
author: Elisabetta A.

description:
really. damn. good. sandwiches.







..especially when you're hungover in bed and your boyfriend brings it to you ;]
author: Susy C.

description:
Molinari has arguably the best Italian sandwiches in North Beach. 

The system for ordering can be a little ambiguous your first time but here are the steps. 
1. Pull a ticket from the red dispenser 
2. Pick your bread. 
3. Decide on your sandwich be looking at the menu behind the counter 
4. Head to the counter with choice bread in hand when your number is called. 
5. Enjoy your sammie with a smile. 

My favorite here is the Italian sausage sammie with roasted peppers. The combination of juicy sausages, sweet peppers, and toasted crusty bread is perfect for an afternoon in the park. 

I wish I have more of my act together earlier on the weekend because I'm always out of luck when I crave their sandwiches on Sunday since they're closed then. But if you're in the neighborhood any other day, you should definitely stop by and get yourself a delicious Italian sandwich at Molinari's.
author: Jon L.

description: Unh. If only I had more time! We just visited Molinari briefly the other day, but man I wish I lived right myeh...it was exactly what I'd want in a delicatessen- their own salami made in house, crazy cases packed with cheeses, meats of all kinds (of which I probably would've bought armloads were I not about to board a plane!) and a wall of wine. Wasn't able to try any of their incredible-sounding sandwiches, a crime I wish I could rectify sooner, but did at least manage to snag one of their salamis, thank you. You know a place is legit if you get accosted to two flirtatious old Italian men at the register - all the Italian being spoken in the joint makes it plain that it's the real deal. And grazie mille for the compliments, gentlemen.
author: Erin F.

description: Looking for a delicious sandwich in the North Beach area? Molinari's got you covered. Their deli selection is fresh and delicious and their sandwiches are sooo filling. They also have a lot of Italian products that you really can't find anywhere. Their olive oil and pasta selection is really extensive and all of their products make great gifts!
author: Regina L.

description: My friend and I stumbled into Molinari in the morning, as we were walking down Columbus Ave.  We sampled a bunch of different meats and cold cuts.  They were each thinly sliced and delicious.  We even tried the head cheese.  I wasn't a big fan, but my friend was.  Everything tasted very fresh and very flavorful.  The people who work there were very helpful and friendly.  We had just eaten breakfast, but if I were more hungry I would have loved to have tried one of these sandwiches that everyone raves about.  This venue is quintessential San Francisco Little Italy and the ambiance takes you back to another bygone-days-butcher-shop era.  I also liked the rare selection of sodas and Italian delicacies they sell.  It was a beautiful sunny morning, so we sat outside and enjoyed our treats.  I can't wait to go back again.
author: Laurie V.

description:
Imagine that. An Italian deli located on Columbus. Finally something that makes sense in San Francisco - a city where the Palace of Fine Arts is home to a children's museum and the Presidio (a military base) is home to the Disney museum.

Here's my tourists guide for ordering a sandwich at Molinari:
1. Take a number.
2. Look at the menu board and pick a sandwich.
3. If the sandwich is not on foccaccia, grab a roll in the open wooden bin that is opposite the cash register.
4. If you want a drink, pick one out of the refrigerator case while you wait.
5. There are limited tables that are only outside and they don't have napkins. Consider eating the sandwich elsewhere and/or bring napkins.

The "Molinari Special" is a basic sub that is heavy on mustard and mayo which interfered with the meats. It's not hard to find a better sub and wouldn't have this one again. So if you're looking for a great Italian sub, this is not the place. But for a wonderful non-traditional sandwich, the "Luciano Special" on pressed focaccia bread with prosciutto, sweet coppa, dried tomatoes, and fresh mozzarella is worth a return visit. It's a great contrast of saltiness, meatiness, sweetness, and tanginess.

The deli case is better than most Italian shops because it has all varieties of Molinari salame and coppas. I like the Molinari style where it's not t too peppercorn hot, but has plenty of fatty meatiness. The rest of the deli is small and the selection is small. The cheese selection is more unique than most Italian delis, but below cheese stores or markets with large cheese cases like Whole Foods.
author: Brian U.

description: My sandwich was insanely good. It took a while during the lunch rush, but it was totally worth the wait. Everyone that works there is super friendly, and the store has an amazing selection. It really feels like a touch of the past.
author: Captain B.

description: Wow.  All I can say about this place is Wow.  This is like any other awesome Italian Deli, other than everyone who is waiting for their number to be called is holding a bread roll, because you need to pick your type of roll from a plastic bin, prior to making your sandwich order.  The place is great.  Cured meats hanging from the ceiling for sale.  More cured meats are displayed behind the glass cooler below.  I got the Renzo Special.  Spicy coppa, salty prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, sun dried tomatoes, I chose the Dutch crunch bread roll and was so good.  If I wasn't driving I would have added sweet peppers, mayo, and mustard.  The quality of the meat was impeccable.  When I go back I will definitely try something else because everything looks so good.  I'll probably buy some salami that is hanging from the ceiling too.
author: Jeremy E.

description:
Until something drastic happens, like I dunno, maybe another earthquake and fire... a trip to SF isn't complete without a trip up to Molinari Delicatessen. 

This time we ordered the Luciano, AND the Molinari Specials.. yeah I guess waiting a whole year for this trip kinda made us a little hungrier. You know, usually ONE sandwich, chips and a couple beers would do the trick, but uh-uh not this time... this time we get two and we'll share both..... yeah good thinking. And for good measure, and to stay in our families good graces, we also grabbed four salami for the trip home!

  Got our sammies, took a nice leisurely walk down the hill to Fisherman's Wharf, grabbed a table in the lobby of the Sheraton (home for now) grabbed some chips and two beers and proceeded to purposely make everyone there JEALOUS!!! I didn't notice anything else for a moment or two, I was lost in Italian meat and cheese heaven. 
  
Hopefully we can continue visiting San Francisco, try different gastronomic venues, while still enjoying places we like most.... like Molinari.

 Small side note, my first review about this gem on Telegraph Hill is where I got my very first YELP friend, Kira W. Maybe someday, when we're visiting here again, we'll be buying sandwiches, and salami and get lucky enough to bump into her.
author: Joe K.

description:
Sublime salami, which is what they are famous for, but you have to love a place where you pick out your bread from a bin and then give it to the guys behind the counter to assembly your order.

This is an old school deli. Their meat and cheese selection is awesome, though not huge and daunting like some other deli/markets. Again, get there early, pre-12:00 b/c the line will be out the door by then, especially on weekends.

I ordered the Molinari Special which is a combo of incredible meats and sharp provolone and some mustard with minimally hot peppers; perfect heat for the sandwich but keep in mind if you order and hot peppers aren't something you want.

Also remember to take a # when you walk in the door; some tourists ahead of me did not and when the guys behind the counter started calling #'s, they went back to grab one (which was fine by me, b/c I got served before they did!).
author: Jason S.

description: Lots of meat, which is huge to me. It's the oldest Italian deli. That's pretty amazing. Not my favorite bread, but still a good sandwich and great experience.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Walking into this amazing deli instantly took me back to my days in Italy. The sight of their various fresh meats, cheeses, and other Italian goods made me hungry. I heard about their sandwiches and instantly went to grab a ticket number. Now folks, I'm sure you read from other reviews but how it works is:

1. Grab a ticket number 
2. Grab a piece of bread in the bread buckets (unless you are getting a focaccia sandwich)
3. Wait for your number (they will skip you if you aren't there)
4. Order either one of their listed sandwiches or you can customize one

My boyfriend and I had their focaccia with prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, and pickled peppers. DELICIOUS....

Note: expect long lines and a bit of a wait but it's worth it
author: Tif L.

description:
Italian deli with meats, cheeses, wines, and sandwiches. Came for the sandwiches. Got the Sausage Sandwich. Everything was fresh and tasty. Most of the workers are friendly but some can be more aloof. The Italian owner is a great guy and got jokes. 

How to:
1. Get a number right when you enter the store
2. If ordering a sandwich, pick bread from bin (or know which specialty one you want)
3. Wait for your number to be called and have order ready
4. Pay at register

Theres some seats outside. Nice little shop. Sandwiches are about $8-10.
author: Arthur C.

description: Tasty and authentic Italian deli sandwiches- go for what sounds good. All options are great. Make sure to pull a number from the red ticket dispenser and grab some bread for yo sammich. Don't forget the Pellegrino! Hit the Washington Square park benches for a comfy and quaint lunch getaway too.
author: S Z.

description: Great Sandwich! Try the Calamari Salad and their dry hanging HOT salami! Everything is super fresh. As close to Italian as you can get in SF!
author: Roman J.

description:
Yummy sandwiches! Straight to the point. Fresh deli meat--- no other way. Bread could have been better though. 
** You guys should offer whole wheat!
author: Lee R.

description: Eating sandwiches from here makes my pants tighter, in more ways than one. Closest thing to a Publix sandwich in San Francisco.
author: Sam S.

description:
This is one of my favorite hidden gems of North Beach:
-Fresh pasta (grab a block of aged parm...yum)
-Renzo special (can't really go wrong with any sandwich; you pick your own bread from a bin too)
-Excellent salami
author: Brian L.

description:
Stopped here for lunch and had the Molinari Special. Different types of meats and cheeses definitely made it tasty, but there was WAY too much mayo for my liking. Next time I will order a different sandwich or specifically ask for less. I do look forward to trying other things from this place though. 
We also bought these little snack things that were little pieces of mozzarella wrapped in prosciutto. Sooooooooooo good. I wished we would have bought a life time supply.
author: Roxanne R.

description:
I was really looking forward to this place. I had seen it on travel channel and bookmarked it. We walked by it while in the city and I had to stop. I wasn't super hungry so I asked my boyfriend to split the Italian sub with me. The grumpy old man behind the counter mumbled something about grabbing bread and we went over and picked our bread, it was Saturday afternoon and there was not a lot of options left. We handed it over and asked for an Italian with everything except mayo.

We paid for our sandwitch and took it outside and sat at one of there tables to enjoy it. The meats were sooo good! Hi quality and amazing! but the bread killed it :( it was hard and dry and difficult to bite and chew. He had also poured what seemed like an entire mustard bottle on there and it was too much, took away from the meat flavor. 

I understand it was later in the day but I do not think it is an excuse to have stale tasting bread. I may give them one more shot next time I am in the city and possibly earlier in the day.
author: Samar N.

description:
YUM YUM.

Excellent Italian sandwiches. My coworkers and I like to come out here when we can use a walk or when someone needs to buy Italian groceries but it is always a delightful treat. They stuff their sandwiches with the freshest ingrediants and are always friendly to boot. LOVE their rosemary bread. Tip: It is typically the first to go from the bins so go early.
author: Raina B.

description:
This place makes amazing sandwiches. I was on a yelp north beach walking tour when I found this place. I wish it wasn't so far away, but if I'm around here for lunch again - this would be a no brainer return spot. 

Highly recommend getting the sandwich with the works!
author: Komal B.

description:
Best vegetarian sandwich in the entire world. I would even be tempted to eat the meat from here and that's saying a lot. 

There are also so many enticing olives, pasta salads and other Italian treats... buying a picnic lunch from Molinari and then eating it in Washington Square Park... one of the best things you can possibly do in San Francisco. :)
author: Carrie G.

description: Renzo special on Foccacia. A good sandwich. Perhaps I was expecting a bit more considering how much talk there's been about it, but solid regardless. A couple of funny dudes in there, fu*king with all the clueless euro tourists.
author: Anthony R.

description: Visiting the Little Italy section in San Francisco, this deli is straight from the old country meats cheeses alcohol everything is fantastic definitely recommend they also ship food to you
author: Ed B.

description: Best Italian deli in San Francisco!  Love the North Beach special (prosciutto, red peppers, sundried tomatos, provolone) is superb. Great deli selection.
author: Andrea D.

description: Amazing! I'm a Jersey Italian transplant and this place is by far the best of the best. Great experience, handsome guys, the Renzo was delish- I substituted soppresatta for the prosciutto and spicy coppa with the fresh mozzarella and sundried tomatoes. Oh man and it was on crusty bread too. So happy.
author: Ginny B.

description:
By far the best Italian sandwich in San Francisco, let alone north beach. though it is always crowded, their sandwiches are delicious and worth the wait. The prosciutto is simply delicious and the Basil Turkey sandwich is amazing. 

Be sure to pick a good bread choice and be patient! The staff is so friendly and gives this place the perfect neighborhood feel.
author: Cristina C.

description: These guys make a good sandwich. It's hopping I. Weekends, but they are well staffed so it moves quickly the pesto and turkey sandwich is delicious. Order some olives and grab a pelligrino, take it to the park and enjoy SF at its best!
author: Jacqueline S.

description: Awesome sandwiches!! good sized with fresh meat, cheese, and bread!!! What more you need?!!!! I would love to come here often, only if I lived closer!!
author: Yoonmi P.

description:
Last night, I swung by after work and ordered a Molinari Special on Focaccia w/ Mozzarella and a side of potato salad.

To be honest, the entire sandwich experience was underwhelming despite the high-quality meat and cheese. Afterall, utilizing mediocre bread to sandwich those succulent meats is like hiding a Porsche engine in a Beetle chassis.

Nonetheless, the authenticity is undeniable. I will definitely be back to buy meats/cheese and maybe even try another sandwich.
author: Nick W.

description:
Molinari's is the real deal.

If you want a traditional old-school Italian deli, this is the place to go.  I have neve had a bad experience here.  The deli selections are solid:

1.  Get a ticket with a number.
2.  Get your bread - crustier the better.
3.  Select the innerds - great options including italian specialities like Mortadella, Salumi, Prosciutto, Cappo...
4.  Spread - go with the the works.

Take a peek at some of the frozen dinners - the lasagna is excellent - cheesy and meaty  and so savory.

Also check out the deli counter for sides like stuffed peppers and salads.

No matter what you order it is unlikely you will be disappointed.
author: Mark D.

description: I have been going here since I was little, and the quality and service has always been amazing! Just has an Italian Combo and a Northbeach Special, both were absolutely amazing and two of us couldn't finish them. Two meals for two! Also, the salami is the best anywhere, hands down. Have it for brunch :3
author: Izzy F.

description:
Bourdain went there. Blah Blah Blah.

Is it good? Yes.

Is it worth going out of your way for? Nope. You can find comparable sandwiches at other Italian delis.
author: Jamie Q.

description: Delicious sandwiches and authentic atmosphere. The Luciano was quite tasty, I recommend you get it panini style.
author: Amauri T.

description:
We were strolling along the streets on our roundabout way to Vesuvio's for a drink and as I walked by I saw all the REAL/delicious sausages hanging in the store.  I was like a kid getting sucked into a candy shop!  SOOOOO tasty.

We got the garlic capicolla and the hot molinari salami and both were fabulous.  Perfect place to grab meats for a sandwich or just something to snack on.  If I lived in the bay I would be here all the time!  :)

Thank you!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Molinari's is what I imagine a true Italian deli to be: from the endless varieties of cheese and meats behind the counter,  to the multitude of Italian goodies (baked goods, pastas, pasta sauces and more), Molinari's brings a slice of Italian heaven to North Beach.

Keep in mind there's a very distinct ritual to be followed when ordering a sandwich here: Walk in, grab a number, pick your own bread (literally), and be ready to order! 

The staff seems pretty impatient with newcomers who do not understand the above system, which surprises me given they are located in a very touristy neighborhood (or maybe that's what makes it not  so surprising).

Either way- any Italian food aficionado could find his fix here.
author: Roxane W.

description: Best salami I've had thus far! Bought a pound of mortadella, peppered salami, prosciutto, piccolini pepperoni and spicy salami. You'll get the most out of your buck here! Definitely will be coming back to try the sandwiches!
author: Liz P.

description:
Cool little euro deli that reminded me of my time in Europe. Great selection of Italian specialties, wine, and cheese. I came in for a sandwich, and wasn't disappointed with my meat and cheese sandwich, which was a welcome change from the normal SF fare. You can't beat the freshness here, as they cut all the meat fresh while you watch. Even the staff is authentically Italian -- I had to chuckle when the patron in front of me dropped a business card for Pinnochio restaurant on the counter, and as the customer turned to leave the guy behind the counter picked it up and muttered "Da fuck do I care about Pinnochio ... " and threw it in the trash.

 I recommend getting a specialty sandwich or creating your own picnic from the various goodies for sale, and get a table outside to enjoy the hustle and bustle of Columbus street, with a view of the Temple of Saint Francis of Assisi -- it's the closest you can come to the streets of Italy without a passport!
author: Johnny W.

description: Fantastic fresh pasta made on Fridays.  If you call Vince ahead of time, he'll set some aside for you, as they run out.  Slice spicy sausage into their homemade meat sauce, and this dinner is so easy and a home run every time!  Love this place.
author: Ana M.

description: Luciano Special is amazing.  Fresh bread, tasty meat, good cheese.  Definitely does not lack in flavor and character.  Great people behind the counter to match - a true old school Italian deli.
author: Charlie R.

description:
Okay, okay . . . you gotta have a sandwich and you gotta wait in line. Well if you didn't take a number you'd never get past the flood of people who are also anxiously awaiting their pure, fresh Italian goodies. Form the freshest Italian cold cuts, aged cheeses, fresh hand made meat and or cheese filled pastas. 
I've been living in North Beach for 40 years and Molinari's Deli is just as packed with great food and great people as it always has been. 
Gotta' eat??? Get in here, except for parking in North Beach  you won't regret as single moment. Mouth watering and yummy.
author: John B.

description:
I have a long history with Molinari, not because I'm from Frisco, I'm from LA, but because I've loved their salami for forever, particularly the spicy version.

Since coming to Berkeley, one of the key agenda items was finding great grub. Iti deli's are a passion of mine, and in LA there are three great ones: Sorrrento's, Bay Cities and Giuliano's, all top notch. And it was through these three institutions I was introduced to Molinari salami.

So of course, I have to make the pilgrimage to the source. It was good, but fell far short. In fact, Oakland's Genova is superior, mainly because they source their bread from Maggiora.

However, parking's a BITCH on a bad day. Prices are ok.

So, while I am still loyal to Molinari salami, and I can die and say "I've been there," Genova, while I'm in the Bay, is still king.
author: Jp K.

description:
Okay, first of all, does anyone know what it is exactly that makes this store smell so freaking delicious? (Message me, I want to know!) I really wanted whatever it was (marinara sauce?) but we were really there for the sandwiches. I got a Molinari Special with everything, and it was everything I wanted it to be - actually slightly more, since the stack of meats and cheeses was a teensy bit too much for me. But that's not really a complaint!

On impulse we also got a couple of arancini and they were super tasty when we heated them up later for dinner.

I definitely didn't get any sense of elitism or rudeness from the guys behind the counter. We didn't know to grab our own bread or anything, but they were just totally polite and wonderful about everything.
author: Amanda P.

description:
This time I'll just review the sandwich I had. Turkey special.  Oh man, oh man this stuff is good quality turkey breast, with sweet bell peppers, basil spread and fresh mozzarella.

Here is a tip ask for a couple of slices of salami to enhance the flavor of the sandwich,  if you don't like too much bread ask them to remove some of the inner bread. 

Here is my secret and what makes the sandwich: ask for it toasted takes a bit longer but is worth it as it blends all the flavors together. 

You can always share a sandwich and a medium container of their colds salads between two people and you walk out with a meal for two for about $15  

Be nice to the guys behind the counter and they'll treat you with respect be a douche and they'll  treat you as you deserve it
author: Manny R.

description: Great old time deli.  Counter guys are quick an friendly and the sandwiches perfect.  Grab a number just inside the door and enjoy the wait.
author: Curt C.

description: Tasty prosciutto! Good prices. It's a popular place. We came here a few days before Christmas, and it was packed. Customers were very patient and so were the staff! They treated every customer very nicely, didn't rush anybody despite how busy the shop was and gave full attention and big smiles to everyone who walked in.
author: Janet C.

description:
We needed a quick bite before we caught our plane home and popped in here to grab a sandwich.  It was packed and rightfully so.  We bought two salami sandwiches on super fresh bread with everything and added fresh mozzarella.  I could not finish all of mine, and you bet I packed that baby on the plane.  I was not about to waste one bite!

Great place.
author: Me E.

description: Fantastic sandwich, I want to go back to try different types. The meat was delicious, but mostly, it was made with real care. The cheese was sliced just so, the veggies were distributed throughout. Just a really well made sandwich.
author: Mike O.

description: One of my favorite sandwiches shops in the city! I recommend any sandwich with their prosciutto di Parma. The eggplant parm sandwich is one of the best I've ever had. On a warm day, remember to bring blankets and eat in Washington square park. I look forward to trying more of their products such as the Italian wines and dried porcini mushrooms imported from Italy. Can we say "yum"?
author: Rebecca D.

description:
Simply the BEST. If you want an authentic Italian deli experience and high quality ingredients served up by some of the nicest and most knowledgeable people around, then you have arrived.

Get the Luciano Special and thank me later.
author: Michael B.

description:
Sandwiches: 5/5

From a guy who grew up eating Italian food basically every day, I can honestly say Molinari makes some of the best Italian subs on the West. Take one step inside and you'll know immediately this place is special. If I lived in San Francisco I would eat lunch here daily. Except Sunday when they are closed... oca!!!

I have tried all their sandwiches and my personal favorites are "The Renzo" with hot coppa and "The Luciano Special." You won't be disappointed with either. There is usually a long queue though, so grab a number right when you walk in. Also, select your bread from the bins and bring it to the counter when you order.

So as luck would have it, I visited Molinari after years on the day Anthony Bourdain happened to be filming "The Layover: San Francisco." If you look in the top-margin around 41:39-41:42, you'll see half of my head along with my love Kiki's LOL. My 0.4 seconds of fame has come and I'm going to bask in it forever.
author: Markham M.

description: A San Francisco institution.  High quality Italian meats, cheeses and sandwiches. Expect long waits around lunchtime, but usually well worth it.
author: Juan S.

description:
Love Molinari's, it has history, great service, great products, great sandwiches. I still think SF needs new Italian restaurants that meet the caliber of Italy, but this place hits the spot. It's the ultimate deli in NB and a must-stop for anyone. 

They have a couple of tables outside, but it's nice to buy some wine, cheeses, prosciutto, and sandwiches and walk to the ferry building. They have Chocolate Hazelnut Pirouline's, Nocciola, and Palmeritas which remind me of Rome.  I came here with my mom and Juan was so nice! He told us he was going to make our sandwich with a lot of love, and sure thing, he did. 

We both had the focaccia proscuitto with mozarella and peppers. The sandwich was awesome, the prosciutto here is such high quality, definitely beats Lucca's, hands down. The rosy meat, thinly sliced, becomes a complex, faintly salty delicacy that dissolves into richness. It gets to me so much, that the Italian in me comes out: Tutto è fantastico, mi ricorda Molinari di Roma, sicuramente tornare!

Enough talk, go out, and stop by Molinari's!
author: Stephanie M.

description: Molinari is an SF institution appropriately located in North Beach and I've loved their salami since I was a kid.  Matter of fact, finishing up a whole salami stick from here as I write this review.
author: Erich D.

description: 1/4 of the salami and the Molinari's Special and I'm very impressed. The bread and meat are incredibly fresh and atmosphere is authentic. For the extreme foodie there is 100 year old olive oil for sale. A short walk from the Wharf and absolutely worth visiting.
author: Scotch E.

description: Friendly service and fine delicatessen. Getting couple of things that we can't find back home...
author: Philippe L.

description: The best sandwiches. Topping and meat selections are great. Just wish the bread quality was a bit better. Overall very very good, though.
author: Brian C.

description: One of the best delis in the city great selection of salami and a big fan of the Molinari Special.
author: Jay M.

description:
Quality service from the sweet guys behind the counter, and awesome sandwiches!

this is my favorite salami place in the city! First you pick a number, wait for that number to be called. Before your number is called, grab some bread in a bin in which they will make your sandwich with. After, order your sandwich from their board (I've also told them what i wanted such as 3 kinds of salami sandwich or they can make a suggestions).

After, go to Washington park and enjoy! 

If you plan on coming often, check if they still give out their business card where they will reward you after buying 10 sandwiches, the next one is free!
author: Janelle S.

description: Authentic Italian deli in the heart of little Italy. Bring a small ice chest and take some of the fresh made tortellini or ravioli home! Don't forget to sample the world renown salami and fresh mozzarella cheese...it's an experience in and of itself.
author: Joy V.

description:
I don't eat beef and pork, but the sandwiches here are still amazing.

I have ordered the South Beach special and the basil turkey special, which are both pretty similar. The difference is that the South Beach has artichoke hearts and provolone, while the basil turkey has red peppers and mozzarella. In both sandwiches,
the turkey is very flavorful, and there is a lot of it. The sun-dried tomatoes and basil spread make both of them taste even better.

You get to grab your bread from a bin before you order. Ordinarily, I prefer Dutch crunch, but unfortunately theirs is not very crispy. However, their Italian bread is still great.
author: Varun N.

description:
At my old office, my co- workers and I would call this place the "pick- your- own-bread place". It took us months to realize that none of us really knew the name of this place. 

So you come in, you grab a number, and you go grab a roll from this big plastic container box. You wait for your number to be called, and while you wait you can browse around (they have a fine selection of home made sauces). when its your turn, you go up to the counter, hand your bread, and you get to choose what type of sandwich you want.

I love their sandwiches, even though I've never really been a big sandwich fan. They have high quality meat with such wonderful flavors. My favorites are the roast beef and pastrami.

It's $8 for a sandwich  and you can pay with card. I know $8 is still considered standard price, and they have high quality ingredients.. But the Asian in me still think sandwiches should never cost more than 5 bucks. Hehe..
author: Libby K.

description:
They have a wide variety of meats and cheeses and they are all really really yummy.

Service is great and they always recommend new products and items which are just in and fresh!
author: Sheila P.

description: A nice pantry of all kinds of Italian goodness. Your one stop shop for meat, cheese, wine and cooking ingredients. Quality products and the best hand crafted sandwiches ever! Don't forget to pick your roll or add the fresh Mozarella!
author: MissM R.

description:
After hearing about the legendary sandwiches, then reading the amazing Yelp reviews my curiosity had peaked. Molinari Delicatessen is a quaint Italian deli that serves up good sandwiches and Italian fare. The place is small but almost every part of the shop is covered in wallpaper, decorations, and products. My first time in at lunch time and it's packed. I didn't need to ask for sandwich protocol because everyone was holding a piece of bread and a blue ticket. There's also a small sign up above the counter.

So you take your ticket, wait for your number to be called, and pick a piece of bread out of a clear acrylic bread box. It feels strange just standing there with a piece of bread in your hands. It was hard not to start chewing on a piece. Even though there's about six guys behind the counter making sandwiches they take their time and don't rush. They clearly see the line and know that their customers aren't going anywhere.

Once you hand them your piece of bread you tell them what special you want. I'm pretty sure you can customize whatever sandwich you can imagine. I got the Molinari Special, aka Italian Special. It's the only special that doesn't list the ingredients but I overheard from everyone it's the best. It's a sandwich full of Italian meats, peppers, your choice of either Swiss or Provolone cheese, lettuce, and tomato.

It's a good sandwich. It's sure better than most sandwich chains because of the fresh meat and crusty bread. My only complaint is that since the meat is pre packed into a layer before sliding into the sliced bread, it tends to slide out when you chew your sandwich. Meat slippage is an annoyance of mine. A perfect sandwich should never slip. But that's just me.

____

Good sandwiches and meats. I'm interested in how good their pastas and other products are.

Note: The only seating is about three tables with chairs out front.
author: Michael H.

description:
Hooked since I was 17.
Finding a bad-ass deli is a hard sell for me since I come from deli lineage.  :)

Molinari sandwiches (which I get on focaccia) get me high - as does the caprese salad.  Something about their fresh mozz makes me weak.

 I don't like to wait so I typically head there when it's not smack in the middle of lunch rush.  If I had no choice, I'd still wait because these guys make a mean sandwich and they're worth it.

Real time note:
This weekend for the NB fest, they'll be slammed so be patient :)
author: Athena S.

description:
We have been to Molinari a few times now, and it is a consistent winner. The first time, we stopped in around breakfast during a stroll down Columbus to pick up some prosciutto (Parma). These guys know what they're doing--the fat was meticulously trimmed, and the prosciutto was thin sliced paper-thin. The flavor was amazing. We could have stayed there eating prosciutto all day!

We recently stopped by again for some sandwiches to go. It's a bit of a machine. First, grab a number from the paper number tape. Second, grab your bread out of the bread case. Don't bother trying to order a sandwich without completing these two steps first; you will upset the balance of the universe.

I had the Molinari special. It's basically your typical Italian cold cut, stacked high with premium Italian meats and served on a nice hearty roll (see step two above). My wife got the foccacia special, which served hot, panini-style. It had fresh mozzarella, prosciutto, roasted red peppers, and sun-dried tomatoes. Both sandwiches were fantastic, and we're wishing we'd bought a few more to snack on later!

The next time we are in SF again, we'll definitely swing back to Molinari Delicatessen.
author: Safford B.

description: Simply put; THE BEST SANDWICHES IN TOWN!!!!! in the mood for a super yummy; freshly sliced Italian cold cuts sandwich?... Like Great service without the pretentious attitude?... This place is for u!!! I come here every time I come into town and its always spot on time and time again! Yummy!!!
author: E.m. H.

description: This place is awesome. There are all kinds of imported goods from Italy available here. They are always very helpful and friendly.
author: Sandy D.

description:
Miles ahead of those deli shops which serve Boar's Head or below.  Tasty meats, but definitely no where near the fine quality of jamón ibérico de bellota.  Their sandwich list is limited and simple, but a great way to sample across their options.  Humble offerings at humble prices, I can understand why the bridge & tunnel crowd goes hog wild here.  As a city-based foodie, I can see myself getting bored quickly after a few visits.

Prosciutto: I'm not a fan of thick, clumped together prosciutto.  I prefer to taste each thin slice alone to really appreciate the artisan craftsmanship that went into the curing.  Not presented well on the sandwich, but tasty individually.

Salame: Got the two pounder.  Something nice about having a big salame in the house.  Pretty mild, but a great balance of meat and fat.  Best sliced as thin as you can at home with some mustard to dip it in.

Onion Foccacia: The onions added a good contrast to the greasy meat sandwich fillings.  Could have been fluffier.  Didn't taste that great grilled, probably best plain.

Mozzarella: Fresh and moist. Probably once a novelty, but I feel like I see this everywhere now.

Sun Dried Tomatoes: Really liked these.  Not too dry or chewy.  Loads of flavor.

Pickled Red Peppers: Roasted and pickled, these boys came in large doses on the sandwich.  Could have been smokier.  Doesn't overpower though.
author: Adam B.

description:
What can i really say about Molinari's that hasn't already been said already?
One of the last truly Italian delis. This place is just a sight to behold. If walking down Columbus on any general day, as soon as you walk into a ten foot vicinity of this place you are smacked in the face by an overwhelming smell of delicious cured meats, oils, and other delicious regional treats. As soon as you enter it's like a picture in a travel magazine. Salumi hung wall to wall, Massive crates of all sorts of mouthwatering foods and wines, stacks of everything you can think of. 

First off as a deli they are one of the best! No skimping on ingredients. Every sandwich is made to order with care and precision. The guy's behind the counter are always very courteous and friendly no matter how packed or empty the shop gets. The ingredients they use are of the best quality. The buns are always fresh; the meats are expertly cured, sliced and, balanced. You can actually taste the olive oil in every sandwich -Quality, quality, quality. 

The salads and antipasto is just as meticulously cared for and delicious. Olive bar, roasted peppers, stuffed peppers, etc. They make their own pasta sauce and seasonal raviolis and they actually make and cut their own pasta!! Seriously i can't use or stress the word "Quality" enough -the most important factor in all Italian food!

Other than the food, the place is packed with all kinds of fine imported and delicious seasonal and regional products. I come here for my olive oil, capers, San Marzano canned tomatoes (a must in all pasta sauce IMO,) and dried pasta's and candies. 

Fantastic, fantastic, fantastic! I am a new lifelong fan and supporter. One of the places i never think twice about or question the price. It's all reasonable and well worth it.
author: Chad B.

description:
Oh man, If we lived here, we would be here possibly every other day! The wine, the cheese, the coffee, the sammies.... Heaven, just heaven!

The sandwiches are made slow, and with love, so don't come when your in a hurry. Place your order and browse a bit, find something new to take home. Another tip, come early, (make it breakfast!), and you will avoid some serious lines. 

Ohhhh Molinari, how we love you so..... now off to scope out the website and see what we can order online! =-)
author: Chantelle E.

description: Came here on a little tour with some students.  We wanted to show them the best of North Beach, so my friend suggested we bring them to Molinari.  I was amazed with all the salami they have hanging (that you can buy!) and all the other meats.  I ended up sharing half of a Molinari Special and half of a North Beach special.  Both sandwiches were good...  packed full of meat and other goodness.  My only complaints were that all the types of bread are just tossed into one big container so you might miss something you liked better (I was sad to see a dutch crunch roll AFTER I picked mine) and the Molinari Special was a little heavy on the mustard- it actually overpowered the meats at times.  Overall though, a good sandwich.
author: Jeff C.

description: I don't eat here, it's usually too crowded to get a seat, forget trying to park nearby, and their bread must be mixed with concrete. That said they have one of the best selection of lunch meats in the city. Great salads & pasta too. Service is good and friendly but you usually have to stand in line for it. Decent selection of wines. Get your meat & cheese & wine and take it to a park or go home and eat. That way you can make more than just one sandwich to enjoy. This is high quality meat not Oscar Meyers. If you like meat you will love this deli.
author: Ron W.

description: Wow. The north beach sandwich is amazing. On par with little Lucca and Ike's, although the dutch crunch was a bit harder than I expected it to be.
author: Evan L.

description:
So many choices... I'm still in search of the perfect cheese. 

But do NOT leave that store without getting a large container of the meat sauce from the deli, a loaf of fresh bread and a bottle of red.  Warm the sauce and dip away with your bread. This sauce is so good, it doesn't need pasta! Well it's that or I can't wait for the pasta to cook and by the time it is, I'm full on sauce and bread, old school style.
author: Quail T.

description: Perfectomento, so.. delicious .. authentic.. and if you know Italian.. you will have the inside.  It is very clear that Molinari cares all about the quality of their foods... They are more about making you happy, so speak up!!!!   Check out stuff (bottled olives, olive oil, canned foods, bottled foods and more) on shelves and bring it home with you.
author: Tito Y.

description:
Quality Italian-style Market

A must see in North Beach. Hard salami, sausages, ravioli and other pasta fresca; prosciutto, mortadella, coppa, fresh mozzarella, classic antipasti. Great selection of Italian wines. Pick a roll and they'll make a sandwich for you. (Columbus near Vallejo)
author: Desiree P.

description:
My boyfriend and I love this place! I absolutely love watching them make everything in front of us. Mouth watering. They can get busy, like when we came, but they are quick and efficient. 

Fresh mozz, fresh cut meat, fresh bread (that you get to pick!).. Those sweet peppers, sun dried tomatoes.. Put it all together, and it tastes ORGASMIC. The flavors mesh so nicely... I'm getting hungry..

It's been a while since I went, but I recommend grabbing a friend and having a picnic in the park after stopping by at Molinari's!
author: M J.

description: After seeing this deli on "Anthony Boundain" "The Layover" I decided to try it one day on my day off. the sandwhich was really good. I got  a turkey sandwhich with everything on it. At first I didn't get why everyone had bread but i guess everyone picks up their own bread before ordering. it was worth the drive from SSF to north beach for molinaris! I will be back soon!
author: Brian B.

description: Very tasty. DUH. Just go try it out already. Don't forget your bun. Mozarella is unsalted for all the salt fiends out there; if you so choose that option. Take your salt. But what fresh mozarella isss salted? I should've known. Very good sandwich.
author: Dee C.

description:
I can't say enough rave things about Molinari's

Just swung right over to get Justin L. a few low carb treats.  Parma Proscuitto - you got it.  Some Mild Copa?  But of course!!  

And I can't forget the aged Provolone.  THAT'S THE GOOD MY FRIENDS!!

And today for the first time I decided to try their jarred Peppercinis -ZESTY!!

I wish I could come here more.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
My husband HAD to get he Italian.  He even passed up Giordano's for a taste of what Molinari's had aging(?) well, he loved it....and I got a primo $10 bottle of vino.  

For  newbies, pick out your bread from the box and wait for your number to be called. The numbers are at the front-ish of the cheese case.  To the right of the register.
author: Heather L.

description:
Raviolis reflecting 115 years of perfection.

In business since 1896 and you can see why. The raviolis are outstanding. Multiple varieties to choose from, including a chicken and spinach combination. Boil water. Pop them in for three minutes. Done. Even I can do it.

They were soon gone, leaving little doubt these were some of the best raviolis I've ever had.
author: Jason B.

description: You have to stop in here if you are in San Francisco. My dad used to take us here when I was a kid for their Italian salami. Later on, I would go there for the same and their delicious sandwiches. So much good Italian food, a lot to choose from. It's the best deli in S.F.
author: George C.

description: My wife and I came to this storied San Francisco italian-american sandwich shop; we are vegetarians and ordered the eggplant parmesan on dutch crunch and the veggie special on wheat. The eggplant parmesan was delicious and comforting while the veggie special was very standard. My assumption is that the non vegetarian options are fantastic. We'd consider coming back but not before trying many of the other sandwich shops in the city.
author: T K.

description: The cold cuts were fresh. But Nothing else is that Great. Not what I am used to being a native NY'er. Italian delis have cooked prepared food for take out. I only saw Fried dry eggplant. No good salads. Good Olive Olive oil to buy. but they are Way over priced for what??
author: August S.

description: Classic Italian deli. Fresh meats and cheese, good bread (picked yourself from a wooden box), fast service, and a tempting wall of Italian wines.  Nothing fancy, thank goodness.
author: Karl B.

description:
Chicken cutlet sandwich .... mushrooms .... fresh mozarrella, mmmmm... Everything at Molinari's is fresh -- makes me so happy!  I dream about eating at Molinari's every day.  Except that I'm usually too lazy to want to walk up that hill on Broadway to obtain some sandwiches -- exercise, meh.

The best thing to do on a nice Saturday afternoon is to grab some Molinari's sandwiches and salads and go sit in Washington Square park and people watch.
author: Elaine Z.

description:
Italian meats make me smile.  I love a sandwich stuffed with house made meats.  Molinari's makes a great sandwich.  They have been making their own sausage for over 100 years.  How can you go wrong?

When you enter the store grab a number and your bread.  Yes, you pick your bread first.  They figure out which yummy combination you would like on that roll. You can modify what goes on it but these are tried and true combinations.  I feel like I need to try every one on the menu.  The filling to bread ratio is perfect.

There are only a couple of tables outside so plan on finding a seat in the park and have an impromptu picnic nearby.
author: Megan P.

description:
For those of you who have not been to this deli, allow me to give you some advice that I only wish I had when I went for the first time.

For those of you who love Seinfeld, the way I do, this deli is like the Soup Nazi, but with style and grace that only Italians can provide. After you take a number you NEED to select your bread from the large plastic box directly behind the counter (that's why you see folks holding sandwich rolls in their hands) or you will be reprimanded by the men behind the counter when your number comes up.

Other than that, it's smooth sailing (sometimes) and you have a chance to enjoy one of the best sandwiches in town. Also, they have fresh pasta and ravioli, tons and tons of olive oils and other fantastic Italian goodies. Enjoy!
author: Hector G.

description: The sandwiches are very good, but what truly earns this place 5 stars is the Italian market within. It reminds me of the great Italian specialty stores of the east coast. While the sandwich is not the best in the city in my opinion, the availability of Italian specialty foods is! A must visit for any SF resident or visitor!
author: Perry D.

description:
By far my favorite Italian deli in SF and probably anywhere in the state... best Italian sandwiches (I always get mine on foccacia). My FAVORITE pasta salad. Also love the raviolis I can pick up and make a delicious and easy dinner out of. They have amazing already made bolognese. Also love their handmade fresh pasta for special occasions. Molinari's is a MUST if you live in SF or are visiting.

I love the South Beach sandwich, meatball sandwich and Renzo's Special. Staff is very accomadating and helpful :)
author: Sarah A.

description: What's so special about the renzo special? It was just ok, and very bready.
author: Ben Z.

description:
As soon as you walk in you can smell that this deli is the real thing. Fresh & delicious ingredients at reasonable prices. The staff here is really accommodating and will make it anyway you want but they also have wonderful sandwich creations to choose from if you want to leave it in the hands of the experts.

Recently I went in with my family and ordered a bunch of sandwiches to take with us to the Giants game. I had the South Beach which is a medley of turkey, artichoke, sun dried tomatoes and provolone tied together with a garlic basil spread. I also made a special request to have it made with love and boy did they deliver. The sandwich artist when labeling our sandwiches wrote "lots of love" instead of the sandwiches real name on mine. With service like this you know they really listen and take care of all all their customers.

I also recommend the Molina's Italian Combo filled with delectable Italian lunch meats.  Some of the meats I don't even know the names of, but the union of all of them together makes for a very memorable sandwich experience. Keep in mind most sandwiches are dressed with mayo & mustard so make sure to ask for oil & vinegar instead for a more authentic taste. 

So walk in, take a number, pick a roll and get ready enjoy
author: Renee M.

description:
Disclaimer: I now reside in Chicago.  I've been to some great sub shops in Chicago (Bari, Fontanos, Vinnie's, JP Graziano, etc...)  In fact, I go to Bari at least once a week.  Their sandwiches are that good.  The other places listed are not too far behind.  I went into Molinari's thinking it'd be comparable.  Wrong!

First off, at Molinari's you get to pick your own bread from a bucket.  Not bad right?  Again, wrong.  Maybe it was because I was there after the lunch rush (around 3PM) but the bread was stale and hard.  I am not talking about hard crust, I am talking hard through and through.   Compare this with Vinnie's in Chicago.  If Vinnie's runs out of bread, they just stop selling sandwiches.  No compromise to quality.  You always get fresh awesome bread (from the D'Amato bakery down the street).

So now to the actual fixings on the sandwich.  I asked for everything that normally goes into an italian sandwich and I ended up with mustard?!  I've never had an italian sandwich in Chicago with mustard on it.  Most places in Chicago wrinkle their nose at you if you ask for mayo on italian sandwiches.  I hate to think what they would do about mustard.  Aside from the mustard, the quality of the ingredients did not compare.  The taste of Bari italian subs just jumps out at you.  You get a mouthful of distinct flavors in every bite.  Molinari's sub was more bland.  I mean, it's better than say Subway, but that's not saying much.  Also, where was the giardiniera?  Bari makes their own giardiniera that is absolutely killer.  I wanted some more kick to my sandwich that was provided (I blame the lack of kick on the mustard).

Also, prices are not "reasonable", at least not compared to Chicago.  The sandwich I got was about $7.  I could have gotten the same size sandwich for $5 in Chicago.

The guy who made my sandwich was friendly enough.  In fact we talked a little football (since I was wearing a ManU jersey).  He seemed liked a fine enough fellow.  I just question his sandwich making skills.

I will be back in the future to give this place another try since I still can't believe that this place is rated so highly.  Maybe I just got the wrong sandwich?  Or the sandwich maker was having a bad day?  

I am not trying to say food in Chicago is better than SF (sometimes it is, sometimes it isn't).  But I was extremely disappointed with Molinari's.
author: David K.

description:
Nom, nom, nommy Italian sandwiches. FYI: grab a ticket when you first get in and grab your bread, then figure out what to order while you wait for your turn. 

The gf and I tried this place when visiting SF last week. I got the basil chicken sandwich and the gf got the hot meatball sandwich. The sandwiches are big; enough to share if you're not that hungry. 

My sandwich was aiight; I discovered that I'm not a big sun-dried tomatoes fan, which was on the chicken basil, so my experience was just alright with Molinari's. But my gf loved the hot meatball sandwich, and that's saying a lot since she's not a sandwich person at all. Whats nice about the meatball sandwich is that its not too messy and the bread just crumbles with each bite...nom. 

Next time we're in the area, I'll get the meatball sandwich with extra sauce, yum. They also have tons of other Italian goods if you need to pick up anything (cheese, meats, olive oil, vinegar, crackers, etc.) 

Only 4 stars because they're kind of pricey and I didn't really enjoy my sandwich.
author: Chris K.

description:
We had heard about how good Molinari is, but only made our FIRST trip there this past January.

North Beach was actually very much out of our way--according to our plans for the day, but my husband insisted on going.  I reluctantly agreed, and was annoyed by how cold it was in North Beach (it was early in the morning).  We bought about 8 pounds of Salami!  And decided to order a sandwich for breakfast.

We went for the North Beach Special... Prosciutto, Provalone Cheese, Sun Dried Tomatoes-- all on freshly baked bread.  It was HEAVEN!!!!-- I hate to admit it but good call on my husband's part.

And if anyone asks my two-year old "what did you do in San Francisco?" She will answer, "I ate bread."  She really LOVED the bread!!!!
author: Joanne N.

description: Excellent Italian Deli... if in SF, don't miss this place.  The fresh mozzarella is to die for as is the proscuitto.  I've walked 30 mins during my lunch hour just to get a sandwich from this place.
author: Dan M.

description: This place is like a sore dick ... you just can't beat it!
author: William B.

description:
Delicious slivers of prosciutto and coppa layered upon creamy, fresh mozzarella and succulent sundried tomatoes drizzled with tangy balsalmic vinaigerette...Like my favorite "Star Meats" in Berkeley, Molinari fulfills your epic deli sandwich cravings!

My only qualm is that the bread choices are too thick too my liking and thus detracts from the awesomeness of the contents. Nonetheless, I do enjoy that you can pick your own bread from the bread box. :)

Also, friendly quick service (at about 1pm on a Thursday), real Italian people in the store!, and great price: a full sandwich (averaging about $8-$10ish) can totally satisfy 2 meals!

I shall be back!
author: Gail N.

description:
Basically a French or Sour Dough roll baked from Italian French Baking Company on
1501 Grant Ave.  Slap some cold cuts and lettuce and condiments.  How can these people have such High expectations from cold cuts that you can make yourself.  It goes to show that the NINJA Generation No Income, No Jobs, No Assets has proven to have no taste and no epicure for fine food.
author: Donald S.

description: No place I'd rather get a sandwich in downtown or north beach. In fact, it's a great excuse to walk OUT of the Financial district. You choose a roll, then go up to the counter and place your order. Anything is good. Really. And beautiful. Plus they have energy and make your sandwich knowing how good it's gonna be. Walk across Columbus and sit on the church steps. They have Meatball, which will blow your mind. And Prosciutto. And Coppa. Plus cool italian soda. Great Macaroni Salad, too. If it's sunny out, take your time, then grab a double espresso anywhere nearby, then stroll over to the no name record shop on Grant.
author: Jono S.

description: You can get a sandwich the size of your head for $9, which is a steal compared to other lunch spots in the area.  The place gets busy but the line moves fast, and either way, it's totally worth it.
author: Victoria G.

description:
Yummy!!

Molinari's is the best place to go if you're craving a sandwich in North Beach. The people here are very friendly and helpful. And they like chatting with the customers.

There's a board with all the selections that they have, but personal favorites include the Luciano and the South Beach. YUM.

Here's the set up here, because it can be intimidating the first time you roll in:
1) Pick up a ticket. They call out based on next number.
2) Choose your bread (its in a huge plastic bin)
3) Figure out what you want in your sandwich while waiting in line.  You can also create your own.
4) Order when they call your number.

Simple, yes? You can also get cheeses and fresh meats and basically anything in an Italian deli here. I have not tried these, but they all look really good. 

The prices are reasonable for the area, and the sandwiches are HUGE.  There's also a buy 10, get 1 free card, so if you're planning on coming by often (or at least 10 times a year), get one.  Its very worth it!
author: Lily W.

description: Renzo's special on focaccia. Do it. Unless for some inconceivable reason you don't like great prosciutto, mozzarella, and sun dried tomatoes. In fact if you don't like those things why are you on yelp anyways? There's probably a box of oatmeal calling for you somewhere.
author: Misha T.

description:
Authentic and cheap
Not a usual combo
Great bang for your buck

Fresh gourmet sandwich
More than just mozzerella
Salame, coppa

Romantic picnic?
Add some Italian wine
Dates, romance galore
author: Sadhika B.

description: Hands down, best deli in the city. Classic Italian is always my go-to. There is almost always a line, but is it ALWAYS worth it.
author: M S.

description:
The South Beach sandwich is delicious! Turkey, provolone, artichoke hearts, sun dried tomatoes and garlic herb spread. YUM!

Here's how it works:
1) Grab a number
2) Select your bread roll in the bin
3) Hand over your bread to the deli guy
4) Pay for your lovely sandwich

Too bad this place is a bit of trek from where I work but it's definitely worth it! I'll be back!
author: Helen Y.

description: Good sandwiches, not overtly exciting though. The bread is okay, dense and spongy. It really is good for a subway sandwich at twice the price!
author: Kelly G.

description: Delicious sandwhiches, but pricey. The prices are one dollar more than stated in the "Explore the Menu" link. Totally worth it as a treat every once in a while though. I had the South Beach Special and it was amazing. Fresh ingredients all around, including the perfect focaccia bread.
author: Misty M.

description: We stopped by this place while we were tasting throughout North Beach. This was the most amazing Italian deli I have ever been to! There was a huge selection of Italian cheese, wine, meats, and of course the side dishes and sandwiches looked absolutely amazing! We bought pancetta, salami, marinara sauce and homemade cheese raviolis. The raviolis had a little bit of nutmeg that was delicious and enhanced the flavor. The men working behind the counter were hilarious and charming. Seattle needs a place like this...we will come back and try the sandwiches on our next trip to SF.
author: Ashley W.

description: I've been wanting to visit this place for a long time. We happened to be in SF on 3/11/2014 and it was our first stop. Parking like everywhere in the city was pretty tough but worth the effort. I not only had the Italian sandwich with everything but I also picked up some whole sticks of salami and pepperoni. They also have Caputo OO flour for a great price. I wish I lived closer but we're about 4 hours north.
author: Michael B.

description:
Tasty, authentic, Italian deli. 
The guys behind the counter are really friendly! 

When you get there, take a number and then choose a piece of bread to give to the guy who's going to make your sandwich. 

The ONE COMPLAINT I have about this place is that it was the end of the day (about 4pm) and all the bread was REALLY hard (like you have to gnaw at it when you bite into your sandwich hard) so I would suggest make sure you choose the softest bread orrr just go earlier in the day when the bread is fresher. 

On the positive: the inside of the sandwich was delicious! you can taste freshness in the salami. and they have homemade uncooked noodles and raviolis. 

Keep in mind: There aren't any tables inside but there are a couple small ones outside. 


I will definitely be returning...
author: Allie E.

description: The sandwiches are made fresh with good ingredients. Fresh mozzarella makes all the difference on an Italian sandwich. Be patient as the line is typically long and they take a long time to make sandwiches.
author: Brian S.

description:
Holy Cow! I just returned from the Molinari Deli 2 at the Ferry Building and damn near dies while eating my lovely sandwich. No wonder there is a line on most days. I heard it was great, but since I love food - I had to experience it for myself.

I got the Turkey Basil on Rosemary Roll. I asked fresh tomatoes instead of sundried and couldn't be happier with my lunch selection today.

I asked for a pint of mixed olives my mistake, but feel pretty lucky. Now I am just sitting here at work, thinking about my lovely lunch and snacking on olives. 

Mmmmm.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
I swear, I'm naming my first born "Luciano Special" after the best sandwich I've ever had. And when he (or her) needs to be called, I am using the full name, as in "Luciaaaaano Specialllll, come clean your room right now!"

The 'wich: parma prosciutto, sweet coppa, fresh mozzarella, sun dried tomatoes, onions with lettuce, on grilled focaccia bread (I added pesto and artichoke too). Yummmmm!! 

Maybe I can make something like this at home, but the vibe of this place made my experience 10x greater. This is what I imagine a delicatessen to be. Salamis hanging everywhere, cheeses galore in their grocery case, canned San marzanos, all kinda of pasta. I didn't mind the wait because I was so busy looking at all the stuff they had in there! 

I went here 2 times during my SF vacay. I'm kicking myself for not trying their salami, but I was just so in love with the Luciano that I couldn't cheat on it! 


Hawaii has many things, but we don't have a good deli. At least not like this. I've probably thought about and talked about those place 50 times since my San Fran trip less than a month ago. I would happily get my butt on a Hawaiian Air SF flight just to have this sandwich.
author: Erika A.

description: While visiting SF, my pure Italian buddy had me hiking the city hills to get to this place, all the while telling me it is where his parents always got their salami when they immigrated here. Sure enough, it is the real deal. You cannot go wrong. Grab your choice of bread and order the sandwich your heart desires.  Then buy a couple pounds of salami to take back home. You won't regret it.
author: Shannon B.

description:
I've wanted to like this place.  Friends, co-workers, and Yelp all rave about it.  But it's just not very good.  And when I say it's not good, I don't mean that my high expectations were quashed.  I mean the sandwiches are so bad that I can't finish them.

I've tried a variety of bread choices, and I do enjoy the grab-your-own-roll schtick.  No matter my choice, though, the sandwiches are dry, tasteless, and mostly disappointing.

I think I'm done with this place.
author: James M.

description: We came in to order a couple of sandwiches . The counter was busy and the food looked good . While waiting we proceeded to ask and look for a restroom . Unfortunately there is no public restroom and the sandwich maker at the counter told us to beat it . Seems harsh , since we did not look like bums . We seemly wanted to relieve ourselves before lunch . The guy was very rude . We are definitely not coming back to this place .
author: Michelle B.

description: Best italian deli in North Beach!!! Love their sandwiches especially the "North Beach" sandwich is great!! Once you go there a little the staff will recognize you  land you'll feel right at home
author: Francesco F.

description: Take it from a guy from the Bronx. The worst  meatballs ever. I had canned rations meatballs in the army that were better.  horrible. tasteless. Iwas shocked ! i gave the meatballs to a homeless guy. he said that the worst meatballs ever.
author: John D.

description:
This place makes me not miss Little Italy in NYC that much.
