The meat is top notch and the sandwiches are awesome and they understand that you might want to order what to put on the sandwich, not what to leave off (it's an East Coast thing vs a West Coast thing).

The have a great variety of cured meats, as any deli should.
author: Brett W.

description: Very yummy.  I had the North Beach Special, ordered and paid through the Yelp partnership, biked over, picked up, came back to work and enjoyed it.
author: Jay S.

description:
My new fave deli:-)  Love it!

Can't say anything that hasn't already been said. Still thinking about the South Beach sandwich I ate yesterday. Typical but better, simple, fresh, Italiano sandwich. Just the way I like it. The place was packed with peeps. Grabbed a number and was 10 behind but it only felt like I waited 10 minutes. As I was paying, another deli guy handed me a freshly sliced piece of prosciutto..... BONUS!! Yep, I was a happy camper:-)
author: Gina H.

description: OMG very delicious sandwiches.  I have to try to remember back when I went here.  I think first... not much seating.  Only a few tables outside, we had to have a car picnic.  Second, you have to walk in, grab a roll out of a bin to the left... pick whichever bread you want and then stand in line and wait your turn.  I think there are numbers to grab when you walk in.  Then you order your sandwiches...  I for the life of me cannot remember what I had but we got two sandwiches and they were both fantastic.  I don't think you can go wrong if you just look up at the board and find something you like.  The bread was a little crunchy on the outside and yummy soft and chewy on the inside.  I can't wait til we go back there so I can eat another sandwich from here!
author: Janine K.

description:
Calling all serious sandwich lovers...this is the place for you.

I have had Molinari's on my list of places to try since I moved here over 2 years ago. The sad part is, I pass it literally everyday on my way to class, however, I have never stepped inside it's doors. That is until about a month or so ago.

On a beautiful sunny day, my wonderful other and I decided to check it out and see what all the fuss was about. After reading so many helpful yelp reviews, we walked in and picked out our bread immediately and then spent a few minutes deciding which sandwiches we wanted to try. Whew...what a task! So many delicious choices to chose from! So we decided on two different sandwiches, Joe's Special and South Beach. The Joe's Special had fresh mozzarella, dried tomatoes, sweet bell peppers, basil and garlic. The South Beach had turkey, provolone, sun-dried tomatoes, artichoke, garlic and basil spread. It's safe to say we were happy campers.

We took our sandwiches to Washington Park where we were able to enjoy them in the sunshine. Just to forewarn, the sandwiches are huge and could easily feed two people, depending on how much you can put away. I saved the other half of mine to eat later, and it was still just as delicious.

Molinari's also offers a plethora of fresh meats, cheeses, homemade pastas, as well as a variety of freshly made deli salads and sides. I hope to make more visits to Molinari's to try out all of their delicious eats.
author: Emily S.

description:
Everytime I go to San Francisco, I have to visit this place, and if you are a deli lover, you will love this place! You get to choose from a vast array of different types of breads and then choose what kind of sandwiches you want (all names after italian singers, etc). 

The first time I went there I couldn't decide what to get , they all sounded good. I ended up getting a sandwich that included mozarella, roasted peppers, and proshutto. It was "heaven." The portions are huge too, I was able to save the half and eat it for dinner. 

You must try this place, another plus, a guy that works there was frim Waipahu, HI and knew that I was from Hawaii without even talking to me.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I had a friend introduce me to this spot and I'm glad he did so.

This store is exactly what I think of when I think of Italy. Not only can you get a sandwich to go and go eat it outside, you can buy your prosciutto, mozzarella, salami, and olives here and they are FRESH. Forget what you get elsewhere. 

First: pick up your bread, hand it to the clerk, tell him what you want in your sandwich, he makes it, you pay, you enjoy it, and it will be damn good! 

P.S. I wish you had tomatoes. I love tomatoes in my sandwiches.
author: Alexia R.

description: Used to work right down the street and Molinari was my go-to spot for sandwiches. Great value here.  Sandwiches are large and the ingredients are delicious, $8-$10.  Highly recommend
author: Brooks R.

description: I would drive or take an hour on the Bart just to eat here again! Perfect little deli in "Little Italy" Definatly go hungry. I had the eggplant sandwhich which was great. They put sundried tomatos which gives it so much more flavor than just eggplant, sauce and cheese. My mom had the meatball which was PACKED with meatballs. Finace had the sausage and peper sandwhich which he talked about for 2 days straight so I know he enjoyed it. Definatly can't wait to make another trip here from San Ramon!
author: Melissa B.

description:
I've been going to Molinari since I was little.  When my family visited SF, this would be one of our usual stops.

I don't need to rehash the ordering process for buying a sandwich, however, even if you think you're not going to get anything and you're looking to browse, GRAB A NUMBER right when you get in.  You'll thank me for it, since I have never seen anyone leave empty handed.

My usual go-to sandwich is the Resto special with mozzarella, sun dried tomatoes, and prosciutto.  Prosciutto freshly sliced paper thin and meticulously piled into the bread I have chosen.

Everything in the deli looks great, I just wished I lived in SF so I could actually take things home, such as the pastas.  However, I have more than once taken a Molinari sandwich on the plane and soaked in the stares of envy from my fellow passengers.  Yes, be jealous.  This is the best sandwich I have ever had until I have the next Molinari sandwich.
author: Meg T.

description: I decided to try Molinari Delicatessen so that I could have a good sandwich on my car-trip back to Los Angeles. Overall, this is a great deli sandwich place, and I'm pretty sure there is no place in LA that can really compare. You get to pick out your own bread too! I remember when I picked out my loaf, it was still warm...which was perfect. The employees are really funny as well. I even took home some great, fresh salami.
author: Sandra C.

description: Probably my favorite deli ever.  They have a wide selection of meats and cheeses and I have loved everything I tasted.  I usually get a quarter pound of several different meats (spicy salamis, and copa) and a quarter pound of their provolone and swiss.  I also purchase some of their breads as well as their prosciutto (my husband is a huge fan).  Several grocery food is also available for purchase.  We spent around $40 and this lasted 3 days.  I love this grocery deli and intend to go here whenever I am in San Francisco.  What a great find!
author: Lauren M.

description:
I work for an Event Marketing agency and we were hired to design and build an authentic 1910 deli in the heart of San Francisco.  I had heard of Molinari's and was told it was a must see to get some inspiration for design.

Every nook and cranny in this place is filled with oils, meats and cheeses. It defnitely has everything you could possibly want to purchase from an Italian market.  I am quite interested in hearing how they actually keep the place clean with that many goods!

Since I got there right around lunch time there was a decent line starting to form, so I was interested in seeing what the hype was all about.  I took my place in line, ordered the Mozzarella sandwich and anxiously awaited the Molinari Experience.  

Maybe it was all the hype my co-workers put around it or that I had to eat in my car and it was hot, but it wasn't epic - good for lunch when you just want a sammy, but not 5 star worthy.
author: Angel S.

description:
Three words:  garlic rosemary turkey.  It is sliced so thin but is remarkably tender and moist with hits of garlic and rosemary!  Da lovely.

I've lived within throwing distance all of my life but only ventured here a few years ago when both Panelli Brothers and Palermo closed their doors and I was craving deli meats.  I'm not a fan of their ultra large sandwiches but love, love LOVE getting a few of their deli meats to go.  

Note:  On weekdays, it gets painfully crowded at lunch time but if you go before 11:30 and after 1:30 the crowd thins and you can enjoy some deli and its environs.  The store has that old world feel charm-Italian imports, from olive oils to tomatoes to cookies and much more stacked high and deep.  A few tables & chairs are sprinkled outside but if you can hoof it, take your meal to Washington Square Park, about 3 blocks away and eat to your heart's content.

Molto, molto.
author: Jen L.

description: Was in the area and visited based on all the positive reviews..... Was not disappointed, bread was extremely fresh, meat portions were excellent, artichoke was fresh as well as the roasted peppers. Would recommend.....
author: James D.

description:
Renzo special + limonata = $10

A first-timer here, I had to have someone explain the process to me - seemingly straight forward but somehow not obvious?

1. Get a number from the red dispenser thingy
2. Choose your bread (unless you want focaccia, which is at the counter and $1.25 extra.. I think)
3. Once they call your order, hand them your bread and make your request
4. Money exchanged for food
5. NOM NOM NOM KTHXBYE

Love the decor too. A 1230 weekday arrival yielded 10 people in front of me - they worked quickly so it didn't take that long.. I'd say 10-15 min.
author: Vicki L.

description: I love this place! Everyone talks about the sandwiches, which, IMO, are pretty good, but not the best in the city. Go here for the other items: the homemade salami, tortellini, lasagna, italian sausage, butter beans, stuffed peppers, homemade pastas, pesto sauce, and many many more! Great place to pick up some gifts for a party host, for a picnic, or just to stock up your refrigerator! The guys who work here are super friendly too. It will be crowded at noon on a Saturday, so be prepared to wait. Don't miss stopping here if you're in North Beach!
author: Alison S.

description:
Ma-ma-mia!   Molinari is a very dangerous place.  It looks cute and innocent enough, like a deli taken straight from the streets of Roma, Milano, or Napoli and dropped right here in The City.   They sell sandwiches, and cheeses, wine, pasta, pasta sauce.... salami... wow, the salami...  You're not going to find salami this good anywhere else in the City.  I promise you...

So anyway, how come every time I walk in there, I come out $200 poorer?   Ah well you see, I am a serious brunello junky... I smoke it, I shoot it, I snort it...   ok, well, maybe not... but I am a serious brunello junky, and Molinari's got quite a good selection of Brunellos.

And the cheeses... we're not just talking Italian cheeses, either.   They have tons of blue cheeses, goat milk cheeses from the French, Swiss, and Italian alps.   Well, let's just say they have a good selection of cheeses.   Definitely the best selection of cheeses in North Beach.

Note that they're closed on Sunday, just like the delis back in Italia.
author: David O.

description: It has been a really long time that, I have not bought myself a sourdough sandwich from Molinari until on a really hot day on a friday afternoon... I went inside on a not so crowded afternoon and bought me a Salame, Mortadella & Provone Cheese Sourdough Sandwich... it is a really yummy yummy sourdough sandwich after when you eat it!!!!!
author: William B.

description:
A LOT can go wrong if you attempt to say things in a language that typically leaves you fumbling and bumbling. All you can do is hope that you error on humor's good side.

My mom tells a story about our dog, Gum See, meaning "Golden Lion Dog", or so she thought. (Saying slightly the wrong tone in Chinese can get you in trouble!) After announcing her excitement of the name, my grandmother laughed and said, "Do you know what you're calling your dog? GOLDEN POOP!" 

My Italian is not much better than my Chinese, but I try anyways and then hope for the best! The friendly guys at Molinari are good about humoring me with a big smile and a little help with my American sounding pronunciations. The moment I step inside, the festive Italian tunes, old world style and warmth in their demeanor make me feel like I'm a long lost Italian cousin. My last big shopping spree here marked a 2 month gap in visits. Walking inside I was greeted with "Where have you been"s that made me blush with pure happiness all the way into the next day.

My Favorite Items:

Pollo in Panato (breaded chicken)
Arancini (fried breaded rice balls with meat/cheese inside)
Pomi brand tomatoes (best price around and great for red sauces)
Fried eggplant
Stuffed peppers
Gnocchi
Illy Coffee
San Pelegrino Aranciata and Limonata
Grana Padano and many other cheeses
Rosemary Ham
Dried Salami
Panettone
Amaretti cookies
Fresh pasta
An awesome selection of crusty breads
As do Mar brand Tonno (Italian tuna in oil)
Vino (How can you forget the wine?!)

Being a North Beach institution with a prime location on Columbus, they are well known for their sandwich making prowess! Come noon time, grab your bread roll, number and prepare to do big line battle with both locals and visitors. My best advice is to also take some fixins to go cuz a little Molinari will make any meal better!
author: Kira R.

description: I love Molinari.  I used to go there for lunch when I worked in the Financial District.  I'm now retired and every couple of years or so, I revisit this wonderful place.  Best sandwiches I've ever tasted!  I pick the bread and then order mortadella and provolone with mayo and include those wonderful red marinated sweet bell peppers.  They had the sweet bell peppers 30 years' ago; they had them 6 years' ago... not sure if they have them now, but I'm thinking of going soon to find out.  (Just checked the menu, they do!)
author: P. R.

description:
Nothing like enjoying a hot Italian sandwich with your hot Italian man!

My bf has been wanting to try Molinari's grilled foccacia sandwich ever since he heard Mario Battali mention it as one of his must-eats when he visits SF. I'm ashamed to say that despite countless visits to North Beach, I never stepped foot into Molinari's until last week, but I am a better woman for it.

We ordered the grilled foccacia sandwich and it was superb - thinly shaved proscuitto, fresh mozz, garlic basil spread and peppers on warm foccacia bread. Unfortunately for me (or fortunately for my waistline), my office is far enough from North Beach so that I can't stop by too often, but when I'm in the area I definitely keep Molinari's in mind!
author: Bella L.

description:
Since selling the deli, this place has gone down a bit.  The bread tastes airy and cheap.  It's the one thing that HAVE to improve on.  Everything else in the store is as it was (I definitely miss the old crew behind the counter though) and the quality of meats and appetizers is still great.

I'm Italian and I will continue to come here on pilgrimage.  I just won't be completely happy with my sandwich I guess.
author: Jason N.

description:
Best. Salami. EVER.
The first time my DH & I discovered this place, we followed an older guy into the shop who was carrying several 6' long salamis over his shoulder! They were coming straight from the factory, where Molinari's makes its own.

I am a salami head, then a cheese head, then a bread fiend so with Molinari's I have dies & gone to heaven on earth. This is a MUST STOP every time I visit SF, and I need to make sure to hit it on Saturday because they are closed on Sunday :-(

I second the motion that the cold calamari sald is unbelievable - crisp, refreshing, just the right amount of dressing. My DH and I still talk about it.

Off to the city this weekend for a round of college tours, so look for me & my son on Saturday afternoon. Can't wait!
author: Julie S.

description: This place is efficient [take a number when you enter and they'll call ya when ready], delicious and seems pretty authentic. Definitely recommend.
author: Kate B.

description: Best sandwiches ever! I love the eggplant sandwich there. It's amazing what a difference fresh great ingredients make.
author: Mariana S.

description: this is the real-deal Italian deli, folks! It doesn't get better than this! I lived in Telegraph Hill, a stone's throw up the hill from this fine establishment a few years back, and came here often for fresh made pastas and hand-stuffed sausages once a week. The sandwiches & cheeses are off the chart. How can you not love a place where you pick out your own bread, and watch 'the fam' work the backside of counter to hand cut you this fantastic meat-laden sandwich. It will be packed at lunch, so time yours. Then walk to park and feast!
author: Jen S.

description: Best Italian style sandwiches anywhere,  if they are out of the hard rolls in the bin ask for one it makes all the difference.  Also great ravioli and tortillini as well as all kinds of other great cheeses, wines and other Italian specialty items.  Place is usually crowded so know what you want and smile before you order and your sandwich will have more meat.  I have been going to Molanari's for close to 28 years now and have never had a bad sandwich.  Worst thing is I go for a couple of sandwiches and leave with 60-80 bucks worth of great stuff.
author: Troy S.

description:
Meats, cheeses, wine, and pasta.  Molinari is well established North Beach institution featuring some delicious sandwiches that are sure to sate the most demanding mid-day hunger.  Be sure to pick up some of their unbelievably delicious salame and a nice bottle of chianti (or any other selection from their well stocked wine selection).

Molinari is seriously old school.   When this place is busy, which is often, you are well advised to take your number, wait patiently, and speak up when it's called.  And be sure to mind your manners.  Upsetting anyone in this joint could get you whacked.
author: Christopher K.

description:
I've been going to this deli since I was a wee girl and I have never been disappointed. They are known for make legendary deli sandwiches, and they have the best damn salami in town! I will make a trip to San Francisco just to buy their salami, and between my boyfriend and I, it will be gone in 3 days max. The staff is always super friendly, too. Last time I went, the man behind the counter was slicing up some prosciutto, and he handed a generous piece of it to each of us standing in line. Yummy!!!

Molinari, I love you.
author: Madeleine R.

description:
I've been living in the North Beach neighborhood for close to all my life and am ashamed that I've only been to this little gem of a delicatessen only twice. One time to get goodies for the bread & cheese luncheon that I was hosting at work and the other time to try the Renzo special. 

I love how they have so many different types of cheeses! A much better selection than I can ever find at big name grocery stores and the cured meats are just so delicious. My all time favorites are the prosciutto and their famous dry Molinari salami. All of my co-workers loved everything I brought in and couldn't get enough! 

As for the Renzo special, not quite what I was looking for because I'm not the biggest fan of finding peppers in my sun-dried tomatoes but it was still a very good sandwich nonetheless. I think next time I come back I'll go for the North Beach special. Until next time, Molinari!
author: Crystal C.

description: Delicious? Yes. Worth waiting an hour for a sandwich? Probably not. Order online or don't bother...
author: Alex p.

description:
Molinari's makes some good sandwiches. Panelli's brother (before they closed down) was a lot better. Never go there on the weekends,especially a nice day or any event happening in North Beach.
"That old man",who works behind the counter, must retire. He has a hard of hearring  at his triple-digit age. He must be the surviving member of the "Great Earthquake of 1906"!
author: Matt G.

description: I should have noticed the signs. One piece of bread left in the basket means you're probably getting stale/very crunchy bread. This is usually the case past 5pm, so you best get here early. I ordered the Renzo which came with lots of meat as well as fresh mozzarella and sundried tomatoes. For some reason I was most enamored by the tomatoes and thought they provided most of the flavor of the sandwich, which I was not expecting from a sandwich full of meat.
author: Jason T.

description: Amazing food, great service, great selection. Can't go wrong with pretty much anything here. The only thing to avoid is the massive crowds around lunch, so plan strategically timed visits!
author: Peter N F.

description:
Is there an "add a star" button around here??? 

You want REAL Italian breads, cheeses, meats and balsamic marinated vegetables? LOOK NO FURTHER. Best delicatessen in the city hands down. (Disclaimer: I have not been to every deli in the city, but now I don't have to because I found perfection in this shoebox of a place.)

Super friendly staff, always a line out the door, a conservative spread of imports, and the smellllll of that fresh baked bread is enough to make you want to fuggedabout ANY other deli you may have had on your radar. 

Every time I am in SF, I make the trip to North Beach for Molinari's. The last time I was there, my father and myself were on a trip together and we stayed close enough to stop for 2 of the 3 lunches we ate. We were lucky enough to grab a table outside, but it's not a sit-down type place. You stand in line, grab your food, you go. It's a beautiful thing.
author: Whitney S.

description: Picked up some of their bulk breads/rolls. I liked the dutch crunch bread, hard french, and then soft french in that order. Molinari special sandwich was okay.
author: A A.

description:
When I come here with a boy on my arm, my sandwiches are decidedly less awesome. However, the ingredients they use are always fresh and delicious, and they are super friendly guys that work there.

I came here once with a crushing hangover, and muttered "Surprise me" from behind dark sunglasses as I handed over my Italian roll. The guy laughed and made the usual quip about too much fun or whatever, but then proceeded to make the most amazing surprise sandwich ever! I think it was mortadella with fresh mozzarella, fresh tomatoes, and hot peppers. And I mean, this sandwich was towering. I had leftovers for dinner! Oh, it was so good.

And yeah, there is a lunchtime rush as other people have pointed out, but the guys work fast and are still smiling and joking around all the while. Definitely worth it to take a number and wait a couple minutes.
author: Kay B.

description: Delicious.  What more can I say?  Went twice in two days and had a sandwich each time.  Seems the earlier you get there, the better chance for a super soft piece of bread though, as my second one was super soft, the first was a little harder.  They slice the meats for you right there, from an assortment of authentic italian cold cut products.  I had a sandwich that had marinated sundried tomatoes, homemade mozzarella cheese, real proscuitto and some other meat.  Insanely good.  Not much more to say.  Well worth the walk over and the $10.
author: A. L.

description:
Authentic Italian deli in between Chinatown and North Beach. Sammiches are simple, large, stuffed with meat, and most importantly, delicious. You even get to choose your own bread!

Got the salami sammich with everything on top. Lettuce, tomatoes, cheese, mayo, and mustard. Salami was definitely legit and piled high. The whole thing was practically bursting out of its wrapper. I approve.

Gotta get the Italian special next time (every kind of meat in the sammich)! Can't wait. 

Note: Take your sandwich to Crissy Field and eat them on the park benches (or the beach). Then fly a kite!
author: Carolyn K.

description:
Awesome. Awesome. Awesome. The line is totally worth it. 

Sandwich: Turkey, prosciutto, and sundried tomatoes, with pesto sauce. Excellent combo with a side of tomato and fresh mozzarella salad! 

Took home some bread and about a pound of domestic prociutto - which is nice and light, great for sandwiches. If you want a saltier pro to wrap around fruits and such, go with the imported one.
author: Jessica W.

description:
authentic! 

you can't even find anything close to molinar's in the fi-di for lunch, so trekking up the hill to north beach for molinari's is an effort and a treat.

everytime people in the office find out i'm heading up there, i get bombarded with orders. obviously the joint is much loved by anyone who had tried them in the past.

my fav...parma with fresh moz.  simple yet delicious.  salty salty goodness, rich creamy moz, soft aromatic roll and just for balance, fresh veggies.  

everything, and i mean everything they offer behind that counter is to die for.  from their chicken parm to the meatball sub.  you can't go wrong the minute you walk into molinar's.

oh, don't complain about the price, you can't get the same portions, quality, taste, authenticity anywhere else.  trust me, i've looked.
author: Ames K.

description: I read all the instructions to grab a number and your bread and all that jazz, and these guys couldn't have been any friendlier. They even told me I didn't need a number. A damn good sandwich that I can't get in Texas, and they seemed to enjoy the tourists on a late afternoon.
author: Cory B.

description:
Tip #1 - Grab a number as soon as you arrive. 
Tip #2 - Pick your bread from their bin, unless you prefer foccacia. 
Tip #3 - Read the menu above. 
Tip #4 - If you don't find anything on the above list, just wing it. 
Tip #5 - Add artichoke hearts to your sandwich. 
Tip #6 - Ask for the sandwich card (buy ten, get one free). 

I came here on a weekday morning and didn't need to grab a number. I picked my dutch crunch roll and handed it to the maestro who would create my masterpiece. Turkey, Salami, and provolone, everything but mayonnaise. This would be my pre-Warrior game meal. While waiting for my sandwich to be built, I perused the salad section and added a 1/2 pint of their white bean salad. The other selections include potato, pesto pasta, macaroni, green bean, and marinated mushrooms. The sandwich prices range from $6.00 to $9.50. I hope to try one of their hot sandwiches soon, after seeing someone order a cutlet cheese sandwich. During the holidays, the lines get a bit longer as people shop for gifts such as olive oil, their house made raviolis, Italian wines, and famous homemade salami. After Pinelli Brothers closed, this became THE sandwich shop of North Beach. For those who frequent Mastrelli's in the Ferry Building, you may wonder why it looks to similar to Molinari's; simple answer: they share the same owners. Just love those local places that are still family owned. 
Oops... almost forgot Tip#7 - ENJOY!
author: Mike C.

description:
Wow, when you walk in here, your nose will be happy, cuz it smells like a  good italian deli.
I like going here once in a while; the sandwiches are huge and one is enough for two hungry tigers. How to get your sando : toward the back, there is a huge selection of fresh rolls ,so # 1. Pick your bread 2. place your order.   Upgrade to 4 stars. No place to eat but three tiny outside tables. I have not tried their ravioli's or the their supposedly legendary home made sausages.
author: Bert K.

description:
It felt like the movie 'good fellas'. 

The italian gangsters are eating original italian sandwiches with their big gold rings on their fingers and with their chest hair showing. It was pretty legit. 

The veggie sandwich was the best italian sandwich of my life. Not better than Ike's but pretty damn awesome!
author: Aidan V.

description:
Quite simply the best sandwich place. Period.
It's not anything like that other healthier chain shop -- Molinari's got too much oil, salt, and taste. It's an explosion of flavor and texture with each bite. And I can never take just a few bites, even if I promise myself I'll have to save some for later. Friendly sometimes bubbly staff completes the experience. Definitely go.
author: Steve C.

description: Favorite Sandwich is the Renzo! OMG the flavors are perfect. This is a great  one. I can eat and this one is one massive size sandwich which will fill you up for sure. There is a reason this delicatessen has been around for this damn long with so many followers.
author: Ilya Movshovich M.

description:
The standard by which all other salame in the Nation is judged by, and has been for 100+ years.

There's a reason people on the East Coast are willing to pay 3x more for mishandled Molinari products than what they charge here for well-kept Molinari products in SF....
author: Michael H.

description:
Crackheads have crack, and I have this place. 

Holy jesus, yes it's that good.
author: Shawn S.

description:
I lived in San Francisco a few years ago, and this was THE place to grab a sandwich.  My roommate and I would designate SANDWICH DAY once every few weeks and designate an entire day to this Deli.  It's THAT good.  

North Beach can be kind of hit and miss sometimes as far as overall enjoyment goes, but Molinari's will never let you down.  Take a number, grab a GIANT chunk of fresh made bread out of the bin and try and keep your mouth closed as you look at all the incredible meats and cheese's stocking the deli cooler.  

Meats are always sliced to order, and portions are MORE than generous.  If you're in the mood for an Italian sandwich, there's no reason to look anywhere else.  THIS IS THE SPOT.
author: Wade M.

description:
Molinari Deli: why do you have to be 370 miles away??

Visited this deli for my love of Italian sandwiches and because of the glowing reviews on Yelp.

Practiced the ordering process mentioned here (pull number, grab bread, wait to be called) beforehand so I was sufficiently prepared.

Got our sandwiches and headed off to Presidio for a picnic, and after taking one bite of the sandwich I selected, fell in love.

We didn't have a chance to go back before leaving town, but I'm trying to figure out a way to get them to deliver to me. I did get a 2lb salami to take home, and it's just waiting for me to cut in to.

Molinari, your delicious bread and meat is the best!
author: mike l.

description:
Now I know what all the fuss is about... 

I have lived in California for almost 5 years and have bounced around neighborhoods, but they were all in or around North Beach. I even walked by the deli daily going to and  from work for months. Never did i decide to pop in for a sandwich. 

Well, Today after an early work out and running around doing some errands, 3pm hit and I was starving. Walking through China Town, thinking about pork buns or tacos or pizza, I decide Hey... Lets give Molinari's a try. 

Boy was I glad!!!

I picked my number and stared at the board trying to decide which tasty sandwich I should try. I had to make sure I picked a good one because this place is supposed to be soooo great!  I made my decision mentally, but thought I would ask someones opinion. With out batting an eye the man yells back, "The Luciano Special".... Ding Dng Ding! I was sooo happy because that is what I wanted.

So, I ordered the Luciano Special - Parma Proscuitto, Sweet Coppa, Fresh Mozzarella, Sun Dried Tomatoes, Onions, Lettuce on Grilled Focacia Bread. Watching the guy behind the counter slice the fresh Proscuitto on to my sandwich made my mouth WATER!!! The mozzarella was ooozing out of my perfectly toasted sandwich.

So, I get my sandwich and decide to enjoy this treat right out side the deli and enjoy this sandwich and some sun. The flavors came together magically. I had planned on eating half and saving the rest for later. Instead of people watching and soaking up the sun, I put my head down and DEVOURED the sandwich... The crunchy bread, Fresh cuts of deli meats, super soft and gooey cheese, crunchy lettuce and onions.... Way to go guys... You NAILED it!
author: Miguel V.

description:
Best freak'n handmade tortellini in town and this is little Italy, so that's saying a lot! Try it if you don't believe me! I like to buy a box of tortellini and freeze them for private parties - always a hit!

Meatball sub - bomb ya mama so good
author: Rayna A.

description:
yum to the maxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

I've been thinking about the sandwich I ate here since the moment i finished it, and maybe it was the way i made it, and what i put in it, but it was definitely also their award winning salame and their quality meats.

If you're not a meat eater i don't suggest this deli - cuz well, whats the point? If you're going to order a turkey sandwich, go somewhere else, because they will probably talk you out of it!! But if you want and authentic italian deli experience with the sounds of old italian men talking in the back and quality ingredients get your a__ over to molinari's NOWWW. 

I love the idea of being able to grab your bread hand it to the guy and walk up and down the deli counter picking and choosing and designing your sandwich, At molinari's you dont feel rushed and they are happy to make your sandwich exactly how you want it. I tried the proscuitto two types of salame and mortadella, might have been a bit excessive but hey my sandwich rocked!!  I wanted pecorino on my sandwich which they didn't have in the deli but i were happy to find one for me in the cheese section (which i purchased) and they cut up and put on my sandwich. 

for a true taste and culture of italy - check this place out.
author: Shadi N.

description:
I have only been here once. Being a veggie, I don't have much use for the meats. But they have plenty of veggie choices! I got the cheese sandwich, but I think next time I might go for something with the sundried tomatoes. 
The bread (pick it out yourself after grabbing a number) is soft, fresh and just bomb! The ingredients are fresh and the sandwiches are well-priced and hefty!
author: joanna r.

description:
My Boyfriend (Who's review is somewhere below LOL) brought me Molinari sandwich for lunch one day and it was really YUMMY!  We both ordered the Renzo's Special.  I mean how can u go wrong with good meat, sundried tomato, fresh mozzarella, and perto on good bread nomnomNOM.  I've been to their deli, and if you're going for lunch, I suggest you go early to avoid the crowd.  Also, grab a number when you walk in and chose the bread you want your sandwich on.  Prices are pretty reasonable for a good size sandwich.   The beauty of this place really lies in the quality of their meat.  I cant rave about it enough.  I'm salivating as I type thinking about it :P

Bottomline: GO! Molinari's is a good place to get lunch and good meat, not to mention other goodies they have in the store, like homemade pasta.
author: Roxanne E.

description:
i can't count the number of times i've gone here to get stuff for picnics in the park and it's always awesome... hot coppa, prociutto, sopressata, cheeses and anti pasta as always were great... 

the only thing i wished they had more of were more types of bread... but even that doesn't matter because you could eat all the stuff on its own...
author: Aarash Z.

description: OMG!!!!!   I cannot express enough the wonderful experience I had here.  So I get there right when it opens and the guy behind the counter is doing his thing signing deliveries getting stuff ready.  Seeing I wasn't in a hurry and i realized I need to be patient I told him Id sit and wait until he was done. He was so nice offered me an espresso while I waited then several more people arrived and he was so calm and not rude  to anyone, he even offered the delivery guy a coffee for waiting.  I ordered the Mafioso....  Its a must have.   But even if the sandwich didn't rock I would love to go back and hang out such a great vibe of a place........
author: Cynthia F.

description:
This place is awesome. My bf and I split the Hot Meatball Sandwich. We requested extra sauce, which they were completely fine with. I wish it was a little more juicier and wet.  It was really yummy tho. But I do wanna come back to try the eggplant sandwich and something with the fresh mozzarella......oh and some pasta ingredients!! 

This is a place where you grab your sandwich to go. There are only two tables in front of the store. 

See you soon Molinari!!!
author: Cnn F.

description: Great customer service!!  I went there in the morning when it wasn't too crowded to pick up meat and ricotta cheese.    The man behind the counter was so helpful and patient  and suggested a ricotta cheese they carry by Calabro (New Haven, CT) after I told him my recipe.    I have to say this ricotta cheese is by far, hands down the BEST I've ever had.  It blew me away.  I so appreciated the man taking a genuine interest and suggesting what might be best for the recipe.  He was a saint!   Next time I'll try one of their sandwiches!
author: Jane E.

description:
As expected, it was packed but what's a little wait for a good sandwich?

If you are new to this place, be sure to grab a number first THEN go pick out your own roll in the plastic bin.  When your number is called, please promptly hand over roll and order - do NOT be undecided when your number is called, it's very annoying for others waiting in line!

The Italian combo was good (but we still miss Panelli Bros. - they used to slice everything fresh when you order the sandwich).  The Luciano looks very good and will have to try next time among other stuff.
author: Gloria H.

description: They make AWESOME sandwiches! The people there were friendly and they took our order as soon as we got in. The sandwiches there are definitely worth it. $8 for one, but considering that HALF of it already makes us full (my boyfriend eats a lot), you can save the other half for later. We really recommend.
author: Yelp R.

description: Great place to grab a sandwich and sit in Washington Square Park.
author: Erica B.

description: This place has the BEST sandwhiches I've ever tasted! The atmosphere is great too. Get there early for lunch though because they get extremely busy.
author: Amber G.

description:
I absolutely love this place!

I love to eat deli sandwiches and Molinari's has some of the best cold cuts I have had in SF.  They have a wide variety of meats from Prosiciutto de Parma, Coppa, Salame, Basil Turkey, and some others that are just fantastic on sandwiches.

During lunch, 11-1, there can be a wait and can get crowded in the deli.  But trust me the wait is worth it.  Everyone who works there is super nice and will help you with anything you need.

My favorite sandwich is the Renzo Special that has Prosciutto, Coppa (I always ask for the hot coppa), Sundried Tomatoes, and Mozzarella on an Italian roll.  SOOO Good!
author: Dustin K.

description: This place deserves the hype! And big ups to Jesus for blasting my 22 sandwich order in 15 mins!
author: Ryan Z.

description: Italian Deli personified.  A must for SanFran.
author: John L.

description:
Molinari's is to North Beach as Satriele's is to the Sopranos. 

Kidding or maybe not, but this is something that I always think about when I stop here and can't help but smile whenever I am inside of the store. It doesn't help to add to this speculation from the last time got a sammie and the line stopped as soon as a couple of guys walked in. The guys behind the counter helped them right away and everyone in the store didn't even argue. 

If you're coming to pick up a few odds and ends for dinner, there's a nice selection of imported pasta, wines olives and cured meat. The deli meat is gorgeous and worth a try if you want something that's fresh. Their sandwiches are what get me everytime; when you can add sun dried tomatoes and not ruin the bread that makes for a good treat. If you're there for lunch grab a number, some bread and check out the store while you're waiting.

Their prices are reasonable considering they're a small shop and where they're located. A lovely deli to snag some food and sit in the park, best part is that they have mini bottles of wine so you can sit out at the park and really enjoy your food.
author: Morgan M.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewd Molinari's sooner.

It's my go to place for my occasional proscuitto and parmessian fix. 
It's close to home and cheaper than Whole Foods.

Their prepared foods are very good, you can't go wrong .
It's fresh and authentic. Love it !
author: Katherine N.

description: A small delicatessen near Chinatown...definitely worth a visit.  You pick your own bread out of the bread box then you line up.  Well, if it's crowded, take a number first or else you don't get service.  I got the Renzo special with fresh mozzarella and basil spread.  It's absolutely delicious...so good...and fresh.  I might try to recreate their sandwich at Claro's (in Tustin) since I live in SoCal.  But if you are visiting NorCal, don't skip this place if you are in the area.
author: Katie L.

description: Dont get me wrong! The sandwiches are deliciously fresh and tasty.  However I do not like that people get their own rolls in the case.  Doesn't seem the most hygenic to me.  And when I was there yesterday I noticed that after ringing someone up and touching the money, the worker simply then used hand sanitizer gel instead of washing properly with soap and water before making the next sandwich.  Also, when I bit down, there was a hard pebble of a sort in the sandwich, and it hurt like hell.  Coincidentally, I see the health department score of 72 on their yelp site... YIKES!! Given that, I won't be back.
author: Tina K.

description: Super fantastic classic Italian deli. I only with the rest of the food world be like Molinari's - simple, fresh, delicious.
author: John C.

description:
Okay, its cool and I know it's your thing but do I really have to eat bread that four hundred people have fondled? If you don't know let me explain. This place has a long tradition of keeping their bread in a plastic box. Each customer selects they bread which will be made into a sandwich for them. Well let me say that my sausage and pepper sandwich was amazing. This was wickedly delicious and I could have eaten a hundred. Unfortunately, some dude had just wiped his nose with his hand and then proceeded to touch half of the rolls in the box before selecting the one for him. I managed to get one that seemed to be buried enough to miss his germs.

Growing up in a home with real honest to goodness italians in it, I love the grocery goods. I have this fantasy that I will start cooking one day and there is plenty of inspiration on these shelves

One could come in here for imported sauce and fresh pasta. Deli meat sliced in store and some delicious fresh sausage. This place apparently has been here for more then a century and it sure feels like it.
author: Eric G.

description:
I've worked in Telegraph Hill for 2 years and only now do I realize that you can get decently priced Italian sandwiches 3 blocks away? Oy.

I came at 11:50am and there was only one other person in the shop. I could see the place getting potentially crowded later during the lunch rush, but I was pleasantly surprised that I wouldn't have to wait in line.

Thanks to fellow Yelpers, I made sure to pick out my bread beforehand. I ordered the $6.25 Molinari special and it was great. Very hearty sandwich! You can ask them to use a different kind of cheese or substitute some of the add-ons (mayo/mustard/lettuce/etc). They even offer some grilled sando options that sounded good.

For $7.50 I got a huge sandwich, friendly service, and a bag of BBQ potato chips (Kettle brand, my fav). Plus, they have some tables outside if it's a nice day and you want to people watch in North Beach.
author: Hannah L.

description:
If I knew how to speak and swear in Italian I would write this review in Italian.  All I know is Ciao, buon giuorno, and mamma mia (and I don't even know if I even spelled these words correctly).

Anyway, I will resort to good ol'' fashioned English.  This place is amazing.  Their sandwiches are amazing.  The bread is amazing.  The seating is not so amazing.  No other italian deli compares to the delectable sandwiches this place puts out.

Simply Amazing!!
author: Marty L.

description: Great Deli.  Sandwiches are amazing.  Come in, pick your bread, and then they make your sandwiches for you.  There's so much food in there it's overwhelming.  All good quality and delicious.  A great place to stop in, get your picnic lunches made, take with your wherever you spend your day.
author: t d.

description:
Lets just start off by saying that you really can't go wrong with Italian Delicatessens in the traditional sense. By my definition these are places which possess the following: A little old lady in the back making meatballs with her hands - she is usually the mother of the owner (although I did not see her - I know she exists), The shop has too many bottles of chianti (in that most of the price tags are dusty), Service wherein If you don't know Exactlly what you want than don't bother to order. Long lines with numbers and Last but not least - an Amazing Italian Sub (mortadello, salami, provolone ect...) which is not only the best/most recommended/tastiest etc... but also the cheapest.

The only reason I give 4 stars is because its just not quite on par with "Mona Lisa's" in San Diego.
author: Stan W.

description:
Straightforward deliciousness. Bring your appetite. 

 I was glad to have the lowdown from the other reviews on how to navigate this place and shared the info with some confused tourists who were grateful. Thanks, Yelp! 

Now to devour the rest of this gargantuan fresh prosciutto, mozzarella and sun dried tomato sandwich! Sooo tasty!
author: Shannon R.

description:
YUM!!  I'm a fan!  Definitely will be coming back for more. I love the fresh deli sliced meat and the variety of sandwiches that they have. The Molinari special is delicious!  Best part is that  you can grab the sandwich, walk to Washington Square Park, and have a picnic!  

If you want a big, fresh, original sandwich try Molinari Delicatessen, it's so    good!
author: Joanna N.

description:
Score...I had a Wednesday off from work and the sun was actually out creating the rare, but appreciated warm day in San Francisco. I had $20 in my pocket, my bikini and sundress on, a towel and the newest issues of at least three gossip magazines. Washington Square park was on the mind...

But I was hungry...

Not like, "Meh...I could eat." More like, I was HUNGRY...ravinous, starving...you know, like the Italian level of hungry. You know what I'm talking about, there are different degrees of hunger and Italian is the highest. This is the time you know you are willing to drop 10 bones on a sandwich as long as it cures what you've got goin' on.

So on my quick jaunt down the hill to the park, I b-lined for Molinari's Deli. Inside the store makes you feel like you are in some tiny little tuscan village market, picking up your groceries for the day. They have a large assortment of cheeses, pastas, crackers, bread, salami, olives, wines, cookies etc for taking home to cook. But in the back, they have a sandwich counter and deli salads/pastas for take-away. 

I ordered up the caprese sand-o with mozzerella, tomatoes, fresh basil, roasted peppers etc on garlic foccacia bread. The guy behind the counter gave me a taste of a few salads and I selected some shrimp tortelli to accompany my sandwich. The last five days of hitting the gym were going to make this lunch's guilt factor melt away...I was not messing around. 

I took this masterpiece with two beers and posted up in the park for the next few hours to catch the warm summertime rays. Despite my afore mentioned hunger, I still could only put back half of this gigantic sandwich. It was fragrant and spicy and cheesy and fresh and everything good. Do yourself a favor and hit up Molinari's next time you decide to make a picnic in the park. You will not be sad you did.

Small disclaimer, if you are a young female, be prepared to be oogled and hit on by the entire Molinari's staff. Don't stress though, it's all in fun and they mean no harm. Take it as a compliment and try to hustle an extra free sample from it...

Ciao bella, manga manga!!
author: Lynsey C.

description:
Yes! I have found my DELI!  Went and ate for the first time yesterday and it was delicious!  They have a range of meat to choose from as well as specialty sandwich that have already been tried and true!  Don't even get me started on the pasta salads and italian goodies.
  Another great thing about this place is you can buy ravioli or fresh pasta!  I will be trying that sooner than later.
author: Natalie L.

description:
Love Molinari's.
Amazing Sandwiches
Always grab their homemade lasagna's, pastas, raviolis.
Llove all their imported stuff from Italy.
An SF instituion.
author: TravelBug W.

description: We eat Molinari ravioli every year for Christmas. They are that special to our family and truly that delicious.
author: Elise S.

description: Very tasty.  We arrived around 1:45pm on a weekday and waited about 20 minutes to have our deli sandwiches made.  The bread, cheese and vegetables were super fresh and delicious, making the wait totally worth it.  You select your own bread for the sandwich out of the bin, we just missed the last piece of focaccia, so can't comment on its quality, but the breads were very good.
author: Paul D.

description: Best Deli around. Fist stop for me on our way to the ski slopes in Lake Tanoe. Last stop for me on the way to SFO Airport for a flight.
author: Terry K.

description:
I eat here frequently. When you get there you grab a number and wait for it to be called- warning going during peak hours can have you waiting for a long time. Next you pick your bread from the basket or you can go with the focaccia that they keep behind the counter (which I recommend trying). They have several other goodies in the store for you to buy as well: cheeses, chips, salads, drinks, etc. There are many sandwich options or you can create your own. One of the most popular is the Molinari special- a combo of cold cuts, condiments, and cheese. I have tried a few different ones, but I always seem to go back to salami & provolone plain. I love being able to taste just the meat and the cheese. Their salami is outstanding. I sometimes buy of stick of it to bring to parties and when I do it always goes quickly. They do have a couple of tables out front, but this is more of a grab & go place. So go, grab, enjoy.    

For the full story & pictures, please visit my blog:
http://consumingcolumbus.blogspot.com/2013/01/mouthwatering-molinari.html
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Grab number, grab loaf of bread, order awesome sandwich.  Fresh bread comes from nearby, and the meats here are fabulous.  North beach is notorious for their sandwich spots, and this no-frills deli definitely competes.  Sometimes I'm in the meed for a designer sando, but a classic italian or another one of their menu offerings pretty much always hits the spot.  They've also got a solid selection of cheeses and other products that you may need to get your hands on if you make a stop by.
author: William B.

description:
Grab a number, grab a roll and then shop. They have good wines for a fare price, nice olive oils & cheeses, a lovely selection of regional Italian foods and yummy meats.

My favorite sando is the chicken cutlet. 

One thing I can't recommend is the fresh pasta. The linguine was dry and the ravioli was too heavy for my taste.
author: Paige B.

description:
Sandwiches are great.

Problem with the service.  it's too crowded on Saturday, the only day i can go given my work location/schedule.  the staff should be more accommodating to locals.  they have a business card to call in for takeout orders, but when you call, they say "too busy in store-- cannot make to go orders".  translation:  they don't give a f**k.  if you don't take care of your neighborhood repeat customers, then your venturing down an eventually inevitable path.  i would definitely stop by every Saturday if it would take less than a 30 minute wait for my sandwich, but ballers don't have that kinda time!
author: eshwar k.

description: Although I live down here in San Diego I have to tell you, when we visit San Fran this is the place we grab our sandwiches at. It's a nice spot to go to that's for sure. I wish San Diego had a place like this.
author: George D.

description: This place is amazing. Staff was friendly and fun and they made a killer meatball sandwich for my son. A must visit on your trip to North Beach!
author: Steven D.

description: Nvm bout the toasting! u can ask for your sandwich to get toasted! but still a lil bit of a wait! been back quite frequently for their Italian Special!
author: Bruce L.

description: Take a step into Little Italy for a second. Everything is authentic & delicious. Their sandwiches are the type you wouldnt mind having everyday. And they make these handmade pumpkin ravioli that are SO tasty! Enjoy!
author: Brianne K.

description:
Old school style deli.
Imported items you wont find else where.
One of the best corned beef sandwich's I've had anywhere.
Went by over the Labor Day weekend,closed..... Dam it!!
author: William D.

description:
Here's how eating at Molinari's works:

1.) Before anything, grab a # from the ticket dispensing unit. Some people stand around looking confused at why people who show up get served while they wait around getting cut in line. Simple. You need a number, you dolt.
2.) Grab the bread you want from the big box. Please use the tongs, you sloth.
3.) Order your sandwich from the menu of options. I recommend the italian combo if you're new...you doof. (seriously who hasn't been to an Italian deli before?)
4.) Specify what you want on it. "Everything" here is lettuce, tomatoes, mustard, mayo, onions, pickles, and pepperoncini. I forgot that last one, and as a result I am spending my time picking pepperoncinis out of my delish-o-wich.
5.) Pay (duh)
6.) Smile (*optional...and encouraged*)
7.) Say thank you (unless you're an ahole)
8.) Leave (duh)

"Lets flip the track, bring the old school back (this is how we do it) ..."

thought a bit of musical training would reinforce how "we** do it"

**please note I am not even Italian. I am Chinese. But "we" refers to the people who know. the people who rock.

p.s. Their cheese ravioli is awesome. Drop in boiling water, when it floats, pull it out. Pour on some stove heated sauce (also purchased here) and bam. A good, simple, delicious meal.
author: Aaron F.

description: This has become a tradition for me. Anytime friends of family come to the city and they want to go to north beach, for lunch, to get a real taste of little Italy I bring them here. I can honestly say i have had all their specialty sammies and they are all killer. Messy at times if you get the roasted peppers in it, which you should. Honestly do yourself a favor, on a sunny day get the North Beach a bit of salami cut, maybe some cheese if you feel so inclined, go down to the liquor store get beer wine whatever, walk over to washington square sit out eat relax and enjoy that moment, its simple rare, and you'll thank me later.
author: Sean MC E.

description:
My goodness.  I'm surprised I didn't find this place earlier.  You walk in and the sheer freshness and smells of Italy hit you!  BAM!  Take a whiff..prosciutto, salami, cheeses, pasta, fresh bread, sun-dried tomatoes...take it all in.

Love this place.  Definitely, if you want to cook some fine, Italian food at home you'll want to get your ingredients here.  I had some of their special Italian sandwiches and wow.  My blood pressure shot up, but it was totally worth the high sodium intake.
author: Yup S.

description: Awesome place! The sandwiches are huge and packed with delicious meat. They are worth every minute of waiting in long line. People seem to love this place during lunch. Surprise
author: Try E.

description:
Sandwich with ...Prosciutto, Sun Dried Tomatoes & Provalone,,,,you actually pick your bread which is , well awesome. Gosh the bread is good. Someone there actually made it and made it well. I just know the flour for the bread is milled & made by hand.  I can't describe this place. Everything was real. Not Organic real, but real real. Hard to explain.
I actually got my best friend to walk in with me on a recommendation but it wasn't comfortable at the moment, was raining & cold, maybe no place to sit & relax I think? Catholic like metal chairs that are uncomfortable? Anyhow, this incredibly simple, old school authentic Italian sandwich shop / Deli is a genuine slice of heaven. 

The place is jammed packed with cheeses and meats and what not but I don't know much about it so I just kept it simple and it worked.

Just try it. I stopped by on my trip back to the hotel,,I somehow ended up near the Piers lost and then North Beach? then the Italian area with the cool park...and alas I was right in front.  

Anyhow.  

BEST Authentic Italian delicatessen I could possibly imagine here in the States.

 Five Stars for old world simplicity.
author: rudy a.

description:
Mmmm...the sandwiches are so fresh and so good. A little reminiscent of the paninis in Rome. Portions are pretty hefty so good enough to split between two. Shared the Luciano on focaccia with proscuitto and fresh mozzarella for about $10, which gave a euphoric glimpse of what the Elysian Fields would be like. 

Just be prepared to wait around 20-30 min if you go there on a Saturday afternoon. Also, there's no seating...it's pretty much a grab and go, save for a few tables outside. Definitely worth the wait though, and it's close to Washington Square park!
author: Miriam K.

description: These sandwiches are way beyond what a sandwich should be. I always believed that the bread makes the sandwich, and being in San Francisco, the bread at Molinari Deli definately makes the sandwich. We make special stops when we visit SF just to get a sandwich. Be prepared to be thirsty the rest of the day because the sandwiches are salty with all the meats, but it's worth it.
author: Jillian O.

description: I wish there was a place like this in every neighborhood in SF. This place just gets it.  The old SF sourdough, fresh cut meats. It is well worth the walk up Columbus for these sandwiches. I almost don't want to review this place and give it 5 stars- it is always usually packed at lunch!
author: Jim B.

description:
I thank Yelpers for guiding me through the ordering process at this place... Otherwise, I would've been standing in front of the counter like a fool waiting for someone to grab a piece of bread for me.  I consider this my "special" sub shop and only go here when I am 1) a hungry beast ready to devour a mountain of salami and 2) willing to shell out good money for a sandwich.  Although some of the food here is pricey, you absolutely get what you pay for, and the quality of the ingredients shines through in the subs.  The mozzarella is particularly amazing... it is a must try!!

Guys behind the counter are friendly and take their time making the perfect lunchtime treat for you.  Bottom line: go here NOW and gnaw on some of the best salami that this city has to offer!!!
author: Christy L.

description: Didnt meet my high expectation! considering the wonderful reviews here. Picking your own bread is not a good idea because anybody can just touch the bin and not monitor by anybody...their most expensive and signature sandwiches are not something I will remember, i rather have the italian sub which is good...ahh just dissapointed and i hope not to come back here.
author: Noel O.

description: This is probably the best sandwich I have ever had. I was just visiting San Francisco and I decided to try this place. I got the siciliano and the service was really great too.
author: Robbie P.

description: Molinari special is the sandwich to order.  If you are feeling frisky add some hot coppa.
author: Mike I.

description:
I finally got a chance to try Molinari the other day, after reading all these fantastic reviews on Yelp.  Personally, I don't think that a sandwich has the capacity to knock my socks off--it's essentially just bread and meat.  However, for what Molinari does, they do pretty damn well.  I think the sandwiches are awesome for a couple reasons:  (1) there really is a difference in flavor (even if it's just in your head) when the deli meat is freshly-sliced to order; and (2) the improvement in flavor exponentially increases when said sandwich contains a whole hell of a lot of that freshly-sliced meaty goodness.

After a long urban hike, this sandwich really hit the spot.  I haven't tried their cheeses and meats, but I'll definitely be hitting up this place next time I need appetizers!
author: Alexis N.

description: Friendly, and opinionated, staff. Good sandwiches. FYI:  the North Beach is tastier than the South Beach.
author: Moira T.

description:
There is really something to be said for a place that does a handful of things absolutely perfectly as opposed to a place that attempts a myriad of things and falls short half of the time.  This type of place is commonly staffed or owned by people called Artisans.  This place is full of these people, and they make an amazing sandwich.  Run, don't walk.

The Caprese (my death row meal) Sandwich is heaven.  You pick your bread, they do the rest.  Excellently.  And they have little Baci chocolates, the best palate cleanser after a meal I'm aware of.
author: Joseph W.

description:
Wow- these sandwiches were fantastic---very very fresh, very much a local deli feel--very authentic. Sandwich was big enough to be filling but not to leave me uncomfortably full afterward. 

A word to my veggie friends, I can eat meat, but  I ordered the vegetarian Joe's Special- which had provolone, garlic pesto, roasted red bell peppers, and sundried tomatoes. And my GOD it was delicious--it definitely packed in the flavor. Service was good, and overall plus. Only thing that kept from a 5-star rating is that it takes a long time during lunch. 
But you know, one can't really complain because the sandwich tasted GREAT.
author: Elle C.

description: Moved here a year ago from NJ and fell in love with this place, reminds me of the east coast sandwich shops.  They pile the meat high and are extremely courteous.  Last time we went when they were about to close and we sat outside with our dog.  One of the workers randomly came out with a few slices of roast beef for my dog, which he practically inhaled.  Great selection of meats and cheeses, and great workers!
author: Jill S.

description: If you like only meat and cheese on your sandwich, go for the Renzo special. Otherwise I recommend the Molinari Special. Try the Pesto Pasta salad too.
author: dean d.

description: I have been going here literally since I was a baby. My family and I come here every Xmas eve morning to get all the delicious fresh meats, cheeses and wines. Despite the line being out the door, the staff is always friendly and patient. Their sandwiches are to die for!!
author: Melody T.

description: You must be willing to wait, and I mean wait! We were in line fore over an hour. But the service was great, and the unique selection of Italian items was well worth it. We purchased 2 sandwiches, some prosciutto, and baçala. If you enjoy any of this, a visit here is a must!
author: Joe F.

description:
We rode our bikes here for lunch today from SOMA and did -not- expect there to be so long of a queue! Hint for newbs: grab a ticket as soon as you get in instead of waiting 5 minutes like us! Molinari's has a very "old world" feel, as my coworker described it. Jam-packed with food-stuff, paintings, maps of italy, cheese displays, fresh bread, antiques -- it's really quite an experience.

On to the food! There were several sandwiches that looked good (like the North Beach Special), but I ultimately decided that I wanted something with meat in it and settled on the meatball sub. What a sub! Huge meatballs cut in half just to fit, delicious marinara sauce, and tasty bread. Molinari's has done the impossible by replacing Valentino's (Cleveland) meatball sub as my favorite.
author: Adam D.

description:
I've had a few sandwiches here over the years. My favorite is a variation on the North Beach Special. I like prosciutto, red onion, provolone, and oil and vinegar on a roll. The North Beach Special is prosciutto, sun dried tomato, marinated bell pepper and provolone on a roll. Nice sandwich, but the sun dried tomato is a little much with the more delicate prosciutto.

The unquenchable Nortth Beach Special thirst is almost worse than the unquenchable pepperoni thirst.

Next time: my variation on the North Beach Special, or their veggie one with artichoke hearts, sun dried, cheese and stuff. 

Nice old San Francisco establishment. I hope the neighborhood continues to treat them well.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: i'm ready to go back...now.  small italian grocery that makes killer sandwiches.  take a number system keeps the crowd sane.  staff is polite and efficient.  take a number, pluck the bread you want out of bin, present it to your deli counter staffer and request the sandwich off the menu board on the wall.  drinks in the cooler behind you.  a couple of small tables on the side walk, but mostly a grab and go kind of place.  the locals know about this one
author: Howard B.

description:
What can you say about a business that survived the great quake of 1906 & has an almost cult-like following?  

"Two 3lb dry salami's please!"
     "Alright, anything else?"
"Ooh, & some pecorino too!"
     "Okay, that'll be..."
"Wait, I want some crackers too."
     "Alright then..."
"Which of these wines would go better with the salami?"
     "Definitely the chianti, a little dry & not too sweet."
"Cool!  Thanks."

As for the salami?  They dry cure it themselves as attested by the baseball bat shapes hanging from the ceiling.  Salty, porky, chewy goodness tastes great with pecorino or whatever moves you.  They also make a great thank you gift for pooch-sitting as well as a pick-pocket deterrent [thwack!].  Just don't show up on a Sunday because you forgot that one last item because that's the day they go to church, you know.
author: Cam T.

description: The sliced Genoa salami is amazing.  Since my wife has a full blooded Grandpa from Italy, she has grown up knowing good authentic Italian food and Molinari's has it all.  They are a must stop anytime we go into the city.
author: Brian N.

description: Luciano Special is one of the best sandwiches I've ever eaten. Love the feel of this place.
author: Andy D.

description:
Prosciutto.
Focaccia.
Fresh mozzarella.
Put them together with olive oil.
Me likey.
author: Kev M.

description: My family swears that the meat to pasta shell ratio is perfect.  Not too much, not too little...so, we make the trek out to the city to get our ravioli to go with our homemade pesto. the guys are really nice and you can call-in orders in advance.  the hours on yelp are incorrect. they said they open at 9am, but id call ahead to check.
author: Nicole D.

description: My favorite deli by far! They have the best sandwiches here. They work with a local baker so the bread is brought in fresh everyday and you go choose your roll and give it to them and they make you the sandwich or your choice. I have had both the south beach and north beach sandwiches and they are both so good ! Try to come before he lunch hour craze because it gets crowded.
author: Ani A.

description:
I crave deli sandwiches almost as much as I crave pizza.  I have recently moved to North Beach and have so much exploring to do, but this was one of the best recent discoveries I have made.  The bread is amazing and fresh.  I have tried both house salami and the turkey with basil garlic pesto and fresh mozzarella (good riddens, that one was delish!) The staff is friendly and quick which ensures that I will be enjoying their creation in a short time.

There are a few tables outside for seating, and it is great to people watch and munch on your sammie.  It is a must if you are in the area! mmmm my mouth is watering.
author: Katie H.

description:
I love Molinari's! 

It's one of my favorite places to eat in the city. The sandwiches are awesome and their deli meats, cheeses, et al are amazing.
author: David C.

description: Really great deli with fresh deli meats and professional service. Breads are fresh with great options. Variety of cheese is like the icing on the cake for me. Secret: I buy the Ravioli serve as the main entree when I am entertaining guests at my home and I tell them I made it from scratch.  Of course they are impressed.
author: Travis S.

description:
Do, do you have some fresh-sliced meat handy?
Do, do you know how much i like provolone cheese?

Are-are-are you patient for the mustard, hold the mayonnaise
Cause I might need some time to fill the hole in my stomach and I

I've tried every sub deli
Nothing seems to work for me

Baby, your special subs are driving me crazy
And I really wanna not be so lazy
But Molinari's makes me want their 

sandwich
their sandwich

And I thought I'd yelp to let you know

My heart for a sandwich, a sandwich
And they can make it wonderful. 

So ... how you gonna fix it, fix it, fix it?

:)
author: Brad C.

description:
Molinari's, unfortunately, goes the way of Victoria Pastry for me. Obviously, it's got the history, and therefore some cred. They do actually have Italian import goodies in there, but much of it appears 40 years old. I do dig the floor-to-ceiling decor. But overall, a disappointing tourist trap of the North Beach variety. 

The thing is, the sandwiches just aren't great. Maybe it's me, but I don't enjoy bloodying the roof of my mouth with a stale white roll that is 80% crust. Not to mention, if you don't pick that roll out of the bread bin before they call your number, they will skip right over your ass. And inevitably, you'll have number 61, and a large family of fatassed Nebraskans who try to talk to the counter guys in what they perceive to be Italian (both counter guys are 3rd generation American, FYI), will have number 59. And because you realize it's going to take all freaking day for them to get their eight pounds of prosciutto, you procrastinate in picking your stale roll out of the bin. Then all of a sudden they call your number and you're screwed. 

So let's say you actually have your bread ready to go when they call you, and you hand it over and ask for salami and swiss with everything. Because the "salami will blow your mind," so what else would you get? So it takes them about ten seconds to slap together your "mind-blowing" sandwich, which consists of the aforementioned salami, pre-sliced limp cheese, iceberg lettuce, tomato, French's yellow mustard and a few pepperoncini shavings, and you hand over $6.00 for the privilege of bloodying your gums on their stale bread. 


P.S. Their oily salami does not "blow my mind."
author: Megan W.

description:
My husband works in Nortbeach and goes here for lunch often. A few days ago I was in the area and stopped by to get a sandwich and it was great. This place is such a cute little Italian specialty shop. 

I don't know what else they offer besides meats, cheeses, wine, pasta, etc. But a woman was in there who was a regular and she was asking for a ton of stuff. She even asked if they had the stuffing for their raviolis which they did so she got a bunch. 
 
If I didn't love my neighborhood so much I would want to live in Northbeach (only if I had a garage of course, it's like the worst place in the city to find parking). There are so many shops and restaurants...If I lived there I would probably go to Molinari's more.
author: Kimberly H.

description: This place has awesome cured meats and sandwiches.  It's like walking into a deli in Italy.  I had an unbelievable sandwich with prosciutto, coppa, mozzarella, and sun-dried tomatoes. The sweetness of the sun-dried tomatoes went perfectly with the salty meats and creamy mozzarella.  There may be a little wait while other customers are helped, but don't worry because they will give you that same attentive service.
author: Amanda O.

description: I had such a unique and cool experience at this place when I stopped by for lunch on a Saturday. You have to pick a number and select your own bread then wait your turn and have them make you a customized sandwich right in front of you. I ordered a veggie sandwich and my friend a turkey sandwich. We were both very happy with what we got. And the portion is more than enough (both of us had the other half of the sandwich left for dinner!). My friend and I were also lucky to get one of only 3-4 tables outside the deli. So it became an even more cool experience, eating our sandwiches while sitting outside, watching people and cars pass by. This is one of those places you should definitely try in San Francisco.
author: Kelly P.

description: Great place to get salami as gifts or just to eat yourself.  Their sandwiches are also amazing.  Staff is always really friendly and helpful.
author: Brent S.

description:
When I used to work in North Beach a few years ago, I would go here at least 3 times a week. The sandwiches are divine. They carry fresh tortellini that is so delicate; it melts in your mouth. 
Molinari pasta, cold cuts and salami are always a hit on the table or at parties.
The staff is friendly and helpful. Just remember if you are coming here for the first time, head towards the counter to get a number so you are not staring at the ceiling waiting to be helped.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Many memorable picnics have begun at Molinari's!  

It would be impossible to find a better, more authentic Italian deli in San Francisco... Molinari's has a superb selection of cheeses, sausages, cured meats, and delicacies from Italy.   

You want a perfect deli sandwich?  You'll find it here.  They also have great salads, pickles, olives, and prepared meals that you just need to reheat.  Also, excellent selection of beverages.
author: Bevy M.

description:
I got a haircut at Chong's (cheap and good at $10) up the street on Kearney between Vallejo and Green and decided to celebrate with lunch! I anxiously strolled into Molinari's Delicatessen and read the big board and figured out the system.  

As tourists stand by dumbstruck trying to decide, here's how the whole thing works. It is simple. Grab a number. Do it no matter what. Figure out what you want - there's a North Beach Special Sandwich there which is wonderful. Go to the bread bin opposite the meat case and select your bread. Use the tongs - what are you, an animal?

When Mister Man calls your number and asks you 'whaddaya want' Soprano-style, you counter with your memorized answer and give him the bread you've selected. Hopefully, the sandwich will include their outrageously tasty sun-dried tomatoes and peppers. Just typing that made me weak in the knees.

While your sandwich is being created, go to the refrigerated case and get your drink. I got a Vitamin Water. Order something else to go with your sandwich. I got 1/4 pint of mozzarella/tomato salad which is my favorite. Oops I think I just drooled.

They take credit cards, debit cards and cash. It is at this point that you can marvel at the fact that all this will cost you around $12 or $13 - and if weather permits, you can eat outside and watch trippy North Beach go by. Cheap food of exceptional quality - PLUS cheap entertainment. 

How can you go wrong? You can't.  Cheaper and just as authentic as lotsa places in New York's Little Italy. Actually, there's no comparison because we're saving ourselves airfare and other transportation costs. Plus, we're not dealing with the airport's righteous TSA idiots. Here, you can eat well AND you can keep your shoes on.
author: Van D.

description: best Italian sandwich in the city
author: David S.

description:
I looooove their Salami! They package it so cutely! I dream of heading over to Molinari with a picnic basket and walking over to Washington Square to enjoy some bread, cheese, and salami on a sunny day.

I had the turkey, provolone, artichoke hearts, sun dried tomatoes and garlic herb sandwich the first time and it was delish. I also love that they carry San Bennedetto Blood orange soda, it takes me back to Italy everytime...
author: Valerie A.

description:
Meat, cheese, meat, cheese, and more meat.... my favorite. 

walk in get your number, grab a piece of bread and have them make one of the best italian sandwiches you'll ever have. 

Part of my SF walking tour, or "first date" place, Grab a sandwich, a orangina and walk up to coit tower and picnic with the views of the bay bridge. So good....
author: Roy L.

description:
When I first went to Molinari's ~ I was but a wee thing whose nose barely cleared the low counter where they wrap your purchases in butcher paper. It was part of the Italian food trail.

My sister and I were led there by our Zia Lena who dragged us on a shopping brigade to prepare for another one of the fabulous feasts that my two Zias so lovingly prepared for the entire famiglia. Or just for us two, as the case may be. My older Zias (great aunts) used to watch my sister and I quite a bit and Zia Lena would take us on the Italian food circuit that at the time included many places no longer here -- a bakery on Green that specialized in very large hand-formed grissini (breadsticks) from a stone oven, then after Cuneos bakery (still here), a deli nearby that had amaretti cookies (so chewy and sweet) in a big bin, obscure shops for semoina flour, and the Ligurian bakery for focaccia (also still here). These were necessary items especially for large family reunions where lots of appetizers were necessary.

We came to Molinaris for the salami (and other cold cuts), prosciutto, and teleme cheese (very nice smeared on a grissini).

It's still here, and this alone is a good thing...still making excellent sandwiches, serving up a fair sample of deli items and stocking numerous odd imported items. It's not as authentic and excellent as it once was--but it's still quite wonderful. 

I bought a bag load of items for a party we had yesterday--a large stuffed bag--proscuitto, grissini, teleme, focaccia, provolone, one flat of the cheese ravioli and a lb of olives--all for 57 bucks. Not bad at all.

The cheese ravioli used to have nutmeg in the pasta casing--very nice--then the last time I had them they didn't (no nutmeg). I asked the guy at the counter and he seemed to be saying they still did, but I won't know until I cook this batch up. We'll see.

**update (10/16): no nutmeg...I knew he didn't get what I was saying (alas--i loved the old style cheese ravioli--that explains one less star) Wait I can't give Molinari's 3 stars. I love Molinaris--there take back that 4th star.
author: Liza B.
