description: We trusted our Yelp friends and they were right!  Showed up early for lunch, picked out our bread and got two italian special sandwiches.  Delish!  Really great sandwiches.  We would definitely go back again.  Nothing better than a good italian deli sandwich.  YUM.
author: D C.

description:
Wow.  Molinari is the best Italian deli I've found in San Francisco-- by far.  The selection and quality of their deli meats is unparalleled.  My friend (L.Y.) and I got two sandwiches to split: the Italian combo and the Renzo.  Each sandwich was piled so high with MEAT that I was shocked they were only $7 and $8.50 respectively.  Coppa, prosciutto, genoa, soppressata, toscana, provolone, mozzarella, sun-dried tomatoes, pepperoncini.  There was an astounding amount of meat and accoutrements on those sandwiches.  

Also, the wonderful sandwich maker was very patient with the two of us as we wavered back and forth between our countless meaty options.  He even took care to put mustard on only one half of the Italian we split because I am horrifically afraid of mustard (we shall save this story for another time...).

My only complaint about Molinari, and it's a small grievance, is their roll selection.  But that's not even enough reason to cost them 1 star.  Being from Philadelphia, I much prefer the long submarine roll to the short, thick rolls that they offer at Molinari.

While I might go back to Marina Submarine for their meatball subs and because it's so close to my home, I'll be choosing Molinari over Lucca's from now on as my go-to Italian delicatessen.
author: Erin L.

description:
The people here are so friendly and knowledgeable.  It gives off a really nice feel.  A little small for my comfort especially when it gets busy, but it's a great delicatessen.  Be sure to get a number and the wait is not long.  They are eager to help you and guide you.

We came here for a quick bite and decided to get the Luciano Special.  They freshly sliced the meat and put a very very generous helping into the foccacia bread.  It was accompanied by fresh Mozzarella, Sun-dried Tomatoes, Onions, Prosciutto, and a thin slice of Lettuce.  Minimal healthy stuff! Just the way I like it! O=) I know I will die of a heart attack soon but at least I died happy! lol  The sandwich was huge, but too me it wasn't anything too special.  Don't get me wrong, it was flavorful but it wasn't anything out of the ordinary.  

They had a fully loaded meat case on one side and cheeses displayed on the other.  We asked about the meats because there were some that we didn't recognize and he immediately gave us a slice to try.  Then we decided on getting salami and asked which one he recommended.  He got so excited and said he had the perfect one... immediately pulled it out of the case and sliced 2 beautiful slices for us to try.  We got 1/2 lb and the meat was so beautifully sliced and positioned on the paper.  I took photos! O=)

The service was great and I had to tip them for making the experience so much better.
author: Kat L.

description: I drive all the way from Santa Rosa to Molinari's for their amazing salami's and cheese's! Great customer service, they will let you try anything to make sure you like it before you buy, and the authentic Italian atmosphere is great! It's so worth the drive, because the smack on the way back is awesome!
author: Bri N.

description:
yum. yum. yum.  Had to wait (like other customers said), but boy was it worth it!  The sandwiches were outstanding -- just what i was expecting from North Beach.  This is the real deal.  Had two of their specials.  

Also, the calamari salad -- which I actually never even got to taste, because everytime I asked my husband if it was good, he just looked at me and kept on eating -- finally, I figured out I wasn't going to get a try -- it was that good.  The orzo, feta, sun-dried tomato salad was delicious.

The only drawback is the seating. Just a few tables outside on the street -- they were dirty, but oh well.  

The prices are good (reasonable, in fact, more than reasonable for the size of the sandwiches).

Again, yum!!!!
author: Jack D.

description:
Molinaris has a lot going for it:

1.  Location right in the epicenter of North Beach.
2.  History - Been in Biz since 1896?  I wonder what it was like then. 
3.  Ambience - has that old school hanging salami thing going for it.
4.  Thriving (surviving?) in a town where most italian deli's generally have no clue. 

The only bad thing I can really say about it is that it ain't NY.  Growing up on italian deli's that were owned and operated by people that looked and acted like real life soprano's, I've seen and tasted better.  Not because they looked and acted like sopranos silly, because they knew how to do italian food.  This isn't a knock on the place, it's just the facts.  Bada bing bada boom.  

Regardless of what it ain't I still think it's one of the better places to grab a sandwich in all of SF.
author: chris o.

description: Like most, I suppose, when you say Molinari, you speak of Francesco & Edoardo Molinari. Solid pro golfers. Had no idea until a friend sent me a bunch of cured delights in some box: Molinari was so much more! So good.
author: D. R.

description:
You gotta check out the Hormel proscuitto they have in the window display. Prosciutto in a CAN!? It looks like a fucking tennis racket. In fact the entire window display is pretty cool. It's like a time capsule and I doubt anyone has changed it since first arranging it.

The sandwiches kick ass but don't come up to the counter without picking out your bread first.
author: Josua P.

description:
Awesome sausage sandwich with peppers and onions!

They also have an excellent selection of Italian groceries from fresh pasta to cured meats.
author: Thel D.

description:
I have been coming in here for years and Just took my cousin over here 
 when I go to an Italian Deli I have to get a Salami Sand I love Molinari's 
 Salami. My cousin had the meat ball which he said was good as well.

Eating here is really just about the people watching from the tourist to tha homeless sista doing her thing on the corner. It takes al kinds what do ya expect it"s tha city.
author: Kim R.

description: the sandwiches are ok less meat than I would like. so I suggest buy the meat and chesse and bread  separate and throw it together yourself . it would cost about the same but a lot more meat and chesse..
author: Nellie J.

description:
"The passion of the Italian or the Italian-American population is endless for food and lore and everything about it." 
~Mario Batali

Molinari!!! molto magnifico!! molto impressionante!!!  The passion of the Italian people come to life in the salamis and the copas, and every other cured meats hanging above and in their deli counter!  Franco behind the counter was awesome, he knew what was great, and he has not steered us wrong so far!  This place has been a permanent fixture in the North Beach district of SF, and although I've been practically raised on the streets of SF, Molinari wasn't one of my stops.  It wasn't until the summer of this year that the gf took me there for the first time, and man like the salami's hanging over the counter, I was hooked!!!  This time out I got a pound of the spicy salami, and the finnochiona, and half a pound of copa and prosciutto... The two types of salami we got before, so I knew exactly what kind of shenanigan I was getting into with those.  The copa was peppery and so flavorful!! I could probably eat the whole thing in one sitting!!!  The Prosciutto melted in my mouth like buttah!! There isn't enough words in the English dictionary that can describe how wonderful this place is... maybe it's time I invest in an Italian dictionary!
author: Eric T.

description:
There's just something about this place.  I don't know what it is.  Oh wait, yeah, I do.  It's that it's an Italian deli.  OTHER things I love about Molinari?:

-- Picking out my own bread out of the bread box
-- The sun-dried tomatoes & peppers
-- The sandwiches are good but are probably not nearly as good as the deli meats and cheeses
-- The fact that one time I saw one of the employees slip an old seemingly senile man in a well-fitting suit speaking Italian a free sandwich
-- Being close to Washington Square Park

It's places like this that make me wanna call up my NYC-residing sister and be like "Our Little Italy kicks your Little Italy's ass.  Yeah, we rock, you suck, neenerneenerneener".  Then I remember a) Brooklyn b) Mario Batali and c) we're not 12.
author: Jack S.

description:
Without question, the best Italian Deli in San Francisco.  The commandments:

1.  Thou shall select your own roll from the bin
2.  Thou shall order the Renzo's Special
3.  Thou shall honor thy old deli manager and order promptly when the store is busy.
4.  Thou shall take a friend with you to snag an outdoor table while you order.
5.  Thou shall enjoy people-watching while the multi-national crowd swarms North Beach.
6.  Thou shall also order home-made tortellini and cook it thyself for dinner.
author: Ari G.

description: The south beach sandwich (turkey, artichokes, sun dried tomatoes, garlic spread)... now THAT'S a deli sandwich. Awesome.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
HOLY @#$#!!! THIS PLACE IS AWESOME!!! 

My friend told me about this place so while i was in SF today, so i decided to try and find this famed deli. I jumped into a cab and headed for the North Beach District but it was funny that i didn't know what street it was on or how to spell the deli's name!!! Of course i yelped and found the address and just in time. It was raining today but that definitely didn't deter me from getting one of these famous sammy's!! 

The place is a small hidden gem right on the corner of vallejo and columbus street. There are very few places as charming as this delicatessen and man do they have one hell of a sandwich. So the first thing i did was take in how authentic italian this market was. Second, the menu board had some key stand out items as well. FRESH PROCHUTTO, MEATBALLS! EGGPLANT PARM, CHICKEN PARM, ETC!!! OH MAN IM IN HEAVEN! 

I actually was in the mood for a combo, so i grab my roll from the bin,  ordered the South Beach Special which was: Turkey, Pesto, provalone, artichokes, sundried tomatoes!! And i added Prochutto and Pepperchini's!! AMAZING!!! After i paid, i took my sammy to one of the out door small tables and dived right in. It was a symphony of flavors! BRAVO MOLINARIS! I WILL BECOMING BACK FOR MORE!!!
author: Rob G.

description: Clean, neat, delicious, real sandwiches.  The bread is soft, the cheese and meat are fresh.  Not much more I could ask for, not much more I could say.
author: Ashley S.

description: This is a great market to shop and eat at. If you like meats and cheeses, then you need to try this place.
author: Tracy R.

description: Its a classic institution, I mean if Bourdain goes on it, lets be real. Anyway, I had the Molinari special of the day and it was great.  I rec. oil and vinegar on any sando too.
author: Drew W.

description: The process is very simple: take a number, choose your bread, make the selection and step aside. Within minutes, Mangia! An Italian Countryside explodes in your mouth. And although the "soup nazi-esque" procedure left something to be desired, these gut bombs will make your mamma cry. I chose the "Renzo's Special" on Sweet Italian with a mountain of prosciutto and hot coppa, accompanied by bufala mozzarella, basil, sun dried tomatoes, and sweet peppers. If a picture speaks a thousand words, then this one is saying "eat me"--500 times.
author: Justin P.

description:
Love the sandwiches, and I've never spent more than 7 bucks there (sandwich and a coke).  The bread is not mega amazing, which is what keeps it from getting a 5th star (well, that and they don't have speck).  Don't get me wrong, the bread is very good, but living in SF makes you a bread snob weather you like it or not.  

The meats are very tasty, and they don't skimp on the portions.  Just a great lunch option.
author: Steve G.

description:
Pure Italian goodness! 

Molinari's is decked out in all things Italian. They have an awesome selection of meats, cheeses, breads like fresh foccacia, wines, etc. But their bread and butter (no pun intended) are their sandwiches. They have a vast selection of extraordinary sandwiches and from what I have heard, they are all spectacular!

Today was my first time there and although I ordered a chicken parmesan sandwich, I regret not trying one of their many cold sandwiches. The reason I say this is because like most chicken parmesan sandwiches from a quit serve deli, they basically just nuke this sandwich to heat it up. It was still a tasty meal, but after I saw the sandwiches my friends ordered, I did have some regret on getting something like them. Regardless, the chicken parmesan was pretty good. My only complaint was how quickly the bread got soggy. Perhaps I shouldn't have picked out such a soft roll. Oh, well, next time...

I will definitely try one of the cold sandwiches the next time I go because each of my friends who ate there today said their sandwiches were fantastic!

I have a feeling the next time I eat here, I will update my review with a 5/5.
author: Jason B.

description: Talk about an authentic Italian deli! Had the Italian Combo here and was quite happy. Made to order and can be customized from the bread you choose and so much more. They also sell ravioli and other cooking needs such as olive oil. The potato salad  is apparently famous. No need to question that as it was amazing. Whenever I'm craving some Italian meats, I shall come here.
author: Justine T.

description:
Molinari, oh oh
Mangiare, oh oh oh oh

Okay, so I'll spare you from my version of "Volare." But I will say that I LOVE Molinari! Always have and always will (I hope)! I've never had a disappointing sandwich ever. What puzzles me though is that I never had a sandwich like Molinari's in Italy. I never saw or ate any sandwiches other than panini, and I traveled all over Italy. Oh well. Thank Goddess for Molinari!
author: Anastasia B.

description:
"Hey, what can I get you sweetheart?"

There's not many businesses today that could get away with that--and make it sound charming.

It's great to see one of the SF classics still around, and still popular.   It's still run by the same family for four generations--not many places in SF can boast that claim.  North Beach was once home to dozens of wonderful family-run delicatessens like this one.  Now, sadly, Molinari's stands alone.  

They have the best homemade cheese raviolis and house-made marinara sauce in town.  Their cheese ravioli have a little basil and seasoning in the filling, which is a step up from the generic all-white-ricotta fill you get from other places.  Plus you can pick up a wedge of Reggiano to grate over it (direct from Parma), some fresh bread, antipasto and yummy italian cookies--Voila, dinner!   In this era of Subways and Quiznos on every block, it's great to see that people still love this old school spot.  I hope they buck the trend and stay in business for a long, long time.
author: SFnativeGal ..

description: Molinari's makes the best Italian sandwich I have ever had in my life. The roasted peppers and the quality of the Italian meats definitely makes this place stand alone at the top of my Italian sandwich pedestal.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Freshest best Italian deli sandwiches in SF, mmmmm!

Seating and lunch hour line, no mmmmm!
author: Aaron I.

description:
My favourite sandwich in SF.

I've tried a few of the sandwiches here at lunch time. My favourite is one of the cheapest - the italian combo for $6.95. Tasty meats with quality deli items aplenty at this place.
author: David P.

description:
I came here this morning after doing a jog with Nike Club Run SF around the Marina and Presidio.  

What better way to award yourself after all that?? 

Try  the Renzo..A sandwich filled with Prosciutto,  Fresh Mozzarella, Pesto and Sun Dried Tomatoes. 

Not the best way to eat after exercising but it was oh so, good!
author: Trish P.

description:
They have the best of my favorite food of all time.
Two words: Parma Prosciutto. 
Okay, six words: Parma Prosciutto on a French Roll. That's it. 

No condiments. 

No produce. 

As a matter of fact, I only eat the bottom of the roll. So it's really Parma Proscuitto and HALF a French Roll. So, I can get my favorite sammich here, pick up one of their amazing salamis for my hubby AND a bottle of Brioschi for the after-affects of said salami. 
If it's a nice day, I take my sammy and eat it in Washington Square. If it's a lousy day, I eat it in the car. In either case, I eat it ALONE. I don't share my Parma Prosciutto. So don't ask.

This place is heaven on a corner, I'm telling you. 

Full disclosure: I was a vegetarian for 15 years. I still ate prosciutto on the sly. Don't tell anyone....
author: Teri M.

description:
About 8 years ago, my then 82 year old Italian grandmother amazingly walked through San Francisco from the Powell street station, through Chinatown, into North Beach.  She stopped in front of Molinari's and said "oh!  this reminds me of the delis from when I grew up!"  Sure, that was in New Jersey, but it's still a fond memory and a moment that brought one of my favorite sandwich spots in SF to my attention.

This is one of my favorite sandwich places in SF.  They are just overflowing with flavor (some may say too much) but the fresh mozzarella, pesto, sun dried tomatoes, roasted peppers....  so good!  Not to mention the huge variety of deli meats.  You can't really go wrong as far as I'm concerned.  Perfect for an afternoon in Washington Square park or to take along on a hike in Marin.
author: Jenny S.

description: I just had a sandwich from here this week . I didn't expect their sandwiches to be good at all but their sandwiches were actually not bad . I had the Renzo special which was basically just slices of proscuitto , mozzarella , pesto , and sundried tomatoes . I know it sounds simple but it actually tastes better than it sounds . The sandwich did however , get kinda oily towards the end . Their sandwiches are not bad but at the same time , they don't really impress me either . Their sandwiches lack the wow factor ... they're sorta boring . Their potato salad was just blah ... okay but lacked flavor .
author: Eileen L.

description:
The Molinari Special ,a.k.a. the kitchen sink, has orgasmic potential.  But to increase the odds of such an occurrence, select a soft(er) hunk of rosemary roll from the choose your own bread bin.  

The wild card after that is the sandwich maker.  All sandwiches are not created equal.  Some of these guys are sandwich artists and lovingly pile all kinds of goodness (meats, cheeses, roasted peppers, the works) on your perfectly cut roll with strict attention to the architecture of the sandwich, while others take less care and slop your lunch together with less attention to detail and more attention to attitude thus rendering an inferior product.  Even so, the worst case scenario will still leave you satisfied.

You may end up waiting in line a while.  But as long as you are prepped with your bread of choice, you can peruse this charming Italian deli until they call your number to get down to business.
author: Sharon R.

description:
I really don't get the Molinari hype.  The sandwiches are mediocre, and at 8-10 bucks are not particularly cheap.

I can think of  tons of sandwich shops that I would rather go to - the sentinel? Ikes? much better.

Here's why I don't like Molinari's:

1.  Their food is no longer "unique" - you don't have to go to specialty shops to get buffala anymore- Molinari's wares are just run-of-the-mill now.

2.  The bread is "meh" - good bread makes a good sandwich and there are too many places in the city that make excellent bread.  Also, it sits out and gets all dry.

3.  It's always horribly crowded and the servers have a soup-nazi attitude.  I despise customer-facing businesses with surly employees, regardless of how great their food is.

4.  The sandwiches just aren't that interesting.  Everything has sun-dried tomatoes and peppers on it.  I personally don't value "simplicity" in my sandwiches, and "simplicity" definitely doesn't cut it when the ingredients aren't amazing.  (which they simply are not here)

5.  I've noticed people rating this place highly due to 1) simplicity, 2) the "authentic" nature of the place, and 3) the annoying process by which a sandwich is constructed (pick your bread out, take a number, get glared at by the guys behind the counter).  

I don't think any of these characteristics translate to a tasty sandwich, and I am convinced that their clientèle just likes restaurants that abuse them (stockholm syndrome, cognitive dissonance, whatever you want to call it).
author: Anthony L.

description:
Best sando in town hands down. Ingredients are as fresh as it gets and the Italian dude who runs the place is a boss, always friendly and takes a lot of pride in the quality of his store front.  To all sandwich lovers, this is Ike's for the adult...  Instead of a bunch of deep fried crap thrown on a sandwich, this deli uses real, quality ingredients.  As a 12 year old I would go Ike's, as a 21 year old, MoMo's is the real deal.  My only issue is the one guy who makes the sandwiches, not the owner, has kind've a stick up his.. you know.  I don't know why you would you be such a johnny raincloud when you're boss is as cool as his is but c'est le vie.  Anywho, one guys bad attitude isn't making their food any less amazing, and I'm not that much of a cry baby to knock this dude's store cuz of a bad employee.
In summary, go to Molinari's and take your tastebuds on a tour of Italy!
author: Freddy H.

description:
O M Goodness... YUM IN MY TUM.  

I have to go to Molinari's every time I am in the North Beach area.  Anyone who lives in the area is just so lucky.  I would be at Molinari's everyday if I lived near it.  Unfortunately, Stockton is always busy no matter what time of day, but if you just decide to go on a whim you can take your sandwich to the park that isn't too far away.  I usual order the North Beach sandwich on Focaccia when I go.  The Focaccia is so large and soft and they always stuff your sandwich with tons and tons of meat.  They are fast at servicing you even when there is a line out the door.  I've heard that this is the best Italian deli in the SF area... I'd have to agree.
author: Crystal R.

description: This review is based off having only the Molinari sandwich, which is basically a nice rainbow of Italian cold cuts.  It was pretty damn good, you can tell everything is fresh and authentic.  That said, it was pretty straight-forward.  I look forward to trying to break away and try one of the other recommended combos, but that will be hard to do.
author: e w.

description:
Sigh, the people who work here are rooooooood.

I've never gotten a sandwich here and never will. I come here for certain pasta and tomatoes and sausage and cheese you can't get at Safeway-and all of those things are always the best--BUT---JEEBUS-you'd think they could be a little nicer to me because I'm not asking them to make me any special sandwich or otherwise do me any favors, I just go in, get my stupid number, pick out my stuff, bring it to the counter and pay.

They always seem annoyed there and once I asked if I could have a paper bag (after he'd already put my heavy tomato cans in plastic) because I was walking and that would be easier to carry in my arms and he openly glared at me then threw a tiny paper sandwich bag on the counter that you couldn't even fit one can in before turning away from me! I could plainly see hundreds of different sized paper bags behind the counter and was shocked at the balls on this guy especially in plain sight of other customers.

Someone posted that you shouldn't go here on weekends and I suspect that might be the case. The only time I'm ever in North Beach is on the weekends.

I think I may give them one more chance during the week next time. They do have good stuff I can't find anywhere. I'm just used to the east coast where Italian delis seem to be everywhere and the customer service rocks. These guys aren't good enough to be so persnickity, IMNSFHO
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Great sandwiches, great staff, amazing meats.
Take a number, pick out your choice of bread, and enjoy the generous helping of protein. The sandwiched look small because of the size of the bread but the height gives it substance. Definitely worth the money.
author: Gabriela O.

description:
The *best.*

Get the Italian combo sandwich.  It has all sorts of meat and cheese (a crazy thick stack) and nice spicy peppers.

You'll probably have to wait, but it will be worth it for that moment you finally manage to unhinge your jaw and wrap your mouth around this fantastic sandwich.  Yay!
author: Smog R.

description: Great Sandwiches and Italian deli/grocery.
author: Mark B.

description: This is a good Italian deli.  Great sandwiches: First you have to choose your bread.  They have a good selection of breads.  Next you tell  them what you want in your sandwich. Of course you are going to love your sandwich because it is exactly what you want!  Meats and cheese are fresh and good quality.  Enjoy!
author: rachelle t.

description:
Great slow food, local kind of place.  But damn, there's a reason I was surrounded by big burly guys and bike messenger types in this deli.  If I started eating these sandwiches all the time I would certainly start looking like one of them.  
I have to say though, my sandwich (the renzo) was a tiny bit dry and the sun dried tomatoes a bit rough.  The meat (coppa and prosciutto) was amazing though and I'll go back just to buy some of that solo.
author: Kiki R.

description:
Oh Italian deli that I swear was transplanted from Arthur Avenue, I love you!
Now, it isn't often that I crave freshly cut Italian meats and cheeses, or rather I crave these things at hours that no deli is open....however, when I plan a picnic, it ALWAYS starts at Molinari's. the sandwiches are scrumptious, and yes, I admit it, I'll get 1/4lb of prosciutto and eat it in bed in the dark...uhhh.....yea, weird, I know.
But really, I love coming here to taste all the cheeses, salamis, buy pastas.....oh Molinari....thank you for being within walking distance of my house....YUM
author: Bianca L.

description:
Damn fine sandwiches...

Why pay $5 for a Footlong when you can get such better quality for $6.25...

Just don't forget to grab a number right away...
author: Nathan W.

description:
Hmmm, I ordered some hot salami to go but it didn't taste hot. It tasted like regular salami. Maybe the chub was in the wrong place at the wrong time. 

The prosciutto looks lean and appealing. I'll have to try this next time and reorder the hot salami.
author: Nanette L.

description:
I love sandwiches, I also really like ninjas.  One day my roommates and I decided to have a ninja and sandwiches party.  We decided the only way to host such a party would be to have ONE large party sandwich made specifically for us.  We're not talking about some 2 foot sub from Safeway's deli, or some pathetic multi-foot long from Subway, we wanted a legit sandwich that was ready to party.  I tried Marina Subs, I tried Yellow Submarine and I tried King Foot Subs...everyone that answered the phone thought that I was crazy and/or playing a practical joke on them.  To their credit, I WAS asking for a 6-foot sandwich, and I WAS pretty pumped about it...so maybe I did sound crazy.

My roommates and I were in full distress mode when I decided to dial one last number, Molinari's.

Employee: Molinari's
Me: Yeah, hi, I'm wondering if you guys do party subs?
Employee: Yeh
Me: You do?!
Employee: Yeh, how big?
Me: Like...6 feet?
Employee: When do you want to pick it up?

The ninja and sandwiches party was saved!  And we owe it all to Tony at Molinari's.  He was real friendly, and helped me through the process, and to order a sandwich of that magnitude...it actually is a process (They specially order the bread from a local bakery in advance, and then have to put together 6 ft of sandwich and wrap it up).

4 stars because the sandwich was delicious and 6 feet, minus 1 star because it was crazy expensive...I'm even ashamed to admit how much we dropped on it.
author: Josh T.

description:
While Molinaris can rightly be called touristy it is by no means a tourist trap. A stop here on the way back from work is a must for me. I pick up a pound of fresh pasta, some pesto sauce on occasion, some fresh mozzarella, etc. Also, great olive oil, a step up from TJ in quality and much more reasonable for the quality than Safeway IMHO. Yes standing in line during lunch is lame, but the sandwiches are phenomenal. Also, try some of their more unique cured meats like the bresaola (cured beef) it's worth the steep price. I also prefer this place to Palermo deli, which is less touristy but somehow also less satisfying.

Minus one star however for being closed Sundays and the early closing (5:30, but I've come by at 5:15 just to find them closed).
author: Ross G.

description:
At first I was a little intimidated because everyone in the long line looked like regulars and I had no idea what to do. I ended up ordering a foccacia sandwich. From what I remember it was on garlic foccacia and had fresh mozzarella, prosciutto, sundried tomatoes, etc...

It was yummy! The people there are really nice and the cashier gave me a chocolate! The sandwich itself was HUGE. But I felt like it was a little mushier than I liked..maybe they didn't toast it by itself before adding the ingredients. Other than that, very good :) I would definitely go back.
author: Lauretta L.

description: Great counter service.  They make the sandwiches with care and are very helpful even under busy conditions.  Great selection of meats and cheeses!  Fresh bread and rolls.  Pesto penne and molinari special are killer!
author: Justin H.

description: A sunny day in Washington Square Park with a sandwich from Molinari's.  Life is good!
author: Rosemary B.

description:
These guys just might have, 
The best meatball sub ever,
Toasted grilled squeezed shut.
author: Brian J.

description:
Looking for a sandwich in SF? It doesn't get any better than this.

1. The bread is unbelievable.
2. They will happily make you a sandwich with pretty much any ingredient in the place and they won't tack on a bunch of extra charges.
3. Let's say you don't know the difference between Salami and Genoa. They'll slice you a bit of both and let you figure out which one you want.

I WOULD give them 5 stars, but...

1. Parking is difficult.
2. It's usually really busy.
3. There isn't really any seating to speak of. I usually remedy this by hiking up Russian Hill or Telegraph Hill and eating somewhere with a nice view.
4. Closed on Sunday. In my mind, this is the real killer.
author: Derek S.

description:
Pick your own pre-fondled bread out of a bin and wait.  Know what you want or be ignored and/or yelled at.  Take note that the main guy is a sandwich nazi, you will know who he is.  My friend accidentally ordered tortellini thinking it would come cooked (it's on the menu afterall with no indication that it's uncooked and packaged).   Sandwich nazi promptly replied under his breath "shitfuckfuckingfuckshitassfuck" for a good five minutes until he finished ringing us up.

But the meatballs rule.
author: jess l.

description:
Oh I love this place.
They have all the regional italian food here. Prociuto di parma was awesome!! The cheese selection is awesome, the deli line is awesome, the sandwiches are awesome, the home made pasta is awesome, even the frozen pasta is awesome. Everything's awesome! Hearing the conversations in italian is awesome.

Here's a conversation with the owner:
"Ha la mozzarella di buffala?"
"No, you ask me? no."
"Do you know where I could get it in the city"
"No, you ask me? no...e...no! you try trader joe's, you ask me? no. I have no mozzarella di buffala. You ask me? no. no. no."

(......m......ok......i hope you don't kill me cuz you look like a mafia in the God Father.....)

I love it here.
author: Yuchi C.

description: Best sandwiches --worth the wait! Take a ticket as soon as you walk in the door so you can get in line.   You can tell it is a popular place as the line was long but definately worth the wait.  Select your bread from the case or try one of he foccia rolls.   Try the sandwich specials they are great.  I had the Basil North Beach Turkey and my husband had the North Beach Special turkey.   Wish we were not just passing through I would have tried the fresh made pastas and sauces.
author: Susan R.

description:
Came here at noon on a Tues worried about the line. Surprisingly, there were only a few patrons so we were helped right away. Maybe the loud construction outside is driving people away.

I was overwhelmed by the selection and asked the guy what their most popular sammie was. Ended up ordering the $6 special on french bread - yum and oh so cheap! They sure do give you a lot of meat in that sandwich.

Will definitely come here again - I've paid much more at lesser joints so it's a great deal if you don't go nuts with one of the fancier sammies.
author: T. B.

description:
The deli sandwiches are great. The first thing to do upon entering is to grab a number, *then* spend your time figuring out what you want for lunch.

Minus one star for serving humongous coma-inducing portions of lunch sandwiches. Please charge me less for less!
author: Rob T.

description:
If you have a passion for italian food then Molinari is where you want to be, it's like putting a crack addict in a crack house, yeah it's that good, well not in relations to crack but in relations to....oh you know what I mean!

Still it's a great place for pasta, salami, bread, whatever italian dish you feel like cooking, Molinari's has something that can help or if you don't feel like cooking big but still crave something italian and delicious, try one of their sandwiches or some of their homemade ravioli's, now that my friends...that's AMORE!
author: Troy R.

description:
Walking into this place is like stepping back into time.  

It's old-school neighborhood.  

Hey isn't that the guy married to the girl who works down the street at US?  I see the owner in Cavalli's around the corner in the mornings... and where else would one buy a gallon-sized box of those Italian Amaretti with the wrappers you light on fire ala Big Night?

When I'm out of town my husband lives on their cannaloni and lasagna which I lovingly stock our freezer with.

Please NEVER leave us!
author: Genevra P.

description:
If you love Italian sub, you gonna try this place!
One of the staff said that all the time when my husband showed up here "Hey! Mr. Taylor".
However, it's big sandwich and selections are too many.
You can ask them if you are not sure what kind sandwich do you want.
They are so friendly.
Salami is great! This is the best sandwich I've ever had!
author: Megumi T.

description:
Let me start off by saying that i should probably give this place five stars....but I got yelled at by some crazy homeless guy as I got to the end of my sandwich.  With that being said, now I can tell you my experience with this wonderful place.  

So I have been here on more than one occasion now because my first experience was so great!  I came here with a few friends for a late late lunch on a Sunday afternoon so needless to say, the normal line was not there.  We waited behind 5 or 6 other people but got served in about 10 minutes.  I ordered the Joe's Special which is a vegetarian sandwich with mozzerrella, sun dried tomatoes, pesto and some other stuff.  It was DELISH!!!!!!  The weather was nice, a bit chilly but still tolerable so we sat outside on one of the few tables on the street.  It was a great spot for a casual lunch with friends.

On another visit however, things were relatively the same as the first visit except a  homeless man came toward me yelling.  The irony of it all was that he was saying "Speak proper English."  But his was so slurred and un audible that I could barely make out what he was saying.  It was awesome.  My friends and I ignored the man believing that it was better to quell the flames than to fuel the fire.  So that's pretty much the reason why this place receives 4 instead of 5 stars.  Oh and sometimes you can't get a table outside so you have to bring your lunch elsewhere to eat it.  BUT GO TO THIS PLACE FOR A SANDWICH EXPERIENCE THAT WILL LEAVE YOU COMING BACK FOR MORE!
author: jen k.

description:
The first time I was here they didn't tell you to pick a roll in the bin.  I didn't even see the bin of buns.  Too distracted by the hanging meat and wall covered wine.  I ordered.  He blankly stared at me, "Well ya gotta pick your bread, sweetie."  ???  Alrighty.  Is this sanitary?  I'm sure people had poked and sniffed at some of the buns I had to choose from here.  

The staff can be a bit impatient and impersonal.  But they make a pretty good hearty sandwich.  "The North Beach" sammie is generous with prosciutto, provolone (tasted great here), and sun dried tomatoes.  The sun dried tomatoes are extremely sweet, but I swear I saw it sopping in some fatty substance.  Sandwiches aren't that cheap, but they are pretty tasty.  Large choices of cured meats, cheese, and wine.
author: Chris T.

description: This place gets crowded easily, but it is worth the wait especially for the sandwiches.  I always order the "North Beach" special which has prosciutto, red peppers, sundried tomotoes and provolone cheese!  OMG it's so ono - licious.  It's such a treat!  Friendly staff & service!
author: Arlene Z.

description:
I like the salami here, and everywhere else they distribute it to...anywhere you go to get some quality salty cured meats, no doubt Molinari's is a choice. 

Good spot for a good deli sandwich, although like Lucca Deli, they are kind of overpriced and sometimes not up to my insane deli sandwich standards. But most of the time, they hit it right on.

Usually, the staff is neither friendly nor particularly helpful, although I tend to think older Italians who don't have time for any BS are kind of funny. Don't expect to be coddled when you can't decide if you want cheese or onions on your sandwich when there are 30 people crammed in line with you in the shop. 

Overall, this place has changed a bit since I remember coming here with my Nana, but one still remains the same - that instant aroma of delicious meats and cheeses and red peppers and olive oil that will always be a comforting sign to me that it's authentic.
author: Kelly R.

description:
This place gets busy on the weekends, but, their system is pretty efficient and the wait of 12 people in front of you goes by super fast as the staff is quick yet the quality of the sandwich is preserved.  Hard to find service like that these days.

Tips:

1.  As soon as you get there, make sure you grab a number.
2.  After you grab a number, make sure to go to the bread bin and pick your choice of bread.
3.  Be ready when they call your number. They call em quick.
4.  Make sure you know exactly what you want to keep the system rolling.

As far as the sandwiches go, I'm pretty sure you can order pretty much any type of sandwich from here and be 100% satisfied.
author: Delilah B.

description: First day in SF and we bee-lined it for Molinaris.   My wife, son and I all ordered the the Molinari Special which was absolutely fantastic.   The bread was crisp and the meat is piled to a really nice thickness.   The cheese is awesome and the little pepper were so delicious.   It was just a perfect Italian lunch.  We grabbed a table outside and just soaked in the SF atmosphere.   I love this neighborhood and the Molinari Delicatessen is a great place to soak it in.
author: Sean O.

description:
I LOVED THIS PLACE!!! Went there today with a friend of mine and we were just blown away... like kids in a candy store... I wanted everything.
I was so impressed by the size of the capers jars lol.  Got all kinds of goodies! Sausages (which I have heard are the best in town), fresh ravioli and cappelleti, pasta sauce, crackers, lady fingers, polenta, fresh cheese... I'm in love... 
They also have pre-cooked food if you want to take stuff home... all kinds... when I went they had pesto pasta, sausages, breaded chicken fillets, all kinds of olives, stuffed peppers... 
They are also known for their sandwiches (we didn't try them but saw them preparing one... LOADED with fresh mortadella and other cold cuts).
They were so nice and friendly! I'm def coming back!
author: Mrs. G.

description:
I would give 10 stars if i could. I'd even take every other star i've issued to a deli to give it to Molinari's.

I recently reunited with a deli i fell in love with 7 years ago. I had since traveled across Italy, and it just confirmed the way i felt about this deli.  As i was in SF this past weekend, this was my first stop. I was very nervous that it wouldn't live up to my expectations from my last stop years ago. Was it all a dream, was it all hopped up in my mind on sentiments? Walking through the door just opened the flood gates of memories.

I think their service is awesome. The staff is very friendly and very accommodating. I had a North Beach w/ a little garlic/pesto kicker and it blew me away. Man, that is my perfect sandwich. Why don't they have an Italian Deli like that in LA?  I can only hope it doesn't take another 7 years to get back up there.
author: Michael J L.

description:
All I'ze gotsta say is their Panini with proscuitto, roasted bell pepper, and buffola mozzarella on focaccia is scrumptious. They don't make a bad potato salad either. This slightly vinegary, sweet, salty (yum) sandwich is huge and can easily be shared by 2 people..or one really hungry person..

Personally I don't know if I would go for the bread in the bread box..so there you go - another reason to get the focaccia panini..
author: Natalie G.

description:
I'm going to tell you a little secret - when I make lasagna, I tell everyone I made the sauce from scratch when I really get it from here. 

I've been coming here since I was a kid, and the guys working the counter have always been the best. Sometimes they'll even invite you back to dip bread into sauce with them and chat.

There's nothing else to say aside from the fact that this place is pure North Beach (before it got so sketchy).
author: Carla C.

description: I don't know why I waited this long to write a review for Molinari's.  Just got back from a SF trip and had to do my usual visit to Molinari's.  I took four family members who have never been here before and they loved it.  I suggested the chicken parm which is awesome and they ate in silence (which means it was good).  I also brought home an Italian sausage sandwhich for dinner and it was delicious.  This was my first time trying the Italian sausage sandwhich and I highly recommend it, FANTASTIC!!!!  If you're you're in little Italy (and you definately should be visiting little Italy) and love a good sandwich you need to stop by, trust me you will become a Molinari's advocate.
author: Ripcurl A.

description: My second favorite deli in the City.  The best thing to get here is the Sangiovese wine for less than 9 bucks a bottle with a Renzo sandwich.  Great eating!
author: Joseph M.

description: Nice service, obviously it's a local favorite. Everbody in there was a regular, and it quickly became apparent that we were lucky that the place wasn't more packed (we were 4th in line when we came by, before noon on a weekday). Shared a Renzo sandwich with my wife - her choice.  it was good...fresh, good quality. I probably would have picked something else, so this may hurt my review a bit.  Overall it was a good sandwich.
author: Adam D.

description:
This is hands down the best deli on the west coast. Like everybody else has mentioned, take a number, pick your bread and hand to the deli clerk to prepare your sandwhich.

This place is perfect for getting your deli meats in order for a christmas party, etc. The place is located next to the communist store where all the beatniks chill.

Be sure to ask for IMPORTED prosciutto - you'll thank me later. It's hidden somewhere in the back of the case.  It can get busy during lunchtime so plan accordingly.
author: Jaime G.

description: I just ate a South Beach sandwich from here, and it was quite good!  Fresh ingredients.
author: Niniane W.

description: Delicious cheeses, delicious meats, and delicious sandwiches!  I've only been here once, to try a sandwich for lunch & to pick up things for Christmas gift baskets (mmm, panettone).. but I have been meaning to make a trip up again to buy more cheese, and browse their wine selection as well.
author: Shar M.

description:
Just had the tastey luciano special with pepperoncinis. perfectly made and toasted, great service, no wait.
my tummy hurts cuz i couldn't stop eating it.
author: Julie H.

description:
This is an awesome Italian deli in North Beach, where you get to pick out your own fresh bread from a bin for your sandwich. I was having a busy, stressful day at work last Friday - with no time for lunch. I knew I was going to leave an hour or two early that day and at some point decided I was going to get a late lunch at Molinari's. After that decision was made, I was instantly in a better mood. 

Get the Molinari Special. You won't be sorry. And if it is nice that day, enjoy it at an outdoor table while people watching.
author: Katie W.

description: I generally hate any high-pressure ordering situation, but it's worth it for Molinari's. Just have your bread and order ready to go, and the other people waiting won't stab you with knife-eyes.
author: Shannon V.

description:
So I work about 5 blocks away from this place and have to pass by on the way to Wells Fargo. I have alway seen it, I have heard it was awesome, but I have always been in a rush and therefore never stopped inside since there was always a line.

But today I had the time, so I went inside to discover (to my surprise) that there was no line.

"What can I get you?" the guy behind the counter asked.

"I don't know" I said, looking slightly confused at the selection of meats, cheeses, vegetables, oils, pastas and various things offered.

Luckily, there was only one other person in the shop, so they were willing to put up with me. I let him go first, of course.

"Would you like to try the prosciutto or turkey or salami?" he asked.

"Sure..." I respond still looking stupidly at the huge selection.

He cuts me a thin slice of each meat and hands them to me over the counter. Wow. what quality. The salami was the best I've ever had and it's been so long since I've had prosciutto that it was perhaps one of the greatest things I've tasted...not too salty

I got the North beach special (prosciutto, provolone, marinated bell peppers and sun dried tomatoes) and it was damn good. Price is reasonable for the quality and service ($7.50 for a decent size sandwich) but I was amazed because this is one of the few authentic delies still around (the only italian deli i've ever seen). I got it with this amazing basil garlic sauce that I recommened to everyone as it improves everything tenfold.

More than that, they're like a little import grocery store at the same time. I'll have to come here next time i need olive oil or dry salami.

Fun staff and a great place to go during the off-hours. They can be a bit soup-nazi-esque during lunchtime.

Will totally come back again if i didn't think the prosciutto would wedge itself in my arteries. Oh hell, I know i'll come back again.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Helpful staff and the best salami/prochitto  I have had in awhile. Def worth the drive for fresh Italian meats!
author: Katie P.

description: One regret I have as I've now left San Francisco is that I didn't spend enough time enjoying North Beach. I went to Molinari for the first time the day before packing up my stuff and leaving, and it has all the makings of a great deli. Grab a couple sandwiches (the Italian combo I had was a winner) and head down the street to Wash Square and enjoy! Oh, and it's 60 degrees in February here as opposed to 20 in Brooklyn, yep.
author: Brian B.

description:
The sandwiches are good. But you know what makes this place 5 stars?
The salame. 
If you like salame:  you need to run right now to Molinari's and get a salame.
This is the best damn salame. I can't stress this enough. 
I am Italian. When I was growing up, my family always had a salame hanging in the pantry. If you are Italian then you'll know what I am talking about.
Molinari's Italian sausage also rocks!!!
If you have never been to Molinari's here is a tip:
If you are going to order a sandwich: As you enter, grab a number and turn around. The bread is in a drum on the left as you walk in about 15 feet. Pick your roll. Hand it to the nice gentleman who is crafting your lunch. Know what you want, and you'll be in business.
But the real deal here is the salame and the sausages.
author: SF N.

description:
Ah, I forgot what a good delicatessan was suppossed to be like.  If you want to go to a good deli in this area you have to go to Whole Foods, and you better bring your wallet.
Thank you so much Yelper, for if it weren't for you I would never have thought to stumble into this humble little place.
We started our day at Trieste down the street with coffee and pastries, then walked over to Molinari's to have a sub prepared for lunch later in the day.  We got one sub for the two of us, they are huge!  And we got, per your recommendations, the mozzarella and basil pesto sub.  F yeah!!!
Also, thanks to you guys, I didn't look like a complete schmuck walking in.  I walked right up to the bread bin and picked out the largest and hardest piece I could find and handed it to the quiet deli masters behind the counter.
They wrap your sandwich beautifully in parchment paper so you can carry it around lovingly with you all day.
From Molinari's we hiked to the Coit Tower, then to the wharf, caught a bus to the GG, then back to the wharf.  From here we caught the cable cars and eventually ended up in GG park.  We hiked to the coastal side and finally enjoyed half of our sandwich at the chalet.  Then we hiked back through GG park and eventually had the rest of our sandwiches outside the DeYoung.  How sad when it was all gone.
What a beautiful day and lunch it was.
author: david w.

description: Very good Italian Combo.  Tons of meat on really good bread.  Excellent Value.  I will be back for sure.
author: Bobby S.

description:
Beside the interesting Italian specialty items that line every inch of the available shop space, Molinari is offering up some traditional Italian sandwich goodness that is difficult to deviate from. 

I have to go with the panini made of focaccia, proscuitto, roasted bell peppers, buffola mozzarella cheese, some blend of veggie that I can't quite remember right now, but I'll post back with more details the next time I eat there. 

As for their regular sandwiches, I don't know if I'd ever go for one. They use high quality ingredients, and even make their own salami and sausages, but the bread sits in a bin that you hand choose from, which leads me to believe that the bread may get stale over the course of a day. I'll take mine hot hot and pressed, thank you.
author: Shannon F.

description: You don't come here to sit down or enjoy the service. You come because it's a phenomenal Italian deli with a variety of sandwiches that will hook you for life. I'm partial to the focaccia, but you can pick your own piece of bread as well. The ingredients in each sandwich are simple, delightful complements that make your mouth water as soon as you start to think about them.
author: Corey B.

description:
Wow, this is the Italian version to my Hungarian last name (Molnar)  so I really must check it out.  Obviously it's going to be awesome.

~Panchita Molnar
author: Krissy M.

description: Y.U.M. This place is pretty authentic and has a great selection of wines, oils, pasta salads, and delicious jars and cans of all things Italian-definitely the place to come for a spread. And the sandwiches! Grab a number, grab your bread, choose the fill. Sandwiches are pricey ($8ish) but worth it for the quality, and the experience. They have a few tables on the street, right across from the large white church, you feel like you're in Europe. Or take a picnic down to the Washington Square!
author: J E.

description: Friendly staff and good vibe! The meats are super fresh! Great sandwiches! I've heard the ravioli is good so I will probably try that next time. I like the fact that you have to pick your on baguette. Great place to drop in for a snack! Highly recommend it!
author: Steve C.

description: On our most recent visit to SF, we made a weekday lunchtime trip to Molinari's for their famous sandwiches. I knew how the ordering system worked from other Yelp reviews, so thank you Yelp reviewers! I was excited to try the Dutch Crunch bread and so we picked out our rolls from the bin (FYI: please use the tongs provided) and waited for our turn. I ordered a turkey sandwich with mayo, lettuce, and tomato. My husband ordered the sun dried tomato turkey sandwich and our friend got a pastrami sandwich. They took credit cards for payment and we even got to speak a couple of words of Italian with the deli guy. Our lunch was enjoyed back at our rented apartment on the rooftop deck on a beautiful SF day. We all thoroughly enjoyed our lunch and it was plenty filling, saving our other half for another day. Delizioso!
author: Tammy G.

description: Just back from Tuscany, wanted my Italian fix so I headed to North Beach. Did my Yelp research and went with Molinari, which I had been eyeing for a while, but was never there in daylight! Was not too crowded at late lunch, scored the foccacia, meat was great, but sandwich was just too bready for me. In Italy, I had been turned on to schiacciata, which is thin bread and a fabulous bed for maximum meat flavor. I am a mortadella gal from my Italian grandfathers tutelage. He used to have to come over to SF from Marin to get our fixings for anitpasto plates. This sand wich was light on the meat, too heavy on bread. Next time, Lucca gets a shot. Italian product stock in store was also just ok, though wine selection was excellent and well priced. May try ravioli sometime, but gnocchi was filled, boo.
author: Erin S.

description: It appears this place doesn't need much help from my Yelp review, but its so darn good I just gotta give some props!  The sandwiches aren't anything but the best italian sandwiches I've had, anywhere.  The bread is from a bakery up on grant and filbert I believe, and its always fresh and good.  The meats are to die for, everything from the turkey to the spicy cappicola.   My favorite sandwich right now is the Renzo, but that's subject to change.  On top of that, they have a great and not outrageously priced selection of cheeses, lots of italian imports (pasta, wine, various sauces) and the staff are cool friendly.  You gotta grab a ticket when its busy, which adds to the character.  I just can't think of anything to say against this place.  Makes me glad I live 2 blocks away.
author: Sam C.

description:
This place is so great!  Not only are their snadwiches to die for, but so is the deli.  They have fresh pasta, ravioli and gnocchi as well as an extensive meat and cheese selection.  

If you are going during the week, make sure to get there early.  If not, you will have to get in line with the other 40 tourists that rush this place around 1130am.
author: Megan H.

description:
one word: AUTHENTICITY. (without a doubt)


they have so many sandwich combos to choose from! and sooo much meat to choose from too! the jalapenos stuffed with prosciutto weren't too shabby either! ;)

oh and super friendly too! (only downside is that there can be a wait at times.... -_-  )

all in all, LOVED it! and ill be back! =)
author: Lisa N.

description: Believe the hype. For the $ (cheap) to taste/size ratio of the sandwich (I had sausage) I have not had better.
author: Mark R.

description: Absolutely the BEST! I love coming here every time I am in the city. The service is good, fast and get's you out of the door pretty quick, even with long lines. I appreciate the ambiance, just wish they had more seating outside - but hey, that's life in a city as old as San Francisco. Grab some sandwiches (you pick you own roll), order from the menu above, get some mushrooms or other deli treats, some Orangina and head down to the park or Marina and enjoy a wonderful daytime meal.
author: Tony P.

description: go to roxie!!!! better yet if this is your place stay there! i'll keep roxie and not venture out to north beach.  where has the real sf gone?
author: Phil B.

description: Delicious sandwiches! Probably the best italian deli in SF. I got a turkey sandwich with provolone, basil garlic spread, sun dried tomatoes, and sweet peppers.  Although the bread selection could have been better, the meat, cheese, and veggie options were good. We also got some sausages to go and made them for dinner. Yummy!
author: Debbie C.

description: The only thing i've ever tried out of this Deli is their frozen take home ravioli and i'd have to say it's probably the best ravioli i've ever had.  they use rice flour in their dough mixture which when you cook them the pasta turns a little transparent, and the texture is amazing.   I've tried Lucca's ravioli (a deli in the mission dist.) and they don't compare to these.  So my 5 star rating only applies to the ravioli, but they're 5 stars of goodness.
author: Spencer W.

description: I lived in North beach for years and never found this place..I recently had a friend take me there and was so upset it took me so long to find it! The sandwiches are fabulous!
author: Danielle A.

description: First time here and I got the Rezno (prosciutto, sun-dried tomatoes, fresh mozarella, and basil garlic spread). It was pretty packed, but the line moved quickly. I can see why people like this place, I just feel like I should have picked something better. The quality of the ingredients are good, and the staff is dedicated haha. If I'm ever around again, I'd like to try another sandwich.
author: Patrick P.

description: Awesome bread, great ingredients, reasonably priced. Grab your lunch here and get a spot in the sun at  Washington Square Park... heavenly!
author: Tom C.

description: The north beach with asiago dill pasta salad and a bottle of sardinian sparkling water.....perfectamente! On point for authenticity, brought back memories of the years I lived in fruili guilia.  A tasty italian deli experience!
author: Garrett D.

description: LOVE me a good molinari salami.  Friendly crew inside and many other yummy italian favs to choose from.
author: Samantha A.

description: Ridiculously delish sandwiches best eaten on a sunny day on a stoop or in Washington Square Park with a few pepper shooters, someone you really, really dig and a bottle of champagne to wash it all down.
author: Laura M.

description: The sandwiches are great - fresh ingredients. My favorite is the "South Beach." The staff are friendly. BUT THEY DON'T WASH THEIR HANDS AFTER TOUCHING THE MONEY AND THE CASH REGISTER. THEY GO RIGHT BACK TO HANDLING FOOD! I don't understand how such a well known and long established business can operate in such an unhygienic way. Food is great but they've got to get on the ball with the hand washing. I gave them 1 star to call attention to this obvious lapse. Otherwise I'd give them 5 stars for their food and customer service.
author: lee m.

description:
Really authentic Little Italy (New York)-style Italian deli.  Delicious sausage, chicken parm sandwiches, and fresh bread.  Friendly staff and reasonable prices.

The only downside is that it can get very busy at lunchtime... bring a book or iPad to read while you wait for your number to be called.
author: Bruce H.

description: Mmmmm... just all oozing with so much goodness. My favorite's the Veggie. The line can get a bit long, but it's so worth it. And the music playing in the shop make you want to stay in a bit longer, while daydreaming of being in italy.
author: M C.

description:
Molinari's is way high on my list of favorite places to eat in the city.

The best way, IMO - go a tiny bit after the lunch rush, on a weekday, late spring or summer.  Grab a roll from the bin.  Hand it to the guys behind the counter and tell them what to put on it - preferably something with salami and provolone.  Go with one of your favorite people or with one of your favorite novels.  Sit at one of the rickity little tables out front, eat your amazing sandwich, and watch the world go by.  

Repeat as needed or (if you're me and have to live somewhere else) whenever you're in the Bay Area.
author: Suz F.

description:
A friend of mine in Los Angeles told me about this place.  He loves it so much that he rides his motorcycle up from LA on Saturdays just to grab a sandwich and then ride back to LA the same day.  I'm not making this up - he really is that insane.

Anyway, the sandwiches are indeed quite tasty, the chacuteries, cheeses, homemade pastas, prepared Italian foods, etc make the place smell so heavenly, and the staff are friendly and very Italian.
author: Asteridae A.

description: A jewel in the crown of SF delicatessens.  My absolute favorite since my mom took me here as a kid.  Giant wine bottles around the cieling, meat hanging everywhere you look and lines out the door (better take a number).  The NB Special + archichoke hearts with a Pellegrino my ultimate pleasure.  MMMMM.  Never had a bad experience and I will love this place forever.
author: Sin F.

description: Went this past Monday for an afternoon sandwich. I am still dreaming of the taste! Got the North Beach Special (prosciutto, provolone, sun dried tomatoes, with sweet bell peppers).It was by far the best sandwich I have ever had. Ate outside right on Columbus. Northbeach on a nice day. You must come check this place out. A real Deli.
author: David A.

description:
Damn!

A salami sandwich never taste so gooood! I have to come back and get some wine or maybe some other meats. But all I know is that I had a bomb ass salami sandwich when me and two of my good friends decided to go for a late lunch one Sunday. fresh meat big ass sandwich, some kettle chips and a coke...hello SERENITY! It was great..be prepared to take it to go, although they have pleasant seating outside. Its a little far from me, but still its worth the trip, but definitely go if you are in their hood!
author: Natalie F.

description:
I love this place. If i'm at a loss for where to go for lunch, Molinari's is on the short-list of sure-fire good lunch places near my work.

I haven't tried everything there, but the hot coppa and salami rock the house. The bread is generally good; I prefer the sweet rolls over the sourdough, though the sourdoughs are the favorite of many.

The only drawback of this place is that insane wait around lunchtime, especially during tourist season.

Also, they do catering, but don't let your Chinese-as-her-first-language coworker do the ordering cause you'll just get a platter of turkey and tunafish sandwiches. If i wanted that, i'd go to Lee's. Make sure you order some of the specialty cuts. They're all good.
author: Bernie L.

description:
Anthony Bourdain once said something to the effect that when he gets to heaven, he expects to see a multitude of hanging pork products. I don't think I've ever heard truer words before or since.

  I've grown up around great Italian food and great Italian delis and my passions run deep. An Italian deli can brighten up even the darkest of crappy work days or busted relationships in much the same way Ben & Jerry's and Cold Stone do it for seemingly everyone else. But beware the faux Italian deli's that can sometimes be found in shiny new suburban shopping centers sporting Hormel meats and processed cheesefoods! Thankfully Molinari's has never sold out and is still the old school neighborhood Italian deli. The kind your nonni would have been going to for 30 years, on a first name basis with everyone there, patrons and staff... except really crowded with tourists (but that's ok, great things should be shared). The meats are hanging, the pasta, sauces and sausages are made fresh in the back, the bread comes from down the street and everything is exactly the way it should be.

  My only gripe would be the fact that there is no fresh made foccacia. Sure you can get foccacia anywhere these days, but it's that crappy, fluffy, crumbly McFoccacia stuff that is about as authentic as the General Tsao's chicken at Panda Express. Oh and I guess I should gripe about them closing at 5pm. Still, both of those gripes don't constitute knocking off a star.

  Their sandwiches are superb, mine being "the most expensive sandwich I've ever sold" (though it's still reasonable for a lunch in NB): hot coppa, toscano salami, buffalo mozzarella and all the trimmings.

  The bread is fresh that day, the meats and cheeses are sliced to order and if you need any Italian kitchen ingredients, this is the place to go. Floor to celing wines, salt-packed capers and anchovys, san marzano tomatoes, pannaforte, etc. Plus there are patio tables so you can people-watch over your monster sammich. Molto buono.
author: Thomas S.

description:
THE best italian sandwiches in all of San Francisco.  I don't eat meat, so my favorite is the Joe's special.  take a number, pick your choice of bread, hand it over....and within a minute you get an amazing fresh mozzarella, pesto, sun dried tomato and SUPER yummy yellow roasted bell pepper sandwich!!  

sometimes i work up that way, but generally I don't get to north beach a lot...i lived in the mission for years and always went to lucca for my italian delights (still do).  i would give them both 5 stars.  but my italian-ness could make me slightly biased? :)  mmmhmm.
author: Isabel C.

description:
Molinari's is one of the cornerstone establishments of North Beach.  Authentically Italian, the place might be busy and packed but the guys behind the counter always keep their cool and crack a joke every now and again.

We have been buying their fresh pasta for the last couple years, and it's always fantastic.  Two boxes of their fresh raviolis, with a matching amount of the meat sauce, is a perfect, simple meal for three (+ leftovers for lunch).  

They have a great selection of olives, salamis, cheeses, and other Italian foods to accent your meal.  The biggest problem is that they aren't open very often.  The place closes down early, so the best time to get there is during the day on the weekend.

Sandwiches are great too, by the way, but too many people end there - this place has so much more to offer!
author: Mitchell F.

description: We come here every time we are in San Francisco and always get good service and a great sandwich. This time however we came after the crowds. The food was fantastic as usual but they had some extra time to show off their great service too. My wife's family is from Italy and they took the time to point out on a map where the city is located. They they spent several minutes helping us pick out some meats and cheeses for a little picnic we were doing. They whole time they were all so friendly and wonderful we felt like part of the family. Of course the food was wonderful as always too! Thank you very much for a memorable experience!
author: Robert S.

description:
Great deli meats to go, although the prices are on the higher side. Seems that many restaurants use Molinari's meat in the area, mainly because its just that good...especially the wafer-thin prosciutto...

Update: the bread has always been stale. I've given up on the sandwiches and just stick to the meat.
author: Nicolas H.

description:
Fabulous sandwiches and very nice staff. Makes me feel like I'm in Italy. But they need more tables!!

And if you're showing someone around North Beach, you really can't miss Molinari's. It's historic!
author: Sophie D.

description:
You gotta love a place where you knock an entire shelf of capers and pepperconis on the floor and they don't even make you feel bad.
In my defense, the shelf was missing one of its supporting pegs. 
Oh, and the sandwich was good, too.
What are you gonna do? What are you gonna do?
author: Sara B.

description:
I hate to write this review, because the last thing I want is more people going to the best Italian deli in North Beach, but with 155 Yelps, I suppose the word's out.

Molinari's is really quite good. Is any place perfect? No, of course not. This place is kinda packed most lunchtimes. But otherwise, the sandwiches are authentic, the meats fresh and thinly sliced, and the "take a number" service moves pretty fast.

I've lived in North Beach for almost two years, and Molinari's is still the best Italian deli food you can get in the immediate area.
author: Christopher M.

description:
The best sandwich in the world!  Been going here since i was 8 and they never failed to bring me the perfect South Beach Special sandwich.  Very friendly service, easy to find parking around the corner just gotta look, great sandwiches, and a beautifull sceancery now what more can you ask for?

DO NOT I REPEAT DO NOT GO TO THE Philpino or asian guy he will make the best Italian deli in the west coast look like a sandwich from a cornerstore. Trust me its that serious.  This will not affect my rating of the place because any other person who makes it will turn into perfection.
author: Hanna A.

description:
One of the best deli's.  And I grew up in a blue collar town in NY.  The guys don't gush with service, but they are as rough around the edges as some say they should be.  Palermo's is great too, but Molinari's has them on selection and scale.  Their ravioli is amazing.  The deal is the foccacia bread substituted for your roll.  The sandwich is 2 meals.  
I love the north beach special, keepin it old school with the italian mix, and the sausage with pepper onions and provolone.  
Nothing like sitting in north beach on a sunny day eating a fine sandwich with a san pellegrino soda.
author: Christian W.

description:
I get cravings for coppa from Molinari. The staff is helpful and nice, they know their Italian food & wines, they call my number in Italian, and they love that I love their meat. 

Their wine selection is also fantastic--it's the first place I've seen a vermentino from Liguria in the US--ever. 

The only thing is that I get a little sad when i forget they're closed on Sunday and show up hoping to stock up.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm!!!
This is the second best vegitarian sandwhich in the city of San Francisco!  I love how they put it all together with marinated and roasted vegetables.  The portions are ginormous and more than fullfilling.  

Great little Italian deli!
author: Dangerous T.

description:
This is absolutely, bar none the best Italian shop in San Francisco.

Let me tell you why.

Every weekend or so a few buddies and I (we all live around inner richmond) jump on longboards and make the trek across the city to eat here. It's a long way, but it is well, well worth it.

The breads are fresh and tastefully chewy in the middle with just the right amount of crispiness around the crust. The meats are sliced thin to perfection while you wait. Never have I had such a great combo of sun dried tomatoes and artichoke hearts. The spicy meats are particularly delicious. Walking into the place is great as well, as it is adorned with swinging sausages and dried veggies. 

Granted, the guys behind the counter aren't going to give you lovey attention like you get at starbucks. They are there to make you your (delicious) sandwich and take the next number. There's a bin to pick up your bread and once you take your number be ready. They are good at what they do and they are quick, help them along. 


Bottom line: This place is an absolute jewel. Here's to its continuing success!
author: Jay C.

description:
Columbus st., and this delicatessen are as good as it gets for the family deli in San Francisco.
As china town grew and in my point of view destroyed upper grant and all the great italian eateries, and bakeries, this operation is a icon of great food, and yes the atmosphere remains in tack.
Coppa, prosciutto, salami in its various seasonings, and regional trademarks are big favorites of mine, and they know the sandwich, you are craving for.Plus one of the few delis that understand that you do not need all that white bread in you sandwich, ripp it out, drizzle it with olive oil,  some sweet red peppers,pepperoncini and wrap that baby up.
The Sweet sausage (Finoccchio), is the best for sauces and grilling so stock up.
Chorizo use to be made close by, but I am not sure if the family is still doing them, if they are they are the best, although some of my latin buddies might dispute this.
For salami remember they started it on the west coast, and  I still
favor it over Gallo , for seasoning and taste, hard or soft.
author: John W.

description: Holy Cow! When my boss said that we MUST MUST MUST go here when we visited SF, I couldn't have begun to understand how right he would be! I got a turkey pannini with marinated bell peppers and mozzarella and my bf got nothing bc he was being stubborn. We sat outside at the tables and noshed (of course I ended up splitting it with him) on what we both agreed was seriously the MOST AMAZING pannini/sandwich creation we have EVER had. To this day the bf regrets not getting a sandwich of his own and he longs for the day we return to SF and of course to Molinari's!
author: Chelsea T.

description: I came here with a friend of mine last week, and it was our first time coming here! We were pretty lost when it came to the whole ordering system, but the guys behind the counter were kind enough to direct us. My friend really wanted salami, saying it quite loudly for the entire place to hear, including the guys serving customers. They heard her and gave us both a slice to try! (Super nice). While I suspected that we would face a lunch line (we came at noon), the people working there were very efficient-it was the customers who took a long time to decide what to get! Anyways, I got the Renzon's special toasted. So Yummy! They are not skimpy when it comes to the meat inside the sandwiches, but they were with the pesto on my sandwich :( I think they were supposed to, but they simply forgot. Regardless, they were amazing, and my friend and I ate at Washington square-a happy lunch on a great day :)
author: Sophie D.

description: So my girlfriend and I think Molinari's may have created the perfect sandwich in the Renzo Special. Prosciutto, coppa salami (drool drool), sun-dried tomatoes, and fresh mozzarella, all on your choice of bread. (Literally: you choose the actual piece of bread your sandwich gets put on. Nice touch and, I think, a good quality control measure.) Order two (or one Renzo and another off their long menu), grab some drinks from the cooler, you've got yourself a killer picnic for about $20. Next time I'm staying a little longer to get some of their house-made pasta--hard to go wrong with prosciutto-filled tortellini.
author: Scott L.

description: If you don't love this place you're weird. Staff and food are awesome and the prices are phenomenal for what you get. Grab a sandwich and go sit in Washington Square park and enjoy the atmosphere. Its a touristy neighborhood but this makes North Beach awesome. Then later, go to the saloon and have a beer. Or if you're dry, grab a gelato.
author: Danielle W.

description:
This place is amazing!. Their salami selection is incredible. We have a tradition at work, that everytime someone leaves we take them there for lunch and eat at washington square park. 

They have a pretty good selection of sandwiches in the menu, however I like to make my own with the following:

Dutch Crunch
Pesto
Sundried Tomatoes (they are really good here)
Fresh Mozarrella
Salami

with a side of Calamari Salad.

They also have a great selection of wine and cheese. This place is a gem. Eat here!
author: Javier B.

description:
Love the Garlic Rosmary Turkey with swiss.
Bread is super fresh.. and the service is quick considering how many people are waiting in line for a sandwich during lunch.
author: Matt H.

description:
Originally from the northeast, I love my new home in San Francisco and hate those implants who talk about how things are better elsewhere.  However, great bagels, pizza, and sandwiches are few and far between here in SF.    Molinaris has taken sandwiches off that list for me.  
The grilled focaccia sandwich is one of the most delectable things I have ever put into my mouth, and although my friends swear the italian is amazing, I have yet to gather enough strength to go there and get anything but the grilled focaccia....
author: Morgen N.

description: Yum, best salami sandwich I've ever had! Very big, enough for 2 meals. Fresh vegetables, yummy bread, what's not to like?
author: Ben R.

description:
Hands down the best place in the city for a sandwich.

The guys who work here are awesome.
author: Ali G.

description: Ummmmm....most amazing sandwiches ever!!!! And the people who work there are really nice!!! We've all been to those famous delis where they are NOT nice and it makes you want to never go back no matter how good it may be.  The has awesome food AND are nice guys!! You select your bread and then you order your sandwich.  They pile it high with meat and cheese! We had the North Beach and the Renzo Special.  The roasted peppers are amazing.  I'm not a fan of sun-dried tomatoes, but they are really good here.  If I ever make it to San Fran again, I will definitely make it here.  Hands down - complete awesomeness.
author: Anne B.

description: Wow. What a great place! The biggest reason why I respect this place is because of the amazing family history associated with Molinari. It has been around since 1896, and the business has been passed down throughout the family since then. You walk in and they have every Italian food brand you could think of, from candy to cookies to soda, they have it! They are very well-known for their salami, so I had to get a salami sandwich. My mom ordered the mortadella sandwich and we sat outside with great blood orange sodas. They have a giant bin with fresh bread that you choose with tongs so they can make your sandwich for you. My mom and I kept it simple, with just provolone, mustard and mayo, and a tiny bit of olive oil. The mort was very tasty. My salami was to die for. The flavor was ridiculous! So ridiculous that we bought 3 pounds of it after eating lunch. I think the bread was pretty solid, but It would have been better if it was warmer. Provolone was superb. I love this place. 5 stars for the salami alone :).
author: Sheeva G.

description:
This is by far the best sandwich shop/deli in SF.  They have some of the best Italian cold cuts anywhere in the world and the sandwiches are the bomb.

I will respond to a handful of the reviews.

1) To the person who complained about sun dried tomatoes on every sandwich.  If you don't like them order the sandwich without.

2)  This place is not expensive.  It is cheaper than Quiznos and ways better quality.  I mean where else in the city can you get a great, large all meat sandwich and a soda for $7.50?
