3)  Finally, for the person who said they only have 1 type of bread, you are totally wrong.  They usually have at least 3-4 types of italian breads.  Would you complain at a German deli if they only had rye?  I don't think so.
author: Chris L.

description:
Be prepared to wait in line here because it's good and everyone knows it.  Sandwiches are delicious... good cheese selection... and the best frozen raviolis.  Also great for picking up italian speciality foods liked dried porcinis, tomato paste, good olive oil and vinegar, etc.

There is no where to park nearby and it takes a while, so illegal parking outside isnt really an option.  Get a friend to drive around the block while you go in and order.
author: Mary S.

description:
I come in for cheese and wine. They have both in abundance.  Eventually, when I have three or four hours to kill, I'll try their sandwiches.  Which brings me to why they lost a star.  

They need a different paying system.  If I'm standing there with a chunk of cheese and a bottle of wine, why should I stand for half an hour behind some mouth-breathing yokel of a tourist as he stands gaping at the sandwich board, mouth  hanging open, drool dripping down, trying to figure out what kind of bread he wants for his sandwich and, "will that sandwich stay good in my backpack all day?" And then wait for the sandwich to be made just so I can pay for my two things?  Can't someone take my money while the other guy makes the sandwich?

For the love of all that is holy, just let me pay for my cheese and wine and get out of here!  

Other than that, awesome deli.
author: Jamie C.

description:
For a food-town, we don't have enough of a sandwich culture.  Fortunately, Molinari's is an outstanding Italian deli.  I grew up and live here.  I spend a week a month in NYC or NJ.  I'm prepared to thrown down on the subject of Molinari's.

Ah, the sandwiches.  Too many experiences to mention, but I've spent many years working with Joe on condiment combinations.  I remember one time when Joe just drizzled the oil from the sun dried tomatoes on a sandwich - no tomatoes, just the oil...

And the pasta, meat, etc. are well worthwhile.  I've found some true finds.
author: Stefan A.

description:
If you are hungry, there is no question, San Francisco is a place that can feed you, and feed you well. Whether it's cheap eats or gourmet dining, San Francisco can be called a food mecca.  Am I biased, not at all, but I live here!

When I moved across the continent to the East Coast in 1999, after a short while, there was one thing I really missed, one thing I hungered for. My mouth watered for bacon and not just any bacon, pancetta Italian bacon. A delicacy not unique to San Francisco, surely? Of course not, depending on where you live, there is usually a good italian deli, usually an ability to find a decent salami and succulent italian sausages. But good hand cured pancetta, that's an entirely different story.

I lived too far from Washington D.C. to get to Dean and Deluca for goods and let's face it, good though they may be, they are also overpriced. I also lived out in what would be considered the sticks, so I was nowhere near a deli and Safeway's deli counter had nothing so esoteric as pancetta. What's a girl to do?

I did what any hungry person would do, I found a way! If I was flying back to San Francisco for a visit, I always included a stop in North Beach to my own holy grail of an italian deli, Molinari's for pancetta, which I then froze and carried lovingly in my luggage and doled out as slowly as I could manage. At this I was not successful and it never lasted nearly as long as the cravings. I induced friends to do the same, or people in the San Francisco branch of the law firm I worked for, yes, I was desperate, I would have them freeze and send me pancetta through inter-office fedex.

So, now eight years on, I am returned home and it was not too long before I found myself making a pilgrimage to the mecca for all things good that are Italian. Molinari's on the corner of Columbus (cross Vallejo). It is a well known spot for people working in the Financial District to take a short hike to Molinari's for a delicious hand-made sandwich at lunch time (remember, take a number and pick your roll for your sandwich in advance folks).

Enough about me, though.

Molinari's has all sorts of delicious prepared foods, fresh pasta and Italian goods on the wall, you almost feel like you've stepped back in time to an old-fashioned grocery.  As a matter of fact, you have.  Molinari is 100+ and going strong, Thank God.  If it's a sandwich you want, go here, if you want to stock your pantry, go here, if you want the most delicious domestic salami and other delicate cured meats, go here.  There is no better spot in SF to satisfy that rustic craving for cured meats and cheeses.  The wine selection is pretty good.  The guys are friendly, helpful with questions and quick as they can be and it's entertaining just to shop there.  I love Molinari and, unless you're a vegan or dead, you'll love them too, trust me on this one.
author: Donna H.

description:
obnoxious sandwiches.
pepper shooters, marinated shrooms and arties.
Rosemary foccacia.
Awesome wine.
Chicken-parm to die for.
author: Rick H.

description:
Try salami and bread!
Cant find better than in this place. 
Used to make my lunch sandwiches outta their products!
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: This place has awesome, tasty sandwiches. The ticket system doesn't seem to work all that great here but they use fresh ingredients which make up wonderful sandwiches. There are a few seats and tables outside which are good for eating and people-watching.
author: Sam G.

description: During my trip up North, we were staying nearby at the Hilton in the FiDi and found ourselves walking to Molinari's almost every day. I love the fact that you're able to create your own sandwich or just order right off the menu. My sandwich of choice consisted of prosciutto, sun-dried tomatoes, roasted red bell peppers, and fresh mozzarella. My boyfriend ordered the Molinari's which consisted of different salami meats. I became addicted to their sandwiches after the first bite and dragged my boyfriend back here right before we left SF so I could get just one more sandwich for the road.
author: Tiffany L.

description: There operation behind the counter is absolute chaos.  No one is stationed at the cash register for those who only want to buy some cheese or wine.  You have four people behind counter each working on a sandwich order, each in everyone else's way while the customers who only want to pay for their items in hand must wait for up to 10 minutes to pay for their items.  After 5 visits to this deli, customer service is not a hallmark of this operation.  The last visit I got tired of waiting and left after 10 minutes.  Apparently is you aren't buying a sandwich, your business does not matter here.
author: Michael L.

description:
Yummy yummy yummy!!!  This is the best delicateessan I have every been to!!!  The meats, chesse, pastas and much much more!!!  The Joes Special is seriously special!  I can just taste the delicious basil spread or the homebaked bread with large slices of mozzarella, sundried tomatoes and amazing peppers!!!   Clearly I am salavating! 

Everytime I walk in the staff recognizes me and knows what I want.  The manager Franco is a sweetheart always singing.  Jesus, Vinny, Fidel and another guys with cool shapes shaved in his head are always so helpful and will add a little extra salami when I need it . ;)

Once peiece of advice, make sure you grab a # as you enter, because its not obvious.  since the deli is well known it is always busy so you dont want to wait extra time.  And bringing lots of quarters for the meters.  The change and short wait are well worth it!
author: erica b.

description:
EPIC epic sandwiches, if you are a sandwich lover and live in the city you have to try this place. Its been around for 100+ years or so and its got all the charm of an old Italian market.

I recently tried the chicken parm, which was unbelievably good, but over priced at 9 bucks. Other sandwiches are great too, and here's a tip: take a number and grab your bread from the clear bins next to the counter then hand it to the dudes behind the counter. Messed this up the first time and felt like a rookie....
author: Nick A.

description:
Really good, the sandwiches are top-notch, some of the best panini in frisco! The meats are also b-e-a-utiful and the people that work there are great too!
If you like a classic Italian deli, sandwich, or even just love meats (like me) then this is a place to go.
author: Asher G.

description:
*How I love Italian Deli, let me count the ways...*

I dream about this place.  I really do.  Order something you've never tried before.  Go out on a limb and ask the guys behind the counter what their favorite is.  A sandwich from Molinari's can set you a blaze.  Be Brave!!! Enjoy.
author: Alicia W.

description:
SO good! I took my parents and we split 2 sandwiches, and we still had too much food. Very generous portions. The pressed sandwich we had was the best. It had some tasty pesto spread on it.

It also seemed like they had a good selection of wine too. Fun place to grab food for a picnic in the park across the street.
author: Lisa H.

description:
SANDWICHES... I agree. take you bread, take a number and join the queue. No complaining. It's gonna be a great sandwich.
While you're there you should definitely stock up on fresh pasta to take home for dinner.  The Lasagna is killer, especially the vege.  Same goes for the fresh ravioli, & tortellini.
The cut meats - five stars. 
Olives - 4 stars
My personal favorite .... White Sardines. They're pricey but great.
author: MissSkip Z.

description:
My quest for the new "Phat Hippos' Best Deli" is still an ongoing failure.  One big reason, Molinari's. Few come close to Molinaris, and many have failed.  So snag your number, head for the bread trough, and make sure you know what you want. Don't be an idiot and ignore the boys behind the counter calling your number.

Hands down, my favorite deli in San Francisco.  It's even better than Genova's Deli in Oakland.  Monster sandwiches, with premium meats hand sliced to order.  The herb seed bread is my favorite, but the foccacia upgrade is always another great choice. The cold foods are a plenty.  The pasta salads are creamy and darn tasty.  Mortadella, Head cheese, Roast Beef, supreme slices of Prosciutto, Coppa, Salami, you name it baby; the meat is all that, and a bag of chips.  They're always consistent with the right amount of everything.  My father told me stories about an amazing ox tongue they used to carry back in the days.  I'm sad that its not there, but I mean this place was up and running since the 1800's. If your unsure, the Italian sub is a must try.  A little bit of the best they have all in one packed sub. 

The fresh pasta's are a must take home for the home cook.  Light, almost airy with a heavenly texture, the reasonably priced pastas are ohh so yummy.  Fresh pastas cook fast so be careful not to over cook. There are many great selections of wines, specialty cheeses,  oils, vinegars and other specialty items.  I've had my eye on the big bag of dried porcini mushrooms.

Women, I suggest flirting with the boys behind the counter. The boys seem to provide a "little extra" for a smile.  It's sad that it doesn't work for me, but I'd come back any day. It's worth the wait, and the money.  Molinari's please don't ever close, for I have no other to turn to.  Thanks for being the most amazing deli in San Francisco.  This place does it right.
author: Phat Hippo L.

description: Yikes. A friend of mine took me here today -- now I feel like I'll be going back every day and going broke because of it. The veggie sandwich is AMAZINGLY DELICIOUS. The sun-dried tomatoes at this place are so perfectly juicy and sweet. I can't speak for the sandwiches with meat but I'm sure they're out of this world as well. Go here. You won't regret it.
author: Margaret Y.

description: Want an excellent italian deli sandwich? Go here.  I had the hot coppa sandwich, and it was exceptional.  The best deli sandwich I've had in a very long time.
author: Eric V.

description: Delicious, Delicious Sandwiches !!!!! Now I only wish I lived in SF ! LOVED the ambiance.. So traditional and Italian!
author: Jessica L.

description: This is one of my favorite places for salami and Italian products in San Francisco's North Beach area.
author: Gordon H.

description: Got the Lusciano (Luciano?) special. It was moist, but crispy. Very large portion - easily splittable if u each grab some chips. Meats were high quality and the mozzarella was heaven. Funny staff - very Italian American personas.
author: Khalid N.

description: Real deal salumeria!  Reminds me of Enoteca Verdi in Firenze. Only thing missing are the Italians!
author: Roger H.

description: Great Italian deli / market. I got the Renzo Special sandwich and it was amazing. You choose your own piece of bread, which I love. The cheese was fresh and in huge chunks, the sun dried tomatoes were tangy and perfect. The prices were reasonable, everyone takes a number so orders aren't chaos. Will definitely be back, I was scoping out the cheeses and the prices were great.
author: Beth D.

description: amazing sandwiches, and an amazing knowledge staff.  I go here often and you always think there is not enough seating but when you go outside there always seems to be a seat if not off to washington square for a spontaneous picnic :)
author: Jennifer D.

description:
That Italian Feel | Fantastic Sandwich's

Family run, been around for ages, staff is friendly and a bunch of characters.  Sandwich's are great and if you need some supplies for that Italian dinner your making for your honey you can here.

When I first went there to order lunch I was a bit confused.  If there is a line, and there usually is at lunch time, you have to take a deli number.  While you wait you have to select the type of bread you want for your sandwich form a bin of bread.  Then when it's your turn give them your bread tell them what type of sandwich and any customization you require.

Atmosphere - A deli from Italy, reminds me of the North End in Beantown.  There are two small round tables outside where you can enjoy your sandwich.
Staff - Friendly with some having Italian accents.
Food - I have a had a lot of their sandwiches, but I recommend getting the Lucciano Special (if you like cured ham)
Price - Sandwiches range from $7 - $9, w/ the Lucciano being $9, but it's so big you can eat the other half for lunch the next day.
Recommend - Yes, a score of 5 meat balls!

5 Stars - Friendly staff, food is good and it has a lot of character.
author: Po L.

description:
They have great deli meat and good bread. But the people who work there are really careless and grumpy. My sandwich today had so much mayo, that it was bordering on being inedible. When I opened up my bag, there was mayo overflowing everywhere. I think the guy who made my sandwich put 4 to 5 times more mayo than needed. And this is coming from a guy who loves mayo.

In addition, most of the time I go here, the workers look so annoyed that it's hard to maintain any kind of a good mood when I visit. I always wonder why these guys just don't quit. I'd probably rush back to Molinari's if I didn't think some angry old man was gonna get annoyed at me.

I still think the best sandwich is from Andronico's. Their products are as good if not better than Molinari, and their staff always has a smile on their face.
author: Joon L.

description:
Yummy sandwiches! Thank you!
Love their sweet bell peppers and home-made mozzarella. Have to try their famous sausages next time.

One small note:
Would you please wear gloves when putting together yummy sandwiches??  It's more sanitary. Thanks!
author: adlib a.

description:
WOW! Simple and great... 

Had the Molinari special sandwich, walked a few blocks north to the park... and had the best lunch since landing in SF.
author: tyrus s.

description:
Easily the best sandwiches in North Beach.

A great Italian deli as well with a good selection of meats, cheeses, breads and wine.
author: Eric T.

description:
Awesome. 

Walked by this place while strolling on Columbus and saw the sizeable line. Once I got a view of the home made salumi hanging over the deli I knew this was the place. 

Got the sausage sandwich, grilled pannini-style on the recommendation of the easy-going counter guy with a noticeable Phily accent.  I took it up to Washington Square park, sat on the grass in the sun, and ate the whole thing.  It was a mess, but I didn't care. I licked the marinara off my fingers and picked the onions stuck in the melted cheese out of the nooks of the paper wrapping. 

Couldn't have been happier.
author: stephen a.

description: This was a must stop for my good friend and now I see why. Fantastic salami that is made by Molinari. They are the best! They also make sandwiches on site, something I will definitely keep in mind for my next trip! If you are in the area check them out.
author: Tony T.

description: The best place to get a great sandwich! They make their own salami and sausages. They sell everything thats Italian.I like the Northbeach special but I change it to the Toscano salami and add some basil and garlic sauce to my sandwich! YUM!!! :)'
author: Benjamin G.

description: When I think of home and I think of Italian, this is the first place that comes to mind. The people working the place are authentic and they love their work. You stay inside long enough, you start talking with an Italian accent. The food is awesome, which is a given, but you cannot walk into this joint and not walk out with gifts and stuff to send to friends or just keep for yourself. They also ship their items. I only wish we had one here in Colorado.
author: Deb K.

description:
I like the feel of Molinari. But, the fact that you have to literally hand-hold the sandwich maker each and every time you order (they all have their own mind when it comes to the "works"), makes it kinda annoying.
Back in the day we had options in No. Beach - Iacopis, Panneli Bros., the ravioli factory. Now, it's just molinari and palermo and I hear molinari is closing soon.
oh, the good ole days.
author: Ron P.

description:
Best sandwiches ever, especially the South Beach Special.  I love the fact that you pick your own bread of our a bin.

The staff is extremely friendly (and sometimes flirty) and look like they're having fun.

Grab a sandwich and go eat it in Washington Square Park!  Perfect!
author: Jen N.

description: Love this place.  Great deli sandwiches that are big and lasted me from lunch through dinner.  Can be long lines, but very worth it.  The sweet peppers in the vegetarian are very tasty.  I could definitely get fat on this place.
author: Phil J.

description: Great old time Italian deli.  I have been going here for years and it is more into sandwiches now.  The salami and cured meats are the best.  The raviolis are awesome (beef) and the meat sauce and mushrooms.  I did not like the young server (with thin razor etchings on his face) was flippant and thinking he was funny...I came during the North Beach festival this weekend and it was crazy busy.  The sandwiches are good, but you must have good teeth for the crispy hard bread and I did not see a sourdough which I love.  They used to have wonderful antipasto and pastina soup,but not anymore.  They have the best mortedella with pistacios.
author: Gina G.

description: Holy flipping cow....today I had such a wonderful sandwich from them.  I had the south beach special and was in heaven.  Their turkey breast is so tasty and flavorful, the provolone was fresh and delicious, the garlic basil spread was something I need to add to my sandwich WAY more often... add that with some delicious sun dried tomatoes and artichoke hearts and they made me one happy lady.  I didn't know when I first walked in, but you grab a roll out of a bin and give it to the guy behind the counter when you are ordering a sandwich.  It only took a few people ahead of me for this genius to catch on!  :)  I would highly recommend it.  Large sandwiches, be forewarned!  I believe the price was 8.95.
author: Kirsten O.

description: my former coworker always raved about this place, and i finally finally made it out here today. got the molinari special with fresh mozzarella and basil spread. the meats and ingredients are top quality, best sammich in the fidi... alas, might be the last time i visit. bummed... thank you a.r.
author: Ethan L.

description:
Cheap San Marzano tomatoes! 

If you like to cook Italian food, Molinari is a great place to shop. They introduced me to Del Verde pasta by explaining what makes it better than De Cecco. I do love stores where they know their products!  (Side note: I'll buy any Del Verde and then figure out a sauce to go with it.)

They've advised me on brands of capers and uses for their olives, of which they have a nice selection for antipasti. They carry good carnaroli for risotto. They also make excellent sausage without fennel seeds (VERY hard to find.)

Take a ticket the moment you walk in, then shop, unless you think you'll be forty-five minutes browsing, because they can get busy at a moment's notice. This is no doubt due to the demand for their sandwiches, which are quite good.

The location makes Molinari a fun place to shop for dinner, have lunch, and stroll around. Since it's right in the heart of North Beach, you'll need to drive compact and be aggressive to find parking, but when you do, Molinari is worth it. It's my favorite Italian deli in SF, hands down.
author: Simone E.

description:
Great sandwich.  If Roxie did not exist, could be #1

If you live in SF,  go during the week.  If you want a good ravioli and meat sauce, this is the spot if you can't get to LUCCA on Valencia. Family style deli that is more famous than you may think outside of SF.  

Chicken cutlet, add spicy copa, swiss on soft roll. So good.

Grab a number, know what you want before your number is up.
author: Mo G.

description:
Mmmm best provolone and prosciutto sandwich ever!
They'll even let you drink wine out front with your lunch. (classy plastic cup included!)
True Italian Deli.
author: Kitty S.

description: This is by far the best italian deli we have ever been to.  Great sandwiches, friendly service and a cute place with nice outdoor seating.  Having just moved to NB , we were able to take it all in while enjoying our lunch from Molinaris!
author: Fabian M.

description: I started to salivate while thinking of the memory of half a Molinari sandwich sitting in the fridge. This place is a gem, especially in the North Beach neighborhood. Don't forget to get a number as you walk in.. then peruse all the wonderful imported Italian goodies lining every free inch of space. I love sandwiches and delicious grilled ones make me feel like I'm walking on clouds of warm bread and melted cheese. I really enjoyed the Luciano sandwich, made on a large focaccia round..enough for two meals, ergo the half in the fridge. Grilled or cold, equally delicious. It will definitely be my go-to spot in North Beach from now on, and I want to try different sandwiches. No more pasta restaurants where I feel I could have made it at home and done it better.
author: Faye P.

description: Let me just preface this by saying, im Italian, I lived in places that know great Italian foods, Italy, Philly, and south Jersey. I've been to countless Italian delis and this is one of the Best! It reminds me of my favorite one back in South Philly. Its kind of an inside opertation as far as grabbing your own bread and taking a number. Once you know that tho, the rest is heaven. The day we went it was packed, elbow to elbow. All the guys behind the counter were friendly, helpful and even patient (which for anyone from jersey/philly will tell you doesn't happen there!). My friends and I all ordered sandwiches can't remember specifically but didn't matter I would've been happy with them all. They were delicious. We grabbed a table outside and it was perfect. We also bought some frozen homemade raviolis to take home. I usually don't eat meat raviolis but these were the best EVER hands down. So much flavor. So grab some and make em at home, you wont regret it.
author: Vickie B.

description: Make sure to grab the bread BEFORE they call your number. If you're not ready, they'll move on! I had the eggplant parmesan sandwich and it was hot and delicious. Perfect for a cold day. There's only a couple tables outside, so make sure you have a place to go in mind if the tables are full. I'll definitely be back!
author: Tamara M.

description: Been here a few times. Haven't had a bad sand yet.. reasonably priced and big enough to share, me and B usually split a salami and pastrami. Been delicious every time. Seating is limited to a few small tables on the sidewalk out front, but this neighborhood is saturated with bars that don't have a problem with you bringing your carry out sand in with you. One thing that kinda pissed me off the last time we went though.. B wanted to have a roll of Salami so she bought one and asked the guy how long it will keep. Dude was like "3 or 4 months, just wrap it in cellophane and if you see some mold on it, cut it off.." So I'm looking at B like WTF and she nods her head, like "ok" implying this shit is normal. The counter guy yammered on about how "most people think the white stuff on the salami rolls hanging overhead is flour. It's not. It's mold." WTF, over? He's carrying on about nitrates and who knows what the fuck else. I don't know..B is the house cook and she says it's all good and I'm sure I've ate a lot of shit that can kill me from McD's and numerous random Taco stands, but still, this case was def TMI...
author: Morris D.

description: oh hell yes. Some of the best deli sandwiches EVER
author: M. W.

description: Amazing sandwiches (anything with their fresh mozzarella and roasted peppers will blow you away) are just the start, it's also a great place to pick up gifts for your Italian friends and family.
author: Russ C.

description: Not that impressed. They only have 1 type of bread. Really...a deli with only 1 type of bread!  Not sure what you call it.....maybe a dutch crunch roll? Some type of white bread roll that they slice in half.  They don't even have it behind the counter. You have to grab it from a bin, where people may or may not have probably already touched it. I'm not a germaphob at all, but it's a little disconcerting to know that someone probably had their germy un-washed hands all over my bread. Now that I know this, I will never, ever go here again for a sandwich. With the plethora of other great sandwich spots in north beach, why would I go here? Yes, this is a real deli though...they've got salami hanging from the ceiling and wall to wall pasta, sauces, and olive oil.  I may come back here to purchase ravioli, but definitely not for a sandwich.
author: Julie F.

description: Molinari sandwiches are FUCKING DELICIOUS. I love salami, and prosciutto (my favorite sandwich meats) . My boyfriend took me here because I was craving for a prosciutto sandwich. You go in, grab a number, pick out some bread for your sandwich and wait until someone calls your number. The day that I came, it was super crowded ..waited about 15 min for my sandwich, but the wait was well worth it because I was very pleased with my sandwich. Coincidentally one of my boyfriends old high school friend worked here so he made him a totally different sandwich with all sorts of different meats with some delicious bread. I liked how he just created something and it turned out bomb. We walked over to washington square park and enjoyed lunch on a nice sunny day. Parking is really hard (anywhere in north beach is hard in general) so dont get too frustrated if it takes a long time...because I mean thats like asking to find parking in downtown. I'm not sure if they take card, so bring cash. Happy eating!
author: Colette P.

description:
Stumbled upon this deli while walking around north beach the other day, WOW.

Got the luciano special (prosciotto de parma, coppa, fresh mozz, sun dried tomatoes, arugula, maybe something else? on grilled foccacia)

Best sandwich I have had in a LONG time. Also got some white bean salad that was super legit. 

While I was waiting I noticed a lot of locals stopping in for raviolis, pasta sauce, cheese, etc. which is always a good sign.

I will be back.
author: Brian D.

description: Founded in 1895, this landmark - reputed to be the oldest delicatessen west of the Rockies - is to North Beach what Lucca is to the Marina, a one-stop-shopping source of Italian necessities and delicacies. Deli meats include prosciutto, hot and sweet copa, salami, and pepperoni, and among the cheeses you'll find imported aged provolone, Paremsan, Romano, gorgonzola, fontina, and fresh mozzarella di Bufala. The shelves are lined with cans of tuna, sardines, and anchovies, bottles of olive oil and balsamic vinegar, cans of espresso, and boxes of biscotti, and you'll find an array of fresh pastas and sauces. The staff churns out overstuffed hot and cold gourmet sandwiches rapidly enough to keep the line moving at a steady clip.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I've been going here for 29 years, and it's by far the best deli i've ever been in.  Please do yourself a favor and try to order from something that's NOT a pre-determined sandwich.  Mix it up a little bit.  Hot Coppa and Toscano Salame together, or Mild Coppa and Prosciutto, or Prosciutto and boiled ham.  The combinations of salted, cured meats is endless.  Also, go to the back case and get some home made Prosciutto stuffed tortellini.  Amazing.
author: Nick T.

description: GAAAAAAAAAHHHHHH! This place is so stupid good. They never never miss. Grab a number, pick your bread and practice your Italian on the fellas. The bread is delivered at 11:30am so that is the best time to get there. Get peppers and sun dried tomatoes on everything!
author: William R.

description:
Call me crazy, I'm Italian, and I actually didn't care for their sandwiches.  For 9-10 bucks per sandwich, they had very little flavor.  After the first bite, I had to pretend I was eating the $5 footlong chicken teriyaki from subway just to get through it 

Now, that's not to say that the atmosphere isn't awesome.  I felt like I was in the middle of New Yawk the way they speak.  And yes they even speak Italian! Very cool.  Very authentic.  And the staff was nice, except for the pressure they put on us to buy the most expensive foods and drinks..blahh. 

They do have a good selection of CHEESE! Can't go wrong there.  Sometime I'd like to go back and get some. Also the meats are pretty good. Try the spicy coppa. It was DEE-LISH. 

I wouldnt recommend getting a SANDWICH here at all.  If anything, go and buy individual things like meats, cheese, etc and go home and make your own.  But all-in-all, I can't say I was too impressed, sorry!
author: Christine X.

description: This deli is quite popular in the heart of lil italy down in NorthBeach.  It's the typical italian deli that is usually  bustling with business.  The workers are friendly but do sometimes snap like the seinfeld soup nazi if you delay or sound confused, they'll lay into pretty good.  With that said, the sandwiches are pretty good and they make them fair size.  The main con to this place i'd say is the sandwiches weren't over the top great, they were good but nothing spectacular that'd make you crave the place.  It's definately one of the top deli's in SF that i've been to, no complaints about the sandwiches or experience i've had there.
author: Christian W.

description: Grab a sandwich and walk two blocks to Washington Square Park and dine al fresco.  I'm not a sandwich lover, but am in love with their sausage and green pepper sandwich.   Not too greasy (not exactly heart healthy either) but seasoned/cooked just right.  I'm going for one now.  Just the right meal to get rid of the bad taste from dinner at Chez Panisse last night. (note to self-skip CP in future)
author: Peter S.

description:
Exactly how you would expect North Beach to be.  (Overall, North Beach isn't authentic.  It's sad - kinda like how I feel about the chain restaurants invading Manhattan.)

I digress - awesome sandwiches, I had the sausage and peppers.  I plan to go back one day after work when I'm in the mood to cook an Italian dinner.  The fresh pasta, pancetta, focaccia and cheeses looked amazing!
author: AngelaS F.

description:
Best sandwiches in SF. 

To the previous posters: you have to get there early for an extensive choice of bread, they run out. And you have to grab your own from the bin...come on!
author: J. B.

description: I have very fond memories of coming to Molinari's on lunchtime adventures. When the world was simpler, cruising around the streets of SF with fun co-workers seemed like such a right. Any way, I always got the same thing, the Mozarella and peppers sandwich on a hard roll (self selected, of course). Delicious.
author: Milk and Cheese ..

description: Sometimes, I miss the east coast.  Not the cold winters or the humid summers...not the fast pace...or the traffic on the NJ Turnpike.  What i miss the most are the great Italian delis.   Molinari has the best Italian sandwiches in the city and by far the best ravioli (no offense grandma!)  If you haven't been here, get there (and bring an appetite).
author: Mike F.

description: I once catered a party of cold cuts from Molinari's, and it was fantastic, though I forgot what one of the salamis was and named it 'mystery meat'. Used to get their red pepper sandwich and sit in the park for lunch when I worked nearby. Very knowledgeable staff, and a great collection of meats.
author: Anna B.

description: Meats, cheese, and wine galore - amazing.  I wish we lived closer!
author: J B.

description:
1)  Take a number in front of the register once you walk in.
2)  Pick out which bread you want...NOT what type of bread...but which 
      piece of bread you want...i know...i know...only one type of bread?! (i 
      'think' the selection depends on the time you get there)
      ...but...trust me!  it's what's on the inside that matters!
3)  Wait til your number gets called...tell them what you want in your 
      sammie, and order sides.
4)  ONLY if it's a nice day...take your food to the park...
      ...If the weather sucks...skip to 5. 
5)  Enjoy your super super SUPER deeeeelish meal!
author: Nancy T.

description: Wow, just thinking about writing this made me decide to go here for a lunch of caprese samdwich... SOOOO good, but sometimes really really busy.  The guy from Philly in the office thinks this place is the business, and as I have never really known anything but Genova in the east bay and the odd pizza shop in NYC... I'm happy with what I get and what I can buy there!
author: Catherine R.

description: I am almost positive Molinari is the only place left in town that sells Kimbo espresso coffee.  For that alone it gets 5 stars.  The Italians out there know why...
author: Matteo F.

description: One of my favorite places to bring out-of-towners.  If you have to go to North Beach, at least take the time to grab one of the best sandwiches you'll ever have.  I mean, come on.  You spend forever looking for parking, at least grab a Lorenzo's special and an arancini for your efforts.  Their stuffed peppers are also killer.  If my fiance ever finds out that I went to Molinari's without bringing some home, I will definitely by sleeping in the dog house that night.
author: Benjamin P.

description: The only reason this mega-cracked-laced deli doesn't get 5 stars is b/c there is basically no seating in the place and they're not open on Sundays. Other than that, may this place be a contributor to my last meal. Salami piccante and coppa will restore your faith in just about anything and brighten up the darkest of days.
author: Jen H.

description: I felt like I was in New York when I was in Molinari's.... The sandwich was great, I love that they use sun dried tomatoes instead of fresh.  I had a Joes special which is a great vegetarian choice.  The bread was good and hard just the way I like it.  My only complaint was the sanitary practices.  No one was wearing gloves and they took peoples money and then went straight for the meat and veggies without washing their hands.
author: Marissa P.

description: Does this place need any more 5 star reviews??  Haha, screw it---here we go.  This is hands down the best Italian deli I've been to in SF.  Great cuts of meat, fresh cheeses and condiments (like sundried tomatoes, etc) which translate into excellent sandwiches.  Regarding what to get---I feel like you can't miss.   The real cool thing is how fresh everything is so assemble something you'll like.
author: Raman R.

description: Hands down, the best Italian sausages anywhere. They supply some of the markets around town and wish I could mail order these from LA.
author: Scott M.

description: Prosciutto foccacia special... that thing is like an UFO kekek!!  The sammich is mucho mucho delicious!  That thing is so huge that I can totally split with someone and still be mucho full!  The Raviolli are so good and easy, add some vodka sauce, slice some mozzarella balls on top, dinner served.  Also, the foccacia look-a-like herb bread in a bag is TO DIE FOR!!  omg... just... omg....
author: Gigi T.

description: This is the only surviving authentic italian deli in North Beach, genuine right down to the sticks of salami hanging down from the rafters.  The sights and smells are wonderful here. You start by picking out your own french roll from a basket and then walk over to the meat counter with it where they display a truly glorious selection of italian deli meats and cheeses, some of which you are sure to have never heard of before.  They have standard sandwich selections for sure, but if you prefer, and I did, you can ask for an italian sandwich and pick out which meats you want on yours.  I'm sure the service dude was annoyed with me, because I asked for about six different kinds of cold cuts. But the result was one of the most satisfying and delicious italian sandwiches I've had.
author: Rick H.

description: Such a cultural experience. So much selection. I love this place. Have to come and try the sanwiches.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
molinari's used to be my favorite place to pick up sandwiches for impromptu picnics at washington sq. park..back before i cared that i'd wake up to a homelessperson spooning me on the grass. 

the lines can be rough and there is painful parking in the area so be prepared...but it's a well-stocked, proper italian deli so you can create something wonderful or let their staff guide you. molinari's homemade lasagnas are great to take to [those unfortunate] potluck events. and the fresh ovolini di mozzarella make for a delicious appetizer when a single anchovy is wrapped around each (ladies, don't squirm. anchovies are dead sexy).

p.s. make sure you get a number...i have severe ADD and sometimes can't BELIEVE how long i have to wait when i forget this one hugely important detail
author: Lola S.

description: It's been months since our trip to San Francisco and by partner still says this deli ruined all mediocre delis for him. Try the fresh, fresh mozzarella!
author: Andrea S.

description: Such a big sandwich at such a reasonable price.  I got the Italian combo on foccacia and that sucker had so much meat and vegetables in it.  Next time I will try some of their ravioli and house made sausages.  So good.
author: Anna K.

description: Probably the best Italian deli in San Francisco (may be tied with Lucca in the Mission).  Great sandwiches, fresh pasta and Italian food that you can't find anywhere else.  Don't forget to take a number!
author: Gabriella K.

description: We have 2.5 lbs of Italian deli meats to play with over the holiday weekend!  DAMN good salami, best I've had in this country I believe. The hot coppa is quite good--it has that perfume of coppa you find  in Italy, but the heat is all at the finish, rather than any kind of subtle dynamic where you get some heat at the beginning, a different reach heat in the middle, and another kind at the end, which is what we usually found in Italy.  But that is admittedly too much to expect, eh?  Nonetheless so much better than what I got at Draeger's or numerous other deli's in this city.  The meat far exceeds the rest of the store.  I found the cheeses a little disappointing.  The dusty shelves of Italian groceries are really just decor.  Friendly dude waited on us, and we had a nice chat about Barcelona.
author: Kevin S.

description: My husband thinks this is his place and his discovery. He's going to be mad that I'm writing about "his" place. Anyway, two words from me--Hot Salami. The best deli and the best salumi in San Francisco. Not like an east coast deli, but still classic.
author: Thanya S.

description: Best Italian sandwiches....HUGE! with the roasted peppers, olive oil and vinegar....YUM! You walk in and feel like you are watching an episode of Soprano's....seems everytime I go there is usually older Italian women doing their shopping....variety of cheeses and meats.....
author: Nancy P.

description: Their Genco Olive oil in gallon can sucks. Stomache didn't feel good after trying it 3 times. Loss of 21 dollars.  It says "Imported From Italy" on the front of can. Great I want Italian olive oil, but then in smaller, hard to see print on the side of the can says it also may have Tunisian oil. No fresh date either. Looked it up on the web and there's no presence of this company in Italy, its just some American importer's company name probably, scamming Tunisian olive oil as Italian oil. The owner of Molinari should put more energy into the grocery products.
author: Tom K.

description: Thank goodness I moved to NB, man.  Gastronomical delights abound, but few satisfy me more than Molinari's.  Best salame sandwich ever.  I'm a purist sandwich lover-- give me some meat, bread, and mustard, and I'm a happy girl.  At Molinari's, they pile on the meat, you choose your own bread, and the mustard is spicy-but-not-too-spicy.  Bravo!  Sandwich bliss.
author: Sheila W.

description:
i got all flustered when i was in here trying to nail the perfect sando the first time i was there and just ordered the molinaris special. i also picked up a softer bread than i would have liked but the half that i ate in the park with a small bottle of wine didn't leave me disappointed at all. the display with their parms made me want to try their parm sandos too and i can't wait to go back and get a meatball. the guys working behind the counter were also super friendly and patient. my sandwich was up a lot quicker than i thought it was going to be and the guy just waited to ring me up while i obliviously wandered the store looking for other things to buy. i can't wait to go back.

gosh i love sandwiches!!
author: marisa g.

description:
Yum. I love this place. It's in the middle of touristville so it's a little frustrating to push away from the people with socks and tevas and fanny packs and big grey sweatshirts that has "SAN FRANCISCO" emblazoned on it because they can't actually believe that it could possibly be sunny and 60 degrees in August here and just didn't bring anything.

Very Italian. Pick your bread, bring it up to the counter and pick your favorite cured meats, add peppers and voila. One freaking delicious sandwich you will never forget.
author: Tracy Y.

description: Seriously the best place for sandwiches, period. The sandwiches with sundried tomatoes are my favorite. I forget the names but the turkey, pesto and sundried tomato one was the last kind I had there and it was absolutely yummy! The BF got the spicy sausage/red pepper kind and he loved it as well. There's not many tables outside to sit and eat your sandwich so you have to eat it somewhere else...if it's a nice day you can go to the park and eat it there! Or eat it at the church across the street on the mountain  high stairs. Best sandwiches! :) You rock Molinari!
author: Joy A.

description: Great food, great service, great prices. Among the better sandwich shops in SF. Not my favorite--that honor goes hands down to Petite Deli--but very nice.
author: tegen d.

description: Awesome, authentic Italian delicatessen!  I bought 3lbs. of their handmade salame to take back to Seattle.   If you are visiting San Francisco, definitely goto North Beach and visit Molinari's!
author: James B.

description:
My favorite Italian Deli.  Amazing sandwiches... and the salami!  I could live off of their salami.

Great selection of meats, fresh pastas, and Italian produce.  I wish I had a place like this in my neighborhood.
author: Mike R.

description: It's a good, fun place in north beach to go for lunch. The guys are nicer to you once you've become more familiar to them. So everyone just get over yourselves! It's a freakin' old-school Italian Deli: a sandwich and grocery store. Not a "gourmet" shop. Jeesh!
author: William L.

description:
They have the best ham, salami etc of San francisco !!!!
I highly recommend that place.
author: Talia F.

description: I work near Molinari's, so it's really a treat that I can get a made-to-order sandwich for lunch on a whim. However, be fair warned - this Italian deli is not for the faint of heart. The sandwiches here are hearty, and pile on LAYERS of sliced meat, whether it's prosciutto, salame, bologne, and cheese. Today, I had the "Renzo Special" which was slice upon slice of prosciutto, my choice of spicy salami, and mozzarella cheese. Service is always with a smile if you get one of the younger gentlemen for your sandwich maker. Additionally, most of the sandwich specials do not include anything other than meat and cheese, so specify whether you want lettuce, tomatoes, onions, etc. on your mongo sando. Molto bene! One other caveat: these babies don't come cheap...my sandwich today was $8.50, but for all that premium Italian meat, it's hard to complain.
author: Kira K.

description:
Considering this is in a tourist neighborhood with generally over priced and average food, this is a good find.  It's a very respectable Italian deli, that makes me think of NYC \ though like Disney World it just doesn't have that same real feeling, even if it is an old school place.

I can't give this five stars--Little Lucca is still my favorite sandwich--I can give this a solid four.  They have tables outside, very nice for people watching.  The service is fast, prompt and friendly.

Also, know that if you go in to order a sandwich you have to pick your bread out yourself.

I'm a little less impressed with yellow mustard (new yorkers would use brown mustard), but the meat to bread ratio on my Italian combo was respectable if not NYC style big (so at $6.50 I'd say the price to value ratio was a bit high) and the meat was high quality.  I also got some dry salami to take home.  Next time I'll order extra peppers and no mustard.  And I'll try the meatball sub as well. 

They should can the dean martin though--it makes the place seem like a tourist trap.  

I'll go back, it's nice to have a good sandwich place to walk to.
author: Mel B.

description: Best Deli in the city. Hands down. And an absolutely charming shop to boot.
author: Cameo E.

description: Delicious meat sandwiches. I just consumed the tasty meatball parm on a crusty roll that has made me a very happy camper. I now want to curl up in a ball under my desk and lick the remaining remnants off my face.
author: Stacy T.

description: Tu Piace sandwich?  I've eaten many an Italian sandwich in my day.  Growing up on the east coast and being of Italian descent it was a once a week ritual.  That being said I had high hopes for this place and it delivers, but please take your place in line as the #2 Italian deli in the city (see review of Lucca).
author: Tom C.

description:
taste= **** excellent bread fresh meats sliced to order 
quantity ***** generous portions 
price ** decent price 
heres the problem SANITATION !!!! 
the bread is in a bin where customers put there dirty hands in and fondle ,touch and squeeze to find the perfect bun , nasty !!!
then the people working there don't wear gloves , they touch money , scratch there butts, pick up trash then make a sandwich . I also saw one of them eating olives straight out of the container then go back for more with his bare hands ... I'm surprised more people don't get sick
author: mike p.

description:
L'italia è un paese meraviglioso.  Italy is a wonderful country.  A delicatessen of Italian caliber is hard to find.  Good thing my boyfriend found Molinari's!

Here's how it works

1) Ogle all the specialities that line the shelves
2) Get a number
3) Grab the bread you want from the bin (1.25 for Focaccia)
4) Wait and ogle some more at all the yummies behind the counter, fresh raviolis, fresh pastas, homemade sauces, wide selection of antipasti, italian cheeses
5) Yay it's my turn!  Order a personalized combination of meats and cheeses on your sandwich or a made to order sandwich from the menu.  Might I suggest something with fresh Mozzarella.
6) Grab a san pellegrino from the fridge
7) Pay
8) Eat at one of the few tables outside.
9) Be very quiet as you watch and listen to a guy getting a ticket for parking in the crosswalk... Yes this place is that good, he couldn't even wait to find a parking spot.

Molinari's....Mi piace davvero
author: Ashley Q.

description: Long time classic italian deli.  Grab a sandwitch and go to the waterfront or Washington Square and enjoy!
author: Mark M.

description: Best sandwiches in the city and very friendly staff. Be prepared for a wait as this place is no secret- but it is well worth it. They also have a large selection of cheese, wine and more Italian treats.  I love getting my sandwich to-go and eating it at Washington Square.
author: Melinda Q.

description: It's the salami on the place that makes Senor Molinari the bomb. Friends from asia love it when I serve it as otsumami with beer. Yummy. WARNING: fatty spots in salami get the full flava from the meat, if served at room temperature versus chilled slices, yazzur.
author: miriam b.

description: I just finished my Renzo sandwich from Molinari and had to review while the taste is still fresh in my mouth. Great place! People were really nice. It was my first time so I didn't have a number ticket or my bread ready but since there was no line they just laughed and helped me anyway. They put a generous amount of meat on my sandwich,and the ingredients tasted very fresh. Although I am not a big fan of the really crusty bread that comes with the sandwich it is a very authentic Italian style and added to my back in Italy experience. Very good sandwich and very reasonably priced. Anything that makes me call my friend and tell her about it while I'm still eating it deserves five stars in my book.
author: Andrea B.

description: A real SF institution.  Not much that hasn't been said already, except that they have THE BEST RAVIOLI ON THE PLANET!!! (Just don't cook them much longer than 3 minutes.)
author: Val U.

description: Best deli in the City.  A real old San Francisco Classic.  My Italian grandmother always got her home made ravioli's to bring home and cook.  If you don't make your own gravy they have the best marinara gravy around and if you want real SF sourdough eat a sandwich or take home a loaf of their bread.  Great fresh aged meats, cheeses, etc.  All the Italian foods are fantastic.
author: JohnBurrough S.

description: This place was fantastic - sandwiches made to order (by the way, pick your own bread out of the box in the aisle and hand it to them) and sold side by side with Italian cheeses, pastas, wines and meats.
author: Lauren L.

description:
I tricked myself for so long into loving this place and then one day someone suggested it for lunch and I was like hmm, "I don't think their sandwiches are very good".   

I think everyone is blinded by the cute Italian Deli feel, the outspoken sandwhich handlers, the cured salami hanging from the ceiling, the fact you can pick your own bread, the fancy cheeses and olive oils that adorn the aisles.  When it comes down to it though, the sandwiches always fall short for me. The bread to meat ratio is too high and it always ends up really dry.   

I don't know what it is about this place. The menu sounds great, the sandwiches strive to be good, but I'm always disappointed when I leave.
author: A T.

description: Actually my favorite deli in the city! I live in the neighborhood, so convenience definitely gets a star, but I have never had a bad sandwich from here! The guys who work here are amazing - when I walk in they all say hi, see how my weekend is going, and to be honest I NEVER have to wait in line. They take very good care of their regulars. I brought my parents here and we were able to cut a very large line, which I did feel bad about, but then again I am here literally every week without fail. 100% go here for a delicious deli sandwich!
author: Sara L.

description: They are simply the best sandwich in town. They have a wonderful staff and selection of olives to go with your lunch. They have a menu full of gormet sandwiches that I love. And you can order something not on the menu without a second glance.
author: fuck you p.

description: Love this place great selection of meats and cheese. Friendly staff and great sandwiches! They also have tables out front so if you grab a sandwich and feeling like hanging out in north beach yu can sit and relax outside.
author: Michael W.

description: Came here today to get some tortellini and it was absolutely delicious!  Service was helpful.  When I got home and tasted the tortellini, I knew why they've been in business since 1895.  I would totally come back to this old world, tasty place!
author: Jo M.

description: authentic Italian deli with yummy cheeses, meats, pasta. Fresh mozarella. *yum*
author: Jocelyn L.

description: SA-LA-MI!   Found one of these babies in my xmas stocking--was a very, very merry Christmas.   Last visit noticed a crate of salt cod on the way out--am intrigued.
author: L W.

description: I live in the east bay and come here for my pizza ingredients.  Pepperoni and sausage is the best.  I won't eat any other.  If I don't have it, It's plain cheese for me.
author: F M.

description: There's really not much to add.  Just try Molinari....it's excellent.  I was just going to give some youngsters a tip.  If it's a nice day and you just want to hang out in North Beach, go to Molinari and order some great salami sandwiches to go, grab a bottle of wine at home, and sit in the park at Washington Square.  Or if you're crazy like the Dr., drink a 40 oz. of malt liquor with your sandwich.
author: Steven M.

description: Best deli I have been to! Take a number, pick your bread, and order a "Joe's Special" with everything. Do not go in and order a ham and cheese(God forbid!), you may get a salami thrown at you. The grilled sandwiches are great on a cold day, go for the chicken parmesan.
author: Laura F.

description: Ah, Molinari. Everyone raves about this North Beach staple and it's euphoric epicurean delights. I was eager to sample a bite from this historic eatery. When I had a sandwich I was so disappointed, it was huge on meat but small on savory. I tried a smidgen of my honey's sandwich and it was a lot better. It was an amateur sandwich selection on my part. Don't despair, the ravioli and marinara sauce that we took home was fantastic and worth a try.
author: Jessica D.

description: This is the place you come to when you want to eat the most authentic Italian sandwich. Molinari's is tasty, cheap and has a seriously friendly staff. Both my bestie and I ordered the Italian combo with provolone. And yes, they can toast the bread! Delicious! We probably could've shared a sammy, and in fact next time I return I would prefer to just share. They are quite large. I will certainly be back to pick up some of their homemade raviolis for dinner. The staff is awesome and will suggest some of their favorites if you are having a tough time deciding just what to order.
author: Jen B.

description: I only give this place three stars because one day i found the sandwich of all sandwiches.  Home made roasted pork loin with provolone cheese heated up on a roll with all the trimmings.  So why give it three stars if you love the sandwich you ask... because they quit making it.  I don't know why, because it was one of those specialties you'd have to get there early enough to get.  They would make the pork loin themselves the night before, so once they were out, no more pork loin sandwiches.  And believe me... they ran out of it quite often.  Once they quit offering that, i went on to the chicken marinara sandwich... it's good, but not the pork loin sandwich.
author: esther h.

description: Wonderful! North beach sandwich is fantastic. This is one place where the staff aren't just doing the minimum! Great customer experience! You gotta go here for lunch when in North beach San Francisco!
author: Joseph C.

description: YUM is all I can say. Take a number and get your own bread out of a big ole plastic bin. The roasted red peppers and fresh mozzarella on wheat with pesto is a MUST HAVE! Long lines on Saturdays, but oh so good!
author: Nicole S.

description: The people who slice here put on a great show and the selections   are too many, too awesome, to work your gut through without eating here twice a week for a few years. That's a lotta pork.
author: mickey l.

description: I don't find the sandwiches so great.  I also had a bad experience.  I asked for a pastrami sandwich and I end up with a mozarella/tomato sandwich and they only make the small type of ravioli,  I think they are overated.  In addition, one of the salesperson was somewhat rude making a comment that I looked "rich".  I think there is lot other places in North beach that have better quality sandwiches and products than Molinari.
author: Lutecia s.

description:
Great neighborhood deli. It is a small place but the deli counter is stuffed with a selection of meats and cheeses and deli fare, including bufala mozzarella, fresh pasta sauces, potato salad, meatballs, and breaded eggplant. They also make sandwiches for take out (or to eat at one of the tables outside). 

Cons: The hours are a bit inconvenient for those of us who work during the week (you are basically limited to shopping on Saturday, which is often busy). Staff can also be a bit gruff at times, especially when they are busy (although they have never crossed the line to outright rudeness with me).
author: C A.

description: Molinari's, in my humble opinion, has the best sandwich in the city, especially when they have still warm ciabatta in inventory.
author: pablo e.

description: The South Beach - turkey, sundried tomatoes, basil - mine with no cheese - is my favorite sandwich. LOVE it. Love choosing my own bread. Love the feeling of the store. LOVE the potato salad. I take every out-of-town guest here. It is a treasure of San Francisco and in fabulous North Beach!
author: Lucey M.

description: the quintessential Italian deli and it is located in North Beach. that's all I need to say. eat here!
author: Jeff W.

description: I'm aware that Molinari's makes excellent sandwiches of which I've had many. However, on August 17, 2012, I needed some pasta. I went in and picked up three boxes of pasta. I went to the counter. About 20 customers were there already waiting to have sandwiches made. I stood at the counter to see if there was a counter person who take my money for the pasta and I would not have to wait for the sandwich makers to make at least 20 sandwiches. That didn't happen. The sandwich preparers looked at me several times but never asked to help me. I put the pasta back on the shelf and left. I returned later when I thought they would be less busy. They still had about 20 customers. I picked up the three packages of pasta again and stood at the counter. Once again there was no counter person. I had to wait about 30 minutes before I could purchase the three boxes of pasta. This was after the employees had made about 20 sandwiches. I left after my pasta purchase. It seems that on Saturdays, Molinari's is a sandwich shop and not a deli. I don't think someone who is buying a couple of items off the shelf should have to wait until 20 sandwiches are made to make a purchase of three boxes of pasta.
author: Andrea D.

description:
This is the place to come for the best sandwiches in the city, hands down!  Each one is perfectly made, on the bread of your choice.  You can also find everything you need to make authentic sauces, pastas, etc, as well as delicious ready made sauces.  

There's a great selection of fresh meats and cheeses as well.  Basically, a deli lovers dream!
author: Meghan L.

description: Favorite delicatessen in the city. The best sandwiches and selection of cheeses. I love going here for lunch and for buying food for dinner parties. Ask the staff for their advice on the cheeses - they always give great advice. Everybody always LOVES what I bring from there.   When you go in, grab a number FIRST then start looking. If you are getting a sandwich, select your bread from the bin (my favorite is the rosemary) then check out the menu. The chicken parmesean sub is my favorite!   Note: check out store hours before you go. They don't stay open late.
author: Stephanie I.

description: If you want an old school deli sandwich that's made w/fresh cut meat, then this is the spot. You get to hand pick your bread from the bin and choose your meats and cheeses and anything else you want on it. They also make fresh pasta and sauces for that dinner or office party you decided to begrudgingly host. They also have a great selection of Italian items and ingredients that you won't find anywhere else in the city. If you want some imported salami, pepperoni, proscuitto, etc., they've got that covered too.
author: Gary T.

description: Best Italian Sub in the city! Little expensive, well mainly there sides, but worth the price. Fresh Italians.....ummmmm!
author: Rachel L.

description: Delis don't get any better than this one!  I appreciate the fact that this deli has seating as well.
author: pauline e.

description: One of the best lunches I've had was a Molinari Sandwich with everything on it, took it to Washington Square park and just chilled in the sun.
author: Debbie Y.

description: Great sandwiches.  I like to pick one up on a sunny day, head to Washington Sq park, plop down on the grass and bask in the weather  and the tasty goodness.  I usually get one of the "specials" - the juices from the roasted peppers saturate the bread making it less likely to tear open the roof of my mouth.  (The bread is a little on the tough side, at least the crust portion.)
author: darla s.

description: Oh I love this place. If we are in Little Italy, we try to go here to get our daily fixing on Mufalata. This sandwich is ginormous and delicious. You can split this between 4 people or save it for 3 meals. Very good service and selection on cold cuts. Also have pasta and soups too. I wish they have this where I live causeing parking can be a challenge. Maybe its the combinations of olives and dressing that I am attracted too, or the layers of prosciutto and ham, but anyway they make it, its delicious.
author: Mauling W.

description: This place looks tiny from the outside and if I'm honest a bit shabby, which had put me off going in. Lesson learnt never judge a book by its cover, as once you do go inside, wow! they have the most amazing selection of breads, cheeses, pasta...Fantastic range of sandwiches, which are HUGE.  Don't go here if you're are in a hurry though as you have to wait a while.
author: Carrie A.

description: Can't find a better selection of prosciutto and salami in SF!   $7 will get you a kick ass sandwich with fresh mozzarella and prosciutto.  I just hate the fact that you grab your own bread for your sandwich.   I mean I wash my hands after using the bathroom, do you?    By the way, there is another location at the Ferry Building!
author: Jason A.

description: This place is almost a four, but it gets 5 because it is a North Beach icon, and because the salami is top notch.  I am not sure why I felt like giving it a four...probably because I am just feeling saucy.  I have never had a bad sandwich...in fact, I have only had remarkably good sandwiches.  Go early or go late, because during lunch it gets crowded.
author: Blake W.

description: 6/12/08: Finally I made it to the mecca of italian dry salami (at least from my frame of reference). My wife and I have bought their dry salami all over the bay area never realizing ot thinking that the original location would be right in the middle of north beach. i stopped by this afternoon and grabbed some fresh pasta (homemade ravioli's and gnocchi's) plus a half pound of pancetta. Will have to update my review after cooking the pasta, my mouth has already strated watering...
author: Jesse W.

description: Classic place to get a sandwich.  This place knows how to do there meats right.  Also, they sell homemade pasta as well.  Get there early to beat the lunch rush!
author: Moe J.

description: Before visiting SF, I found out about Molinari Delicatessen through yelp.  It was helpful to read the reviews and find out the system if you want a sandwich (pick a number, then get your bread and wait until number is called, etc.).  Anyway, I had a turkey sandwich, and it was delicious!  Yes, service is a little on the slow side, but when you taste your sandwich, you realize it was worth the wait.  Would I go back the next time I'm in SF?  Hell, yeah!
author: K G.

description: Friendiest people, great sandwiches, all great.  But there is one thing that really bothers me at Molinari's  is when the server who makes your sandwich (no gloves)  and is also the cashier.
author: Eatalot Y.

description: Favorite sandwhich to order, Joe's Special on dutch crunch.
author: Niki M.

description: Have been here a couple of times while hanging out in North Beach and I have to say it's wonderful.  Can't beat the smell when you walk in and peruse all the wonderful Italian Meats and Cheeses...Great sandwiches!
author: Denny R.

description: 4 stars for food, minus one for service.  What is it with these west coast delis and their absolute inability to adapt when you ask for something not on their "official sandwich list".  Yes I want Prosciutto AND Capicola - don't look at me like I have 2 heads.  Joe, the owner is totally cool, some of his workers just don't get it.
author: Max C.

description: Besides the hottie married Italians or the hipsters (at the Ferry Bldg location), the food is delicious.It's not a deli on the east coast, granted, but it's the best deli in San Francisco. They are a bit weary about vegetarians sometimes - they're like "what? no meat?!"
author: Liss C.

description: Great sandwiches, but slightly overpriced.  I should mention, however, that I'm partial to vegetarian sandwiches and if all I'm getting is some cheese and lettuce and maybe a tomato, it shouldn't be over $5, let alone over $6.  The Molinari special is by far a great deal, though. The quality of the food is amazing and the place is fun because it has such character (and some characters who work there too).   They also have a great selection of Italian cheeses and wine that are a nice treat any day of the week.  If you're going for lunch, it's not a bad idea to go early because you could easily be twenty numbers back (be sure to take a number!)
author: Kerry L.

description: Who doesn't like a good salami?  Molinari's is the best.  The best Jerry, the best!
author: Andrew C.

description: If you like sandos this place is THE place.  Pick your bread and meat and have them make it just right.  Oh how I missed you.
author: Chard M.

description: I just had the most amazing prosciutto focaccia sandwich. Imagine thinly sliced proscuitto with fresh mozarella, sun dried tomatoes (the tender kind, not the chewy kind), and sweet pickeled bell pepers, all wrapped by a thin focaccia bread that's been smothered with pesto, balsamic vinegar, olive oil and a bit of sweet mustard corns on the inside and slighly toasted on the outside. It's called the Grilled Focaccia Special and can be had at Molinari's on Columbus for $7.45.  Every cent, well spent.
author: Calvin N.

description: The line can be long, but it's worth the wait. If you can, you have to get the panini bread from the box o' sandwich bread. I usually get the italian sausage with pickled peppers, grilled, and it's sooooo good. I've also tasted the chicken marinara sanwich which is very tasty. It seems like a lot of people buy their homemade (uncooked) ravioli too which is something I want to try next time I go there.
author: Aaron M.

description: This is the only place where I get to grab my own bread so that must make it cool right.  Ya its not bad I don't if its as good as the now long gone Panelli Brothers but I have to give it to them they do make a pretty good chicken parm sandwich.
author: Stevezee C.

description: I'm new to eating pig, so ordering the Luciano special - coppa, proscuitto, mozzarella, and sun-dried tomatoes - was a bit of a risk.  A risk that paid off with some very high dividends.  The sandwich was absolutely delicious, and a perfect way to spend a sunny Saturday afternoon in Washington Square Park.  Except when a dog tried to eat my friend's sandwich.
author: Rachel B.

description: Love, love, love Molinari's! I haven't grabbed sandwiches from there in a long time but was in NB and couldn't wait to savor the cured meats. Be prepared to pull a number and drool over the meat selections. It's definitely well worth it. I wish this place was closer to me so I could have a delightful selection of prosciotto and coppa all the time. The sandwiches are awesome!
author: Josephine H.

description: Delicious sandwiches.  Awesome side dishes like the asiago pasta salad.  Take a number, pick out your bread, order off the specials board, and try to find a spot outside.  My trick is go with someone else and have one person order while the other tries to nab a seat and one of the several tables out front.  When all else fails, walk a couple blocks down to the park and enjoy your food there.  You can't go wrong with Molinari's!
author: Ana V.

description: Great, fresh Itlaian food. One of my favorite spots in the city. Go there to prepare a picnic or order a North Beach Special grilled foccacia sandwich. Head over to Washington Square Park on a sunny day. . .pure heaven
author: Mike B.

description: Go there and order a prosciutto and fresh mozzarella sandwich... tell the man behind the counter to make it as though he was going to eat it. You won't be disappointed! A true North Beach gem!
author: Ari T.

description: I always pray I don't get the supercilious counter guy.  I've pretended to tie my shoe to let the person behind me get him.  The roasted red peppers are dynamite (man, that sounds so fucking lame).  Basically, my favorite sandwich.  But I'm new here, so I'm sure my opinions will change every five minutes in the upcoming year.
author: J P.

description: I love Molinari and Lucca! I mean for a true San Francisco Italian Deli experience you gotta come here. Their sandwich specials are delicious and I love how friendly and happy all the guys are who work there.
author: Kai H.

description: Molinari has a wonderful selection of Salami and dried meats...Their sandwitches are the bomb, but in my experience Palermo up the road makes a much better Turkey sandwitch...That being said, this deli is still an sf staple and it would hold it's own if it was in downtown brooklyn or on mulberry street....
author: Francis K.

description: Great place to grab a sammie for lunch. You can create your own...I always do turkey, hot salami, and fresh mozz......yummmmmmmmo!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
O.K. Be patient with me on this one. First of all, being an S.F. Native, I was raised going to Lucca's  in the mission. Being an adult, I didn't find waiting in line for 45 minutes for service to be well worth the time.

After discovering Molinari's, I found that this was the place to be. the atmosphere was great. The parking isn't all that great but you just have to get there first thing in the morning. 

All the guy's there are great. Props up to Franco and the rest of the team. Everything is well worth it over there.

Hey Franco,  Go Valentino!!!!
author: Peter F.

description: This may be the best Italian deli in the city--or the entire bay area. Though the sandwiches are huge for the price, I would honestly say they're an A-, mostly because I don't love the hard bread they're served on. But the Italian meats, cheeses, and olive oils available here are unparalleled in the city. You will find the best olive oils you'll ever use in a salad, and great advice as to which ones to choose. Their salamis and raviolis are wildly yummy and the capers here are divine. I go here to shop for my sandwich needs, but usually I end up buying one for the road, too.
author: Catherine P.

description: Molinari's is my favorite deli in San Francisco. Generally I'm wary of eating turkey sandwiches because they tend to be on the dry side, but the South Beach Special is by far the best turkey sandwich because the meat is perfect and matches well with pesto spread, artichokes and sun-dried tomatoes.... mmm. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.
author: Melinda K.

description: Great sandwiches and very old school San Francisco.  Freddies used to be the best sandwich place in North Beach but since they changed owners I now go to Molinari's.   The salami is the best.  Good old fashioned deli with great sandwiches.
author: P S.

description: THE BEST I-talian deli in the whole damn city as far as Im concerned. All the sandwiches are great, as is their bread selection and cheese selection. Plus they have mini pasta and who doesnt love things in miniature?! Only draw back is - being a German/Irish girl I wanted a salami & butter sandwich and they were HIGHLY offended at me even asking for such a thing. "This is an ITALIAN deli" I was informed. Oops.
author: Inome C.

description:
timeless. 
one of the few remaining originals.  i am glad their meats are shipped all over the country or they might have gone the way of...
Panelli Bros
Rossi Supermarket
Gold Spike
Enrico's
Who else.....

The guys there are great.  yeah, the sandwiches aren't the greatest but that is not what I go for.  The bread comes from the French/Italian bakery on Grant@Union.  Go here for lots of delicious meats, cheeses, vino, and authentic Italian ingredients.  

Go down to Giordano Bros for bomb sandwiches!!!  (just don't be on a diet!)
author: Luke D.

description: This place is very authentic all the way down to "Gino" the old italian character who works behind the counter. I stumbled across this deli while exploring north beach. I was blown away by the selection of salami hanging from the ceiling. All locally made in the city. While buying salami I was given the opportunity to talk with Gino and take his photo for a project. They have a pretty good wine selection, and fresh hand-made pasta!!! I9 don't know about the sandwiches but they must be good I have a seen a line almost to the door of people ordering them. If you don't there to buy just go there to check out the atmosphere and say hello to Gino--he's there M,W,F.
author: andre h.

description: Molinari's has the best sandwiches around! They also carry Auricchio Provolone which is a huge must for an italian deli. The guys behind the counter are great, always working hard for your order and sometimes chatting about the old country...
author: Anthony L.

description: This place is fantastic!  They have a great selection of meats and cheeses...perfect if you're on your way to Washington Square to picnic or great if you want to add a special ingredient to the dinner you're cooking.  Also, the sandwiches are delicious with flavorful homemade spread likes the basil garlic, and the men who make them are so friendly!  Nice to everyone, even the group of tourists--always a good sign!  Also a good spot for some Italian wines...check it out!
author: Emma H.

description: Really delicious Italian combo sandwiches ... incredible salami.  If I lived closer, I'd eat here a couple times a week, easily!
author: Kristen H.

description: Delicious sandos... gets a little crowded with tourists occasionally.
author: Jeff D.

description: I have never been to SF without stopping at Molinari's.  Maybe it's the memory ot tasting those salty slices of deliciousness when my relatives used to bring a salami home after visiting SF, but I've been hooked since I was a kid.  Now I bring the salamis home for folks.  I love the hot salami and their prosciutto as well.  Now that the airlines don't serve meals, I look forward to my salami, hot salami, prosciutto and fresh mozzrella sandwich on rosemary foccacia bread on the plane.  I always get looks of envy as I bite in!  I've also purchased their dried porcini and Italian tuna.  If you've never had Italian tuna, you're in for a treat--really wonderful flavor.  The service at Molinari is always fun--they can spot the Hawaii people a mile away and know we're there for a sandwich and to lug back pounds of salami for eager relatives and friends.  Worth every penny and every aching muscle to carry those babies back!
author: CJ C.

description: The guy who makes your sandwich also handles the money and then makes the next sandwich without washing his hands. This is really dirty because they make hundreds of sandwiches a day.
author: Tyler B.

description: The other great deli of SF, for all you lovers of salami, fresh pasta, and all things that are great about Italian food this is your one stop shop.  The one downfall, if you can even call it that is the selection of cheese for your sandwichs is a little limited, but the quality of service and food make up for it.  If you are ever in north beach around lunch time forget all the resteraunts and save your self the money and time and stop at this old skool deli and get a sandwich.
author: brian m.

description: I'd give it 5 stars if not for the horrible memories.  During the halftime of the Cal-Arizona football game, my friends and I decided to stop here for some sandwiches.  We ordered just before the half and picked them up during, even made it back in time for kickoff.  Cal was up 17-3.  The game ended in disaster, destroying Cal's chances at a BCS Championship.  The sandwiches are however very tasty.  It took me two months to go back despite the fact I live only a couple blocks away.
author: Eric C.

description: my favorite deli.  pick a piece of bread, order a sandwich and either take it with you or eat it right outside on colombus and enjoy the north beach atmosphere.  They have a nice selection of all authentic italian products also ranging from gnocchi to wine.
author: Peter A.

description:
I love this store.  Everything is so fresh and delicious.  When I was living close by, I was regulary buying my favourite italian and french cheeses, rosemary ham, bottles of chianti, excellent olive oil and fabulous frozen lasagna (only $10).  Their sandwishes are huge and excellent. The quality is high and consistent.
