It can get a little crowded at lunch time, you have to get a ticket to get in line.
author: Flore L.

description: I tried this place out after walked by and noticing a guy munching away on a nice-looking sandwich.  Ordered the molinari special and a san pellegrino limonata, which came to $7.50.  I don't know how you can call that expensive, especially in freakin' SF.  The sandwich was packed full of meat and toppings and absolutely hit the spot.  Washed down with the limonata, it was a bright spot in a rainy day.
author: Karl B.

description: YOu better know the drill here when you order a sandwich or the clerk will give you mean looks and huff and puff. My first time here , I walked in and finally got took a number after standing at the counter for 5 mins, which the clerk said nothing about taking one! I had to figure it out myself. When I ordered a sandwich the guy told me to grab the bread myself which was behind me, but I could not tell the difference between the types  . So when I asked for a certain type of bread he got mad and came and got it (service without a smile). (well excuse me)!! First time here buddy, how should I know?   I did enjoy the sandwich, though the latino clerk made me feel like I was bothering him. No tip for you!
author: Anthony M.

description:
Fantastic Deli!!! Great food and great people that work in there. Friendly and italian makes you feel they are in Italy!!!

Why can't the place at the Ferry Building have the same people??? boo!!

Great job Northbeach guys!!
author: ROSANNA W.

description: I have lived in this area for most of my life and have never tried their sandwiches until last week...boy have I been missing out.  I tried both the Luciano and Renzo specials.  I had the Renzo on dutch crunch and the Luciano comes made with foccacia.  Though the Renzo was good the Luciano was the better of the two.  I will definitely be back to try their other creations.
author: Eric T.

description: The ABSOLUTE WORST FRESH PASTA I HAVE EVER PURCHASED!  We took relatives from Itay to Molinari's to buy fresh pasta as they wanted to make dinner for us.  When we got home we discovered the pasta was old, practically moldy (if that's possible).  We could not use it and were embarrassed that we went to Molinari's after speaking so highly of it.  They are living on a reputation that no longer applies.
author: Steve H.

description:
Great sandwiches!  

We had the grilled focaccia special- garlic focaccia, sweet peppers, fresh mozerella, prosciutto, and sun dried tomatoes- and prosciutto, hot coppa, provolone with the works on a roll.  The cold sandwich was great, but the grilled focaccia was a real treat.  

The line wasn't too long for a GORGEOUS Saturday in the city.  Definitely will go back again.
author: Sophia C.

description: My son took me here, otherwise I am sure I would never have found it!  We went here on my last hour of my visit on Mother's Day.  I had my Mom and son with me, and I gotta say, when my Mom took one bite of our veggie sandwich that we split, she said "This is the best F-*ing sandwich I have EVER had!!!"  She was right.  Not sure what it was that made it so divine.  The oil? The sundried tomatoes? Artichoke?  It was just like nothing I've ever had!  The place is so authentic Italian.  We don't have places like it where I come from, darn!
author: Kelli F.

description: BOMB ASS DELI.  This place has no shortcomings whatsoever. I have had all of the sandwiches and they are all top-notch. The Renzo and the North Beach are the best. Grab the drink of your choice, a Perugina chocolate bar, sit outside and enjoy deli heaven
author: chris b.

description: a real authentic italian deli! very popular on the weekends. when i used to live in north beach i would always come here for a deli sandwich and had to stand in very a long line. worth it though. dont forget to pick your bread out of the bin before getting to those italian guys behind the counter. i could almost swear ray liottas twin was one of the guys back there making sandwiches! oh, and get some of that imported italian tuna in the cans to take home... yum!
author: Michelle I.

description: came here for the first time about a week ago, for lunch with some friends. i'm a vegetarian so i went for the eggplant sandwich, which was great! it was quite a large sandwich, nice and toasted, no complaints. there is very limited seating, so make sure you can go eat at the park nearby or have another spot lined up if you want to sit down. no complaints---just be sure you've got a few min to wait if you're there at lunch time.
author: Kelli M.

description: This one is for you Grandma Ruby, I love and miss you bunches........I was lucky to have spent summer and Christmas vacays with my Grandma Ruby who lived in North Beach and ran/owned a neighborhood bar called Hawaii West. I regret not taking in every experience she offered me but I am proud I have them in my mind n heart til this day to share with my kids. Of course there was the usual lessons of life speeches (rolling of the eyes remembering the embarrassing ones) but the BEST was our walks that came along with them before opening the bar and during bar hours (while the old timers watched the bar for her =)). From Alice across the street at the chinese restaurant that used to be there to Liguria Bakery she showed me the world through food. Molinari is one favorite of "ours" that I cherish. Not only do they bring me back to the great days my grandma was here with us but they are the ONLY true traditional italian deli I will forever remember. The cold cuts were/are unforgettably fantastic. I feel horrible for walkling into this deli making faces and rushing to get out when I was younger. "Grandma hurry the cheese smell is making me gag". How embarassing to be so unappreciative!!! Now a days I just fight the urge to go because of the wonderful memories this place brings onto me which sometimes are uncontrollable I have to keep walking and drop a few happy/sad tears. The way I still get a DELIGHTFUL sandwich here is by chickening out and sending a buddy or colleague. MMmmMM Prosciutto, Hot Coppa and Salame....don't forget the melt in your mouth headcheese!! For her I will return in person and suck it up and finally come to terms with her not being here. I can already hear her "Oh for goodness sakes Steph".
author: Stephanie D.

description: One of the few original Italian delis still left standing in the neighborhood.  I'm not a great fan of their hard but crunchy bread (Snobby me prefer Boudin's) even if you're made to somehow feel special by being able to select your cut of bread out of the bin (what to do, what to do, end or middle, end or middle?). They do have seeded, soft and Dutch crunch ones in there.  Their roast beef isn't too bad, tender and not overly salty and the mustard they use is quite good.  It's a great place to get a sandwich for under $7 while some are over $8 and even better to pick up a box of the imported La Florentine Torrone from Italy for only $8.49!  (Victoria's Bakery on Stockton St sells it for nearly $10!) I love the delicious individually foil-wrapped then boxed orange, vanilla and lemon with almond nougat pieces.  They are heavenly and have no preservatives. The boxes of La Florentine Torrone are located on the shelf right above the bin of bread.  Some stores sell the individual boxes for 50-75 cents a piece for just a bite!  They're hard to find except in Italian delis or specialty stores.  I didn't have enough hands to get a box of their store made ravioli to carry home, but they sure look like the ones that Lucca Deli in the Mission sells.
author: Ry T.

description: 112 years old, same family.  can't get any more authentic.  mmmmm, their veggie sandwhich is awesome.
author: Lindsay T.

description: I love deli sandwiches and this place is awesome. You chose your bread from a bin and then get to eat yummy salami, what could be better? Only downside is the limited seating to eat these delicious sandwiches but washington square park is only a few blocks away and always a good option
author: Genevieve H.

description: a north beach institution that should not be missed. the north beach sandwich made my head spin. don't forget to take home some of there fresh made ravioli. add some simple red sauce and you will be in heaven.
author: Eric K.

description: We stumbled upon this place while walking around North Beach, and the very un-American (okay, I will go as far as to say authentic Italian) look of it drew us in.  Everything looked so good, but we couldn't buy much because we still had to go out for dinner, so we only bought a salami.  I will definitely be back to try more of the delicious looking food.  I also liked the fact that they closed the store after we left, it was only 5.30pm, but it almost felt like home (Belgium) where every store closes early.
author: Marijke D.

description: I've finally checked out every sandwich place that I know of in North Beach.  I'm now able to say with confidence that Molinari has the best sandwich around.
author: Brian S.

description: This deli is is da bomb yo.  When I worked in the Transamerica building over 5 years ago, I was a regular here.  You pick your choice of bread out of a box (with tongs), they generally have about 4 or 5 different kinds of rolls.  The bread is phenomenal, and their sandwiches are out of this world.  They put fresh mozzarella on your sandwich, or whatever cheese you like.  Their peppers are out of this world, and their meats are so fresh and tasty.  This is one of those places I took for granted when I was a regular.  I have yet to come across many delis since I left SF that compare to Molinari.  Also, they have delicious takehome gnocchi and pastas that cost next to nothing.  They have all sorts of delicious pasta and potato salads too, and the like.  I loved their calimari salad.  I miss this place, it's an excellent, filling sandwich, served up by true Italians, that sets you back maybe $7.
author: Jim D.

description: the sandwiches a little pricey, but considering they're giant enough to serve as both your lunch and a mid-day snack, totally worth it. the guys behind the counter come off as being your "typical italian" but they can also be very endearing (they secretly love babies). anything with the prosciutto is amazing - try to pick out the foccaccia bread out of the bin when you're going up to order. i know a lot of restaurants in the neighborhood get their supplies from here, which is a great thing!
author: Jenz y.

description: I don't go here for sandwiches so I can't vouch for that section but for a good ol' italian deli...they're the best. The staff is so friendly and very helpful. Love the Molinari, hate that it's closed on Sundays.
author: Allie O.

description:
The last of the true Italian delicatessens in North Beach, and almost the last vestige of the neighbourhood also known as the City's little Italy, Molinari is a treasure...a truly old-school deli, replete with salame hanging from the ceiling above the counter.

Molinari has just about everything you need to create an authentic Italian meal, from myriad imported and domestic cheeses, imported Italian wines ranging in price from very expensive to quite cheap, more olive oils than you thought could exist, vinegars, as well as the staple fresh mozzarella, marinated sweet peppers, stuffed olives, handmade meatballs, fresh pasta, chicken cutlets, etc.  Also, this is one of the few places you can find imported panettone for the holidays.

Of course, what causes the line to fill the space are the sandwiches.  Definitely the best in the city, Molinari's reputation is based primarily on the quality of their cold cuts--mortadella, coppa, salame, roast turkey, cured roast beef, and particularly, prosciutto (even head cheese, if you're into that).  The trick with the Molinari sandwich is to avoid frills.  The idea is to appreciate the flavour of the meat itself (in Italy, a sandwich is typically just bread, meat, and cheese), therefore, when it comes to a Molinari sandwich, mayo and mustard are an abomination...this is the best tip i've ever been given.  Always say, "No mustard, no mayo, only olive oil," and you can't go wrong.  The staff are fast, efficient, and friendly, and the place has a great old-world charm that seems to have largely gone missing in North Beach.  It's the best quick lunch i can think of, and the outside seating along Columbus is a great place to dig the neighbourhood.
author: J. Brandon L.

description: Great sandwiches!  Can you believe you can buy Molinari Salami at Costco?
author: Su Kyeong K.

description: joe's special on foccacia (in fact get all sandwhiches here on foccacia or dutch crunch) with salami and/or proscuttio, your lunchtime picnic will thank you. oh, and buy an extra pound of salami on the side, you'll thank me for it.
author: cat c.

description: Over-hyped Italian deli.  Was the food good and service reasonable?  Of course - but it does not deserve my best rating.  I thought I had a week roof of mouth with bread crusts but from reading other reviews, I guess I'm not the only one with this problem.  They have a unique system where you grab your roll of choice after you grab your number and then hand it over to the deli-man with your order of sandwich.  It felt cool in the sense that this place could be in Italy or something but again, the food was not exceptional.  They also make sandwiches bare handed - the same bare hands they ring you up with and handle cash with.  They do not wash their hands between customers...  Does/did this disturb anyone else?!  I was also a bit disturbed by the aging wood cutting board counter that runs across the service side of the deli where they make and cut the sandwiches.  Makes you feel good to go in and order - makes you wonder what is so great about their sandwiches...
author: Sokokyu K.

description: the best Italian sand witches, period! i am on a subway sandwich style budget and for the same price you get so much more. you can also get a decent 5 dollar bottle of wine with it and walk to the park and make the most of lunch on a budget.
author: Chizzy T.

description: My favorite Italian deli. Great salami sandwiches.
author: Mike R.

description: as i've said in other reviews, i grew up in NYC, and my mother is italian, so i got roots, ya here! which makes a place like molinaris great. not only do they make great sandwiches and other italian foodstuffs, but they have all the little things that i grew up with in an italian household that would can't find at safeway or wholepaycheck
author: Rich B.

description: Don't let the grumps intimidate you here.  Just figure out what you want before getting a number so that you are prepared when your number comes up.  Anything I have ever ordered here is fabulous, definitely better than any other place around.
author: Sophie G.

description: Best italian sandwiches, cheeses, olive oil, pasta and related goods, and highly knowledgeable staff.  Way better than its Ferry Building sister.  Go late morning or late afternoon to avoid the lunchtime rush.  Be sure to take a number.
author: Grace R.

description: My wife and I stopped here while walking through North Beach.  Had always heard about it but had never eaten there.  We split the Luciano special which was Prosciutto, Copa, mozzarella, sun dried tomato, lettuce, onions on grilled foccacia.  The sandwich was huge and it was fantastic.  The flavors in this sandwich were incredible.  The place was also packed.  Great place with wine everywhere. We felt like we were in Italy.  Park is nearby and it was a beautiful day.  It is a must stop if you are in North Beach.  I want to take home some of the ravioli and homemade sauce next time.
author: Wayne E.

description: the best deli in town...no doubt.  i used to go to this place when  I worked in the financial district, and never got disappointed.  their bread are fresh, choose what you like and follow that line to the counter to fill in what you want in the sandwich.  for me, it's always a huuuuge sandwich for a small eater, but very satisfying.  try their salads and some of their imported goods.  i'm missing it...i have to go back just to bring old memories and to get their freshest sandwich deli....yummmm.
author: Kui T.

description: I first heard about this place when my aunt bought proscuitto and gouda cheese from them.  I knew I just had to try one of their proscuitto sandwiches after I had a sampling of their meat.  I went there on a Wednesday morning with my boyfriend when there weren't that many customers.  We were not asked to take a number or choose our bread.  We chose the "Luciano Special" where we had a choice of garlic, onion, or plain foccacia bread.  I went with garlic.  It was toasted with proscuitto, fresh mozarella cheese, and onions.  We also bought a 6 pack of Sanpelligrino Limonada, a 1/2 pound of potato salad and a 1/2 pound of macaroni salad (when we asked for 1/4 pound).  They had a couple of tables and chairs outside where we sat and ate our sandwich and salads.  The sandwich was very good.  The meat was fresh, the balance of everything in it was perfect.  The salads sucked.  Kind of tasteless and not fresh.  The limonada was also great.  The customer service was mediocre.  They rushed me into picking what I wanted when I was not yet decided.  I would recommend this place for its sandwiches.
author: Samantha B.

description: great food made the way you want.  im not big on sandwiches, but this place is really good.
author: Jay S.
